('70', 0, 1, 2, 46) 1. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR
('70', 0, 2, 3, 70) SEGAON, WARDHA, Octorber 21, 1936 MY DEAR REBEL, You have certainly provided me with excellent material for Harijan.
('70', 0, 2, 4, 187) 1 Mahadev will see your letter.
('70', 0, 2, 5, 219) I shall make judicious use of portions of it.
('70', 0, 2, 6, 265) You must then do a little propaganda work, even write to the papers and invite other women to do likewise.
('70', 0, 2, 7, 372) If you women would only realize your dignity and privilege, and make full use of it for mankind, you will make it much better than it is.
('70', 0, 2, 8, 510) But man has delighted in enslaving you and you have proved willing slaves till the slaves and the slave holders have become one in the crime of degrading humanity.
('70', 0, 2, 9, 674) My special function from childhood, you might say, has been to make woman realize her dignity.
('70', 0, 2, 10, 769) I was once slave holder myself but Ba proved an unwilling slave and thus opened my eyes to my mission.
('70', 0, 2, 11, 872) Her task was finished.
('70', 0, 2, 12, 895) Now I am in search of a woman who would realize her mission.
('70', 0, 2, 13, 956) Are you that woman, will you be one?
('70', 0, 2, 14, 993) If Shummy will be happy and healthy going to Europe and won’t go without you, why should you not accompany him?
('70', 0, 2, 15, 1105) No time for more.
('70', 0, 2, 16, 1123) Gave you a long letter yesterday.
('70', 0, 3, 17, 1157) TYRANT [PS.] Yes, you should write to Natesan without doubt.
('70', 0, 4, 18, 1218) From the original: C.W. 3597. Courtesy: Amrit Kaur.
('70', 0, 4, 19, 1270) Also G.N. 6406

('70', 3, 1, 2, 4354) 7. LETTER TO AMTUSSALAAM
('70', 3, 2, 3, 4379) SEGAON, WARDHA, October 23, 1936
('70', 3, 3, 4, 4412) AMTUL SALAAM, I got your letter just now.
('70', 3, 3, 5, 4454) I had Kanti’s letter expressing his happiness on the Rentia Baras Day.
('70', 3, 3, 6, 4525) It is not worth sending to you.
('70', 3, 3, 7, 4557) I don’t bother him since he has no time to spare.
('70', 3, 3, 8, 4607) It is good that you went to hospital.
('70', 3, 3, 9, 4645) Khurshedbehn had written to me.
('70', 3, 3, 10, 4677) I should of course be glad if you helped her.
('70', 3, 3, 11, 4723) I myself never undertake a pilgrimage.
('70', 3, 3, 12, 4762) There is so much hypocrisy prevailing in places of pilgrimage.
('70', 3, 3, 13, 4825) I know several persons who have been to Mecca Sharif.
('70', 3, 3, 14, 4879) I couldn’t see that they had regained health by going there.
('70', 3, 3, 15, 4940) But since you have the faith, why should I stop you?
('70', 3, 3, 16, 4993) By all means go, and return more firm of mind, healthier and (free from attachment).
('70', 3, 3, 17, 5078) What more need I say?
('70', 3, 3, 18, 5100) I am leaving for Kashi today.
('70', 3, 3, 19, 5130) I shall spend two days there and then a few hours in Rajkot.
('70', 3, 3, 20, 5191) I reach Ahmedabad on the 30th.
('70', 3, 3, 21, 5222) The patients here are now free form fever.
('70', 3, 3, 22, 5265) Get well soon.
('70', 3, 4, 23, 5280) Blessings from BAPU
('70', 3, 5, 24, 5300) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N.359
('70', 3, 6, 25, 5342) 8. TALK WITH AN ENGLISHMAN 1
('70', 3, 7, 26, 5371) [Before October 24, 1936]
('70', 3, 8, 27, 5397) A friendly Englishman asked Gandhiji the other day a question which rather surprised me: “You are a Gujarati, you belong to Gujarat.
('70', 3, 8, 28, 5530) Why should you have selected a Marathi speaking part for your work and experiments?
('70', 3, 8, 29, 5614) And why Wardha of all places?” Gandhiji was no less surprised, but he calmly replied: I do not belong to Gujarat, I belong to the whole of India.
('70', 3, 8, 30, 5760) Wardha I selected because it afforded so many facilities for work.
('70', 3, 8, 31, 5827) There is Jamnalal Bajaj who is interested in my programme of work and my experiments, and he gave me his valuable garden and his garden house for the Village Industries Association of which I made Wardha the headquarters.
('70', 3, 8, 32, 6049) Harijan, 24 10 1936
('70', 3, 9, 33, 6069) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”
('70', 4, 0, 1, 6118) VOL. 70: 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 5
('70', 4, 1, 2, 6164) 9. ALL ROUND RISE?
('70', 4, 2, 3, 6183) Sri Krishnadas Gandhi of Maharashtra Charkha Sangh informs me that the rise in the spinners’ wage has necessitated a rise in the twisters’ wage.
('70', 4, 2, 4, 6328) Experiments are therefore now being made how without raising the price of khadi the efficiency of the twister can be raised so as to enable her to make 3 as per day.
('70', 4, 2, 5, 6494) He has therefore started using the double spindle Magan Rentiyo for the purpose.
('70', 4, 2, 6, 6575) If all the workers engaged in khadi production will work with the spirit that fires Krishnadas Gandhi and a few such workers, we shall attain the ideal rise in wages in all the departments of khadi without putting an undue strain upon the consumers purse.
('70', 4, 2, 7, 6831) And if we succeed in giving the full wage to all the khadi artisans, we shoud have no difficulty in reaching the level for all other village industries.
('70', 4, 2, 8, 6984) What is needed is a scientific spirit that will take nothing for granted, that will brook no laziness of body or mind, that will have an undying faith in its mission.
('70', 4, 2, 9, 7151) All work is dead without faith.
('70', 4, 3, 10, 7183) Harijan, 24 10 1936
('70', 4, 4, 11, 7203) 10. BUFFALO v.
('70', 4, 5, 12, 7218) Those who are engaged in saving the cow from the swift destruction that awaits her if measures are not taken betimes to save her, are often confronted with the question whether, apart 1 from the religious sentiment, the buffalo is not the cheaper animal to keep.
('70', 4, 5, 13, 7481) As a layman I have always hazarded the opinion that the cow is the cheaper to keep, at any rate in the long run, that it is impossible to save the two animals, and that if we would but concentrate attention on saving the cow, the buffalo will take care of herself.
('70', 4, 5, 14, 7746) But if the cow goes, the buffalo will never be able to take the cow’s place and the struggling, starving farmer will have in the deprivation of the cow and her male progeny a handicap that will leave him prostrate.
('70', 4, 5, 15, 7961) Those who are interested in this important problem will get some help form the following opinion 2 of Sardar Datar Singh M.D.D.(Eng.) of the Montgomery Dairy Farm sent to me by a friend.
('70', 4, 6, 16, 8148) Harijan, 24 10 1936
('70', 4, 7, 17, 8168) 1 The source has “even apart” 2 Not reproduced here.
('70', 4, 7, 18, 8221) It gave reasons why the buffalo was not an economical animal.

('70', 6, 9, 18, 10972) It has only a relief map of India made of marble stone in it.
('70', 6, 9, 19, 11034) I hope this temple, which will serve as a cosmopolitan platform for people of all religions, castes and creeds including Harijans, will go a great way in promoting religious unity, peace and love in the country.
('70', 6, 10, 20, 11246) I can hardly express my sentiments in declaring open this shrine.
('70', 6, 10, 21, 11312) I have left Segaon, and my dear patients and my work in the village, to come to Kashi in obedience to the irresistible call of love— love which, in Saint Mirabai’s language, is as soft and fragile as a

('70', 7, 1, 2, 11852) weak thread, but as strong as life itself.
('70', 7, 1, 3, 11895) It draws men together from thousands of miles, and I could not possibly resist Shivprasad’s affection.
('70', 7, 1, 4, 11998) I am in no way worthy of opening the shrine, but Shivprasad’s affection has made me forget my limitations.
('70', 7, 1, 5, 12105) 1 Babu Shivprasad lives on the bank of the Ganga which purifies his body, but even in his heart flows another Ganga—that of emotion and imagination.
('70', 7, 1, 6, 12254) One can fly on the wings of emotion and imagination right up to Heaven, and also sink to hell when they are unhealthy.
('70', 7, 1, 7, 12373) Shivprasad’s pure and noble imagination has prompted him to think of the shrine of Mother India and to dedicate a portion of his wealth to its making.
('70', 7, 1, 8, 12524) In the temple about to be opened he has given a concrete shape to his imagination which he conceived in Prof.
('70', 7, 1, 9, 12634) Karve’s Home for Widows 2. He rallied craftsmen, sculptors and engineers who could appreciate his sentiment.
('70', 7, 1, 10, 12743) There was a time when he had despaired of life, but God has enabled him to live to see his dream take shape.
('70', 7, 2, 11, 12852) As I was asked to perform the opening 4 ceremony in the morning, and as I listened to the chanting of the Vedic mantras, I thought of a verse in our morning prayer which we have been repeating now for 20 years: ‘Mother Earth, Spouse of Vishnu, ocean clad and mountain breasted, I bow to Thee.
('70', 7, 2, 12, 13145) Forgive me the touch of my feet.’ It is this Mother Earth to the service and devotion of which we are dedicating ourselves today.
('70', 7, 2, 13, 13275) The Mother who gave us birth was bound to die some day; not so the Universal Mother who bears and sustains us.
('70', 7, 2, 14, 13386) She must die some day, but when she passed away she would take all her children also along with her.
('70', 7, 2, 15, 13487) She therefore demands a life long dedication.
('70', 7, 2, 16, 13533) Shivprasad had dedicated this shrine for the worship by all, irrespective of creed.
('70', 7, 2, 17, 13617) He had imposed no conditions whatsoever.
('70', 7, 2, 18, 13658) Everyone who loved Mother India was welcome to the shrine to offer his or her worship according to his or her light and capacity.
('70', 7, 2, 19, 13788) Therefore, I could not resist Shivprasad’s affectionate summons.
('70', 7, 2, 20, 13853) Let us all forget our divisions and differences,

('70', 8, 3, 6, 14761) 15. SPEECH AT BANARAS
('70', 8, 4, 7, 14783) October 25, 1936
('70', 8, 5, 8, 14800) It strikes me as peculiarly inappropriate to ask a man like me to make this presentation 1. I am wholly unfit for the task 2. I am neither a Hindi scholar nor a poet.
('70', 8, 5, 9, 14967) I do not even like celebrating jubilees of great or small people.
('70', 8, 5, 10, 15033) If we must celebrate somebody’s jubilee we should do so when he is no more among us.
('70', 8, 5, 11, 15118) I regard it as peculiarly inappropriate if not impertinent for people to present great men with a book of what I should call certificates of merit.
('70', 8, 5, 12, 15266) I therefore refused to contribute anything to the Commemoration Volume; but the word Mahatma covers a multitude of disqualifications and so, I suppose, I was asked to present the Volume.
('70', 8, 5, 13, 15453) It is my innermost conviction that a man cannot be called a poet or a Mahatma or an avatar so long as he is alive 3. Ramchandraji was not considered an avatar during his lifetime.
('70', 8, 5, 14, 15633) Tulsidas’s birth anniversary was not celebrated when he was living.
('70', 8, 5, 15, 15701) It is we who have made them avatars.
('70', 8, 5, 16, 15738) After all the Gita maxim, “To work thou hast the right, not to the fruit thereof”, applies peculiarly to poets and Mahatmas.
('70', 8, 5, 17, 15863) I should therefore have a bone to pick with Maithilisharanji if he were to believe that he was a great poet of India.
('70', 8, 6, 18, 15981) So this anniversary should have been celebrated when the Poet was no more.
('70', 8, 6, 19, 16056) People would have then known that something was being done for honouring him.
('70', 8, 6, 20, 16134) You will please forgive me.
('70', 8, 6, 21, 16162) When Padmanarayanji came to Segaon I told him that it was not decent to
('70', 8, 7, 22, 16234) 1 Of a commemoration volume to Maithilisharan Gupta who had completed his fiftieth year 2 Th is se nten ce is fr om Ma hade v De sai’s “We ekly Le tter ” in Ha rija n, 31 10 193 6 3 These paragraphs are from Harijan.
('70', 9, 0, 1, 16451) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('70', 9, 1, 2, 16492) go about collecting opinions on a reputed poet.
('70', 9, 1, 3, 16540) Such a poet’s work does not call for an expression of opinions.
('70', 9, 1, 4, 16604) If ever I had delivered myself of an opinion on Gurudev or Malaviyaji or Dwivediji, it was always under pressure.
('70', 9, 1, 5, 16718) If you ask me, I have never felt like writing about great men.
('70', 9, 1, 6, 16781) The fact that I did so on former occasions is no reason why I should repeat the mistake.
('70', 9, 1, 7, 16870) If you also press me I might write something for you too, but not willingly.
('70', 9, 1, 8, 16947) I know Maithilisharanji very well.
('70', 9, 1, 9, 16982) Even if I refused to write about him he would not misunderstand me.
('70', 9, 1, 10, 17050) I had the honour of having his hospitality in Chirgaon.
('70', 9, 1, 11, 17106) A poet writes under inspiration and not to the dictation of any one.
('70', 9, 1, 12, 17175) He therefore does not write for applause.
('70', 9, 1, 13, 17217) His work is its own joy and compensation.

('70', 11, 1, 2, 19158) 20. LETTER TO EDMOND AND YVONNE PRIVATE
('70', 11, 2, 3, 19198) AS AT SEGAON, WARDHA, C.P. INDIA, October 26, 1936
('70', 11, 3, 4, 19249) DEAR BHAKTI AND ANAND, Your dear letter has just come into my hands.
('70', 11, 3, 5, 19318) You need not have included yourselves among those to whom my appeal for sparing me was addressed.
('70', 11, 3, 6, 19416) Letters from informal friends and co workers like you living in distant lands are always welcome.
('70', 11, 3, 7, 19514) That you cannot come again to India owing to your duty keeping you there is no cause for regret.
('70', 11, 3, 8, 19611) Where hearts are one, physical separation is of no moment.
('70', 11, 3, 9, 19670) Truth and ahimsa are truer than many so called scientific facts.
('70', 11, 3, 10, 19735) Only they are difficult to put into practice.
('70', 11, 3, 11, 19781) And then too, they are not so difficult as they seem if there is the proper previous preparation.
('70', 11, 3, 12, 19879) But we do not care to give this most important thing in life more than a part of our leisure hours.
('70', 11, 3, 13, 19979) Our valuations need revising.
('70', 11, 3, 14, 20009) Mira, of whose serious illness you must have read, is out of the wood.
('70', 11, 3, 15, 20080) She is still weak.
('70', 11, 3, 16, 20099) This is being written in a moving train.
('70', 11, 3, 17, 20140) Love to you both.

('70', 12, 1, 2, 20745) 22. LETTER TO SYED MAHMUD
('70', 12, 2, 3, 20771) ON THE TRAIN, October 28, 1936
('70', 12, 3, 4, 20802) MY DEAR MAHMUD, This is being written in a moving train.
('70', 12, 3, 5, 20859) I hope you got my previous letter 1 written to you on a cursory glance at your note.
('70', 12, 3, 6, 20944) Now I have read it carefully.
('70', 12, 3, 7, 20974) There is one very big historical error in it.
('70', 12, 3, 8, 21020) You will evidently think that the vast majority of Mussalmans are immigrants and their descendants.
('70', 12, 3, 9, 21120) The truth is just the opposite.
('70', 12, 3, 10, 21152) The vast majority are converts and their descendants and therefore inheritors of the Vedic civilization and culture.
('70', 12, 3, 11, 21269) And why should not the immigrants take pride in the achievements of the ancestors of the original inhabitants?
('70', 12, 3, 12, 21380) Your note contains several other glaring inaccuracies and faulty conclusions or inferences.
('70', 12, 3, 13, 21472) I detect much haste in its preparation.
('70', 12, 3, 14, 21512) I wish I had time to point out these.
('70', 12, 3, 15, 21550) But I have no time.
('70', 12, 3, 16, 21570) You should reread your note and perhaps you will detect some errors yourself.
('70', 12, 3, 17, 21648) To conclude, I should even now refuse to go to heaven without Mussalmans nor has my effort for unity abated in any way.
('70', 12, 3, 18, 21768) Only my method is different but deeper and more substantial.
('70', 12, 3, 19, 21829) The result is in God’s lap.
('70', 12, 4, 20, 21857) From a photostat: G.N.5078

('70', 13, 6, 12, 22857) 25. ADDRESS TO HARIJAN WORKERS 2
('70', 13, 7, 13, 22890) RAJKOT, October 29, 1936
('70', 13, 8, 14, 22915) Gandhiji said to them that in view of cases of impurity of Harijan workers having come to his notice, he had been confirmed in his conviction that no Harijan ashrams should look to the central office for any financial help; that they may be, if they would; under the discipline and control of the Central Body; and that the impurity had so far alarmed him that he had not the courage to ask individuals to support these institutions financially.
('70', 13, 8, 15, 23361) It was the clearest duty of those in charge of these institutions to put the public at ease about the purity of the institutions before they approached them for financial help.
('70', 13, 9, 16, 23538) Harijan, 7 11 1936

('70', 14, 1, 2, 23813) 26. SPEECH AT VITHAL KANYA VIDYALAYA HOSTEL, NADIAD 1
('70', 14, 2, 3, 23867) October 30, 1936
('70', 14, 3, 4, 23884) I ought not to have been asked to speak on this occasion, inasmuch as my presence is enough to show that the institution has my blessings.
('70', 14, 3, 5, 24023) Besides, I already blessed the institution when I came here last year 2 to lay the foundation stone.
('70', 14, 3, 6, 24124) But now that I have been asked to speak, let me say that my blessings are conditional.
('70', 14, 3, 7, 24211) I should like to impress on those in charge of this institution, the teachers and the girls that the institution will not last without a moral foundation.
('70', 14, 3, 8, 24366) The workers should all be selfless workers and the education imparted here should be true education, that is to say, which draws out the best in the character of the taught.
('70', 14, 3, 9, 24540) Every one of us has good inherent in the soul, it needs to be drawn out by the teachers, and only those teachers can perform this sacred function whose own character is unsullied, who are always ready to learn and to grow from perfection to perfection.
('70', 14, 3, 10, 24793) The girls also will have to be receptive, they will not think of showing themselves off but of enabling their teachers to draw out the best in themselves.
('70', 14, 3, 11, 24948) I have had bitter experience of institutions of this character and therefore hesitate to bless newly opened institutions.
('70', 14, 3, 12, 25070) I am even doubtful about the teachers needing my blessings.
('70', 14, 3, 13, 25130) Some of them, I dare say, think of me a back number, not in touch with the spirit of the age and modern tendencies and not at all competent to speak to the modern youth.
('70', 14, 3, 14, 25300) Well, let those who think like that reject what I have said.
('70', 14, 4, 15, 25361) Harijan, 7 11 1936
('70', 14, 5, 16, 25380) 27. TALK WITH STUDENTS
('70', 14, 6, 17, 25403) NADIAD, October 30, 1936
('70', 14, 7, 18, 25428) The girls of the institution 3 gathered in the afternoon to give Gandhiji their yarn spun on the occasion of his birthday.
('70', 14, 7, 19, 25551) There were boys, too, of the Vallabh Vidyalaya of Bochasan.
('70', 14, 7, 20, 25611) The girls gave 122,475 yards of yarn but, what is more, 60 of them took pledge to spin 100,000 yards during the year for their own clothing needs.
('70', 14, 8, 21, 25758) 1 Jamnalal Bajaj declared open the hostel.
('70', 14, 8, 22, 25801) 2 On May 31; vide “Speech At Inauguration of Vithal Kanya Vidyalaya, Nadiad 3 Vithal Kanya Vidyalaya
('70', 15, 0, 1, 25902) 16 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('70', 15, 1, 2, 25943) [GANDHIJI:] You know that Seth Jamnalal Bajaj has opened your hostel today.
('70', 15, 1, 3, 26019) You must try to be worthy of that good man.
('70', 15, 1, 4, 26063) You perhaps know that he is a good man?
('70', 15, 2, 5, 26103) [GIRLS:] Oh, yes.
('70', 15, 2, 6, 26121) No ‘oh, yes’ but ‘yes, please’.
('70', 15, 3, 7, 26153) ‘Yes, please,’ they shouted in a chorus.
('70', 15, 3, 8, 26194) But if he is a good man, what about the rest?
('70', 15, 4, 9, 26240) Everyone is good.
('70', 15, 4, 10, 26258) Not including you?
('70', 15, 5, 11, 26277) We are good, too.
('70', 15, 5, 12, 26295) All, without exception?
('70', 15, 5, 13, 26319) Are you sure?
('70', 15, 6, 14, 26333) Yes, Sir.
('70', 15, 6, 15, 26343) Well, then, now tell me if any of you tell lies.
('70', 15, 7, 16, 26392) ‘We do,’ said some of them.
('70', 15, 7, 17, 26420) Always or on occasions?
('70', 15, 8, 18, 26444) On certain occasions.
('70', 15, 8, 19, 26466) And don’t you quarrel?
('70', 15, 9, 20, 26489) Always?
('70', 15, 10, 21, 26497) ‘Yes’, which was drowned in hearty laughter.
('70', 15, 10, 22, 26542) Well, but I must say that you are good, because you are ready to confess that you sometimes tell lies and quarrel amongst yourselves.
('70', 15, 10, 23, 26676) And the rest of us are also good only in that sense and no other.
('70', 15, 10, 24, 26742) But what about those who go about saying that everyone must tell the truth but who, themselves never do so?
('70', 15, 11, 25, 26850) They are hypocrites.
('70', 15, 11, 26, 26871) That’s perfect.
('70', 15, 11, 27, 26887) Let us never be hypocrites.
('70', 15, 11, 28, 26915) Now, one more question.
('70', 15, 11, 29, 26939) You have taken a pledge to spin 100,000 yards during the year.
('70', 15, 11, 30, 27002) What if you break the pledge?
('70', 15, 12, 31, 27032) ‘No fear,’ they emphatically protested.
('70', 15, 12, 32, 27072) But if you do?
('70', 15, 13, 33, 27087) ‘We know we will not,” they rejoined with even greater emphasis.
('70', 15, 13, 34, 27152) But supposing you do?
('70', 15, 14, 35, 27174) (One voice) ‘Fasting !’ Who is to fast?
('70', 15, 14, 36, 27214) I or you?
('70', 15, 15, 37, 27224) We of course.
('70', 16, 0, 1, 27238) VOL. 70: 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 17
('70', 16, 1, 2, 27285) Fasting on milk and fruit?
('70', 16, 2, 3, 27312) No, Sir, We shall take only water.
('70', 16, 2, 4, 27347) But how many days will you fast?
('70', 16, 3, 5, 27380) So long as we do not finish our promised quota.
('70', 16, 3, 6, 27428) Splendid.
('70', 16, 3, 7, 27438) But know that there are reporters here who will publish this talk of ours and you will have to rue it if you fail.
('70', 16, 4, 8, 27553) Then came the turn of Vallabh Vidyalaya boys—boys of the Dharala community who are being taught and given their board and lodging free.
('70', 16, 4, 9, 27689) The teacher presented to Gandhiji cloth woven out of the yarn spun from slivers carded on the 12th of October, from cotton purchased out of the wages they had earned from carding.
('70', 16, 4, 10, 27869) The teacher said that the boys did cleaning and sweeping of the streets as well.
('70', 16, 4, 11, 27950) Every day?
('70', 16, 5, 12, 27961) No, we did so on Gandhiji’s birthday.
('70', 16, 5, 13, 27999) Well, I tell you, if you do it every day you will make Bochasan a model village from the standpoint of sanitation and you may some day be Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel.
('70', 16, 5, 14, 28163) Even if you fail to be Sardar Vallabhbhai, you will have done something good.
('70', 16, 5, 15, 28241) But you may take it from me that if you do not do this street cleaning, you will never be Sardar Vallabhbhai.
('70', 16, 6, 16, 28351) But,’said one of the boys, ‘ours is a bad village.
('70', 16, 6, 17, 28402) It does not deserve these heroic measures.
('70', 16, 6, 18, 28445) We may clean the streets, but they will go on spoiling them.’ Now, now, don’t say so.
('70', 16, 6, 19, 28531) All villages are like that, and it is our duty to persevere the more, the more they persist in defiling the streets.
('70', 16, 6, 20, 28648) And you must not forget that you belong to the village.
('70', 16, 7, 21, 28704) Harijan, 7 11 1936
('70', 16, 8, 22, 28723) 28. SPEECH AT MUNICIPAL GIRLS’ SCHOOL 1
('70', 16, 9, 23, 28763) AHMEDABAD, October 30, 1936
('70', 16, 10, 24, 28791) My heart is in Segaon.
('70', 16, 10, 25, 28814) I am not interested in such things although I used to take interest in them before my life turned in a different direction.
('70', 16, 11, 26, 28938) He added that women’s education should aid development of womanhood whereby women might lead pure life.
('70', 16, 12, 27, 29042) The Bombay Chronicle, 31 10 1936
('70', 16, 13, 28, 29075) 1 At the inauguration of the building.
('70', 17, 0, 1, 29114) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('70', 17, 1, 2, 29155) 29. VOLUNTEER BHANGIS
('70', 17, 2, 3, 29177) Let not the word Bhangi frighten any reader as it does many.
('70', 17, 2, 4, 29238) [The] Bhangi is probably the most useful member of society.
('70', 17, 2, 5, 29298) Its health depends more upon proper sanitation than perhaps on proper food.
('70', 17, 2, 6, 29374) Needless to say I am not thinking of the Bhangi caste.
('70', 17, 2, 7, 29429) I am thinking purely of the occupation that the word ‘Bhangi’ connotes.
('70', 17, 2, 8, 29501) I regard the scavenger’s or the cleaner’s as a noble ‘profession’, nobler than the professions known as ‘honourable’.
('70', 17, 2, 9, 29619) They may easily become dishonourable; this never can.
('70', 17, 2, 10, 29673) Well, Shri Appa Patwardhan who is an M.A. has become commander of a corps of volunteer Bhangis which he is trying to form for attending to the sanitation of the Congress camp at Faizpur.
('70', 17, 2, 11, 29860) The issue before the Reception Committee was whether to employ professional Bhangis or to have the sanitation attended to by volunteers.
('70', 17, 2, 12, 29997) Someone pointed out that at the previous Congress the work was done by the town Bhangis.
('70', 17, 2, 13, 30086) But the volunteer scheme won the day.
('70', 17, 2, 14, 30124) The task could not have been allotted to fitter hands.
('70', 17, 2, 15, 30179) Appasaheb has qualified himself for it by long previous training and, what is more, by his love of the most despised member of society.
('70', 17, 2, 16, 30315) His love has not been purely sentimental.
('70', 17, 2, 17, 30357) He has done the work of sanitation side by side with Bhangis, and he knows that proper scavenging is as much a science as any other.
('70', 17, 2, 18, 30490) He has invited applications for the free services of two hundred persons not under 18 years of age for the work.
('70', 17, 2, 19, 30603) They must be willing and ready to attend to the cleaning of latrines and the whole camp while the Congress work lasts.
('70', 17, 2, 20, 30722) They must be zealous youths who won’t neglect the duty entrusted to them for the sake of seeing the tamasha or the Congress delegates at work.
('70', 17, 2, 21, 30865) Theirs will be the privilege of making the work of the delegates possible by attending to their sanitary comforts.
('70', 17, 2, 22, 30980) Maharashtra is a bee hive of good hardy workers.
('70', 17, 2, 23, 31029) It should not be difficult for the province to supply two hundred good and true young men to do the work.
('70', 17, 2, 24, 31135) Not that young men from other provinces may not apply.
('70', 17, 2, 25, 31190) But for the sake of economy, if nothing more, it is better to have young men from the province and, better still, the taluq or the district in which the Congress is held.
('70', 17, 3, 26, 31361) Harijan, 31 10 1936
('70', 18, 0, 1, 31381) VOL. 70: 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 19
('70', 18, 1, 2, 31428) 30. WHOSE IS THE HUMILIATION?
('70', 18, 2, 3, 31458) From a long letter of a worker among Harijans I take the following paragraph:
('70', 18, 3, 4, 31536) There is a growing discontent on the part of educated Harijans to call themselves Hindus.
('70', 18, 3, 5, 31626) Because if they say they are Hindus, they have to disclose their caste also, and the inferiority complex makes this unpleasant.
('70', 18, 3, 6, 31754) They would rather call themselves Christians than undergo humiliation by calling themselves Hindus.
('70', 18, 3, 7, 31854) Why may we not then ask them to become Sikhs or Buddhists and end the humiliation?
('70', 18, 3, 8, 31937) For Sikhs and Buddhists are as good as Hindus.
('70', 18, 3, 9, 31984) The correspondent gives up his case when he says that Sikhs and Buddhists are as good as Hindus.
('70', 18, 3, 10, 32081) For if that is so, there is no occasion to prompt Harijans or anyone else in the direction.
('70', 18, 3, 11, 32173) Any Hindu is free to call himself a follower of any one of the innumerable Hindu sects and yet remain Hindu.
('70', 18, 3, 12, 32282) And why should a Hindu disclose his caste if he does not want to or if he has renounced caste?
('70', 18, 3, 13, 32377) Many Hindus do not believe in caste.
('70', 18, 3, 14, 32414) I have endeavoured to show that caste is no part of Hinduism.
('70', 18, 3, 15, 32476) Varna is not caste, it is class.
('70', 18, 3, 16, 32509) A man may call himself a Brahmin, i.e., a teacher of religion, if he is one in fact; or a Kshatriya, i.e., a soldier, if he is one; or a Vaishya, i.e., a merchant or a farmer, if he is that; or a Shudra, i.e., an employee, if he is one.
('70', 18, 3, 17, 32746) These divisions are not castes but classes and have reference to callings.
('70', 18, 3, 18, 32821) There is no such class as untouchable.
('70', 18, 3, 19, 32860) Hence an untouchable is not bound to say he is one.
('70', 18, 3, 20, 32912) He may say if he wishes that Hindu society has regarded him as such but he does not recognize that distinction.
('70', 18, 3, 21, 33024) I may say that though I have been classified by Hindu society as belonging to the Bania caste, I am not that, as I do not believe in caste, but that if I must call myself anything more than mere Hindu, I am a Harijan by choice, having made, so far as in me lies, common cause with Harijans.
('70', 18, 3, 22, 33315) And why is there any humiliation in a Harijan disclosing his classification made by Hindu Society?
('70', 18, 3, 23, 33414) Surely the humiliation is of the society that reduces its members to the condition of helots, consigned to ghettos and shunned by society.
('70', 18, 3, 24, 33553) The very education of the Harijan should make him proud of the fact that he can truthfully call himself a Hindu even though so called higher castes have denied their religion in their lives and persecuted him in a manner beyond description.
('70', 18, 3, 25, 33794) If untouchability is destroyed root and branch and Hinduism lives, the future historian will assign the place of honour to Harijans who will have stood by their faith in spite of heartless persecution by their
('70', 19, 0, 1, 34004) 20 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('70', 19, 1, 2, 34045) fellows.
('70', 19, 1, 3, 34054) Each time, therefore, a Harijan has to say what he is classed as in Hindu society, the humiliation is not his but of his persecutors—the so called caste Hindus.
('70', 19, 2, 4, 34215) Harijan, 31 10 1936
('70', 19, 3, 5, 34235) 31. SPEECH AT LABOURERS’ MEETING, AHMEDABAD
('70', 19, 4, 6, 34279) October 31, 1936 In 1918 some workers had become indifferent and had also weakened.
('70', 19, 4, 7, 34363) To carry on a strike for twenty one days—remaining peaceful, not even throwing a little stone at anyone—is a hard test for anyone.
('70', 19, 4, 8, 34494) You passed through the test lasting 21 days.
('70', 19, 4, 9, 34539) Then you weakened somewhat.
('70', 19, 4, 10, 34567) Do you know what I had to do then and what the results were?
('70', 19, 4, 11, 34628) For 21 days you carried the banner on which were written the words” Unbreakable Vow”.
('70', 19, 4, 12, 34714) Every day I asked you to remember God and do everything with Him as your witness; otherwise the time would have come for a person like me to die.
('70', 19, 4, 13, 34860) As on the banner, so in the heart, “Unbreakable Vow” was written.
('70', 19, 4, 14, 34926) You had all lost heart but you played your part well.
('70', 19, 4, 15, 34980) Anyone who wishes to keep a pledge should take it only after due deliberation and recognizing his limitations.
('70', 19, 4, 16, 35091) One should know one’s own capacity and, as the saying goes, “You should stretch yourself according to the length of your bedspread.” Do I need to explain this to labourers?
('70', 19, 4, 17, 35264) For you always huddle up when you go to sleep.
('70', 19, 4, 18, 35311) Everyone should have a seven foot long bed; the labourer’s may well be made of coir strings and the rich man’s have silk webbing.
('70', 19, 4, 19, 35441) The rich may have a painted cot and yours may be [made of] babul wood, but everyone needs to stretch himself full length while sleeping.
('70', 19, 4, 20, 35578) I can see that this is not the case today.

('70', 38, 2, 7, 81236) 35. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 1
('70', 38, 3, 8, 81263) SABARMATI, [November 2, 1936] 2
('70', 38, 4, 9, 81295) Q. The work of removing untouchability seems to be insuperable.
('70', 38, 4, 10, 81359) How exactly are we to tackle it?
('70', 38, 5, 11, 81392) A. Silent plodding.
('70', 38, 5, 12, 81412) I better tell you how I am doing it in Segaon.
('70', 38, 5, 13, 81459) I do not preach to them, but work away never thinking of the result.
('70', 38, 5, 14, 81528) The one condition is that you should not harbour untouchability in any shape or form .
('70', 38, 5, 15, 81615) I have made it a point to have as many Harijans about me as possible.
('70', 38, 5, 16, 81685) They come as servants but they soon know that they are brothers to us.
('70', 38, 5, 17, 81756) We tolerate no distinction between Harijans.
('70', 38, 5, 18, 81801) Though I cannot present you with tangible results of this silent service, I may safely say that there is a marked change for the better among all—Harijans and the orthodox Hindus.
('70', 38, 6, 19, 81981) It is not quite easy for the Harijans to leave their village where they feel like doing so, as in Kavitha.
('70', 38, 6, 20, 82088) How can they get work?
('70', 38, 7, 21, 82111) A. I still adhere to my advice.
('70', 38, 7, 22, 82143) We should be ashamed of asking them to stay on in the village and suffer the continuing persecution.
('70', 38, 7, 23, 82244) It should not be impossible for us to find work for them.
('70', 38, 7, 24, 82302) The number of those who will migrate will never be large.
('70', 38, 8, 25, 82360) Q. The Bhangis’ lot is pitiable in many places.
('70', 38, 8, 26, 82408) How can they secure their elementary rights from Municipalities?
('70', 38, 9, 27, 82473) A. They must know that they are not bound to serve under all conditions.
('70', 38, 9, 28, 82546) They may leave the work if the Municipality will not listen to them.
('70', 38, 9, 29, 82615) But we have to settle down in their midst and educate them and not make reckless attempts to drive them to strike work.
('70', 38, 9, 30, 82735) They must be taught to know that they have friends.
('70', 38, 9, 31, 82787) Whilst they like others have the right to go on strike, they should know its limitations.
('70', 38, 10, 32, 82877) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('70', 38, 10, 33, 82927) The questions were asked by a group of Harijan workers of Gujarat and Kathiawar who were spending a month at Harijan Ashram, Sabarmati, learning carding and spinning.

('70', 39, 1, 3, 83261) I have no doubt that they are the most neglected social servants and deserve every assistance we can render them.
('70', 39, 2, 4, 83375) Q. What is the outlook, in view of the precarious financial position of our Ashrams and institutions today?
('70', 39, 3, 5, 83483) A. It is not our financial position but our moral position that is precarious.
('70', 39, 3, 6, 83562) You know the instances of moral lapse that have occurred.
('70', 39, 3, 7, 83620) Purity is the only social foundation.
('70', 39, 3, 8, 83658) No movement or activity that has the sure foundation of purity of character of its workers, is ever in danger of coming to an end for want of funds.
('70', 39, 3, 9, 83807) Then we in Gujarat have to realize that we must not always depend only on our monied men.
('70', 39, 3, 10, 83897) We have to tap humbler resources.
('70', 39, 3, 11, 83931) Our middle classes and even poor classes support so many beggars, so many temples, why will they not support a few good workers?
('70', 39, 3, 12, 84060) We must beg from door to door, beg grain, beg copper coins, do as they do in Bihar and Maharashtra.

('70', 39, 3, 14, 84217) It will be the finest form of propaganda among caste Hindus.
('70', 39, 3, 15, 84278) But remember everything will depend on the singleness of your purpose, your devotion to the task and the purity of your character.
('70', 39, 3, 16, 84409) People won’t give for such work unless they are sure of our selflessness.
('70', 39, 4, 17, 84483) Q. What about the Harijans turned Christians who are today no better than Harijans?
('70', 39, 5, 18, 84567) A. Everything will be all right the moment untouchability disappears.
('70', 39, 5, 19, 84637) When there is no untouchability, there will be no occasion for them to label themselves otherwise than as Hindus.
('70', 39, 5, 20, 84751) I am talking of nominal Christians.
('70', 39, 5, 21, 84787) If we put our own house in order, we need have no anxiety about Harijans changing religion as people change clothes.
('70', 39, 6, 22, 84904) Q. If it is impossible to get the caste Hindus’ co operation in antiuntouchability work, would it not be better to take up the village industries work?
('70', 39, 7, 23, 85056) A. That is a delusion.
('70', 39, 7, 24, 85079) You may be sure that he who gives up Harijan work on a pretext like that will be able to do less for the village industries work .
('70', 39, 7, 25, 85210) You can’t settle down in a village and miss the Harijans who are the foundation of society.

('70', 48, 0, 1, 98504) VOL. 70: 21 OCT0BER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 49
('70', 48, 1, 2, 98551) 50. SILK AND COTTON
('70', 48, 2, 3, 98571) There is a subtle rivalry going on just now between hand manufactured silk and khadi hand made from cotton.
('70', 48, 2, 4, 98679) So far as the A.I.S.A. is concerned the matter was settled long ago.
('70', 48, 2, 5, 98748) Certified khadi stores were permitted to stock indigenous silk cloth only to attract more customers for khadi and to enable the stores to make up somewhat for loss on khadi by charging fancy prices for silk cloth.
('70', 48, 2, 6, 98962) The line was often overstepped by overzealous store keepers but never with the approval of the A.I.S.A. Now the manufacturers of silk cloth have discovered that they can easily displace Andhra khadi because they can afford to undersell Andhra saris, and now silk merchants are to be found defying the A.I.S.A. in pushing their wares.
('70', 48, 2, 7, 99296) So far nothing can be said against these merchants for no one is bound to respect the policy of the A.I.S.A. unless its virtue is recognized.
('70', 48, 2, 8, 99438) But in Bombay as elsewhere, too, perhaps, silk merchants have been found doing their business so as to lead the credulous public to believe that they, the merchants, are doing their business with the approval of the A.I.S.A. and in the interest of khadi.
('70', 48, 2, 9, 99693) It is necessary, therefore, to warn the public against being deceived by such devices.
('70', 48, 2, 10, 99780) The public should know that the A.I.S.A. has adopted no arbitrary policy.
('70', 48, 2, 11, 99854) Trade in indigenous silk had not died out when khadi revival was ushered in.
('70', 48, 2, 12, 99931) Khadi can give employment to crores whereas silk hardly to more than a few thousand.
('70', 48, 2, 13, 100016) Khadi is a necessity for both the poor and the rich.
('70', 48, 2, 14, 100069) Silk is a necessity for none but a few who, in order to nourish a religious sentiment, insist on silk garments on certain occasions.
('70', 48, 2, 15, 100202) Hence when it is a question of choice between silk and khadi, naturally those who have the welfare of starving millions at heart will always choose khadi.
('70', 48, 2, 16, 100357) And the very object of the All India Spinners’ Association requires it to give the first place always to khadi made of cotton.
('70', 48, 2, 17, 100484) I say khadi made of cotton in order to avoid confusion in the minds of those who have seen the wider definition of khadi as being cloth hand spun and hand woven out of cotton, silk or wool.This wide definition was and is necessary in order to cover woollen and silken hand spuns when the latter two are used not to supplant cotton hand spuns but to supplement them.
('70', 48, 2, 18, 100850) Thus in winter many people want the warmer woollen or silken stuff.
('70', 49, 0, 1, 100918) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 50
('70', 49, 1, 2, 100959) No one need run away with the idea that the policy I have advocated in these lines disregards the welfare of silk spinners and weavers.
('70', 49, 1, 3, 101095) Nothing can be farther from my thoughts than this.
('70', 49, 1, 4, 101146) For I know that if khadi dies, indigenous silk dies automatically.
('70', 49, 1, 5, 101213) Japanese silk and the artificial imitation from the West will sweep every piece of indigenous cloth out of existence.
('70', 49, 1, 6, 101331) It is the khadi spirit which has enabled Kashmir woollens and Bengal Assam silks to hold their own.
('70', 49, 1, 7, 101431) It is the far seeing policy of the A.I.S.A. which in protecting cotton khadi against all odds automatically protects indigenous hand spuns made of wool or silk.
('70', 49, 1, 8, 101592) Put the three in competition with one another and you dig the grave of all the three.
('70', 49, 1, 9, 101678) Lastly, let it be remembered that if cotton khadi lives but silk dies, the hands left idle due to the death of silk can easily take up cotton spinning and weaving, but if silk displaces cotton, it cannot employ the crores that will be without occupation or chance of it due to the death of cotton khadi.
('70', 49, 1, 10, 101982) It seems to me, therefore, to be the obvious duty of all lovers of Daridranarayana to prefer cotton khadi always when the question of making a choice confronts them.
('70', 49, 1, 11, 102148) It will be economical in the long run to pay for the present dearer prices for fine cotton khadi than for the corresponding fine silk wear.
('70', 49, 2, 12, 102288) Harijan, 7 11 1936
('70', 49, 3, 13, 102307) 51. ONE THING NEEDFUL
('70', 49, 4, 14, 102329) The one thing needful for effective Harijan service and, for that matter, all service of the poor, the forlorn, the helpless, is purity of personal character in the servant.
('70', 49, 4, 15, 102503) Without it possession of even the highest intellectual ability and administrative capacity is of no account.
('70', 49, 4, 16, 102612) It may even prove a hindrance, whereas possession of a pure character combined with love of such service will assuredly develop or provide the requisite intellectual and administrative capacity.
('70', 49, 4, 17, 102807) This reflection is prompted by the discovery of very painful instances of grave moral lapses on the part of two well known workers in the Harijans’ cause.
('70', 49, 4, 18, 102962) They were both regarded by all who knew them to be above suspicion and of unsullied character.
('70', 49, 4, 19, 103057) They have both been betrayed into conduct unworthy of those occupying the positions they did.
('70', 49, 4, 20, 103151) They were no doubt victims of lust that was hiding like a deadly snake in a dark corner of their hearts.
('70', 49, 4, 21, 103256) But poor mortals that we are, we cannot read into others’ hearts.
('70', 49, 4, 22, 103322) We can but, and we must, judge other fellow men by their acts which we can see and handle.
('70', 49, 4, 23, 103413) In these two
('70', 50, 0, 1, 103426) VOL. 70: 21 OCT0BER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 51
('70', 50, 1, 2, 103473) cases they are such as to make it impossible for them to remain as workers in the Harijan Sevak Sangh.
('70', 50, 1, 3, 103576) This would be no punishment.
('70', 50, 1, 4, 103605) Their withdrawal would be necessary for the protection of the Sangh and its cause if not also for themselves.
('70', 50, 1, 5, 103715) I can safely say that it will be unnecessary for the Sangh to take any step against them.
('70', 50, 1, 6, 103805) These workers will themselves retire from the Sangh and, I hope, from all public activity.
('70', 50, 1, 7, 103896) The duty of service is denied to none.
('70', 50, 1, 8, 103935) A person who has had a grievous moral fall but has come to his senses will serve no matter where he is placed.
('70', 50, 1, 9, 104046) His very reformation will be a service of society.
('70', 50, 1, 10, 104097) But performance of such service that comes of itself and is rendered almost secretly is wholly different from being in an organization and enjoying all its privileges.
('70', 50, 1, 11, 104265) For such re entry into public life a complete restoration of public confidence is absolutely necessary.
('70', 50, 1, 12, 104369) There is in modern public life a tendency to ignore altogether the character of a public worker so long as he works efficiently as a unit in an administrative machinery.
('70', 50, 1, 13, 104539) It is said that everybody’s character is his own private concern.
('70', 50, 1, 14, 104605) Though I have known this view to have been often taken I have never been able to appreciate, much less to adopt, it.
('70', 50, 1, 15, 104722) I have known the serious consequences overtaking organizations that have counted private character as a matter of no consequence.
('70', 50, 1, 16, 104852) Nevertheless the reader will have, observed that for my immediate purpose I have restrictecd the application of my proposition only to organizations like the Harijan Sevak Sangh which make themselves trustees for the welfare of the dumb millions.
('70', 50, 1, 17, 105099) I have no manner of doubt that possession of a spotless character is the indispensable requisite of such service.
('70', 50, 1, 18, 105213) Workers in the Harijan cause or for khadi or for village industries must come in closest touch with utterly unsophisticated, innocent, ignorant men and women who might be likened to children in intelligence.
('70', 50, 1, 19, 105421) If they have not character, they must fail in the end and for ever damn the cause they espouse in the surroundings in which they are known.
('70', 50, 1, 20, 105561) I write from experience of such cases.
('70', 50, 1, 21, 105600) Happily they are rare enough for the numbers engaged in such services, but frequent enough to call for publc warning and caution on the part of organizations and workers who are engaged in such services.
('70', 50, 1, 22, 105804) These last cannot be too watchful or too exacting of themselves.
('70', 50, 2, 23, 105869) Harijan, 7 11 1936
('70', 51, 0, 1, 105888) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 52

('70', 57, 6, 15, 115655) 63. DISCUSSION WITH C.F. ANDREWS 2
('70', 57, 7, 16, 115690) [On or after November 9, 1936] 3
('70', 57, 8, 17, 115723) GANDHIJI: Their behaviour has been as bad as that of the rest who are in the field to add to their numbers.
('70', 57, 8, 18, 115831) What pains one is their frantic attempt to exploit the weakness of Harijans.
('70', 57, 8, 19, 115908) If they said, ‘Hinduism is a diabolical religion and you come to us,’ I should understand.
('70', 57, 8, 20, 115999) But they dangle earthly paradises in front of them and make promises to them which they can never keep.
('70', 57, 8, 21, 116103) When in Bangalore 4 a deputation of Indian Christians came to me with a number of resolutions which they thought would please me, I said to them: ‘This is no matter for bargain.
('70', 57, 8, 22, 116281) You must say definitely that this
('70', 57, 9, 23, 116315) 1 Thin, crisp chapatis made out of wheat flour 2 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('70', 57, 9, 24, 116412) Andrews had just returned from a visit to New Zealand, Fiji and Australia and had been, since his return, in correspondence with various missionaries.
('70', 57, 9, 25, 116563) He wanted to know Gandhiji’s reaction to the attitude of the missionaries.
('70', 57, 9, 26, 116638) 3 According to Gandhi—1915 1948: A Detailed Chronology, Andrews arrived in Segaon on November 9. Vide also “Letter to Amrit Kaur”, 9 11 1936 4 Gandhi was in Bangalore from 31 5 1936 to 13 6 1936.
('70', 58, 0, 1, 116834) VOL. 70: 21 OCT0BER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 59
('70', 58, 1, 2, 116881) is a matter to be settled by the Hindus themselves.
('70', 58, 1, 3, 116933) Where is the sense of talking of a sudden awakening of spiritual hunger among the untouchables and then trying to exploit a particular situation?
('70', 58, 1, 4, 117079) The poor Harijans have no mind, no intelligence, no sense of difference between God and no God.
('70', 58, 1, 5, 117175) It is absurd for a single individual to talk of taking all the Harijans with himself.
('70', 58, 1, 6, 117261) Are they all bricks that they could be moved from one structure to another?
('70', 58, 1, 7, 117337) If Christian Missions here want to play the game, and for that matter Mussalmans and others, they should have no such idea as that of adding to their ranks whilst a great reform in Hinduism is going on’.
('70', 58, 2, 8, 117541) C.F.A. Let me ask one question.
('70', 58, 2, 9, 117573) I said in Australia that all the talk of Dr. Ambedkar and his followers was not in terms of religion, and I said also that it was cruelty to bargain with unsophisticated people like the Harijans as they are in most parts of India.
('70', 58, 2, 10, 117804) Then came the London Missionary Society’s statement that the Ezhavas in Travancore had asked for Christian instruction.
('70', 58, 2, 11, 117924) I said then that the Ezhavas were quite enlightened and if they had really asked to be instructed in Christianity, it would be an entirely different matter.
('70', 58, 2, 12, 118081) Was I right?
('70', 58, 3, 13, 118094) GANDHIJI: I do not think so.
('70', 58, 3, 14, 118123) Whilst there are individual Ezhavas who are doctors and barristers and so on, the vast majority of them are just the same as the Harijans elsewhere.
('70', 58, 3, 15, 118272) I can assure you that no one representing the vast body of Ezhavas could have asked for Christian instruction.
('70', 58, 3, 16, 118383) You should ascertain the fact from our principal workers there.
('70', 58, 4, 17, 118447) C.F.A. I see what you mean.
('70', 58, 4, 18, 118475) Only I wanted to say that the London Missionary Society was a liberal body and would not make an irresponsible statement.
('70', 58, 5, 19, 118597) GANDHIJI: But they at the centre cannot know, as the Parliament cannot know the truth of what is happening in India.
('70', 58, 6, 20, 118714) C.F.A. But that apart, I should like to discuss the fundamental position with you.
('70', 58, 6, 21, 118797) What would you say to a man who after considerable thought and prayer said that he could not have his peace and salvation except by becoming a Christian?
('70', 58, 7, 22, 118951) GANDHIJI: I would say that if a non Christian, say a Hindu, came to a Christian and made that statement, he should ask him to become a good Hindu rather than find goodness in change of faith.
('70', 58, 8, 23, 119143) C.F.A. I cannot in this go the whole length with you, though you know my own position.
('70', 58, 8, 24, 119230) I discarded the position that there is no salvation except through Christ long ago.
('70', 58, 8, 25, 119314) But supposing the Oxford Group Movement people changed the life of your son, and he felt like being converted, what would you say?
('70', 58, 9, 26, 119445) GANDHIJI: I would say that the Oxford Group may change the lives of as many as they like, but not their religion.
('70', 58, 9, 27, 119559) They can draw
('70', 59, 0, 1, 119573) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 60
('70', 59, 1, 2, 119614) their attention to the best in their respective religions and change their lives by asking them to live according to them.
('70', 59, 1, 3, 119737) There came to me a man, the son of Brahmin parents, who said his reading of your book had led him to embrace Christianity.
('70', 59, 1, 4, 119860) I asked him if he thought that the religion of his forefathers was wrong.
('70', 59, 1, 5, 119934) He said ‘No.’ Then I said: ‘Is there any difficulty about your accepting the Bible as one of the great religious books of the world and Christ as one of the great teachers?’ I said to him that you had never through your books asked Indians to take up the Bible and embrace Christianity, and that he had misread your book—unless of course your position is like that of the late Maulana Mahomed Ali’s, viz., that a believing Mussalman, however bad his life, is better than a good Hindu.
('70', 59, 2, 6, 120419) C.F.A. I do not accept Maulana Mahomed Ali’s position at all.
('70', 59, 2, 7, 120481) But I do say that if a person really needs a change of faith I should not stand in his way.
('70', 59, 3, 8, 120573) GANDHIJI: But don’t you see that you do not even give him a chance?
('70', 59, 3, 9, 120641) You do not even cross examine him.
('70', 59, 3, 10, 120676) Supposing a Christian came to me and said he was captivated by a reading of the Bhagavata and so wanted to declare himself a Hindu, I should say to him: ‘No.
('70', 59, 3, 11, 120834) What the Bhagavata offers the Bible also offers.
('70', 59, 3, 12, 120883) You have not yet made the attempt to find it out.
('70', 59, 3, 13, 120933) Make the attempt and be a good Christian.’
('70', 59, 4, 14, 120976) C.F.A. I don’t know.
('70', 59, 4, 15, 120997) If someone earnestly says that he will beocme a good Christian, I should say, ‘You may become one’, though you know that I have in my own life strongly dissuaded ardent enthusiasts who came to me.
('70', 59, 4, 16, 121194) I said to them, ‘Certainly not on my account will you do anything of the kind.’ But human nature does require a concrete faith.
('70', 59, 5, 17, 121322) GANDHIJI: If a person wants to believe in the Bible let him say so, but why should he disregard his own religion?
('70', 59, 5, 18, 121436) This proselytization will mean no peace in the world.
('70', 59, 5, 19, 121490) Religion is a very personal matter.
('70', 59, 5, 20, 121526) We should, by living the life according to our light, share the best with one another, thus adding to the sum total of human effort to reach God.
('70', 59, 5, 21, 121672) Consider whether you are going to accept the position of mutual toleration or of equality of all religions.
('70', 59, 5, 22, 121780) My position is that all the great religions are fundamentally equal.
('70', 59, 5, 23, 121849) We must have the innate respect for other religions as we have for our own.
('70', 59, 5, 24, 121925) Mind you, not mutual toleration, but equal respect.
('70', 59, 6, 25, 121977) Harijan, 28 11 1936

('70', 67, 1, 2, 133278) 76. AN INTERVIEW 1
('70', 67, 2, 3, 133297) [After November 12, 1936] 2
('70', 67, 3, 4, 133325) The modern miracle in Travancore is mainly due to the influence of women, or if you please, to the influence of one woman, Her Highness the Maharani of Travancore.
('70', 67, 3, 5, 133489) When I was in Travancore some years ago 3, I met the Maharani.
('70', 67, 3, 6, 133552) She was determined to do what was the purest act of justice, and it is she who is really at the back of the Maharaja’s decision.
('70', 67, 3, 7, 133681) It was a most courageous act to issue the proclamation and still more courageous to carry it out to the letter.
('70', 67, 3, 8, 133793) The Maharaja could not have done it without the support of his mother.
('70', 67, 3, 9, 133864) So I see the hand of woman in this miracle.
('70', 67, 3, 10, 133908) The opening of temples would not have been possible without the widest co operation of the caste Hindus.
('70', 67, 3, 11, 134013) It is a unique demonstration of the power of non violence.
('70', 67, 3, 12, 134072) I had thought that the State would at least have to post a strong police force at the main temples, and that at least a few heads would be broken.
('70', 67, 3, 13, 134219) The process began with the biggest State temple, the one that the Maharaja visits himself.
('70', 67, 3, 14, 134310) There was no political pressure here.
('70', 67, 3, 15, 134348) It could not be imposed on a million people.
('70', 67, 3, 16, 134393) I had no idea that there were nearly 2,000 temples in Travancore.
('70', 67, 3, 17, 134459) I only knew that ten years ago our volunteers had been severely hammered for even crossing a forbidden road near the temple at Vaikom.
('70', 67, 3, 18, 134594) Now the humblest of the humble have entered the Vaikom temple without the slightest difficulty.
('70', 67, 3, 19, 134690) The proclamation did not enthuse me, though it was a solid thing.
('70', 67, 3, 20, 134756) For I had feared that there might be a political motive behind it.
('70', 67, 3, 21, 134823) But all my fears have been dispelled.
('70', 67, 3, 22, 134861) That the orthodoxy, who used to swear by the letter of the ritual and made so much of the efficacy of temple worship being destroyed by even the shadow of a pariah, would fall in with the proclamation, is a thing I was not prepared for, so soon at any rate.
('70', 67, 3, 23, 135119) But God has made possible what man could not have done.
('70', 67, 4, 24, 135175) Mahatma, Vol. IV, pp.
('70', 67, 5, 25, 135197) 1 The identity of the interviewer, an American woman, is not given in the source.
('70', 67, 5, 26, 135279) 2 From the reference to the proclamation issued by the Maharaja of Travancore, throwing open all State temples to Harijans 3 In 1927; vide of “Speech At Trivandrum”, 10 10 1927

('70', 68, 7, 34, 136975) 78. OBSCENE ADVERTISEMENTS
('70', 68, 8, 35, 137002) A sister 1 sending me a cutting from a well known magazine containing the advertisement of a most objectionable book writes:
('70', 68, 9, 36, 137127) 1 Amrit Kaur; vide “Letter to Amrit Kaur”, 21 10 1936
('70', 69, 0, 1, 137181) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 70
('70', 69, 1, 2, 137222) The enclosed came under my eye when glancing over the pages of .
('70', 69, 1, 3, 137287) I do not know if you get this magazine.
('70', 69, 1, 4, 137327) I do not suppose you ever have time to glance at it even if it is sent to you.
('70', 69, 1, 5, 137406) Once before I spoke to you about ‘obscene advertisements’.
('70', 69, 1, 6, 137465) I do so wish you would write about them some time.
('70', 69, 1, 7, 137516) That books of the type advertised are flooding the market today is only too true, but should responsible journals like .
('70', 69, 1, 8, 137637) encourage their sale?
('70', 69, 1, 9, 137659) My woman’s modesty is so utterly repelled by these things that I cannot write to anyone but you.
('70', 69, 1, 10, 137756) To think that what God has given to woman with intent for an express purpose should be advertised for abuse is too degrading for words.
('70', 69, 1, 11, 137892) I wish you would write about the responsibility of leading Indian newspapers and journals in this respect.
('70', 69, 1, 12, 137999) This is not the first by any means that I could have sent to you for criticism.
('70', 69, 2, 13, 138079) From the advertisement I do not propose to reproduce any portion except to tell the reader that it describes as obscenely as it can the suggestive contents of the book advertised.
('70', 69, 2, 14, 138259) Its title is Sexual Beauty of the Female Form and the advertising firm tells the reader that it will give away free to the buyer two more books called New knowledge for the Bride and the Sexual Embrace or How to Please Your Partner.
('70', 69, 3, 15, 138492) I fear that in relying on me in any way to affect the course of the advertisers of such books or to move the editors or publishers from their purpose of making their productions yield profits, she relies on a broken reed.
('70', 69, 3, 16, 138714) No amount of appealing by me to the publishers of the objectionable books or advertisements of them will be of any use.
('70', 69, 3, 17, 138834) But what I would like to tell the writer of the letter and other learned sisters like her is to come out in the open and to do the work that is peculiarly and specially theirs.
('70', 69, 3, 18, 139011) Very often a bad name is given to a person and he or she in course of time begins to believe in the badness.
('70', 69, 3, 19, 139120) To call a woman member of ‘the weaker sex’ is a lible.
('70', 69, 3, 20, 139175) In what way is woman the weaker sex I do not know.
('70', 69, 3, 21, 139226) If the implication is that she lacks the brute instinct of man or does not possess it in the same measure as man, the charge may be admitted.
('70', 69, 3, 22, 139368) But then woman becomes, as she is, the nobler sex.
('70', 69, 3, 23, 139419) If she is weak is striking, she is strong in suffering.
('70', 69, 3, 24, 139475) I have described woman as the embodiment of sacrifice and ahimsa.
('70', 69, 3, 25, 139541) She has to learn not to rely on man to protect her virtue or her honour.
('70', 69, 3, 26, 139614) I do not know a single instance of a man having ever protected the virtue of a woman.
('70', 69, 3, 27, 139700) He cannot even if he would.
('70', 69, 3, 28, 139728) Rama certainly did not protect the virtue of
('70', 70, 0, 1, 139773) VOL. 70: 21 OCT0BER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 71
('70', 70, 1, 2, 139820) Sita, nor the five Pandavas of Draupadi.
('70', 70, 1, 3, 139861) Both these noble women protected their own virtue by the sheer force of their purity.
('70', 70, 1, 4, 139947) No person loses honour or self respect but by his consent.
('70', 70, 1, 5, 140006) A woman no more loses her honour or virtue because a brute renders her senseless and ravishes her than a man loses his because a wicked woman administers to him a stupefying drug and makes him do what she likes.
('70', 70, 1, 6, 140218) It is remarkable that there are no books written in praise of male beauty.
('70', 70, 1, 7, 140293) But why should there always be literature to excite the animal passions of man?
('70', 70, 1, 8, 140373) May it be that woman likes to live up to the titles that man has chosen to bestow upon her?
('70', 70, 1, 9, 140465) Does she like to have the beauty of her form exploited by man?
('70', 70, 1, 10, 140528) Does she like to look beautiful of form before man and why?
('70', 70, 1, 11, 140588) These are questions I would like educated sisters to ask themselves.
('70', 70, 1, 12, 140657) If these advertisements and litreature offend them, they must wage a relentless war against them and they will stop them in a moment.
('70', 70, 1, 13, 140791) Would that woman will realize the power she has latent in her for good if she has also for mischief.
('70', 70, 1, 14, 140892) It is in her power to make the world more livable both for herself and her partner, whether as father, son or husband, if she would cease to think of herself as weak and fit only to serve as a doll for man to play with.
('70', 70, 1, 15, 141112) If society is not to be destroyed by insane wars of nations against nations and still more insane wars on its moral foundations, the woman will have to play her part not manfully, as some are trying to do, but womanfully.
('70', 70, 1, 16, 141334) She won’t better humanity by vying with man in his ability to destroy life mostly without purpose.
('70', 70, 1, 17, 141433) Let it be her privilege to wean the erring man from his error which will envelop in his ruin that of woman also.
('70', 70, 1, 18, 141546) This wretched advertisement is merely a straw showing which way the wind is blowing.
('70', 70, 1, 19, 141631) It is a shameless exploitation of woman.
('70', 70, 1, 20, 141672) It would not leave alone even “the beauty of female form of savage races of the world”.
('70', 70, 2, 21, 141760) Harijan, 14 11 1936
('70', 70, 3, 22, 141780) 79. TEMPLE ENTRY
('70', 70, 4, 23, 141797) A co worker writes:
('70', 70, 5, 24, 141817) A worker in the Harijan cause came in the other day and wanted money for a Harijan temple and school in Phagwara (Jullundur) District).
('70', 70, 5, 25, 141953) I resolutely refused money for a ‘temple’, because I am dead against the building of all such, especially exclusive ones for the Harijans, for it is one form of perpetuating their ‘untouchability’, and just as he was vehemently arguing
('70', 71, 0, 1, 142189) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 72
('70', 71, 1, 2, 142230) with me the postman brought in Harijan with your article 1 on this theme.
('70', 71, 1, 3, 142304) It was quite a godsend.
('70', 71, 1, 4, 142328) Some sanatanists, I understand, are trying to induce Harijans to build a temple for themselves, so that they need not then claim entry into existing temples.
('70', 71, 1, 5, 142486) The Harijans really need protection in this respect and your article has not come a bit too soon.
('70', 71, 2, 6, 142584) I had a huge discussion the other day with a mutual acquaintance about your advocating ‘temple entry’ for Harijans.
('70', 71, 2, 7, 142700) The friend maintained:
('70', 71, 3, 8, 142723) ‘(a) The Mahatma never goes to worship in a temple himself; why, then, does he encourage Harijans to do so?
('70', 71, 3, 9, 142831) For advocating ‘temple entry’ is an indirect means of encouraging worship in temples.
('70', 71, 4, 10, 142917) (b) Our ‘temples’ are in the vast majority of cases solely means of livelihood for priests who are incapable of earning an honest living in any other way.
('70', 71, 4, 11, 143072) Why encourage them?
('70', 71, 5, 12, 143092) (c) To every priest in charge of such temples the entrance of Harijans will mean more money because no one can go to a temple without putting in a pice (minimum).
('70', 71, 6, 13, 143255) (d) Why impoverish the Harijan community?
('70', 71, 7, 14, 143297) (e) Why can’t the Mahatma teach Harijans to worship in the open air as he does himself?’
('70', 71, 8, 15, 143386) I do not know if these questions have been specifically put to you by others and whether you have ever answered them and think it worth while doing so.
('70', 71, 8, 16, 143538) I do feel, however, that Harijans must not be allowed to build separate temples for themselves and that the removal of the ban on temple entry will purify the caste Hindu only.
('70', 71, 8, 17, 143715) The Harijan has to raise himself in other ways with his own as well as our help.
('70', 71, 8, 18, 143796) This letter contains the answer, too, to the questions raised therein.
('70', 71, 8, 19, 143867) Nevertheless it invites publicity and discussion.
('70', 71, 8, 20, 143917) These questions have been often raised and equally often discussed in these columns in some shape or other.
('70', 71, 8, 21, 144025) The worker who wanted a donation for a separate temple for Harijans, and the one who put the various conundrums before the writer of the letter reproduced above, missed the main reason for temple entry.
('70', 71, 8, 22, 144228) The demand for opening all temples to the Harijans is made not because the Harijans desire entry, or that when the temples are thrown open to them they will become changed beings.
('70', 71, 8, 23, 144408) The demand is made for the purification of caste Hindus.
('70', 71, 8, 24, 144465) It is made
('70', 71, 9, 25, 144476) 1 “Task before Harijan Sevaks”, vide “Task Before Harijan Sevaks”, 10 10 1936
('70', 72, 0, 1, 144554) VOL. 70: 21 OCT0BER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 73
('70', 72, 1, 2, 144601) because Harijans are deprived wrongfully of a right that belongs to every Hindu.
('70', 72, 1, 3, 144682) Even though not a single Harijan enters Hindu temples, it is the duty of caste Hindus to throw them open to their brethren the Harijans.
('70', 72, 1, 4, 144819) It is the truest sign of removal of untouchability from the caste Hindu heart.
('70', 72, 1, 5, 144898) The other disabilities have undoubtedly to go, but if this one remains untouchability does not die.
('70', 72, 1, 6, 144998) The civil disabilities will go in course of time, whether caste Hindus wish it or not, but the temples cannot be opened without their free will.
('70', 72, 1, 7, 145143) There is nothing to prevent a Harijan from drawing water from a public well or demanding at a public school equal treatment with the other pupils.
('70', 72, 1, 8, 145290) He does not do so today in a vast majority of cases, only because he is yet too timid to assert his legal right.
('70', 72, 1, 9, 145403) He has reason to be afraid of physical hurt and worse from the caste Hindus.
('70', 72, 1, 10, 145480) But as he grows from strength to strength, he will certainly assert himself and exercise the right which, owing to his helplessness, he has been hitherto unable to exercise.
('70', 72, 1, 11, 145654) Not so, however, about temple entry.
('70', 72, 1, 12, 145691) If Harijans in a body marched to a temple, they would be prevented by law from entering that temple.
('70', 72, 1, 13, 145792) Hence the necessity for agitation by caste Hindu reformers for opening their temples to Harijans.
('70', 72, 1, 14, 145890) As to temples designed specially for Harijans, I have always opposed such projects.
('70', 72, 1, 15, 145974) But there have always been reservations.
('70', 72, 1, 16, 146015) I would not oppose a movement among Harijans themselves for building a temple accessible to both themselves and the caste Hindus.
('70', 72, 1, 17, 146145) Nor would I oppose the building of such temples by caste Hindus.
('70', 72, 1, 18, 146210) In other words I do not always oppose the building of temples as such.
('70', 72, 1, 19, 146281) I think that they play an important and useful part in the lives of millions of people.
('70', 72, 1, 20, 146369) That I do not go to the orthodox temples is irrelevant to the issue before us.
('70', 72, 1, 21, 146448) In order to prove my belief in temples, I need not be a visitor myself.
('70', 72, 1, 22, 146520) Surely it is enough that I believe in God and offer daily worship not as a mere formality but as an integral part of my spiritual food.
('70', 72, 1, 23, 146656) Of course I go out of my way to invite Harijans to attend the daily open air worship.
('70', 72, 1, 24, 146742) I do so, however, not to wean them from the desire to visit orthodox temples.
('70', 72, 1, 25, 146820) Corruption in the temples there undoubtedly is.
('70', 72, 1, 26, 146868) The illiteracy and cruel ignorance of the priests in charge of most temples is deplorable.
('70', 72, 1, 27, 146959) But that is a reason for their reformation, not condemn ation to destruction.
('70', 72, 1, 28, 147037) Nor need Harijans pay anything to the priests.
('70', 72, 1, 29, 147084) Thousands visit temples without paying even a pie.
('70', 72, 1, 30, 147135) I verily believe that
('70', 73, 0, 1, 147157) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 74
('70', 73, 1, 2, 147198) the movement for the opening of temples to Harijans, when it succeeds, as it must some day not far distant, will sweep the temples clean of any of their glaring abuses.
('70', 73, 1, 3, 147367) Harijan, 14 11 1936
('70', 73, 2, 4, 147387) 80. DISCUSSION WITH JOHN R. MOTT 1
('70', 73, 3, 5, 147422) [November 13/14, 1936] 2
('70', 73, 4, 6, 147447) JOHN MOTT: You have been one that has given a great initiative to the movement, you have put your life blood into it, you have suffered and triumphed, and I want you to help me to a profound understanding of what the issues are and tell me how I may help, for I do not want to hinder.
('70', 73, 4, 7, 147732) What is happening in India is going to have a profound effect on the world.
('70', 73, 4, 8, 147808) We are in front of forces the influence of which it would be difficult to prophesy or predict.
('70', 73, 4, 9, 147903) Give me your own diagnosis of the problem.
('70', 73, 5, 10, 147946) GANDHIJI: So far as I am concerned with the untouchability question, it is one of life and death for Hinduism.
('70', 73, 5, 11, 148057) As I have said repeatedly, if untouchability lives Hinduism perishes, and even India perishes; but if untouchability is eradicated from the Hindu heart root and branch, then Hinduism has a definite message for the world.
('70', 73, 5, 12, 148278) I have said the first thing to hundreds of audiences, but not the latter part.
('70', 73, 5, 13, 148357) Now that is the utterance of a man who accepts Truth as God.
('70', 73, 5, 14, 148418) It is therefore no exaggeration.
('70', 73, 5, 15, 148451) If untouchability is an integral part of Hinduism, the latter is a spent bullet.
('70', 73, 5, 16, 148532) But untouchability is hideous untruth.
('70', 73, 5, 17, 148571) My motive in launching the [anti ] untouchability campaign is clear.
('70', 73, 5, 18, 148640) What I am aiming at is not every Hindu touching an untouchable, but every touchable Hindu driving untouchability from his heart, going through a complete change of heart.
('70', 73, 5, 19, 148811) Inter dining or intermarrying is not the point.
('70', 73, 5, 20, 148859) I may not dine with you, but I ought not to harbour the feeling that if I dined with you I should be polluted.
('70', 73, 5, 21, 148970) If I was a woman to be married, I should not say ‘I cannot marry a man because he is an untouchable.’ I am making this clear to you because in the programme of the Harijan Sevak Sangh we say we

('70', 73, 6, 24, 149338) 2 The source gives no date.

('70', 74, 1, 3, 149895) Many of us have no scruples about inter dining or intermarriage.
('70', 74, 1, 4, 149960) That untouchability is an ancient custom I admit, but there are many such things intertwined with Hinduism because it is an ancient religion, even a prehistoric religion.
('70', 74, 1, 5, 150131) Instead of being the dead faith that it threatens to be, I want it to be a living faith, so that it may exist side by side with other religions of the world.

('70', 74, 4, 8, 150665) The conversation led to the genesis of the Yeravda Pact 1 beginning with Gandhiji’s declaration, at the Round Table Conference, to lay down his life to stop the vivisection of Hinduism.

('70', 78, 1, 2, 160002) J. M. What are the governing ideals and aims of this Indian Village Industries movement?
('70', 78, 1, 3, 160091) What is the object of your settling down in this little village?
('70', 78, 2, 4, 160156) G. The immediate object of my stay in Segaon is to remove to the best of my ability the appalling ignorance, poverty and the still more appalling insanitation of the Indian villages.
('70', 78, 2, 5, 160339) All these really run into one another.
('70', 78, 2, 6, 160378) We seek to remove ignorance not through imparting the knowledge of the alphabet by word of mouth, but by giving them object lessons in sanitation, by telling them what is happening in the world, and so on.
('70', 78, 3, 7, 160584) J. M. What you are doing here has great industrial significance.
('70', 78, 3, 8, 160649) Japan with about as high a rate of literacy as any country in the world is not exempt from the sins of industrialism.
('70', 78, 4, 9, 160767) G. But I am not seeking to industrialize the village.
('70', 78, 4, 10, 160821) I want to revive the village after the ancient pattern, i.
('70', 78, 4, 11, 160880) e., to revive hand spinning, hand ginning, and its other vital handicrafts.
('70', 78, 4, 12, 160956) The village uplift movement is an offshoot of the spinning movement.
('70', 78, 4, 13, 161025) So great was my ignorance in 1908 that I mixed up the spinning wheel with the loom in my small book on Indian Home Rule 1.
('70', 78, 5, 14, 161148) J. M. What is the cause of your greatest concern, your heaviest burden?
('70', 78, 6, 15, 161220) G. My greatest worry is the ignorance and poverty of the masses of India, and the way in which they have been neglected by the classes, especially the neglect of the Harijans by the Hindus.
('70', 78, 6, 16, 161410) This criminal neglect is unwarranted by any of the scriptures.
('70', 78, 6, 17, 161473) We are custodians of a great religion and yet we have been guilty of a crime which constitutes our greatest shame.
('70', 78, 6, 18, 161588) Had I not been a believer in the inscrutable ways of Providence, a sensitive man like me would have been a raving maniac.
('70', 78, 7, 19, 161710) J. M. What affords you the greatest hope and satisfaction?
('70', 78, 8, 20, 161769) G. Faith in myself born of faith in God.
('70', 78, 9, 21, 161810) J. M. In moments when your heart may sink within you, you hark back to this faith in God?
('70', 78, 10, 22, 161900) G. Yes.
('70', 78, 10, 23, 161908) That is why I have always described myself as an irrepressible optimist.
('70', 78, 11, 24, 161981) J. M. So am I .
('70', 78, 11, 25, 161997) Our difficulties are our salvation.

('70', 78, 12, 27, 162075) G. Yes.
('70', 78, 12, 28, 162083) My difficulties have strengthened my faith which rises superior to every difficulty, and remains undimmed.
('70', 78, 12, 29, 162190) My darkest hour
('70', 78, 13, 30, 162206) 1 Hind Swaraj, which, however, was written in 1909 and not in 1908
('70', 79, 0, 1, 162273) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 80
('70', 79, 1, 2, 162314) was when I was in Bombay a few months ago 1. It was the hour of my temptation.
('70', 79, 1, 3, 162393) Whilst I was asleep I suddenly felt as though I wanted to see a woman.
('70', 79, 1, 4, 162464) Well a man who had tried to rise superior to the sex instinct for nearly 40 years was bound to be intensely pained when he had this frightful experience.
('70', 79, 1, 5, 162618) I ultimately conquered the feeling, but I was face to face with the blackest moment of my life and if I had succumbed to it, it would have meant my absolute undoing.
