('70', 85, 0, 1, 172490) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 86
('70', 85, 1, 2, 172531) 90. AN EXAMPLE FOR HINDU PRINCES AND THEIR ADVISERS
('70', 85, 2, 3, 172583) [Before November 16, 1936] 1
('70', 85, 3, 4, 172612) The Travancore Durbar have earned the congratulations of the whole Hindu world and all thoughtful men by issuing the following proclamation:
('70', 85, 4, 5, 172753) Profoundly convinced of the truth and validity of our religion, believing that it is based on Divine guidance and on all comprehending toleration, knowing that in its practice it has throughout the centuries adapted itself to the need of the changing times, solicitous that none of our Hindu subjects should, be reason of birth, caste or community, be denied the consolation and solace of the Hindu faith, we have decided and hereby declare, ordain and command that, subject to such rules and conditions as may be laid down and imposed by us for preserving their proper atmosphere and maintaining their rituals and observances, there should henceforth be no restriction placed on any Hindu by birth or religion on entering or worshipping at temples controlled by us and our Government.
('70', 85, 4, 6, 173539) The action has been long overdue.
('70', 85, 4, 7, 173573) But better late than never.
('70', 85, 4, 8, 173601) It may be said without pride that the way for the great step was prepared by the gentle but persistent efforts of the Travancore branch of the Harijan Sevak Sangh headed by Shri K. Parameswaran Pillai.
('70', 85, 4, 9, 173803) The workers of the Sangh had awakened the conscience of the savarna Hindus who had sent numerous petitions to the Durbar praying for the opening of the State temples to Harijans on the same terms as they were to caste Hindus.
('70', 85, 4, 10, 174029) Untouchability, though an excrescence, has taken such hold of the Hindu world that whenever a Hindu breaks through it and declares against it, he excites admiration among reformers and becomes the object of fierce criticism from the orthodox.
('70', 85, 4, 11, 174272) This is much more so when the action is taken by one in high authority as H. H. the Maharaja of Travancore, an ancient orthodox Hindu State.
('70', 85, 4, 12, 174413) Let us hope all criticism will be hushed before this well thought out, deliberate act of piety and justice.
('70', 85, 4, 13, 174521) Let us hope, too, that no attempt will be made to whittle away the hard earned freedom of Harijans by hedging it round by any the least distinction between one Hindu and another.
('70', 85, 4, 14, 174700) If the proclamation
('70', 85, 5, 15, 174720) 1 Though this was first published in The Bombay Chronicle on November 17, it is clear from the following item that it was ready for release on the 16th.
('70', 86, 0, 1, 174873) VOL. 70: 21 OCT0BER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 87
('70', 86, 1, 2, 174920) means anything it means that in the temples conducted under the State aegis Harijans will offer worship precisely on the same terms as the highest caste Hindus so called.
('70', 86, 1, 3, 175091) In other words, in the house of God in Travancore henceforth there will be no distinction between man and man, there will be no Harijans and no high caste, all will be Harijans— children of God.
('70', 86, 1, 4, 175286) If these are not the implications of the great proclamation, it is nothing but a mere scrap of paper.
('70', 86, 1, 5, 175388) But we have no reason to doubt its sincerity or suspect any mental reservations.
('70', 86, 1, 6, 175469) Travancore has a large and important Christian community.
('70', 86, 1, 7, 175527) Christian missions are flirting with Harijans, rightly no doubt from their own standpoint, they are spending money on them and holding out hope of real freedom and equality of social status.
('70', 86, 1, 8, 175718) It is beside the present discussion that for Harijans there is no social equality, no real freedom anywhere except when it is first obtained in Hinduism.
('70', 86, 1, 9, 175872) I am not thinking of individuals.
('70', 86, 1, 10, 175906) I am thinking of the whole mass.
('70', 86, 1, 11, 175939) The latter are so intertwined with the other Hindus that unless they become brothers with them instead of remaining serfs which they are, no change of label can avail anything.
('70', 86, 1, 12, 176116) But this apart, let us realize that the working of the proclamation will be narrowly watched and criticized by the sister communities.
('70', 86, 1, 13, 176251) It therefore behoves the State authorities as well as the caste Hindus to give full effect to the letter and the spirit of the proclamation.
('70', 86, 1, 14, 176392) The main duty of working the proclamation, however, devolves in a way upon the reformers and Harijans.
('70', 86, 1, 15, 176495) They should avail themselves of the freedom in a religious, becoming and humble spirit.
('70', 86, 1, 16, 176583) Reformers should see to it that Harijans enter these temples after proper ablutions and in a clean condition.
('70', 86, 1, 17, 176693) I know that this primary rule is observed more in the breach than in the performance by the vast majority of temple going caste Hindus.
('70', 86, 1, 18, 176829) Harijans may not copy the bad manners of caste Hindus.
('70', 86, 1, 19, 176884) They should take pride in setting a good example in cleanliness both of body and heart.
('70', 86, 1, 20, 176972) The proclamation should have no political significance, as it has none.
('70', 86, 1, 21, 177044) I regard it as the performance of a purely religious duty by the State.
('70', 86, 1, 22, 177116) And it should be so taken and so treated by all the Hindus of the State.
('70', 86, 1, 23, 177189) To give it any other colour will be to destroy its great spiritual purpose and effect.
('70', 86, 1, 24, 177276) Let us hope that the example of Travancore will prove infectious and all the othere Hindu States will follow suit.
('70', 86, 1, 25, 177391) There is no reason why they should not.
('70', 86, 1, 26, 177431) It is the privilege and duty of a Hindu prince to
('70', 87, 0, 1, 177481) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 88
('70', 87, 1, 2, 177522) propound religious codes which are not inconsistent with the fundamental principles of Hinduism as derived from the Vedas and which are demanded by the spirit of the times.
('70', 87, 1, 3, 177695) This must be true of all the progressive and living religions.
('70', 87, 1, 4, 177758) This rule accounts for apparent inconsistencies of the different smritis and also obvious departures from the original tenets as even a careless student will detect even in the same smriti.
('70', 87, 1, 5, 177948) If the Hindu princes do not perform this primary function, it is not so much their fault as of the lost Brahminhood.
('70', 87, 1, 6, 178065) If the Brahminical spirit was restored, princes would be rishis, who would take from the revenues the honest minimum necessary to support them as a commission for their labours on behalf of the ryots, and hold their revenue in trust for the ryots.
('70', 87, 1, 7, 178313) They would not have private property as they possess today and feel independent of their ryots and their wishes.
('70', 87, 1, 8, 178426) But whether we reach the ideal state outlined here during the present generation or ever, surely there is nothing to prevent the Hindu princes from following the example set by Travancore, and thus hastening the day of the total removal of untouchability from Hinduism, and helping to save it from certain destruction.
('70', 87, 1, 9, 178745) I would advise the responsible Hindus in every Hindu State to approach their princes and their advisers to initiate the overdue reform.
('70', 87, 2, 10, 178881) Harijan, 21 11 1936

('70', 91, 1, 2, 182852) 98. LETTER TO AMRITLAL T. NANAVATI
('70', 91, 2, 3, 182887) SEGAON, November 17, 1936 CHI.
('70', 91, 2, 4, 182918) AMRITLAL, I got your letter after Vasumati had left.
('70', 91, 2, 5, 182971) So the address for the information of the relatives could not be given.
('70', 91, 2, 6, 183043) I am sending Kanu your address.
('70', 91, 2, 7, 183075) Among other fruits are pomegranate, custard apple, pineapple, jambu, sweet guavas, mangoes, fully ripe rayan, sweet berries, etc.
('70', 91, 2, 8, 183205) There is no harm in taking bananas occasionally.
('70', 91, 2, 9, 183254) But it is better to take them in place of rotli.
('70', 91, 2, 10, 183303) You may wash them and add butter or ghee.
('70', 91, 2, 11, 183345) It is possible that some of these fruits may not suit you as the apples did not.
('70', 91, 2, 12, 183426) You should give up such fruits.
('70', 91, 2, 13, 183458) I follow the point about soap.
('70', 91, 2, 14, 183489) Chhotelal says that even soap powder is more expensive than the soap made at Maganwadi.
('70', 91, 2, 15, 183577) Can you say anything on this matter?
('70', 91, 2, 16, 183614) You are gaining weight satisfactorily.
('70', 91, 2, 17, 183653) It should go on.
('70', 91, 2, 18, 183670) See that you do not have the slightest indigestion.
('70', 91, 2, 19, 183722) Mirabehn is also recouping her health and she does not feel tired while walking.
('70', 91, 2, 20, 183803) She does some work also.
('70', 91, 2, 21, 183828) Although sometimes she does transgress the limit.
('70', 91, 2, 22, 183878) One day she even had fever.
('70', 91, 2, 23, 183906) I was scared and so was she.
('70', 91, 2, 24, 183935) She took almost nothing on that day and remained on honey, water and lemon juice and was well again.
('70', 91, 2, 25, 184036) Amtul Salaam lives at Santa Cruz.
('70', 91, 2, 26, 184070) Do go there.
('70', 91, 2, 27, 184083) The address is Easter Villa, 7th Road.
('70', 91, 2, 28, 184122) See Kanti if you can.
('70', 91, 2, 29, 184144) Your recipe for making gruel is correct.
('70', 91, 2, 30, 184185) No lumps will form even if you put paste of flour made in cold water into the boiling water.
('70', 91, 2, 31, 184278) I had made gruel for 75 prisoners at a time by this method.
('70', 91, 2, 32, 184338) It cooks in a very short time.
('70', 91, 2, 33, 184369) It takes quite a long time if we put the cold mixture on the fire and it requires stirring continuously.
('70', 91, 2, 34, 184474) Do you understand what I write?
('70', 91, 2, 35, 184506) I hope you do.
('70', 91, 2, 36, 184521) You must pour into boiling water the thick paste of flour, stirring the while.
('70', 91, 2, 37, 184600) The intake of milk should be up to 120 tolas.
('70', 91, 2, 38, 184646) Make a habit of taking lemons.
('70', 91, 2, 39, 184677) There is nothing about Harilal in the newspapers.
('70', 91, 2, 40, 184727) I do wish to know, however, what he said on the occasion, where it was and what happened there, and so on.

('70', 94, 1, 2, 188224) 102. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR November 19, 1936
('70', 94, 2, 3, 188268) MY DEAR IDIOT, I write never to make you weep but always to make you laugh.
('70', 94, 2, 4, 188344) After your letter I realized the meaning you gave to your previous letter.
('70', 94, 2, 5, 188419) At the same time your paragraph did bear the meaning I put upon it.
('70', 94, 2, 6, 188487) But why should my play make you weep?
('70', 94, 2, 7, 188525) Why don’t you weep over the many choice adjectives I apply to you?
('70', 94, 2, 8, 188592) You must develop a thick skin, if you will be well, both physically and mentally, and will take up the task for which you seem to be cut out.
('70', 94, 2, 9, 188734) I am not going to Faizpur on 1st December but I may on 10th or 11th, certainly about 20th.
('70', 94, 2, 10, 188825) If you come after 27th it will be very late.
('70', 94, 2, 11, 188870) Why not come earlier and go from there to Ahmedabad.
('70', 94, 2, 12, 188923) Then you may be a little late, if you like.
('70', 94, 2, 13, 188967) But you will see what is possible.
('70', 94, 2, 14, 189002) I am not touring after the Congress.
('70', 94, 2, 15, 189039) My destination is Segaon.
('70', 94, 2, 16, 189065) I shall have to go to Belgaum in March or April, whenever Gandhi Seva Sangh meets.
('70', 94, 2, 17, 189148) This gives you all the information you need and ask for.
('70', 94, 2, 18, 189205) The session begins on 27th and ends 29th.
('70', 94, 2, 19, 189247) I shall certainly read your article if it comes to me in time for suggestions.
('70', 94, 4, 20, 189326) From the original: C. W. 3754. Courtesy: Amrit Kaur.

('70', 94, 7, 32, 189967) Why don’t you content yourself with what you can do within the limits of your strength?

('70', 96, 7, 11, 191809) 106. LETTER TO RAMNARAYAN N. PATHAK
('70', 96, 8, 12, 191845) November 19, 1936
('70', 96, 9, 13, 191863) BHAI RAMNARAYAN,
('70', 96, 10, 14, 191880) Your first statement is not an indication of truth.
('70', 96, 10, 15, 191932) It fails to incorporate many points that should have been there.
('70', 96, 10, 16, 191997) Even my opinion has not been quoted correctly.
('70', 96, 10, 17, 192044) How can a person ignorant of the background understand it?
('70', 96, 10, 18, 192103) I have to join issue with you, should I not, when you do not accept my opinion and at the same time publish it?
('70', 96, 10, 19, 192215) If you wish, you may publish your second statement.
('70', 96, 10, 20, 192267) However, you need not do anything under pressure from me.
('70', 96, 10, 21, 192325) Write and do only what your mind and your heart permit.
('70', 96, 10, 22, 192381) I expect nothing more than that you will weigh calmly the words of one like me.
('70', 96, 10, 23, 192461) It is not up to me to forsake or ignore you.
('70', 96, 10, 24, 192506) To the end of my life I shall hope, as I do in the case of Harilal, that you will be reformed.
('70', 96, 10, 25, 192601) To me Narmada’s staying in Jyoti Sangh, her being considered a pious woman, your staying near her and other things are like branding one who has already burnt himself.
('70', 96, 10, 26, 192769) I do not know what kind of morality you accept.
('70', 96, 10, 27, 192817) Probably you do not find any immorality in your conduct and therefore my simile would hurt you as everything I say hurts Harilal.
('70', 96, 10, 28, 192947) However, there is no other way before me to awaken
('70', 97, 0, 1, 192998) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 98
('70', 97, 1, 2, 193039) either him or you.
('70', 97, 1, 3, 193058) I do not know you but I do know Narmada a little.
('70', 97, 1, 4, 193108) She is a foolish girl and has very little understanding.
('70', 97, 1, 5, 193165) She is ignorant of truth and untruth.
('70', 97, 1, 6, 193203) Any young man can mislead her.
('70', 97, 1, 7, 193234) You became her husband instead of being a brother or father to her and did obvious injustice to Ganga.
('70', 97, 1, 8, 193337) Narmada could not even stand the talk she had with me before leaving.
('70', 97, 1, 9, 193407) I keep on receiving laments from your brother, Ganga and Hemubhai.
('70', 97, 1, 10, 193474) It is terrible if all that they write is true.
('70', 97, 1, 11, 193521) And if it is—and from what you yourself write it seems to be— one shouldn’t be surprised if you were playing false with them.
('70', 97, 1, 12, 193647) I know young men who feel satisfied that they have done their duty when they partially acknowledge their sins and if other people are not satisfied with it they get angry.
('70', 97, 1, 13, 193819) They think that society is ungrateful to them.
('70', 97, 1, 14, 193866) I wish you would not make such a mistake.
('70', 97, 1, 15, 193908) Believe it that whatever I have written is for your good and for your guidance.

('70', 97, 1, 17, 194036) So how can I do that with you or anyone else?

('70', 100, 1, 2, 197471) 112. SEX EDUCATION 1
('70', 100, 2, 3, 197492) Maganbhai Desai, who received the other day the degree equivalent to Master of Arts from the Gujarat Vidyapith, wrote to me a Gujarati letter dated 7th October from which I cull the following: 2
('70', 100, 3, 4, 197687) May I invite you to discuss in the columns of Harijanbandhu a question which you have so far left more or less untouched, I mean the question of imparting sex instruction to young people?
('70', 100, 4, 5, 197875) Should sex education be included in the educational curricula of our children?
('70', 100, 4, 6, 197954) Who should impart it?
('70', 100, 4, 7, 197976) What would be the necessary qualification for the task?
('70', 100, 4, 8, 198032) Should this subject be taught in a matter of fact manner to all and sundry just like geography or arithmetic?
('70', 100, 4, 9, 198142) Or is there any limit?
('70', 100, 4, 10, 198165) And if so, who is to draw the line and where?
('70', 100, 4, 11, 198211) Again, should the aim of sex education be to combat the onset of libido or simply to recognize it as an inevitable fact of nature which has to be accepted and submitted to?
('70', 100, 5, 12, 198384) May I also take leave to make a special request in this connection?
('70', 100, 5, 13, 198452) Apart from what you may write on this subject in English, won’t you write something for the Gujarati reader in Gujarati?
('70', 100, 5, 14, 198573) You know it is an old standing grievance of ours that you have ceased to give your original contributions in Gujarati.
('70', 100, 6, 15, 198692) I kept this letter for such a long time hoping that one day I should write something on the subject discussed in it.
('70', 100, 6, 16, 198809) Meanwhile I had to go to Ahmedabad to preside at the Twelfth Gujarati Sahitya Parishad 3. During my stay of four days at the Vidyapith and in course of contact with Gujarati men and women there, past incidents came afresh to me.
('70', 100, 6, 17, 199038) I was confronted by the man who had gently castigated me in the above mentioned letter.
('70', 100, 6, 18, 199126) He even asked me, “What about that letter?” I pacified him by saying that I was carrying it everywhere with me and that I would definitely write about it.
('70', 100, 6, 19, 199281) At that time I wanted to write in English.
('70', 100, 6, 20, 199324) On reaching Segaon, I felt the impact of Maganbhai’s castigation.
('70', 100, 6, 21, 199390) I was reminded of the bitter but affectionate
('70', 100, 7, 22, 199436) 1 Translated from Gujarati by Pyarelal.
('70', 100, 7, 23, 199476) The original appeared in Harijanbandhu, 22 11 1936. 2 Only extracts have been reproduced here.
('70', 100, 7, 24, 199571) 3 Vide “Speech at Gujarati Sahitya Parishad”, 31 10 1936 and “Speech at the Concluding Session of the Twelfth Gujarati Sahitya Parishad, Ahmedabad”, 2 11 1936
('70', 101, 0, 1, 199730) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 102
('70', 101, 1, 2, 199772) quarrel with Swami Anand in the days of Navajivan.
('70', 101, 1, 3, 199823) He could not bear that I should contribute my original ideas to Young India while only stale versions should go to Navajivan.
('70', 101, 1, 4, 199949) I also felt the same.
('70', 101, 1, 5, 199971) Yet my insistence on writing in Young India was not out of place.
('70', 101, 1, 6, 200037) I think at long last Swami Anand got tired and stopped troubling me.
('70', 101, 1, 7, 200106) Even after the lapse of such a long time I cannot say definitely which of us two was right.
('70', 101, 1, 8, 200198) Be it as it may, having said this much by way of introduction I wish to tell the readers of Harijanbandhu that I fully agree with Shri Maganbhai’s complaint.
('70', 101, 1, 9, 200356) And from now onwards, every week I will try to give something new to the Gujarati readers.
('70', 101, 1, 10, 200447) I appeal to them to encourage me in my effort.
('70', 101, 2, 11, 200494) Preoccupation with sex is daily becoming more marked in Gujarat as in the rest of India.
('70', 101, 2, 12, 200583) And what is more, those who fall under its sway feel as if there is something meritorious about it.
('70', 101, 2, 13, 200683) When a slave begins to take pride in his fetters and hugs them like precious ornaments, the triumph of the slave owner is complete.
('70', 101, 2, 14, 200815) But this success of Cupid, spectacular though it may be, will, I am convinced, prove to be short lived and ignoble, and at long last end in inanition even like a scorpion whose venom is spent.
('70', 101, 2, 15, 201008) But that does not mean that we can in the meantime afford to sit with folded hands.
('70', 101, 2, 16, 201092) The certainty of its defeat need not, must not, lull us into a false sense of security.
('70', 101, 2, 17, 201180) The conquest of lust is the highest endeavour of a man’s or a woman’s existence.
('70', 101, 2, 18, 201261) Without overcoming lust man cannot hope to rule over self.
('70', 101, 2, 19, 201320) And without rule over self there can be no swaraj or Ramarajya.
('70', 101, 2, 20, 201384) Rule of all without rule of oneself would prove to be as deceptive and disappointing as a painted toy mango, charming to look at outwardly but hollow and empty within.
('70', 101, 2, 21, 201552) No worker who has not overcome lust can hope to render any genuine service to the cause of Harijans, communal unity, khadi, cow protection or village reconstruction.
('70', 101, 2, 22, 201718) Great causes like these cannot be served by intellectual equipment alone, they call for spiritual effort or soul force.
('70', 101, 2, 23, 201838) Soul force comes only through God’s grace, and God’s grace never descends upon a man who is a slave to lust.
('70', 101, 2, 24, 201947) What place has then instruction in sexual science in our educational system, or has it any place there at all?
('70', 101, 2, 25, 202058) Sexual science is of two kinds, that which is used for controlling or overcoming the sexual passion and that which is used to stimulate and feed it.
('70', 101, 2, 26, 202207) Instruction in the former is as necessary a part of a child’s education
('70', 101, 3, 27, 202279) 1 This paragraph has been taken from Harijanbandhu.
('70', 102, 0, 1, 202331) VOL. 70: 21 OCT0BER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 103
('70', 102, 1, 2, 202379) as the latter is harmful and dangerous and fit therefore only to be shunned.
('70', 102, 1, 3, 202456) All great religions have rightly regarded Kama as the arch enemy of man, anger or hatred coming only in the second place.
('70', 102, 1, 4, 202578) According to the Gita, the latter is an offspring of the former.
('70', 102, 1, 5, 202643) The Gita of course uses the word kama in its wider sense of desire.
('70', 102, 1, 6, 202711) But the same holds good of the narrow sense in which it is used here.
('70', 102, 1, 7, 202781) This, however, still leaves unanswered the question, viz., whether it is desirable to impart to young pupils a knowledge about the use and function of generative organs.
('70', 102, 1, 8, 202951) It seems to me that it is necessary to impart such knowledge to a certain extent.
('70', 102, 1, 9, 203033) At present they are often left to pick up such knowledge anyhow, with the result that they are misled into abusive practices.
('70', 102, 1, 10, 203159) We cannot properly control or conquer the sexual passion by turning a blind eye to it.
('70', 102, 1, 11, 203246) I am therefore strongly in favour of teaching young boys and girls the significance and right use of their generative organs.
('70', 102, 1, 12, 203372) And in my own way I have tried to impart this knowledge to young children of both sexes for whose training I was responsible.
('70', 102, 1, 13, 203498) But the sex education that I stand for must have for its object the conquest and sublimation of the sex passion.
('70', 102, 1, 14, 203611) Such education should automatically serve to bring home to children the essential distinction between man and brute, to make them realize that it is man’s special privilege and pride to be gifted with the faculties of head and heart both; that he is a thinking, no less than a feeling, animal, as the very derivation of the word manushya shows, and to renounce the sovereignty of reason over the blind instincts is therefore to renounce a man’s estate.
('70', 102, 1, 15, 204064) In man reason quickens and guides the feeling, in brute the soul lies over dormant.
('70', 102, 1, 16, 204148) To awaken the heart is to awaken the dormant soul, to awaken reason, and to inculcate discrimination between good and evil.
('70', 102, 1, 17, 204272) Who should teach this true science of sex?
('70', 102, 1, 18, 204315) Clearly, he who has attained mastery over his passions.
('70', 102, 1, 19, 204371) To teach astronomy and kindred sciences we have teachers who have gone through a course of training in them and are masters of their art.
('70', 102, 1, 20, 204509) Even so must we have as teachers of sexual science, i.e., the science of sex control, those who have studied it and have acquired mastery over self.
('70', 102, 1, 21, 204658) Even a lofty utterance that has not the backing of sincerity and experience will be inert and lifeless, and will utterly fail to penetrate and quicken the hearts of men, while the speech that springs from self realization and genuine experience is always fruitful.
('70', 103, 0, 1, 204923) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 104
('70', 103, 1, 2, 204965) Today our entire environment—our reading, our thinking, our social behaviour—is generally calculated to subserve and cater for the sex urge.
('70', 103, 1, 3, 205106) To break through its coils is no easy task.
('70', 103, 1, 4, 205150) But it is a task worthy of our highest endeavour.
('70', 103, 1, 5, 205200) Even if there are a handful of teachers endowed with practical experience, who accept the ideal of attaining self control as the highest duty of man, are fired by a genuine and undying faith in their mission, and are sleeplessly vigilant and active, their labour will light the path of the children of Gujarat, save the unwary from falling into the mire of sexuality and rescue those who might be already engulfed in it.
('70', 103, 2, 6, 205621) Harijan, 21 11 1936, and Harijanbandhu, 22 11 1936

('70', 103, 4, 9, 205742) Thakkar Bapa the following letter: 1
('70', 103, 5, 10, 205779) The havoc caused by the terrible cyclone that burst over the coastal districts of Andhradesa, especially Guntur District, cannot be adequately measured in terms of money.
('70', 103, 5, 11, 205950) The official estimate is one crore of rupees.
('70', 103, 5, 12, 205996) I am writing this to you specially on behalf of Harijans who have been terribly hard hit.
('70', 103, 5, 13, 206086) Their plight is very pitiable and calls for prompt and adequate relief.
('70', 103, 5, 14, 206158) Over 3,000 weavers have lost homes and looms.
('70', 103, 5, 15, 206204) Fishermen on the coast, aboriginal tribes, Harijans and other Depressed Classes have lost their all— food, clothing and shelter .
('70', 103, 5, 16, 206334) .A sum of Rs. 25,000 is the bare minimum required to give them immediate relief .
('70', 103, 5, 17, 206416) Donations may be sent to Deshbhakta Konda Venkatapayya, Guntur.
('70', 103, 5, 18, 206480) I gladly publish this letter.
('70', 103, 5, 19, 206510) Calamities such as the one that has overtaken Guntur have become part of our life.
('70', 103, 5, 20, 206593) There is no doubt that philanthropists will be helping cyclone stricken people in Guntur, but the call of the Harijans affected by the cyclone required special emphasis, and I hope that those who are interested in Harijans will not fail to respond to this call.

('70', 112, 0, 1, 219935) VOL. 70: 21 OCT0BER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 113
('70', 112, 1, 2, 219983) 129. DISCUSSION WITH BASIL MATHEWS AND OTHERS 1
('70', 112, 2, 3, 220031) [November 24, 1936] 2
('70', 112, 3, 4, 220053) I cannot speak with either the definiteness or the confidence of a Stalin or a Hitler, as I have no cut and dried programme which I can impose on the villagers.
('70', 112, 3, 5, 220214) My method, I need not say, is different.
('70', 112, 3, 6, 220255) I propose to convert by patient persuasion.
('70', 112, 3, 7, 220299) This is a kind of practical adult education to be put to use as it progresses.
('70', 112, 3, 8, 220378) The centre is automatically shifted from the cities to the villages.
('70', 112, 3, 9, 220447) They will be taught to know what they should want and how to obtain it in the shape of sanitation and hygiene, improvement of material conditions and social relations.
('70', 112, 3, 10, 220615) If this primary education is taken by them in its fullness everything else follows.
('70', 112, 3, 11, 220699) But in indicating the ideal I have told you of the difficulties of this stupendous task.
('70', 112, 3, 12, 220788) For you should know that we have smaller, more illiterate villages even than Segaon, where people hug their ignorance and dirt as they do their untouchability.
('70', 112, 4, 13, 220948) With this he gave Mr. Mathews a vivid idea of the village and its inhabitants and surroundings, and spoke on the problem of utilization of waste hours and waste products or of products that were going to waste.
('70', 112, 4, 14, 221159) He described how a successful experiment was now being made of tapping palm trees for gur which were either being used for toddy or not used at all.
('70', 112, 4, 15, 221308) And he gave Mr. Mathews and Mr. Hodge and others present a sample of the gur made that morning.
('70', 112, 4, 16, 221404) A palm tapper had to be engaged, he dictated his own terms.
('70', 112, 4, 17, 221464) Gandhiji said: I want them to dictate their own terms.
('70', 112, 4, 18, 221519) He charges Rs. 10 a month for tapping 25 trees, but when more people begin doing the thing and have learnt how to utilize their idle hours, the adjustment will take place of itself.
('70', 112, 5, 19, 221701) He next talked of sanitation .
('70', 112, 5, 20, 221732) He said: Lionel Curtis 3 when he wrote that the Indian village consisted of dilapidated structures built on dung heaps did not overdraw the picture.
('70', 112, 5, 21, 221881) We have to remove the dung heaps, turn them to good account and make the village site a smiling garden.
('70', 112, 6, 22, 221985) Mr. Basil Mathews .
('70', 112, 6, 23, 222005) .discussed the place of the money lender and the zamindar in the village economy.
('70', 112, 6, 24, 222087) Gandhiji said:
('70', 112, 7, 25, 222102) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly letter” 2 The date is from the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.
('70', 112, 7, 26, 222211) 3 Vide “Interview to “The Star”, 6 1 1908
('70', 113, 0, 1, 222253) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 114
('70', 113, 1, 2, 222295) The money lender who is inevitable today will gradually eliminate himself.
('70', 113, 1, 3, 222370) Nor are co operative banks needed, because when I have taught Harijans the arts I want to teach them they will not need much ready money.
('70', 113, 1, 4, 222508) Besides, those who are today deep down in mire cannot make use of co operative banks.
('70', 113, 1, 5, 222594) I am not so much concerned in getting them loans of money or plots of land as I am about getting them bread and butter and even a little cheese.
('70', 113, 1, 6, 222739) When people have learnt the art of turning idle hours to wealth all the adjustment we need will follow.
('70', 113, 2, 7, 222843) But what about the zamindar?
('70', 113, 2, 8, 222872) Would you eliminate him?
('70', 113, 2, 9, 222897) would you destroy him?
('70', 113, 2, 10, 222920) I do not want to destroy the zamindar, but neither do I feel that the zamindar is inevitable.
('70', 113, 2, 11, 223014) I will illustrate how I work out my trusteeship theory here.
('70', 113, 2, 12, 223075) In this village Jamnalalji has a 75 per cent share.
('70', 113, 2, 13, 223127) Of course I have come here not by design but by accident.
('70', 113, 2, 14, 223185) When I approached Jamnalalji for help he built me the required hut and outhouses and said, “Whatever profit there is from Segaon you may take for the welfare of the village.” If I can persuade other zamindars to do likewise village improvement becomes easy.
('70', 113, 2, 15, 223443) Of course the next question is that of the land system and that of Government exploitation.
('70', 113, 2, 16, 223535) I regard the difficulties surrounding that aspect of the question as for the moment necessary evils.
('70', 113, 2, 17, 223636) If the present programme is carried through, I shall perhaps know how to deal with the Government exploitation.
('70', 113, 2, 18, 223748) Your actual economic policy would differ from Mr. Nehru’s?
('70', 113, 2, 19, 223807) He, so far as I understand him, would wipe out the zamindar.
('70', 113, 2, 20, 223868) Yes, we seem to differ in our ideas of village uplift and reconstruction.
('70', 113, 2, 21, 223942) The difference is of emphasis.
('70', 113, 2, 22, 223973) He does not mind the village uplift movement.
('70', 113, 2, 23, 224019) He believes in industrialization; I have grave doubts about its usefulness for India.
('70', 113, 2, 24, 224105) He believes in the ultimate inevitability of class conflict, though he would avoid it if he could.
('70', 113, 2, 25, 224204) I expect to convert the zamindars and other capitalists by the non violent method, and therefore there is for me nothing like an inevitability of class conflict.
('70', 113, 2, 26, 224366) For it is an essential part of non violence to go along the line of least resistance.
('70', 113, 2, 27, 224452) The moment the cultivators of the soil realize their power, the zamindari evil will be sterilized.
('70', 113, 2, 28, 224551) What can the poor zamindar do when they say that they will simply not work the land unless they are paid enough to feed and clothe and educate themselves and their children in a decent manner?
('70', 113, 2, 29, 224744) In reality the toiler is the owner of what he produces.
('70', 113, 2, 30, 224800) If the toilers intelligently
('70', 114, 0, 1, 224829) VOL. 70: 21 OCT0BER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 115
('70', 114, 1, 2, 224877) combine, they will become an irresistible power.
('70', 114, 1, 3, 224926) That is how I do not see the necessity of class conflict.
('70', 114, 1, 4, 224984) If I thought it inevitable I should not hesitate to preach it and teach it.
('70', 114, 2, 5, 225060) Mr. Mathews referred to the Archishop of Canterbury’s speech at the Central Hall, Westminster.
('70', 114, 2, 6, 225155) Gandhiji said: That is a question to which I have given great thought and I am convinced that if Christian missions will sincerely play the game, no matter what may be their policy under normal circumstances, they must withdraw from the indecent competition to convert the Harijans.
('70', 114, 2, 7, 225438) Whatever the Archbishop of Canterbury and others may say, what is done here in India in the name of Christianity is wholly different from what they say.There are others in the field also, but as a devotee of truth I say that if there is any difference between their methods, it is one of degree and not of kind.
('70', 114, 2, 8, 225750) I know of representatives of different religions standing on the same platform and vying with one another to catch the Harijan ear.
('70', 114, 2, 9, 225882) To dignify this movement with the name of spiritual hunger is a travesty of truth.
('70', 114, 2, 10, 225965) Arguing on the highest plane I said to Dr. Mott, if they wanted to convert Harijans had they not better begin to convert me?
('70', 114, 2, 11, 226090) I am a trifle more intelligent than they, and therefore more receptive to the influences of reason that could be brought to bear upon me.
('70', 114, 2, 12, 226228) But to approach the Pulayas and Pariahs with their palsied hands and paralysed intelligence is no Christianity.
('70', 114, 2, 13, 226340) No, whilst our reform movement is going on, all religious minded people should say: Rather than obstruct their work let us support them in their work.
('70', 114, 3, 14, 226491) M. Do not the roots of the reform movement go back to the missionary movement?
('70', 114, 3, 15, 226570) Did not the missionaries wake up the reformers and make a certain amount of stir among the untouchables?
('70', 114, 4, 16, 226675) G. I do not think that the missionary movement was responsible for a stirring of the right kind.
('70', 114, 4, 17, 226772) I agree that it stung the reformers to the quick and awakened them to their sense of duty.
('70', 114, 4, 18, 226863) They say: ‘Here is some good work being done by these missionaries; they open schools and hospitals, train nurses.
('70', 114, 4, 19, 226978) Why don’t we do these things for our own people?’ And they try to do something in indifferent imitation.
('70', 114, 5, 20, 227083) M. You have spoken of some good work being done by missionaries.
('70', 114, 5, 21, 227148) Should not we go on with it?
('70', 114, 6, 22, 227177) G. Oh yes.
('70', 114, 6, 23, 227188) Do, by all means.
('70', 114, 6, 24, 227206) But give up what makes you objects of suspicion and demoralizes us also.
('70', 114, 6, 25, 227279) We go to your hospitals
('70', 115, 0, 1, 227303) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 116
('70', 115, 1, 2, 227345) with the mercenary motive of having an operation performed, but with no object of responding to what is at the back of your mind, even as our children do when they go to Bible classes in their colleges and then laugh at what they read there.
('70', 115, 1, 3, 227587) I tell you our conversation at home about these missionary colleges is not at all edifying.
('70', 115, 1, 4, 227679) Why then spoil your good work with other motives?
('70', 115, 2, 5, 227729) Mr. Mathews was curious to know if Gandhiji followed any spiritual practices and what special reading he had found helpful.
('70', 115, 3, 6, 227853) G. I am a stranger to yogic practices.
('70', 115, 3, 7, 227892) The practice I follow is a practice I learnt in my childhood from my nurse.
('70', 115, 3, 8, 227968) I was afraid of ghosts.
('70', 115, 3, 9, 227992) She used to say to me: ‘There are no ghosts, but if you are afraid, repeat Ramanama.’ What I learnt in my childhood has become a huge thing in my mental firmament.
('70', 115, 3, 10, 228156) It is a sun that has brightened my darkest hour.
('70', 115, 3, 11, 228205) A Christian may find the same solace from the repetition of the name of Jesus and a Muslim from the name of Allah.
('70', 115, 3, 12, 228320) All these things have the same implications and they produce identical results under identical circumstances.
('70', 115, 3, 13, 228430) Only the repetition must not be a lip expression, but part of your very being.
('70', 115, 3, 14, 228509) About helpful readings we have regular readings of the Bhagavad Gita and we have now reached a stage when we finish the Gita every week by having readings of appointed chapters every morning.
('70', 115, 3, 15, 228701) Then we have hymns from the various saints of India, and we therein include hymns from the Christian hymn book.
('70', 115, 3, 16, 228813) As Khan Saheb is with us, we have readings from the Koran also.
('70', 115, 3, 17, 228877) We believe in the equality of all religions.
('70', 115, 3, 18, 228922) I derive the greatest consolation from my reading of Tulsidas’s Ramayana.
('70', 115, 3, 19, 228996) I have also derived solace from the New Testament and the Koran.
('70', 115, 3, 20, 229061) I don’t approach them with a critical mind.
('70', 115, 3, 21, 229105) They are to me as important as the Bhagavad Gita, though everything in the former may not appeal to me—everything in the Epistles of Paul for instance, nor everything in Tulsidas.
('70', 115, 3, 22, 229285) The Gita is a pure religious discourse given without any embellishment.
('70', 115, 3, 23, 229357) It simply describes the progress of the pilgrim soul towards the Supreme Goal.
('70', 115, 3, 24, 229436) Therefore there is no question of selection.
('70', 115, 4, 25, 229481) M. You are really a Protestant.
('70', 115, 5, 26, 229513) G. I do not know what I am or not; Mr. Hodge will call me a Presbyterian!
('70', 115, 6, 27, 229587) M. Where do you find the seat of authority?
('70', 115, 6, 28, 229631) Pointing to his breast, Gandhiji said:
('70', 116, 0, 1, 229670) VOL. 70: 21 OCT0BER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 117
('70', 116, 1, 2, 229718) It lies here.
('70', 116, 1, 3, 229732) I exercise my judgment about every scripture, including the Gita.
('70', 116, 1, 4, 229798) I cannot let a scriptural text supersede my reason.
('70', 116, 1, 5, 229850) Whilst I believe that the principal books are inspired, they suffer from a process of double distillation.
('70', 116, 1, 6, 229957) Firstly, they come through a human prophet, and then through the commentaries of interpreters.
('70', 116, 1, 7, 230052) Nothing in them comes from God directly.
('70', 116, 1, 8, 230093) Mathew may give one version of one text and John may give another.
('70', 116, 1, 9, 230160) I cannot surrender my reason whilst I subscribe to Diving revelation.
('70', 116, 1, 10, 230230) And above all, ‘the letter killeth, the spirit giveth life.’ But you must not misunderstand my position.
('70', 116, 1, 11, 230335) I believe in Faith also, in things where Reason has no place e.g., the existence of God.
('70', 116, 1, 12, 230424) No argument can move me from that faith, and like that little girl who repeated against all reason ‘yet we are seven’ I would like to repeat, on being baffled in argument by a very superior intellect, ‘Yet there is God.’
('70', 116, 2, 13, 230645) Harijan, 5 12 1936
('70', 116, 3, 14, 230664) 130. LETTER TO L. A. HOGG
('70', 116, 4, 15, 230690) WARDHA, November 25, 1936
('70', 116, 5, 16, 230716) DEAR MR. HOGG,
('70', 116, 6, 17, 230731) Thank you for your letter of the 21st instant.
('70', 116, 6, 18, 230778) I am sorry we have not made much headway with papermaking.
('70', 116, 6, 19, 230837) An expert whose services we had secured left us three or four months ago and we are unfortunately now where we were.
('70', 116, 6, 20, 230954) Our students are manufacturing paper of a sort, but it is not up to much.
('70', 116, 6, 21, 231028) I could send you samples of various varieties of hand made paper that we use, but I could not tell you how they are made and the materials from which they are made.
('70', 116, 6, 22, 231193) We here use waste paper clippings from the local press.
('70', 116, 6, 23, 231249) We have now here with us a chemist who can make paper out of gunnybag waste, cotton seed waste, white rags and such other raw materials available in villages.
('70', 116, 6, 24, 231408) But he is still a novice and I am afraid I have nothing to communicate to you which you can profitably pass on to your friend in Egypt.

('70', 122, 7, 12, 239725) 142. A SPUR TO FURTHER PURIFICATION
('70', 122, 8, 13, 239761) If the Travancore proclamation of the religious freedom of Harijans is a matter for great rejoicing, it is also an event calling us to greater humiliation, greater effort and greater purification.
('70', 122, 8, 14, 239958) It is not the end of untouchability.
('70', 122, 8, 15, 239995) It is certainly, as C. Rajagopalachari says, ‘an indication of the potentiality that exists in us, if only we seek His aid’.
('70', 122, 8, 16, 240120) It inspires us with hope and faith in our mission.
('70', 122, 8, 17, 240171) But on no account will it warrant relaxation of effort and vigilance over ourselves.
('70', 122, 8, 18, 240256) If the proclamation is a result of prayer and purification, if the mute prayer of the selfless workers of Travancore aided by kindred spirits all over India, rather than the advertised meetings and their resolutions, inspired H.H. the Maharaja and his advisers to issue the proclamation (it does not matter whether consciously or unconsciously to them), it follows that greater selflessness and devotion of workers must do the rest.
('70', 122, 8, 19, 240689) Let us realize the contents of the rest.
('70', 122, 8, 20, 240730) We do not yet know how the orthodoxy of Travancore and the Harijans will react to the proclamation.
('70', 122, 8, 21, 240830) If it is not followed up by suitable response on the part of the public, it can easily become a dead letter.
('70', 122, 8, 22, 240939) The mere opening of temples will mean nothing, if it does not lead to their purification and that of the priesthood.
('70', 122, 9, 23, 241056) 1 Vide “Letter to Narahari D. Parikh”,6 11 1936
('70', 123, 0, 1, 241104) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 124
('70', 123, 1, 2, 241146) The opening of temples in Travancore must lead to their opening in the sister State Cochin and must also lead to the opening of the sister temple of Guruvayyur.
('70', 123, 1, 3, 241307) These are of a piece, guided by the same tradition and ceremonial.
('70', 123, 1, 4, 241374) Then come the great temples of Tamil, Telugu and Canarese India.
('70', 123, 1, 5, 241439) Kashi Vishwanath, Dwarika and Puri temples in the North, West and East still remain closed to the Harijans.
('70', 123, 1, 6, 241547) Of the big black patches of India Travancore, though a big patch in itself, considered relatively, was a small speck.
('70', 123, 1, 7, 241665) It has, by the grace of God showing itself through the proclamation of H. H. the Maharaja, become suddenly a bright spot radiating its light throughout India.
('70', 123, 1, 8, 241824) Will the radiation prove strong enough to affect the big patches I have mentioned?
('70', 123, 1, 9, 241907) And the religious freedom, if it is real in the sense that it comes from the heart of orthodoxy, must be followed by the economic and social betterment of the Harijans all over India.
('70', 123, 1, 10, 242091) A mere mention of these most important things should be sufficient to chasten us.
('70', 123, 1, 11, 242173) But it cannot frighten us if we have a living faith in God and our cause.
('70', 123, 1, 12, 242247) For this great and glorious task we want more workers—men and women, boys and girls.
('70', 123, 1, 13, 242332) We want more money, paper, gold, silver, copper, even handfuls of grain, but these too will surely, as also only, come if the workers whom we already have are, like Caesar’s wife, above suspicion.
('70', 123, 1, 14, 242529) Are we all pure in heart?
('70', 123, 1, 15, 242555) Are we faithful to our trust?
('70', 123, 1, 16, 242585) Have we faith in the purely spiritual nature of our mission?
('70', 123, 1, 17, 242646) If the answers can be in the affirmative, all is well.
('70', 123, 1, 18, 242701) But the cases I have somewhat discussed 1 in these columns and which I am still following up, make me cautious.
('70', 123, 1, 19, 242813) How will it fare if we have other black sheep among us?
('70', 123, 1, 20, 242869) We are none without sin.
('70', 123, 1, 21, 242894) But if we are not men enough publicly and without any attempt to underestimate it, to own up to our guilt, again I ask, how will it fare with us and the cause we have dared to represent?
('70', 123, 1, 22, 243081) My rejoicing over the proclamation is thus tempered by the necessary sadness induced by a vivid knowledge of what is happening in our midst.
('70', 123, 1, 23, 243222) No cause for gloom, equally no warrant for over exultation but the greatest cause for vigilant introspection and a vivid sense of our responsibility rendered greater by the proclamation.
('70', 123, 2, 24, 243409) Harijan, 28 11 1936
('70', 123, 3, 25, 243429) 1 “One Thing Needful”, 7 11 1936
('70', 124, 0, 1, 243462) VOL. 70: 21 OCT0BER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 125
('70', 124, 1, 2, 243510) 143. WOMAN IN THE SMRITIS
('70', 124, 2, 3, 243536) A correspondent sends me an issue of Indian Swarajya published at Bezwada.
('70', 124, 2, 4, 243611) It contains an article on the place of woman in the Smritis.
('70', 124, 2, 5, 243672) From it I copy the following few extracts without any alteration:
('70', 124, 3, 6, 243738) The wife should ever treat the husband as God, though he be characterless, sensual and devoid of good qualities.
('70', 124, 3, 7, 243851) (Manu 5. 154)
('70', 124, 4, 8, 243865) Women should follow the word of their husbands.
('70', 124, 4, 9, 243913) This is their highest duty.
('70', 124, 4, 10, 243941) (Yajnavalkya 1. 18)
('70', 124, 5, 11, 243961) A woman has no separate sacrifice, ritual or fasting.
('70', 124, 5, 12, 244015) She gains a high place in heaven by serving the husband.
('70', 124, 5, 13, 244072) (Manu 5. 145)
('70', 124, 6, 14, 244086) She who fasts and performs rituals, while the husband lives, cuts off the life of the husband.
('70', 124, 6, 15, 244181) She goes to hell.
('70', 124, 6, 16, 244199) A woman who is after the sacred waters should wash the feet or the whole body of the husband and drink the water; and she attains the highest place (Atri 136 137)
('70', 124, 7, 17, 244362) There is no higher world for the woman than that of the husband.
('70', 124, 7, 18, 244427) She who displeases the husband cannot go to his world after death.
('70', 124, 7, 19, 244494) So she should never displease the husband.
('70', 124, 7, 20, 244537) (Vasistha 21 14)
('70', 124, 8, 21, 244554) That woman who prides in her father’s family and disobeys the husband should be made by the king a prey to the dogs in the presence of a big assembly of people.
('70', 124, 8, 22, 244715) (Manu 8. 371)
('70', 124, 9, 23, 244729) None should eat the food offered by a woman who disobeys the husband.
('70', 124, 9, 24, 244799) Such a woman is to be known as a sensualist.
('70', 124, 9, 25, 244844) (Angiras 69)
('70', 124, 10, 26, 244857) If the wife disobeys the husband when he is given to bad habits or becomes a drunkard or is suffering from physical ailment, then, for three months she should be deprived of her valuable clothes and jewels and kept away.
('70', 124, 10, 27, 245078) (Manu 10. 78) It is sad to think that the Smritis contain texts which can command no respect from men who cherish the liberty of woman as their own and who regard her as the mother of the race; sadder still to think that a newspaper published on behalf of orthodoxy should publish such texts as if they were part of religion.
('70', 124, 10, 28, 245404) Of course there are in the Smritis texts which give woman her due place and regard her with deep veneration.
('70', 124, 10, 29, 245513) The question arises as to what to do with the Smritis that contain texts that are in conflict with other texts in the same Smritis and that are repugnant to the moral sense.
('70', 124, 10, 30, 245687) I have already suggested often enough in these columns that all that is printed in the
('70', 125, 0, 1, 245774) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 126
('70', 125, 1, 2, 245816) name of scriptures need not be taken as the word of God or the inspired word.
('70', 125, 1, 3, 245894) But everyone can’t decide what is good and authentic and what is bad and interpolated.
('70', 125, 1, 4, 245981) There should therefore be some authoritative body that would revise all that passes under the name of scriptures, expurgate all the texts that have no moral value or are contrary to the fundamentals of religion and morality, and present such an edition for the guidance of Hindus.
('70', 125, 1, 5, 246262) The certainty that the whole mass of Hindus and the persons accepted as religious leaders will not accept the validity of such authority need not interfere with the sacred enterprise.
('70', 125, 1, 6, 246446) Work done sincerely and in the spirit of service will have its effect on all in the long run and will most assuredly help those who are badly in need of such assistance.
('70', 125, 2, 7, 246616) Harijan, 28 11 1936
('70', 125, 3, 8, 246636) 144. THE IDEAL BHANGI 1
('70', 125, 4, 9, 246660) The ideal Bhangi of my conception would be a Brahmin par excellence, possibly even excel him.
('70', 125, 4, 10, 246754) It is possible to envisage the existence of a Bhangi without a Brahmin.
('70', 125, 4, 11, 246826) But without the former the latter could not be.
('70', 125, 4, 12, 246874) It is the Bhangi who enables society to live.
('70', 125, 4, 13, 246920) A Bhangi does for society what a mother does for her baby.
('70', 125, 4, 14, 246979) A mother washes her baby of the dirt and insures his health.
('70', 125, 4, 15, 247040) Even so the Bhangi protects and safeguards the health of the entire community by maintaining sanitation for it.
('70', 125, 4, 16, 247152) The Brahmin’s duty is to look after the sanitation of the soul, the Bhangi’s that of the body of society.
('70', 125, 4, 17, 247258) But there is a difference in practice; the Brahmin generally does not live up to his duty, the Bhangi does, willy nilly no doubt.
('70', 125, 4, 18, 247388) Society is sustained by several services.
('70', 125, 4, 19, 247430) The Bhangi constitutes the foundation of all services.
('70', 125, 4, 20, 247485) And yet our woebegone Indian society has branded the Bhangi as a social pariah, set him down at the bottom of the scale, held him fit only to receive kicks and abuse, a creature who must subsist on the leavings of the caste people and dwell on the dung heap.
('70', 125, 4, 21, 247744) He is without a friend, his very name has become a term of reproach.
('70', 125, 4, 22, 247813) This is shocking.
('70', 125, 4, 23, 247831) It is perhaps useless to seek the why and wherefore of it.
('70', 125, 4, 24, 247890) I certainly am unaware of the origin of the inhuman conduct, but I know this much that by looking down upon the Bhangi we—Hindus,
('70', 125, 5, 25, 248020) 1 Translated from Gujarati by Pyarelal.
('70', 125, 5, 26, 248060) The original appeared in Harijanbandhu, 29 11 1936.
('70', 126, 0, 1, 248112) VOL. 70: 21 OCT0BER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 127
('70', 126, 1, 2, 248160) Mussalmans, Christians and all—have deserved the contempt of the whole world.
('70', 126, 1, 3, 248238) Our villages have today become seats of dirt and insanitation and the villagers come to an early and untimely death.
('70', 126, 1, 4, 248355) If only we had given due recognition to the status of the Bhangi as equal to that of a Brahmin as in fact and justice he deserves, our villages today no less than their inhabitants would have looked a picture of cleanliness and order.
('70', 126, 1, 5, 248590) We would have to a large extent been free from the ravages of a host of diseases which directly spring from our uncleanliness and lack of sanitary habits.
('70', 126, 1, 6, 248745) I therefore make bold to state without any manner of hesitation or doubt that not till the invidious distinction between the Brahmin and the Bhangi is removed will our society enjoy health, prosperity and peace, and be happy.
('70', 126, 1, 7, 248971) What qualities should such an honoured servant of society exemplify in his person?
('70', 126, 1, 8, 249054) In my opinion an ideal Bhangi should have a thorough knowledge of the principles of sanitation.
('70', 126, 1, 9, 249150) He should know how a right kind of latrine is constructed and the correct way of cleaning it.
('70', 126, 1, 10, 249244) He should know how to overcome and destroy the odour of excreta and the various disinfectants to render them innocuous.
('70', 126, 1, 11, 249364) He should likewise know the process of converting night soil and urine into manure.
('70', 126, 1, 12, 249448) But that is not all.
('70', 126, 1, 13, 249469) My ideal Bhangi would know the quality of night soil and urine.
('70', 126, 1, 14, 249533) He would keep a close watch on these and give a timely warning to the individual concerned.
('70', 126, 1, 15, 249625) Thus he will give a timely notice of the results of his examination of the excreta.
('70', 126, 1, 16, 249709) That presupposes a scientific knowledge of the requirements of his profession.
('70', 126, 1, 17, 249788) He would likewise be an authority on the subject of disposal of night soil in small villages as well as big cities and his advice and guidance in the matter would be sought for and freely given to society.
('70', 126, 1, 18, 249994) It goes without saying that he would have the usual learning necessary for reaching the standard here laid down for his profession.
('70', 126, 1, 19, 250126) Such an ideal Bhangi, while deriving his livelihood from his occupation, would approach it only as a sacred duty.
('70', 126, 1, 20, 250240) In other words, he would not dream of amassing wealth out of it.
('70', 126, 1, 21, 250305) He would consider himself responsible for the proper removal and disposal of all the dirt and night soil within the area which he serves and regard the maintenance of healthy and sanitary condition within the same as the summum bonum of his existence.
('70', 127, 0, 1, 250557) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 128
('70', 127, 1, 2, 250599) How may we have this ideal Bhangi?
('70', 127, 1, 3, 250634) Only when we have produced an army of Appa Patwardhans 1. To clothe the Bhangi with the dignity and respect due to him is the especial task and privilege of the educated class.
('70', 127, 1, 4, 250811) Some members of the class would first themselves master the science of sanitation to educate the Bhangi round them in the same.
('70', 127, 1, 5, 250939) They would carefully study their present condition and the causes underlying it and set themselves to the task of eradicating the same by dint of inexhaustible perserverance and patience that never looks back and knows no defeat.
('70', 127, 1, 6, 251169) They would teach them the laws of cleanliness.
('70', 127, 1, 7, 251216) Our Bhangis do not today possess even good brooms or other suitable means for the removal of night soil.
('70', 127, 1, 8, 251321) The latrines themselves are wretched.
('70', 127, 1, 9, 251359) The site round the Bhangis’ quarters is no better than a cesspool of dirt.
('70', 127, 1, 10, 251434) All this can only go if some of the educated class give themselves up to the task of redeeming the Bhangi from his present plight and thus redeeming society from its terrible insanitation.
('70', 127, 1, 11, 251623) Surely this is work enough to satisfy the highest ambition of one who has the spirit of service in him.

('70', 129, 1, 2, 254227) 148. BIRTH CONTROL THROUGH SELF CONTROL
('70', 129, 2, 3, 254267) The following letter 1 has been lying with me for a long time: In the mean time, I visited Ahmedabad.
('70', 129, 2, 4, 254369) I did not have the occasion to express my views on the above subject.
('70', 129, 2, 5, 254439) But, as mentioned by the correspondent, I certainly believe that birth control can be made effective only through self control.
('70', 129, 2, 6, 254567) Any other means of birth control is likely to result in harm.
('70', 129, 2, 7, 254629) One can easily discern the evil effects of artificial birth control methods where they have taken root.
('70', 129, 2, 8, 254733) It is not surprising that those who advocate birth control without abstention cannot see these, as it has gained footing in the name of morality.
('70', 129, 2, 9, 254879) It is an exaggeration to say that the object of the committee formed in Ahmedabad is what the correspondent states it to be.
('70', 129, 2, 10, 255004) But whatever its aim may be, its activities will definitely result in an increase in sexual indulgence.
('70', 129, 2, 11, 255108) Water when thrown on the ground is bound to follow a downward course; similarly, if means are invented to facilitate sexual indulgence, it is bound to increase.
('70', 129, 2, 12, 255269) Similarly, it is an exaggeration to believe that doctors and vaidyas do not preach self restraint as it is likely to affect their incomes adversely.
('70', 129, 2, 13, 255418) Doctors and vaidyas have never considered it their field to advocate self restraint.
('70', 129, 2, 14, 255503) But I see clear signs of these men tending more and more to do so.
('70', 129, 2, 15, 255570) Their field is to diagnose diseases and cure them.
('70', 129, 2, 16, 255621) If they do not assign primary importance to indulgence and lack of self restraint as a cause of disease, a time will come when they will have to stop their practice.
('70', 129, 2, 17, 255787) As society becomes increasingly intelligent, it will not rest satisfied unless diseases are completely eradicated.
('70', 129, 2, 18, 255902) And, so long as society does not turn towards self restraint and does not observe the rules to prevent diseases, it is impossible for it to remain healthy.
('70', 129, 2, 19, 256058) This is so clear that ultimately everyone will be able to see it and honest doctors will give it the utmost importance.
('70', 129, 2, 20, 256178) I have no doubt that birth control without self control will contribute largely towards increase in sexual indulgence.
('70', 129, 2, 21, 256297) Hence, it is my humble opinion that the Ahmedabad League can obtain the desired results if it goes deeper into the problem and, taking into account the dangerous consequences of lack of self 
('70', 129, 3, 22, 256489) 1 Not translated here.
('70', 129, 3, 23, 256512) The correspondent had noted with disapproval the setting up of a Birth control League in Ahmedabad which in his view must lead to an increase of licentiousness.

('70', 130, 3, 4, 256871) 149. ONE ENEMY ALONE
('70', 130, 4, 5, 256892) A man has only one enemy and only one friend: and that is himself.
('70', 130, 4, 6, 256959) These are not my words but of all the Shastras.
('70', 130, 4, 7, 257007) A person becomes his own enemy when he deceives himself.
('70', 130, 4, 8, 257064) He becomes his own friend when he puts himself in the hands of the God who is within him.
('70', 130, 4, 9, 257154) The necessity for writing this has arisen from the two instances of fall which I have mentioned and other such instances, major as well as minor, which I come across.
('70', 130, 4, 10, 257321) As I go deeper into these, I find that the persons concerned are practising self deception.The results of my investigations have yet to be known.
('70', 130, 4, 11, 257467) All of us commit sins.
('70', 130, 4, 12, 257490) But we degrade ourselves more when we try to appear innocent though we are really guilty.
('70', 130, 4, 13, 257580) A man degrades himself with two women who regard him as a brother, a saint, a sincere worker, a teacher or guru, and then marries one of them.
('70', 130, 4, 14, 257723) I regard it as a device to hide one’s licentious conduct.
('70', 130, 4, 15, 257781) To call such a relationship marriage is to abuse the sacrament of marriage.
('70', 130, 4, 16, 257857) I know such things are happening at many places these days.
('70', 130, 4, 17, 257917) But any adding to sin or multiplying it will not make it accepted as virtue.
('70', 130, 4, 18, 257994) If the whole world practises sin it may well become a custom, nevertheless it will remain sin.
('70', 130, 4, 19, 258089) I am aware that this does not apply to all acts which are regarded as sins.
('70', 130, 4, 20, 258165) I have in mind things which have been regarded as sinful for generations and which are considered as such by society today.
('70', 130, 4, 21, 258289) Teachers develop secret relationships with their women students.
('70', 130, 4, 22, 258354) That in some cases these relationships are given the form of marriage does not make them virtuous.
('70', 130, 4, 23, 258453) It is my firm opinion that just as husband wife relationship is not possible between brothers and sisters, so should it not be possible in the case of teachers and pupils.
('70', 130, 4, 24, 258625) If this golden rule is not faithfully adhered to, educational institutions will eventually collapse; no girl will be safe from her men teachers.
('70', 130, 4, 25, 258770) A teacher’s position is such that students—both boys and girls—are constantly under his influence; they regard the teacher’s words as gospel truth.
('70', 130, 4, 26, 258918) So they do not entertain any doubts about any liberties taken by the teacher.
('70', 130, 4, 27, 258996) Hence such relationships are regarded, and
('70', 131, 0, 1, 259039) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 132
('70', 131, 1, 2, 259081) should be regarded, as uncondonable where the soul is respected as something apart from the body.
('70', 131, 1, 3, 259179) When such relationship creeps into an institution such as the Harijan Sevak Sangh, it has far reaching evil effects and ruins its activities.
('70', 131, 1, 4, 259321) I am thoroughly convinced that behind the unexpected event of the temples of Travancore being thrown open to Harijans lies the strength of the service of silent workers.
('70', 131, 1, 5, 259491) Such workers are scattered all over the country.
('70', 131, 1, 6, 259540) They do not want fame, they have no false sense of pride.
('70', 131, 1, 7, 259598) They find their fulfilment in service alone.
('70', 131, 1, 8, 259643) As a result of their punya God came to dwell in the heart of the Maharaja of Travancore and made him throw open the temples to Harijans.
('70', 131, 1, 9, 259780) This step is the first glimpse of the glory of God.
('70', 131, 1, 10, 259832) It is an invitation to the workers to become more alert, purer and more dedicated.
('70', 131, 1, 11, 259915) No workers, whether men or women, can rest in peace as long as all the temples are not thrown open to Harijans, hypocrisy, wickedness and filth are not banished from all the temples and untouchability is not eradicated from the very marrow of Hinduism.
('70', 131, 1, 12, 260168) And, they should realize that the delay caused in washing away the sin which has existed since time immemorial is due to the sins of the workers which have come to light recently.
('70', 131, 1, 13, 260348) Who knows, there may be other such workers concealing their sins.
('70', 131, 1, 14, 260414) The workers should not cling to their weaknesses by looking upon their sins as virtues, they should not fall and drag their work with them by hiding their sins, nor should they satisfy themselves with admitting their sins only partially.
('70', 131, 1, 15, 260652) Some persons are hesitant to acknowledge publicly their own sins, some others put a gloss over them while acknowledging them.
('70', 131, 1, 16, 260778) Religion proclaims: Magnify your sins into mountains even when they are as small as mustard seeds.
('70', 131, 1, 17, 260877) If you sincerely confess your guilt you will look as clean as a cloth after its dirt has been washed off.
('70', 131, 1, 18, 260983) And your public confession and repentence will be like a shield to guard you in future.
('70', 131, 2, 19, 261071) [From Gujarati]
('70', 131, 3, 20, 261087) Harijanbandhu, 29 11 1936

('70', 143, 7, 14, 283450) 165. DISCUSSION WITH STUDENTS OF VILLAGE WORKERS’ TRAINING SCHOOL 4
('70', 143, 8, 15, 283518) [Before December 5, 1936]
('70', 143, 9, 16, 283544) For some time past a party of students of Village Workers Training School has been visiting villages in the neighbourhood on appointed evenings reciting the Tulsi Ramayana and bhajans.
('70', 143, 9, 17, 283729) Now that the boys, examinations are drawing near, a proposal came to drop the visits for the time being.
('70', 143, 9, 18, 283834) Said Gandhiji to them: This has shocked me.
('70', 143, 9, 19, 283878) If your studies cannot stand this brief relaxation, and you must pore over your books all the twenty four hours because of the approach of the examination, those studies are worth nothing.
('70', 143, 9, 20, 284067) But apart from this, your proposal augurs ill for the villagers.
('70', 143, 9, 21, 284132) You have promised to go to them on appointed evenings,
('70', 143, 10, 22, 284187) 1 Gandhiji had nursed Mirabehn and Nanavati when they were ill in October.
('70', 143, 10, 23, 284262) 2 This was a joint statement issued by Gandhiji and Kasturbhai Lalbhai, an industrialist and mill owner of Ahmedabad.
('70', 143, 10, 24, 284380) 3 For Gandhiji’s Award, vide “Award in Labour Dispute”, 26 12 1936. 4 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”
('70', 144, 0, 1, 284497) VOL. 70: 21 OCT0BER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 145
('70', 144, 1, 2, 284545) and now you are going to break the promise.
('70', 144, 1, 3, 284589) I tell you the few visits you have paid to them will be as inauspicious as the appearance of the comet is supposed to be.
('70', 144, 1, 4, 284711) They may be worse.
('70', 144, 1, 5, 284730) The comet appears suddenly almost without notice, Nature’s known laws do not seem to govern it.
('70', 144, 1, 6, 284826) But you gave them a promise and now if you go back on it, they will feel that it is not for them that you go there but just to please your own fancies.
('70', 144, 1, 7, 284978) That feeling will breed indifference and ultimatley disgust.
('70', 144, 1, 8, 285039) I tell you these visits are more impotrant than the visits to distribute medicines to the villages.
('70', 144, 1, 9, 285139) The medicines are good for their physical ailments, Ramayana is good for their spiritual ailments.
('70', 144, 1, 10, 285238) If you had not made the beginning I should not have asked you to do so.
('70', 144, 1, 11, 285310) They never invited you or expected you to go there, but now that the beginning has been made you should keep it up.
('70', 144, 1, 12, 285426) These visits give you a living touch with the people; rather than drop them you must think out how you can make them more and more useful and successful.
('70', 144, 2, 13, 285580) He next spoke to them in answer to a question about the profession of the Bhangi.
('70', 144, 2, 14, 285662) He asked them to study the article 1 on the Ideal Bhangi that he had written for the current issue of Harijan and to fill in the details if they were wanting.
('70', 144, 2, 15, 285821) He regaled them with stories of the Bhangi who was serving the village, and who was now being asked to go for negligent work, and of the new Bhangi who asked for Rs. 30 a month and ultimately became ready to accept Rs. 15. [He said:] Now it is your work to mend these people’s ways, and you cannot do so unless you are good Bhangis yourselves.
('70', 144, 2, 16, 286165) As I have explained in my article, I do not want the Bhangi to be the indifferent and perfunctory scavenger that he is today.
('70', 144, 2, 17, 286291) I want him to be a healer of ailments, and a physicians besides being an ideal scavenger.
('70', 144, 2, 18, 286381) In ancient times the village barber used to be also the village surgeon.
('70', 144, 2, 19, 286454) I want the good Bhangi to be the village health inspector and physician.
('70', 144, 2, 20, 286527) You have to pave the way for this.
('70', 144, 2, 21, 286562) Today we have reduced him to the lowest level and we have gone down with him.
('70', 144, 2, 22, 286640) He is content to live in squalor and dirt, we are doing no better.
('70', 144, 2, 23, 286707) You cannot reform him unless you reform yourselves, unless you set about the task with a passion that you momentarily import into your studies.
('70', 144, 2, 24, 286851) The task of rural sanitation is no easy one, it means nothing less than raising the village Bhangi to the status of an ideal Bhangi.
('70', 144, 2, 25, 286984) The whole subject is unexplored; the profession, far from being a dirty one, is a purifying, life protecting one.
('70', 144, 2, 26, 287098) Only we have debased it.
('70', 144, 2, 27, 287123) We have to raise it to its true status.
('70', 144, 2, 28, 287163) I have indicated the lines in my article and I will not repeat here what I have said there.
('70', 144, 3, 29, 287255) Harijan, 5 12 1936
('70', 144, 4, 30, 287274) 1 Vide “ The Ideal Bhangi”, 28 11 1936
('70', 145, 0, 1, 287313) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 146
('70', 145, 1, 2, 287355) 166. TEMPLE ENTRY RULES
('70', 145, 2, 3, 287379) The reader will find in this issue the full text of the rules 1 framed under the famous Travancore Proclamation opening the State temples to Harijans.
('70', 145, 2, 4, 287530) It is not possible to criticize the rules in anticipation of their application.
('70', 145, 2, 5, 287610) As with all rules, naturally they lend themselves to an interpretation and application as liberal as the Proclamation itself, and to so narrow an interpretation and application as to make the Proclamation wholly ineffective and thus make things worse than before.
('70', 145, 2, 6, 287874) There is no warrant whatsoever for fearing any calamitous result.
('70', 145, 2, 7, 287940) The Proclamation, as I believe it, is in response to the Time Spirit by a Prince imbued with the spirit of reform.
('70', 145, 2, 8, 288055) It has behind it the sanction of popular approval, if what appears in the Press and what I have learnt from persons who should know can be relied upon.
('70', 145, 2, 9, 288207) But as I have already said in these columns the brunt of making the working of the reform successful will fall on the shoulders of the reformers of Travancore.
('70', 145, 2, 10, 288367) It should be possible to create an atmosphere whereby the rules may never need enforcement by authority.
('70', 145, 2, 11, 288472) Temples are generally visited by sincere devotees or hypocrites.
('70', 145, 2, 12, 288537) The former are meticulous in their observance of rules prescribed by custom for fear of losing all merit of temple worship, and the latter have to observe the rules equally meticulously for fear of their being found out.
('70', 145, 2, 13, 288758) Framing of rules such as we have now to deal with is a novelty of the modern age though absolutely necessary.
('70', 145, 2, 14, 288868) When the temple doors are opened by a secular proclamation to thousands of people, it becomes necessary also to frame secular rules for its due enforcement.
('70', 145, 2, 15, 289025) There is no doubt the whole of this great experiment of Travancore requires careful, sympathetic and prayerful handling by all concerned.
('70', 145, 2, 16, 289163) If the spirit behind is purely religious all will be well.
('70', 145, 2, 17, 289222) Who can lead in that direction better than the reformers and the Harijans whom they will bring to those temples?
('70', 145, 3, 18, 289335) Harijan, 5 12 1936
('70', 145, 4, 19, 289354) 1 Vide Appendix.
('70', 146, 0, 1, 289371) VOL. 70: 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 147
('70', 146, 1, 2, 289419) 167. SEGAON, NOT SHEGAON
('70', 146, 2, 3, 289444) Several correspondents address their letters to me to Shegaon.
('70', 146, 2, 4, 289507) Now Shegaon is a main line station between Bhusaval and Wardha.
('70', 146, 2, 5, 289571) I am not living in Shegaon.
('70', 146, 2, 6, 289599) I am living in Segaon near Wardha.
('70', 146, 2, 7, 289634) It is not a railway station.
('70', 146, 2, 8, 289663) It has no post office, and no telegraph office.
('70', 146, 2, 9, 289711) All letterrs and telegrams should therefore be addressed to Wardha.
('70', 146, 2, 10, 289779) Harijan, 5 12 1936
