('70', 147, 7, 10, 291809) 170. ABOUT PIERCING THE NOSE AND THE EARS
('70', 147, 8, 11, 291851) From far off Kenya, Shri Badiyani, who is a teacher in the Government Indian School there, writes to say: 1
('70', 147, 9, 12, 291959) The tendency of this correspondent of using adjectives such as “the great child educationist” with reference to Shri Gijubhai and of running down an uneducated person like myself, is not worth emulating at all.
('70', 147, 9, 13, 292170) Gijubhai wishes to grow old teaching young boys and girls, so why should he not hand over poor girls to the control of men like himself by piercing or allowing them to pierce their ears and noses?
('70', 147, 9, 14, 292367) If Gijubhai claims to be a great child educationist and does not allow anyone else to share this title, his opinions will have to be carefully weighed.
('70', 147, 9, 15, 292519) In that case it is necessary to know under what circumstances and in which year he had the noses and ears of his own daughters pierced and in which year and in what context he wrote the above letter.
('70', 147, 9, 16, 292719) Let us, for the sake of argument, accept that Gijubhai is a great child educationist.
('70', 147, 9, 17, 292805) Nevertheless, why should we take it for granted that his views can never be wrong?
('70', 147, 9, 18, 292888) Why should we regard utterances of Mahatmas on every occasion as gospel truth?
('70', 147, 9, 19, 292967) How did my advice, which was being acted upon so far, become wrong after the correspondent had seen and read a letter appearing
('70', 147, 10, 20, 293095) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('70', 147, 10, 21, 293132) The correspondent had stated that having read Gijubhai’s views on the subject of piercing the nose and the ears he could no longer agree with Gandhiji’s views on the matter.
('70', 148, 0, 1, 293306) VOL. 70: 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 149
('70', 148, 1, 2, 293354) under Gijubhai’s name?
('70', 148, 1, 3, 293377) Had Shri Badiyani found anything wrong with the young girls whos noses and ears had not been pierced?
('70', 148, 1, 4, 293479) My advice is that is no matter, whether small or big, should anyone’s opinion be given the importance of a gospel truth.
('70', 148, 1, 5, 293600) Every statement—whether coming from a ‘Mahatma’ like myself or a great child educationist like Gijubhai—should be weighed in the scales of intelligence and one which is more reasonable should be accepted.
('70', 148, 1, 6, 293805) If, later, one comes across even a greater ‘Mahatma’ or a greater Shastri, one should not immediately prostrate oneself before him but remain faithful to the person whom one’s intelligence has accepted.
('70', 148, 1, 7, 294008) This is the meaning of an unwavering intelligence.
('70', 148, 1, 8, 294059) If we do not learn to do so, we shall be left with no faith and our poor intelligence will be rendered ineffective from confusion.
('70', 148, 1, 9, 294190) Let us now consider the basic issue.
('70', 148, 1, 10, 294227) Are only girls fond of jewellery?
('70', 148, 1, 11, 294261) Is this not true of boys?
('70', 148, 1, 12, 294287) What can love of jewellery have to do with the piercing of the nose and the ears?
('70', 148, 1, 13, 294369) In the West, there are innumerable girls whose noses and ears are not pierced, but we do not hear of their lamenting the fact when they grow up.
('70', 148, 1, 14, 294514) If the nose and the ears are to be pierced, how many holes are to be made and why only a specified number of holes?
('70', 148, 1, 15, 294630) What kind of ornaments can be regarded as adornment and when should these be regarded as ugly?
('70', 148, 1, 16, 294725) If the practice of piercing noses and ears is good, then why should we not leave it to the girls to get that done when they are grown up?
('70', 148, 1, 17, 294863) Why increase artificial differences between boys and girls?
('70', 148, 1, 18, 294923) Are there many parents amongst us who get the ears of both their boys and girls pierced?
('70', 148, 1, 19, 295012) Why then show this favour to or inflict this tyranny on girls alone?
('70', 148, 1, 20, 295081) Let me now give my opinion briefly.
('70', 148, 1, 21, 295117) In both my ears, taken together, there were six holes.
('70', 148, 1, 22, 295172) These are still there and I do not like them.
('70', 148, 1, 23, 295218) But how am I to close these up?
('70', 148, 1, 24, 295250) My wife’s nose and ears were pierced.
('70', 148, 1, 25, 295288) She must have resented taking off her ornaments.
('70', 148, 1, 26, 295337) Neither of us feels that either one of us looks less comely for having taken them off.
('70', 148, 1, 27, 295424) If we do not appear comely in the eyes of others, should we have pity for them even in such matters?
('70', 148, 1, 28, 295525) The piercing of the nose and the ears and adorning these with ornaments results in dirt collecting at these places and this sometimes even leads to pus formation.
('70', 148, 1, 29, 295688) The fact that time is wasted in keeping
('70', 149, 0, 1, 295728) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 150
('70', 149, 1, 2, 295770) these clean to avoid such harmful consequences, is also not an unimportant consideration.
('70', 149, 1, 3, 295860) Doctors alone can measure the effect of the pain caused to little children by the piercing of their noses and ears.
('70', 149, 1, 4, 295976) Women, as it is, are slaves.
('70', 149, 1, 5, 296005) In the act of piercing their noses and ears, I have never seen anything but a symbol of their slavery.
('70', 149, 1, 6, 296108) By tying a string to her ear rings, woman can be pulled like a bullock.
('70', 149, 1, 7, 296180) Instances exist of cruel husbands having cut off both the ears and the noses of their wives along with the ornaments in them.
('70', 149, 1, 8, 296306) I invite those who advocate the piercing of the nose and the ears to look at the frightful ornaments on the noses and ears of Indian women and the dirt in them and then advise me as to what I should do.
('70', 149, 1, 9, 296509) Should I have them remove their ornaments or should I advise them to wear ear pendants of pearls in holes large enough for my finger to go through?
('70', 149, 2, 10, 296657) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 6 12 1936

('70', 151, 4, 15, 300183) 174. DISCUSSION WITH STUDENTS OF VILLAGE WORKERS TRAINING SCHOOL 1
('70', 151, 5, 16, 300250) [December 6, 1936] 2
('70', 151, 6, 17, 300271) I have no doubt that this penance 3 willingly undertaken and cheerfully gone through had something to do in bringing about the settlement.
('70', 151, 6, 18, 300410) I do not mean to imply that it had any direct influence upon the Union Government.
('70', 151, 6, 19, 300493) It is my firm belief that all real penances produce unseen but sure effects.
('70', 151, 6, 20, 300570) The penance was undertaken for self purification, for sharing, however humbly, in the suffering of the strikers.
('70', 151, 6, 21, 300683) That was the only way in which I could prayerfully appeal to God.
('70', 151, 7, 22, 300749) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter” 2 According to the source, students of Village Workers’ Training School met Gandhiji on “Sunday last”, which would be December 6. 3 Gandhiji had been asked about the fasts he had undertaken on various occasions, and he had referred to his first fast in connection with a public movement which he had undertaken in 1913, when he had imposed on himself a triple vow of self suffering till the £ 3 tax was abolished: (i) to adopt the labourers’ dress; (ii) to walk barefoot; (iii) to have only one meal during the day—a meal which during those days consisted of fruits untouched by fire.
('70', 151, 7, 23, 301383) This penance went on for some months till the tax was removed.
('70', 152, 0, 1, 301446) VOL. 70: 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 153
('70', 152, 1, 2, 301494) The man who performs such penances throws himself wholly and solely on God.
('70', 152, 1, 3, 301570) He does not undertake such a penance lightly, never in anger, and not certainly with a view to winning any advantage for himself.
('70', 152, 1, 4, 301700) Then it must not be against an opponent with whom there is no bond of affection.
('70', 152, 1, 5, 301781) Then it presupposes personal purity and a living belief in non violence and truth.
('70', 152, 1, 6, 301864) Obviously there can be no room for pride in such penances.
('70', 152, 1, 7, 301923) Harijan, 12 12 1936

('70', 153, 7, 12, 303599) 178. LETTER TO ANAND T. HINGORANI
('70', 153, 8, 13, 303633) SEGAON, WARDHA, December 8, 1936
('70', 153, 9, 14, 303666) MY DEAR ANAND, I am not angry.
('70', 153, 9, 15, 303697) I am filled with pain and dismay.
('70', 153, 9, 16, 303731) Your letter does not mend matters.
('70', 153, 9, 17, 303766) If you felt for Vidya, your duty was clear even if she was the temptress.

('70', 154, 3, 4, 304910) 179. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 1
('70', 154, 4, 5, 304938) SEGAON, [December 8, 1936] 2
('70', 154, 5, 6, 304967) Some time ago a group of friends 3who had come from the World Committee of the Y.M.C.A. were on a visit to Segaon .
('70', 154, 5, 7, 305083) these friends, questions were refreshingly fresh .
('70', 154, 5, 8, 305134) .Gandhiji had sat down in the village to better the social and economic condition of the villagers, especially Harijans.
('70', 154, 5, 9, 305255) How exactly was this being done?
('70', 154, 6, 10, 305288) ANSWER: By living in their midst, by having them to work with us and by working for them.
('70', 154, 7, 11, 305378) QUESTION: That is very good.
('70', 154, 7, 12, 305407) But does that create in them any ambition to live higher?
('70', 154, 8, 13, 305465) A. It does.
('70', 154, 9, 14, 305477) Q. Do they have any big hopes for the future?
('70', 154, 10, 15, 305523) A. I do not know but I think it is better that it comes naturally and gradually.
('70', 154, 10, 16, 305604) You may be sure that they feel and know that better times are ahead of them.
('70', 154, 11, 17, 305681) Q. Our problem is quite different; we have a number of difficult problems like secularism, nationalism and immigration.
('70', 154, 11, 18, 305801) Could you give some advice to our young folk?
('70', 154, 12, 19, 305847) A. It would be sheer presumption on my part to offer advice to those whom I do not know except through hearsay, and I am so constituted that I cannot send advice to people whom I do not know through people I do not know.
('70', 154, 13, 20, 306068) Q. We have here delegates from various countries.
('70', 154, 13, 21, 306118) Some of them will go out in separate groups to the people of India and would like to speak to them about conditions in their countries.
('70', 154, 13, 22, 306254) I wonder what Indians would be particularly interested in hearing about?
('70', 154, 14, 23, 306327) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter” 2 The date is from the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.
('70', 154, 14, 24, 306436) 3 Mr. and Mrs. Davies Reid and a Japanese named Mr. Saito
('70', 155, 0, 1, 306494) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 156
('70', 155, 1, 2, 306536) A. I suppose I may say, subject to correction, that they would be more interested in politics than in questions economic or spiritual.
('70', 155, 1, 3, 306671) It may be sad, but that I think is the state of things.
('70', 155, 2, 4, 306727) Q. In connection with the political situation, I dare say they have heard of communism and fascism, about which we are at loggerheads.
('70', 155, 2, 5, 306862) Would they like to hear about Spain?
('70', 155, 3, 6, 306899) A Indeed.
('70', 155, 3, 7, 306909) Our President would not let us remain without hearing about Spain 1
('70', 155, 4, 8, 306977) Q. I see.
('70', 155, 4, 9, 306987) Now I would put the question from the point of view of our own learning things from India.
('70', 155, 4, 10, 307078) We will be going back to America, Europe, Far East.
('70', 155, 4, 11, 307130) What shall we look for here?
('70', 155, 4, 12, 307159) How can we take back with us something of the imperishable asset of the Indian civilization?
('70', 155, 4, 13, 307252) Can we hope to get at the heart of things?
('70', 155, 5, 14, 307295) A. It is a very difficult question, and yet perhaps not so difficult to answer.
('70', 155, 5, 15, 307375) I would ask you to ignore big cities if you would see the heart of India.
('70', 155, 5, 16, 307449) The big cities here are but poor editions of your big cities.
('70', 155, 5, 17, 307511) Therefore you have to go to the villages, and those too not close to cities or to the railway line, but unspoilt by them.
('70', 155, 5, 18, 307633) Go thirty miles from the railway line where people are untouched by post and telegraphs, and you will see that the people show a kind of culture which you miss in the West.
('70', 155, 5, 19, 307806) You will have to see people with the help of the interpreters.
('70', 155, 5, 20, 307869) You will find there relics of art which has not yet perished, you will find culture which is unmistakable but far different from that of the West.
('70', 155, 5, 21, 308016) Then you will take away something that may be worth taking.
('70', 155, 5, 22, 308076) But of course it depends on the angle from which you would see things.
('70', 155, 6, 23, 308147) Q. But how would you describe the elements of culture we should find in the villages?
('70', 155, 7, 24, 308233) A. Will you explain what you mean?
('70', 155, 8, 25, 308268) Q. A gentleman said we should find in Indian villages qualities of age old culture which we should not find in the West.
('70', 155, 8, 26, 308389) Is it in the philosophy of life, or art, or what?
('70', 155, 9, 27, 308439) A. You would therefore want me to describe to you the predominant aspect of our culture.
('70', 155, 9, 28, 308528) Is that what you want?
('70', 155, 10, 29, 308551) Q. Yes.
('70', 155, 11, 30, 308559) A. I would say it is spiritual.
('70', 155, 12, 31, 308591) 1 Civil War had broken out in Spain and Jawaharlal Nehru had been voicing concern for the Spanish Republic.
('70', 156, 0, 1, 308699) VOL. 70: 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 157
('70', 156, 1, 2, 308747) Q. That leads us to another question.
('70', 156, 1, 3, 308785) One of the questions we are going to discuss is the ‘Impending Challenge of the Will of God to the Youth’.
('70', 156, 1, 4, 308892) Even in the same religion people have different ways of finding the will of God.
('70', 156, 1, 5, 308973) Could you tell us whether the people here are conscious that they are working out the will of God?
('70', 156, 2, 6, 309072) A. They are not, and I am thankful that they are not, because it is natural with them.
('70', 156, 2, 7, 309159) They are not conscious that they are breathing or using their eyesight and yet they are doing it every moment.
('70', 156, 2, 8, 309270) A healthy man will not be thinking or talking of his health.
('70', 156, 2, 9, 309331) In the same way the spirituality here is unconscious of itself.
('70', 156, 2, 10, 309395) It is an inherited culture.
('70', 156, 2, 11, 309423) Thus in a good home they do not know what spirituous liquor is.
('70', 156, 2, 12, 309487) They do not know what it is to be a teetotaller, for they have been that all their lives.
('70', 156, 2, 13, 309577) The words do not occur in their dictionary.
('70', 156, 3, 14, 309621) Q. Japan and India have many things in common.
('70', 156, 4, 15, 309668) A. Well, East is East, but not now.
('70', 156, 4, 16, 309704) Jap an is Americanized.
('70', 156, 4, 17, 309728) In fact Japan is beating America and England hollow in exploiting India.
('70', 156, 4, 18, 309801) You know the quantity of fents that are dumped here by Japan?
('70', 156, 5, 19, 309863) Q. (Taken rather aback) We provide cheap goods, Sir.
('70', 156, 5, 20, 309916) Are they harmful?
('70', 156, 6, 21, 309934) A. I will not say that they are harmful because they are cheap.
('70', 156, 6, 22, 309998) But they leave us poorer.
('70', 156, 7, 23, 310024) Q. It is not good to provide cheap goods?
('70', 156, 8, 24, 310066) You have no business to deprive us of our hands and feet.
('70', 156, 9, 25, 310124) Q. So, then, you are against this machine age.
('70', 156, 10, 26, 310171) A. To say that is to caricature my views.
('70', 156, 10, 27, 310213) I am not against machinery as such, but I am totally opposed to it when it masters us.
('70', 156, 10, 28, 310300) Japan and America and England are doing it today.
('70', 156, 10, 29, 310350) The agreement between India and Japan is a misnomer.
('70', 156, 10, 30, 310403) It is an agreement between England and Japan.
('70', 156, 10, 31, 310449) Japan must wash its hands of this competition.
('70', 156, 10, 32, 310496) It is harmful to us and harmful to you.
('70', 156, 10, 33, 310536) No one can make bond slaves of others without degrading himself.
('70', 156, 10, 34, 310601) Only a few years ago we manufactured our own cloth, and now we get it from Japan and England.
('70', 156, 10, 35, 310695) It is an unnatural position.
('70', 156, 10, 36, 310724) We could make enough cloth for ourselves and the whole world.
('70', 156, 10, 37, 310786) Our country abounds in natural resources.
('70', 156, 10, 38, 310828) There is something most hideously wrong in sending one’s own cotton out and getting manufactured goods.
('70', 156, 10, 39, 310932) Nine crore rupees
('70', 156, 11, 40, 310950) 1 This was said by Mr. Saito.
('70', 157, 0, 1, 310980) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 158
('70', 157, 1, 2, 311022) worth of cattle hides are exported from here only to return to us as manufactured products.
('70', 157, 1, 3, 311114) There is no reason why this should happen.
('70', 157, 2, 4, 311157) Q. You would not industrialize India?
('70', 157, 3, 5, 311195) A. I would indeed, in my sense of the term.
('70', 157, 3, 6, 311239) The village communities should be revived.
('70', 157, 3, 7, 311282) Indian villages produced and supplied to the Indian towns and cities all their wants.
('70', 157, 3, 8, 311368) India became impoverished when our cities became foreign markets and began to drain the villages dry by dumping cheap and shoddy goods from foreign lands.
('70', 157, 4, 9, 311523) Q. You would then go back to the natural economy?
('70', 157, 5, 10, 311573) A. Yes.
('70', 157, 5, 11, 311581) Otherwise I should go back to the city.
('70', 157, 5, 12, 311621) I am quite capable of running a big enterprise, but I deliberately sacrificed the ambition, not as a sacrifice, but because my heart rebelled against it.
('70', 157, 5, 13, 311775) For I should have no share in the spoliation of the nation which is going on from day to day.
('70', 157, 5, 14, 311869) But I am industrializing the village in a different way.
('70', 157, 5, 15, 311926) I shall show you a village product which I am sure compares favourably with American toffee.
('70', 157, 5, 16, 312019) Tell me if you do not prefer this gur (palm juice gur) to American toffee.
('70', 157, 6, 17, 312094) Here a little supply of palm juice gur is distributed to the guests who enjoy it.
('70', 157, 6, 18, 312176) The American lady thoroughly enjoys it .
('70', 157, 6, 19, 312217) her artistic eye catches sight of the palm trees drawn in relief on the wall above the niche in front of her.
('70', 157, 6, 20, 312327) She appreciates it much.
('70', 157, 6, 21, 312352) But there Japan has got plenty to give us.
('70', 157, 6, 22, 312395) In your arts and handicrafts you are matchless.
('70', 157, 7, 23, 312443) Q. But I like the mud floor and the mud walls here.
('70', 157, 8, 24, 312495) A. Oh yes, it keeps us warm in winter and cool in summer.
('70', 157, 9, 25, 312553) Q. That’s what the Germans say about their beer.
('70', 157, 10, 26, 312602) A. So mother earth is our beer.
('70', 157, 10, 27, 312634) Is not that splendid?
('70', 157, 11, 28, 312656) But the American friend was not going to while away the time joking.
('70', 157, 11, 29, 312725) He asked earnestly if Gandhiji would not give a message to youths.
('70', 157, 12, 30, 312792) A. Simply this that 50 years of unbroken practice of non violence to the best of my ability has deepened my faith in it, instead of diminishing it.
('70', 157, 12, 31, 312940) And if my faith is any worth to them, let them not get weak hearted, but be heartened by my faith.
('70', 157, 12, 32, 313039) If that faith went away I should bury myself alive.
('70', 157, 13, 33, 313091) Q. You like the Sermon on the Mount?
('70', 157, 14, 34, 313128) A. Oh yes.
('70', 157, 14, 35, 313139) Even my declaration that I like it is exploited by Christian friends.
('70', 157, 14, 36, 313209) But let that be.

('70', 158, 1, 3, 313396) A. I do not know.
('70', 158, 1, 4, 313414) But I shall give you a passage that I have often quoted to those who came to convert me to Christianity: ‘Seek ye first the Kingdom of God and His righteousness, and everything will be added unto you.’ I saw this emphasized in one of Tolstoy’s beautiful stories.
('70', 158, 1, 5, 313677) It gripped me, and also what he wrote underneath it.

('70', 158, 3, 9, 314053) I wonder if we can reorient our curricula of education for woman, so as to keep her the preserver of the best in us and to enable her to become a good co worker of man.
('70', 158, 3, 10, 314222) Could you give us a thought for our girls?
('70', 158, 3, 11, 314265) A. I believe in the proper education of women.
('70', 158, 3, 12, 314312) But I do believe that woman will not make her contribution to the world by mimicking or running a race with men.
('70', 158, 3, 13, 314425) She can run the race, but she will not rise to the great heights she is capable of by mimicking man.
('70', 158, 3, 14, 314526) She has to be the complement of man.

('70', 163, 5, 8, 322527) The following telegram 2 was received at Poona from the Harijan Sevak Sangh, Trivandrum, on the 3rd instant:
('70', 163, 6, 9, 322636) Actual working Proclamation most successful.
('70', 163, 6, 10, 322681) Has disproved all fears entertained certain quarters.
('70', 163, 6, 11, 322735) No part of temple open to any devotee is barred against Ezhavas and Harijans now.
('70', 163, 6, 12, 322817) Excepting innermost chamber which has been always used only by offciating priest, all other places including mandaps, enclosed platforms, corridors are as freely used by newly admitted devotees as by caste Hindus.
('70', 163, 6, 13, 323031) What is of the greatest importance is that waters in sacred tanks attached to temples are also freely used now by Ezhavas and Harijans.
('70', 163, 6, 14, 323167) Sense of horror at approach of Harijans seems completely overcome.
('70', 163, 6, 15, 323234) Harijan devotees do not seem to excite any special reaction in devotees of other castes who engage in worship at the same time.
('70', 163, 6, 16, 323362) Hardly necessary to say that no special hour or any other distinction made against new entrants.
('70', 163, 6, 17, 323459) A hopeful feature is priests and other temple officials genuinely wholeheartedly co operating.
('70', 163, 6, 18, 323554) They do not seem to suffer any mental strain .
('70', 163, 7, 19, 323601) Orthodox people including Namboodiris have as groups or individuals displayed no hostility, most of them expressing themselves in terms of full approval of Proclamation.
('70', 163, 7, 20, 323771) We see no signs whatever of resentment.
('70', 163, 7, 21, 323811) Their behaviour is such as if nothing extraordinary had happened, which from what we know of previous orthodoxy is an astonishing achievement.
('70', 163, 7, 22, 323954) The noble Proclamation has been followed up by thorough execution.

('70', 168, 11, 27, 333382) Some persons calling themselves friends and well wishers of Shri
('70', 168, 12, 28, 333447) 1 Not translated here.

('70', 169, 0, 1, 333640) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 170
('70', 169, 1, 2, 333682) Ramnarayan have gently chided me.
('70', 169, 1, 3, 333716) This was out of place as I had not given the name or address.
('70', 169, 1, 4, 333778) What I had written was not written without thought or cause.
('70', 169, 1, 5, 333839) However, what Shri Ramnarayan, unable to bear the burden of his guilt, has confessed is far more serious than I had realized.
('70', 169, 1, 6, 333965) I do not repent the habit I have formed since many years of not hiding my own faults or of those dear to me.
('70', 169, 1, 7, 334074) This has only been to the good of the persons concerned and others.
('70', 169, 1, 8, 334142) I have not concealed the failings of my late father, nor those of my wife, nor those of my sons.
('70', 169, 1, 9, 334239) My own failings every reader knows by heart.
('70', 169, 1, 10, 334284) Lest I forget, people, some in good faith, some others to condemn me, keep on reminding me of them.
('70', 169, 1, 11, 334384) By making my failings public I have learnt to avoid them.
('70', 169, 1, 12, 334442) However hard anyone may try secretly to be pure, he will never succeed.
('70', 169, 1, 13, 334514) Why should God’s creation not see the faults which God sees?
('70', 169, 1, 14, 334575) Anyone who is really ashamed of his failings will be safe only by making them public and having his own co workers to protect him.
('70', 169, 1, 15, 334706) This is what is meant by depending on God.
('70', 169, 1, 16, 334749) I must confess that many a time if I have saved myself from a heinous deed it was because of my friends and children.

('70', 169, 1, 19, 335028) This reflection saved me.
('70', 169, 1, 20, 335054) This is what is called God’s protection.

('70', 169, 1, 23, 335236) It is for this very reason that making public our faults is the first step towards purification.

('70', 178, 5, 14, 350021) 207. FRAGMENT OF A LETTER 1
('70', 178, 6, 15, 350049) December 15, 1936 When our speech and actions strive faithfully to follow our thoughts, our speech cannot fully describe those thoughts nor is the meaning of our actions fully conveyed by our words.
('70', 178, 6, 16, 350248) When I describe in words a table of my conception the description falls short of the conception and, when it is made, the product falls short of the description.
('70', 178, 6, 17, 350410) Euclid’s straight line exists only in conception.
('70', 178, 6, 18, 350460) Its definition is only a part of the conception and its figure again a part of the definition.
('70', 178, 6, 19, 350555) If this cannot explain what I want to say, you can delete the bracketed portion without fear of break in the continuity of thought.
('70', 178, 8, 20, 350687) From a photostat of the Gujarati: S.N. 11559

('70', 180, 0, 1, 351859) VOL. 70: 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 181
('70', 180, 1, 2, 351907) 211. INTERVIEW TO MISS FITCH1
('70', 180, 2, 3, 351937) [December 16, 1936] 2
('70', 180, 3, 4, 351959) The chief value of Hinduism lies in holding the actual belief that all life (not only human beings, but all sentient beings) is one, i.e., all life coming from the One universal source, call it Allah, God or Parameshwara.
('70', 180, 3, 5, 352181) There is in Hinduism a scripture called Vishnus ahasranama which simply means ‘one thousand names of God’.
('70', 180, 3, 6, 352288) These one thousand names do not mean that God is limited to those names, but that He has as many names as you can possibly give Him.
('70', 180, 3, 7, 352421) You may give Him as many names as you like provided it is one God without a second, whose name you are invoking.
('70', 180, 3, 8, 352534) That also means that He is nameless too.
('70', 180, 3, 9, 352575) This unity of all life is a peculiarity of Hinduism which confines salvation not to human beings alone but says that it is possible for all God’s creatures.
('70', 180, 3, 10, 352732) It may be that it is not possible, save through the human form, but that does not make man the Lord of creation.
('70', 180, 3, 11, 352845) It makes him the servant of God’s creation.
('70', 180, 3, 12, 352889) Now when we talk of brotherhood of man, we stop there, and feel that all other life is there for man to exploit for his own purposes.
('70', 180, 3, 13, 353023) But Hinduism excludes all exploitation.
('70', 180, 3, 14, 353063) There is no limit whatsoever to the measure of sacrifice that one may make in order to realize this oneness with all life, but certainly the immensity of the ideal sets a limit to your wants.
('70', 180, 3, 15, 353255) That, you will see, is the antithesis of the position of the modern civilization which says: ‘Increase your wants’.
('70', 180, 3, 16, 353371) Those who hold that belief think that increase of wants means an increase of knowledge whereby you understand the Infinite better.
('70', 180, 3, 17, 353502) On the contrary Hinduism rules out indulgence and multiplication of wants as these hamper one’s growth to the ultimate identity with the Universal Self.
('70', 180, 4, 18, 353655) Harijan, 26 12 1936

('70', 185, 4, 8, 361081) 219. A PAINFUL DUTY
('70', 185, 5, 9, 361101) I publish the following without any alteration: 1
('70', 185, 6, 10, 361151) An open letter to Mahatma Gandhi:
('70', 185, 7, 11, 361185) DEAR MAHATMAJI,
('70', 185, 8, 12, 361201) I was shocked to read your note 2 about myself in the Harijan of 21 11 1936 which contains untrue statements about me.
('70', 185, 8, 13, 361320) I am not “carrying on Harijan work near Cuttack” nor did I “come down to Bombay to make the usual collections” nor “as a rule, I consult you before going out for collections”.
('70', 185, 9, 14, 361496) I make the following statements in repudiation and correction of your statement which appeared in Harijan of 21 11 1936. Though I was at one time at Sabarmati Ashram, never received any help from you nor any mandate to carry on Harijan work or any other work near Cuttack or anywhere else.
('70', 185, 9, 15, 361786) I have not been carrying on Harijan work near Cuttack.
('70', 185, 9, 16, 361841) I never consulted you before going out for colleciton for Sevashram started by me and named by me in your honour.
('70', 185, 9, 17, 361955) It has no connection with or dependence on any Congress institution nor with you.
('70', 185, 9, 18, 362037) On my return from Sabarmati in the year 1921, I had an idea of serving the country on the line which you were preaching.
('70', 185, 9, 19, 362158) When some complaints reached you 18 months ago, you wrote to me and I gave you a suitable reply, solemnly negativing the allegations.
('70', 185, 9, 20, 362292) There the duty which I owe to you has ended as far as I and my Ashram are concerned.
('70', 185, 9, 21, 362377) You are free to make any investigation you like .
('70', 185, 9, 22, 362427) I remain, Dated Cuttack, Yours truly, the 6th Dec.
('70', 185, 9, 23, 362478) 1936 GOVIND CHANDRA MISRA
('70', 185, 10, 24, 362504) I would have suppressed the letter if the author had not invited publicity.
('70', 185, 10, 25, 362580) To publish it is a painful task, to comment on it a painful duty.
('70', 185, 11, 26, 362646) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.

('70', 186, 0, 1, 362722) VOL. 70: 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 187
('70', 186, 1, 2, 362770) Govind Babu first came to me sent by Deenabandhu Andrews when he was in the greatest need.
('70', 186, 1, 3, 362861) He was not wanted in Orissa.
('70', 186, 1, 4, 362890) My weakness for Orissa compelled me to keep him in Sabarmati.
('70', 186, 1, 5, 362952) His incoherent conversation did not prepossess me in his favour.
('70', 186, 1, 6, 363017) And but for his being from Orissa and his description of his sufferings I would not have harboured him in spite of Deenabandhu’s recommendation.
('70', 186, 1, 7, 363162) Like everyone else he straight way became like my sons.
('70', 186, 1, 8, 363218) Indeed his manners were so unattractive that the other inmates did not take to him kindly.
('70', 186, 1, 9, 363309) So he was my extra care.
('70', 186, 1, 10, 363334) He went to Orissa after consultation with me.
('70', 186, 1, 11, 363380) He opened the Ashram in consultation with me.
('70', 186, 1, 12, 363426) He used to send his reports regularly to me.
('70', 186, 1, 13, 363471) He did do Harijan work and khadi work under my supervision.
('70', 186, 1, 14, 363531) He collected monies in Bombay principally from those who know me and him as an inmate of Sabarmati.
('70', 186, 1, 15, 363631) I went out of my way to visit his Ashram.
('70', 186, 1, 16, 363673) On going there I was deeply pained to see the bungalow he had built there and publicly condemned it.
('70', 186, 1, 17, 363774) He pleaded guilty.
('70', 186, 1, 18, 363793) The only work worth naming that I saw being done was a well stocked dispensary which was kept in a slovenly condition.
('70', 186, 1, 19, 363912) I rebuked him severely for belying my hopes, for absence of proper accounts and any constructive work.
('70', 186, 1, 20, 364015) The dispensary was certainly not a need.
('70', 186, 1, 21, 364056) I told him it was the easiest thing for anybody to establish if he got some funds.
('70', 186, 1, 22, 364139) He had promised to mend but he did not.
('70', 186, 1, 23, 364179) Then Baba Raghavdas was sent to inquire into the working and his report was adverse.
('70', 186, 1, 24, 364264) Then came grave allegations about his morals.
('70', 186, 1, 25, 364310) These are still under investigation.
('70', 186, 1, 26, 364347) I knew nothing about his being a candidate for the Assembly.
('70', 186, 1, 27, 364408) He never consulted me about it.
('70', 186, 1, 28, 364440) He knew that I would disapprove of the step for him.
('70', 186, 1, 29, 364493) It was only after the paragraph about him had appeared that he felt compelled to disclose the secret to me.
('70', 186, 1, 30, 364601) His first letter was suppression of truth, the second an admission.
('70', 186, 1, 31, 364669) After the paragraph was published he offered to come to Segaon to clear himself.
('70', 186, 1, 32, 364750) I had a number of declarations from his erstwhile friends making most damaging statements.
('70', 186, 1, 33, 364841) I therefore accepted his offer.
('70', 186, 1, 34, 364873) But he backed out of it saying he no longer subscribed to my philosophy.
('70', 186, 1, 35, 364946) In the light of this honest outline of my connection with Govind Babu, I can only say that his letter is a gross perversion of truth.
('70', 186, 1, 36, 365080) It has been no pleasure to me to have to write a word against one in whose making I had a great deal to do and who was at one time ready to do as I would like him to.
('70', 186, 1, 37, 365247) The only relieving feature in this episode is that Govind Babu is so hysterical that he often does not know what he is speaking or that
('70', 187, 0, 1, 365383) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 188
('70', 187, 1, 2, 365425) he is speaking an untruth.

('70', 187, 3, 7, 365838) 220. A CONTRAST
('70', 187, 4, 8, 365854) Thakkar Bapa sends me the following four cases from Gwalior:
('70', 187, 5, 9, 365915) (1) In the diary for October last, Sjt.
('70', 187, 5, 10, 365955) K. V. Datey, the chief Harijan worker of Gwalior State, reports that there was a great commotion amongst the audience in a public meeting held in the Town Hall at Ujjain where Jain Guru Anantsagar was speaking to an audience of about five to six hundred people, because some Harijans entered the hall to hear the religious sermon.
('70', 187, 5, 11, 366286) The orthodex section amongst the audience wanted the Harijans to go out, but the speaker and the reformists were firm, with the result that the orthodox section went away displeased.
('70', 187, 5, 12, 366469) (2) At the end of October the Suba or the Collector of Ujjain issued an order that Harijan sevaks, even of ‘high caste’, were thereafter prohibited from worshipping in the chief temple of Ujjain, because of their close contact with Harijans.
('70', 187, 5, 13, 366711) Neccessary representation has been made to the State in connection with this order.
('70', 187, 5, 14, 366795) (3) A Chamar girl in a village named Mahudia had the audacity to put a golden ring on one of her ears.
('70', 187, 5, 15, 366898) This was resented by some orthodox people who had it removed.
('70', 187, 5, 16, 366960) This came to the notice of one of the workers who went to the village and had them reconciled and the girl was allowed to put the ring on her ear.
('70', 187, 5, 17, 367107) (4) The mother of Shri Moolchand Agrawal, a khadi worker, died on 27th October at Neemuch.
('70', 187, 5, 18, 367198) Dhaniram Sagar, a Harijan and a worker, joined the funeral procession and carried the bier for a short distance out of respect for the deceased.
('70', 187, 5, 19, 367343) The orthodox amongst the funeral party resented this very much, but Sjt.
('70', 187, 5, 20, 367416) Moolchand remained firm and so the matter did not go further.
('70', 187, 5, 21, 367478) What a contrast with what is going on in Travancore!
('70', 187, 5, 22, 367531) The present Maharaja of Gwalior has only just mounted the gadi.
('70', 187, 5, 23, 367595) He made a generous statement about the Harijans.
('70', 187, 5, 24, 367644) If he follows it up by action such as Travancore’s, his Subas won’t issue the rediculous orders such
('70', 188, 0, 1, 367745) VOL. 70: 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 189
('70', 188, 1, 2, 367793) as the Suba of Ujjain is reportecd to have done, nor will caste Hindus molest Harijans as they have done according to Thakkar Bapa’s report.
('70', 188, 1, 3, 367934) The bulk of the caste Hindus are torn between two conflictiong opinions.
('70', 188, 1, 4, 368007) In the Indian States, the thing appears to be simple.
('70', 188, 1, 5, 368061) If the other Hindu princes like Travancore will issue authoritative proclamations, they will have the validity of Smritis and all opposition will be silenced.
('70', 188, 2, 6, 368220) Harijan, 19 12 1936
('70', 188, 3, 7, 368240) 221. WHAT IS A MIRACLE?
('70', 188, 4, 8, 368264) About the 9th of October last there was a meeting of Christian denominations in London.
('70', 188, 4, 9, 368352) His Grace the Archbishop of Canterbury presided.
('70', 188, 4, 10, 368401) The following occurs in the report of the meeting published in the Church Times of 16th October:
('70', 188, 5, 11, 368498) The next speaker was dressed as a layman, without even the smallest discernible purple patch to indicate that he was Dr. J. W. Pickett, a Bishop of the Methodist Episcopal Church, U.S.A. For some years past, Dr. Pickett has been studying the mass movements on the spot in India, and has published the results of his observations in Christian Mass Movements in India, described by the Archbishop of Canterbury as a remarkable and valuable book.
('70', 188, 5, 12, 368942) Dr. Pickett is profoundly impressed with the spiritual significance of the movement.
('70', 188, 5, 13, 369027) He said that four and a half millions of the depressed classes in India have become the disciples of our Lord, and the witness they bear to Him in their lives is making the multitudes in India marvel.
('70', 188, 5, 14, 369228) Even Brahmins have testified—albeit reluctantly—to the power of Christianity to transform the characters and lives of people whom they once thought incapable of religious feelings, and to whom they denied the right of entrance to the temples of Hinduism.
('70', 188, 5, 15, 369483) It is people of this kind, said Dr. Pickett, who have now standards of church attendance and worship difficult to equal in Western Christendom.
('70', 188, 5, 16, 369627) He quoted an example in the Telugu area, where 900,000 people now profess the Christian faith.
('70', 188, 5, 17, 369722) Out of 1,026 villages, 1,002 hold a service for the worship of God every evening of the year, and more than two hundred also a daily morning service.
('70', 188, 5, 18, 369872) It appeared to satisfy Dr. Pickett entirely as a test of the reality of the faith of the converts to hear a surprisingly high proportion of them speak of a sense of mystical union with God and their belief that God had come into their lives.
('70', 188, 5, 19, 370114) Even their Hindu neighbours admitted that the religion of Jesus Christ had lifted them to a new standard of cleanliness of person and home, and made them a trustworthy people.
('70', 188, 5, 20, 370290) More impressive still is the fact that high cast people are now coming into the church, literally by dozens and
('70', 189, 0, 1, 370402) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 190
('70', 189, 1, 2, 370444) hundreds, in areas where this transformation of life has occurred among the untouchables.
('70', 189, 1, 3, 370534) “It is a miracle,” he declared, “one of the great miracles of Christian history.” I have rarely seen so much exaggeration in so little space.
('70', 189, 1, 4, 370676) A reader ignorant of conditions in India would conclude that the figures relate to the conversions due to the movement led by Dr. Ambedkar.
('70', 189, 1, 5, 370816) I am sure Dr. Pickett could not have made any such claim.
('70', 189, 1, 6, 370874) He has in mind the figures to date commencing from the establishment of the first church in India hundreds of years ago.
('70', 189, 1, 7, 370995) But the figures are irrelevant to the general claim said to have been advanced by the Bishop.
('70', 189, 1, 8, 371089) Where are “the multitudes in India who marvel” at the transformation in the lives of “four and a half millions of the depressed classes”?
('70', 189, 1, 9, 371227) I am one of the mul titudes having practically travelled more than half a dozen times all over India, and have not seen any transformation on the scale described by Dr. Pickett, and certainly none of recent date.
('70', 189, 1, 10, 371440) I have had the privilege of addressing meetings of Indian Christians who have appeared to me to be no better than their fellows.
('70', 189, 1, 11, 371569) Indeed the taint of untouchability persists in spite of the nominal change of faith so far as the social status is con cerned.
('70', 189, 1, 12, 371696) Needless to say I am referring to the masses, not individuals.
('70', 189, 1, 13, 371759) I should like to know the Brahmins “who have testified—albeit reluctantly—to the power of Christianity to transform the characters and lives of people whom they once thought incapable of religious feeling.” But if it is of any consequence, I can show many Brahmins who can testify to the power of the reform movement to make a radical change in the lives and outlook of Harijans who were neglected by caste Hindus.
('70', 189, 1, 14, 372174) I must pass by the other unbelievable generalizations.
('70', 189, 1, 15, 372229) But I should like to know the hundreds of high caste Hindus who “are now coming into the church in areas where this transformation of life has occurred among the untouchables.” If all the astounding statements Dr. Pickett has propounded can be substantiated, truly it is “one of the great miracles of Christian history”, nay, of the history of man.
('70', 189, 1, 16, 372578) But do miracles need an oratorical demonstration?
('70', 189, 1, 17, 372628) Should we in India miss such a grand miracle?
('70', 189, 1, 18, 372674) Should we remain untouched by it?
('70', 189, 1, 19, 372708) Miracles are their own demonstration.
('70', 189, 1, 20, 372746) As witness the miracle in Travancore.
('70', 189, 1, 21, 372784) Nobody believed a month ago that the more than 2,000 temples of Travancore could be opened to Harijans and that Harijans would enter them in their hundreds without let or hindrance from the most orthodox Hindus.
('70', 189, 1, 22, 372996) Yet that event has happened in Travancore
('70', 190, 0, 1, 373038) VOL. 70: 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 191
('70', 190, 1, 2, 373086) which even he who runs may see.
('70', 190, 1, 3, 373118) It is beside the point whether it can be called a miracle or not.
('70', 190, 1, 4, 373184) I see in it the visible finger of the Invisible God.
('70', 190, 2, 5, 373237) I believe in the Bible as I believe in the Gita.
('70', 190, 2, 6, 373286) I regard all the
('70', 190, 3, 7, 373303) great faiths of the world as equally true with my own.
('70', 190, 3, 8, 373358) It hurts me to see any one of them caricatured as they are today by their own followers and as has been done by the learned Bishop, assuming of course that the report reproduced above is substantially correct.
('70', 190, 4, 9, 373568) Harijan, 19 12 1936
('70', 190, 5, 10, 373588) 222. WHAT IS NON VIOLENCE?
('70', 190, 6, 11, 373615) A friend
('70', 190, 7, 12, 373624) 1 writes.
('70', 190, 8, 13, 373634) You enjoin on all your disciples to be non violent not only in acts but
('70', 190, 9, 14, 373706) also in words and thoughts.
('70', 190, 9, 15, 373734) In the Harijan of Nov.
('70', 190, 9, 16, 373757) 262, you are reported to have said to Mr. Andrews on his wanting to know from you your reaction to the present attitude of the missionaries, “Their behaviour has been as bad as that of the rest who are in the field to add to their numbers.
('70', 190, 9, 17, 373997) What pains one is their frantic attempt to exploit the weakness of Harijans.
('70', 190, 9, 18, 374074) If they said, ‘Hinduism is a diabolical religion and you come to us,’ I should understand.
('70', 190, 9, 19, 374165) But they dangle earthly paradises in front of them and make promises to them which they can never keep.”3
('70', 190, 10, 20, 374271) If you are reported correctly, I ask—is this not violence in words against
('70', 190, 11, 21, 374346) the missionaries as a class?
('70', 190, 12, 22, 374375) I have no disciples, being myself an aspirant after discipleship
('70', 190, 13, 23, 374440) and in search of a guru.
('70', 190, 13, 24, 374465) But that is irrelevant to the issue raised by my friend.
('70', 190, 13, 25, 374522) To say or write a distasteful word is surely not violence, especially when the speaker or writer believes it to be true as I did when I spoke to Deenabandhu as reported in the quotation.
('70', 190, 13, 26, 374709) But even if it were found that what I said was an exaggeration, or worse still, an untruth, it would not be violent in the sense used by my correspondent.
('70', 190, 13, 27, 374864) The essence of violence is that there must be a violent intention behind a thought, word, or act, i.e., an intention to do harm to the opponent so called.
('70', 190, 13, 28, 375019) Here there was and could be no such
('70', 190, 14, 29, 375055) 1 A. S. Wadia; vide “What Is Non violence?”, 6 2 1937. 2 This should be 28. 3 Vide “Discussion with C. F. Andrews”, 28 11 1936
('70', 191, 0, 1, 375182) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 192
('70', 191, 1, 2, 375224) intention.
('70', 191, 1, 3, 375235) I was engaged in a friendly conversation with two good Christians, both missionaries in their own way.
('70', 191, 1, 4, 375338) I have used much stronger language about sanatanist behaviour towards Harijans and quite latterly about the acts of dear co workers.
('70', 191, 1, 5, 375471) But there has been no violent intention behind the use of my language.
('70', 191, 1, 6, 375542) And generally I have been acquitted by my critics of any violent intention.
('70', 191, 1, 7, 375618) Indeed the acid test of non violence is that one thinks, speaks and acts non violently, even when there is the gravest provocation to be violent.
('70', 191, 1, 8, 375764) There is no merit in being non violent to the good and the gentle.
('70', 191, 1, 9, 375831) Non violence is the mightiest force in the world capable of resisting the greatest imaginable temptation.
('70', 191, 1, 10, 375937) Jesus knew ‘the generation of vipers’, minced no words in describing them, but pleaded for mercy for them before the Judgment Throne, ‘for they knew not what they were doing.’ I gave the company chapter and verse in support of the statements I made.
('70', 191, 1, 11, 376187) I regard myself as a friend of the missionaries.
('70', 191, 1, 12, 376236) I enjoy happy relations with many of them.
('70', 191, 1, 13, 376279) But my friendships have never been blind to the limitations of my friends or the systems or methods they have supported.
('70', 191, 1, 14, 376400) False notions of propriety or fear of wounding susceptibilities often deter people from saying what they mean and ultimately land them on the shores of hypocrisy.
('70', 191, 1, 15, 376563) But if non violence of thought is to be evolved in individuals or societies or nations, truth has to be told, however harsh or unpopular it may appear to be for the moment.
('70', 191, 1, 16, 376736) And mere non violent action without the thought behind it is of little value.
('70', 191, 1, 17, 376814) It can never be infectious.
('70', 191, 1, 18, 376842) It is almost like a whited sepulchre.
('70', 191, 1, 19, 376880) Thought is the power and the life behind it.
('70', 191, 1, 20, 376925) We hardly know that thought is infinitely greater than action or words.
('70', 191, 1, 21, 376997) When there is correspondence between thought, word and deed, either is a limitation of the first.
('70', 191, 1, 22, 377095) And the third is a limitation of the sceond.
('70', 191, 1, 23, 377140) Needless to say that here I am referring to the living thought which awaits translation into speech and action.
('70', 191, 1, 24, 377252) Thoughts without potency are airy nothings and end in smoke.
('70', 191, 2, 25, 377313) Harijan, 19 12 1936
('70', 192, 0, 1, 377333) VOL. 70: 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 193
('70', 192, 1, 2, 377381) 223. HOW TO STOP OBSCENE ADVERTISEMENTS 1
('70', 192, 2, 3, 377423) A correspondent who saw my article 2 on obscene advertisements writes:
('70', 192, 3, 4, 377494) You can do much in preventing obscene advertisements by exposing the names of the papers and magazines which advertise such shameless things as you have mentioned.
('70', 192, 3, 5, 377658) I can’t undertake the censorship my correspondent advises, but I can suggest a better way.
('70', 192, 3, 6, 377749) If public conscience is alive, subscribers can write to their respective papers, if they contain objectionable advertisements, drawing their attention to them and stopping their subscriptions if the offence is not cured.
('70', 192, 3, 7, 377970) The reader will be glad to know that the sister who complained to me about the obscene advertisement wrote also to the editor of the offending magazine who expressed his regret for the inadvertent admission of the obnoxious advertisement and promised to remove it forthwith.
('70', 192, 3, 8, 378245) I am glad also to be able to say that my caution has found support from some other papers.
('70', 192, 3, 9, 378336) Thus the editor of Nispruha of Nagpur writes:
('70', 192, 4, 10, 378382) I have not only read with great care your article in the Harijan regarding obscene advertisements but have given a detailed translation of it in the Nispruha.
('70', 192, 4, 11, 378541) I have also added a short editorial comment thereon.
('70', 192, 5, 12, 378594) I am enclosing a typical advertisement which though not obscene is yet immoral in a sense.
('70', 192, 5, 13, 378685) The advertisement is obviously bogus and it is generally the villager who falls a prey to it.
('70', 192, 5, 14, 378779) I have always refused such advertisements and I am also writing to this party similarly.
('70', 192, 5, 15, 378868) If an editor must supervise the reading matter that he will allow, it is as much his duty to supervise the advertisements, and no editor can permit his paper to be used by people desirous of duping the simple villagers.
('70', 192, 6, 16, 379088) Harijan, 2 1 1937
('70', 192, 7, 17, 379106) 1 The Hindi version of this was published in Harijan Sevak, 19 12 1936. 2 Vide “Obscene Advertisements”, 14 11 1936

('70', 194, 3, 7, 381308) 226. WHAT SHOULD THOSE FAILING IN DUTY DO?
('70', 194, 4, 8, 381351) Some friends have posed the question arising out of the sad incident which I have had to relate: 2 “You bring to light such cases, and suggest to the persons concerned to give up their posts.
('70', 194, 4, 9, 381543) You have been unable to find fault with their work from the material point of view.
('70', 194, 4, 10, 381627) You have even praised their work.
('70', 194, 4, 11, 381661) Have they now lost their ability as well?
('70', 194, 4, 12, 381703) Should the public be deprived of their services?
('70', 194, 4, 13, 381752) Who is to fill the vacancies caused by their going?” This question is worth considering.
('70', 194, 4, 14, 381841) For myself I answered it years ago and on innumerable occasions I have acted accordingly.
('70', 194, 4, 15, 381931) I have not used the adjective ‘innumerable’ thoughtlessly.
('70', 194, 4, 16, 381990) I have acted on my belief so many times that I have lost count of them.
('70', 194, 4, 17, 382062) I believe and I have repeatedly found in experience that however able a person may be, his secret immorality cannot but leave a stamp upon his work.
('70', 194, 4, 18, 382211) This rule does have a limitation on its field of application, namely, that the type of work in question requires moral integrity.
('70', 194, 4, 19, 382341) The work done by those who lack ability but are faultless in character, has shone out.
('70', 194, 4, 20, 382428) There should be no need to give instances of this.
('70', 194, 4, 21, 382479) Doing so is a delicate task.
('70', 194, 4, 22, 382508) But if one looks at the activities which have been founded on morality, one cannot fail to be convinced by what I have said.
('70', 194, 4, 23, 382633) There should be no hesitation in believing that the removal of untouchability is impossible with the help of men who lack character.
('70', 194, 4, 24, 382766) How can even the best orator, well versed in the Shastras, change the beliefs of an orthodox sanatanist Hindu?
('70', 194, 4, 25, 382877) Attacking the intellect is futile.
('70', 194, 4, 26, 382912) The influence of such persons as Chaitanya, Ramakrishna, Rammohan Roy, Dayanand and others, still persists today.
('70', 194, 4, 27, 383026) Is this through any force?
('70', 194, 4, 28, 383053) We may perhaps come across numerous persons
('70', 194, 5, 29, 383097) 1 Verrier Elwin 2 Vide “Need for Cleansing of Heart”, 13 12 1936
('70', 195, 0, 1, 383162) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 196
('70', 195, 1, 2, 383204) more intelligent than they.
('70', 195, 1, 3, 383232) But they will not be able to convert people’s hearts.
('70', 195, 1, 4, 383286) The history of the world is replete with such instances.
('70', 195, 1, 5, 383343) Despite this, if we ask for proofs we will be justifying the saying that a bad dancer finds the courtyard uneven.
('70', 195, 1, 6, 383457) However, it must be admitted that even a person of character must have industry, a keen desire for the necessary knowledge and discernment.
('70', 195, 1, 7, 383597) However, the question asked by the correspondent still remains unanswered.
('70', 195, 1, 8, 383672) Those who have left public institutions do not and cannot give up service even if they want to.
('70', 195, 1, 9, 383768) No one can take a person away from his dharma.
('70', 195, 1, 10, 383815) Dharma belongs to him who practises it.
('70', 195, 1, 11, 383855) Dharma is for those who are engaged in the service of Harijans, in khadi work, in serving the villages.
('70', 195, 1, 12, 383959) If those who had fallen, but have come out of their swoon, will render service wherever they happen to be, who can prevent them from living in a village?
('70', 195, 1, 13, 384113) Who can prevent them from silently doing scavenging in villages while living in obscurity?
('70', 195, 1, 14, 384204) What is there to prevent them from spinning and teaching others to spin or in serving Harijans?
('70', 195, 1, 15, 384300) While doing all this, they would purify themselves to such an extent that they would not find it difficult to face society.
('70', 195, 1, 16, 384424) Even if they lived unnoticed wherever they are, the aura which they would create would spread far and wide.
('70', 195, 1, 17, 384532) I have never said or believed that there is no redemption from sin.
('70', 195, 1, 18, 384600) Even the first among the fallen can become a saint.
('70', 195, 1, 19, 384652) A historian has said this of Tulsidas.
('70', 195, 1, 20, 384691) The Gita proclaims that even for the very sinful the path of devotion leads to liberation.
('70', 195, 1, 21, 384782) It is for this reason that one of the names of God is Patitapavan.
('70', 195, 2, 22, 384849) [From Gujarati]

('70', 195, 4, 24, 384891) 227. THE IDEAL AND THE ACTUAL
('70', 195, 5, 25, 384921) A gentleman has written a long letter on reading my article 2 on the ideal Bhangi.
('70', 195, 5, 26, 385004) The substance 3 of it is as follows:
('70', 195, 6, 27, 385041) 1 Purifier of the fallen 2 Vide “The Ideal Bhangi”, 28 11 1936 3 Not reproduced here.
('70', 195, 6, 28, 385127) The correspondent had written to say that he disagreed with Gandhiji’s views on the ideal Bhangi.
('70', 195, 6, 29, 385225) He felt that Gandhiji could not differentiate between the ideal and the actual and he would not be sucessful in turning anyone into an ideal Bhangi.
('70', 196, 0, 1, 385374) VOL. 70: 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 197
('70', 196, 1, 2, 385422) The correspondent has embellished his letter with many arguments.
('70', 196, 1, 3, 385488) There is nothing new in them.
('70', 196, 1, 4, 385518) The letter merely attempts to convince me.
('70', 196, 1, 5, 385561) Hence I shall not involve the reader in these arguments.
('70', 196, 1, 6, 385618) I intend to make some observations in reply in order to make my stand clearer.
('70', 196, 1, 7, 385697) An ideal which cannot be put into practice at all is not worth the name.
('70', 196, 1, 8, 385770) There will always be a gulf between the ideal and the actual.
('70', 196, 1, 9, 385832) Man’s supreme effort should be directed towards bridging this gulf.
('70', 196, 1, 10, 385900) Even today, we come across many Bhangis who are highly educated and who are carrying on their occupation and are striving to come up to my description of an ideal Bhangi.
('70', 196, 1, 11, 386071) Their number is constantly increasing.
('70', 196, 1, 12, 386110) If some of the carpenters remain carpenters all their lives, some of the farmers remain farmers, some stone cutters and some barbers continue to follow their vocations, then why can’t some of the Bhangis remain Bhangis?
('70', 196, 1, 13, 386330) Do not all these persons have a right to knowledge?
('70', 196, 1, 14, 386382) Actually every doctor and every nurse is a Bhangi.
('70', 196, 1, 15, 386433) He or she has to handle human excreta, smell, clean and analyse it.
('70', 196, 1, 16, 386501) Will it be humiliating to them if we regard them as Bhangis?
('70', 196, 1, 17, 386562) Why should that be so?
('70', 196, 1, 18, 386585) What sin has the Bhangi committed that his occupation is regarded as the lowliest of all?
('70', 196, 1, 19, 386675) This is not the case everywhere in the world.
('70', 196, 1, 20, 386721) Even in England some persons have to sweep the streets and carry away garbage.
('70', 196, 1, 21, 386800) That occupation is not regarded as demeaning by anyone there.
('70', 196, 1, 22, 386862) Any vocation scientifically pursued is as interesting as any scientific pursuit.
('70', 196, 1, 23, 386943) It is in our country that society has not allowed the vocations to grow into sciences by looking down upon them.
('70', 196, 1, 24, 387056) Hence, the carpenter does not compile technical documents on carpentry.
('70', 196, 1, 25, 387128) We import these from the West.
('70', 196, 1, 26, 387159) At present Dr. Fowler is doing the work of a Bhangi in Bangalore.
('70', 196, 1, 27, 387225) He collects all the garbage in the hotel where he stays and is minutely studying how to convert it into manure in the simplest way.
('70', 196, 1, 28, 387357) In the West the disposal of the garbage in the big cities is demanding work.
('70', 196, 1, 29, 387434) Those who do it and devise new methods for doing it are also Bhangis, aren’t they?
('70', 196, 1, 30, 387517) In Darjeeling and Simla, enormous sums are spent on the disposal of garbage.
('70', 196, 1, 31, 387594) Is it not a matter of shame and sorrow that none among our Bhangi brothers have acquired any knowledge of this?
('70', 196, 1, 32, 387706) This is a heinous sin on the part of those who are said to belong to the higher castes.
('70', 196, 1, 33, 387794) Our looking down upon Bhangis, has made them the
('70', 197, 0, 1, 387843) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 198
('70', 197, 1, 2, 387885) object of the disdain of the world.
('70', 197, 1, 3, 387921) I have not the slightest doubt in my mind that there cannot be any happiness or independence, whether economic, social or political, in the country as long the Bhangis do not get the same respect as the Brahmins.
('70', 197, 1, 4, 388134) What I have said here is not about ideals—but purely about what is practicable.
('70', 197, 1, 5, 388214) I ask for respect for the Bhangi as he is today.
('70', 197, 1, 6, 388263) When a Bhangi gains knowledge of the Brahman, we shall perforce worship him.
('70', 197, 1, 7, 388340) But we shall become purified only when we recognize a Bhangi as our own brother even as he is.
('70', 197, 2, 8, 388435) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 20 12 1936

('70', 198, 4, 18, 390804) 230. LETTER TO SHRIMANNARAYAN
('70', 198, 5, 19, 390834) December 20, 1936
('70', 198, 6, 20, 390852) SHRIMAN, I have gone through your article.
('70', 198, 6, 21, 390895) It cannot be published in Harijan, it is not worth publishing.
('70', 198, 6, 22, 390958) Make your scheme public.

('70', 201, 13, 20, 394118) 237. ADDRESS TO CONGRESS VOLUNTEERS 1
('70', 201, 14, 21, 394156) December 21, 1936
('70', 201, 15, 22, 394174) Mahatma Gandhi broke his silence tonight with an exhortation to the Congress volunteers, particularly those in charge of conservancy.
('70', 201, 15, 23, 394308) About 500 men and women listened to him in cloistral silence.
('70', 201, 15, 24, 394370) Speaking in quiet persuasive tones, Gandhiji dwelt at length on what he described as the science of Bhangis’ work.
('70', 201, 15, 25, 394485) He started by pointing out that he had begun his work as a Bhangi long ago in South Africa.
('70', 201, 15, 26, 394577) To be born as a ‘Bhangi’ was the result of great punya in previous birth.
('70', 201, 15, 27, 394651) He did not know what qualifications determined the birth of one man as Bhangi and another as Brahmin, but from the
('70', 201, 16, 28, 394766) 1 This was also reported by The Hindu, The Hindustan Times and The Hitavada.
('70', 202, 0, 1, 394843) VOL. 70: 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 203
('70', 202, 1, 2, 394891) point of view of benefit to society the one was no whit lower than the other.
('70', 202, 1, 3, 394969) Those who considered Bhangis’ work as mean did so in their ignorance.
('70', 202, 1, 4, 395039) Every mother acted as a Bhangi for her children; every doctor often acted as a Bhangi for his patients.
('70', 202, 1, 5, 395143) But the doctors received fat fees, while the Bhangi who was equally working for the benefit of society got very little in comparison.
('70', 202, 1, 6, 395277) Society regarded the work of Bhangis as demeaning, while the wholesome work done by the doctors was considered ennobling.
('70', 202, 1, 7, 395399) One who could not and did not do the work of the Bhangi in the proper spirit and in a thorough fashion and with pride in it could never be expected to do any other item of national service to the country effectively.
('70', 202, 1, 8, 395616) The Congress could go on with its deliberations and win success only if sanitary work was carried out properly.
('70', 202, 1, 9, 395728) Congress deliberations might end in success, but no session of the Congress could be called a success if the sanitary work was not a success.
('70', 202, 1, 10, 395870) One could go without food for two or three days and could do so without serious trouble but no one could do without the Bhangi’s services for that length of time or even less.
('70', 202, 1, 11, 396046) The greatest cause of worry for those in charge of arrangements for Congress sessions was the anxiety to see that there was no complaint on the score of food and sanitary arrangements.
('70', 202, 1, 12, 396231) Other things need not worry them so much.
('70', 202, 2, 13, 396273) Mahatma Gandhi proceeded to refer critically to the actual work he had seen some of the volunteers do.
('70', 202, 2, 14, 396376) What struck him was that they were very slow.
('70', 202, 2, 15, 396422) He did not blame them.
('70', 202, 2, 16, 396445) It was not their fault.
('70', 202, 2, 17, 396469) They were sincere, but there seemed to be none to attend to their training.
('70', 202, 2, 18, 396545) With training he was confident that they would do splendidly.
('70', 202, 2, 19, 396607) Hisconception of Ramarajya, which he said, was certain to come to India, was a dispensation under which there would be no distinction between a Brahmin and a Bhangi or even a Brahmin and a Maharaja.
('70', 202, 2, 20, 396806) They would be treated from the point of view of the usefulness to society of their respective work.
('70', 202, 2, 21, 396906) Re emphasizing the importance of Bhangi in the scheme of things, Gandhiji declared that swaraj would come to India not through the Congress parliamentarians in the legislatures, but through efficient and conscientious discharge of their work by Bhangis and other workers without looking for reward or praise in municipal and public addresses.
('70', 202, 2, 22, 397249) He exhorted the workers as well as the delegates and visitors to Faizpur to make it an ideal village.
('70', 202, 3, 23, 397351) Passing on to the number of volunteers placed at his disposal, Gandhiji said that fifteen volunteers who accompained him during his walks seemed to be too many.
('70', 202, 3, 24, 397512) He would be satisfied if one volunteer came with him just to show him the way.
('70', 202, 3, 25, 397591) Faizpur was a village, not a big city and there was no fear of big crowds requiring the attention of a large posse of volunteers.
('70', 202, 4, 26, 397721) The Bombay Chronicle, 22 12 1936

('70', 203, 22, 25, 398548) December 22, 1936
('70', 203, 23, 26, 398566) Gandhiji said how happy he was to come to the village.
('70', 203, 23, 27, 398621) He regarded it as a
('70', 203, 24, 28, 398641) pilgrimage, remembering as he did the s acrifices and services of Dhanaji Nana Choudhary of the village who resigned a job in the Police department and took an important part in Congress work.
('70', 203, 24, 29, 398834) He also recalled the work of 75 men and women who kept company with Mr. Choudhary in his achievements.
('70', 203, 25, 30, 398937) 1 The report carrying the item bears the date December 22. 2 Gandhiji was presented with a purse of Rs. 100 and an address in Marathi.
('70', 203, 26, 31, 399072) Gandhiji spoke in Hindi.
('70', 203, 26, 32, 399097) Reports of the speech also apeared in The Hindu, The Hindustan Times and The Hitavada.
('70', 204, 0, 1, 399184) VOL. 70: 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 205
('70', 204, 1, 2, 399232) He had come, said Gandhiji, to congratulate the village on that record of service and he was glad to see how clean the surroundings had been kept.
('70', 204, 1, 3, 399379) If the Congress session had come nearer to them, the reason was perhaps their part in the struggle.
('70', 204, 1, 4, 399479) While I am glad to see the way in which you have kept your village clean, I am sorry to say that differentiation of man from man is bad.
('70', 204, 1, 5, 399616) The other motto says real Hinduism does not recognize discrimination between Harijans and caste Hindus.
('70', 204, 1, 6, 399720) But during my walk round the village and round the Harijan quarter I found they are differentiating between Harijans and caste Hindus.
('70', 204, 1, 7, 399855) You are not treating Harijans in the same way as you declare in your motto.
('70', 204, 1, 8, 399931) You do not allow them to have water from your wells and they are driven to have recourse to tank water which I understand is occasionally also drunk by cattle.
('70', 204, 1, 9, 400091) This is bad.
('70', 204, 1, 10, 400104) Our country has been under foreign domination.
('70', 204, 1, 11, 400151) We are not a free people.
('70', 204, 1, 12, 400177) Though all of us agree that swaraj is our birthright, we have not been able to win it so far.
('70', 204, 1, 13, 400271) Mere membership of Congress means nothing.
('70', 204, 1, 14, 400314) How many members of Congress are there today in the country?
('70', 204, 1, 15, 400375) At the most one crore.
('70', 204, 1, 16, 400398) Then what about the rest of the 34 crores?
('70', 204, 1, 17, 400441) I have left the Congress.
('70', 204, 1, 18, 400467) I am not even a four anna member of the Congress, as I have decided to educate the public—I remain in the 34 crores.
('70', 204, 1, 19, 400584) For example, there are only 250 out of 2,500 residents of your village as Congress members.
('70', 204, 1, 20, 400676) Nothing would be lost if you are all not members.
('70', 204, 1, 21, 400726) Not that I do not want you to become Congress members, but I feel there is no use in your merely becoming Congress members.
('70', 204, 1, 22, 400850) I am in favour of all of you becoming members of the Congress.
('70', 204, 1, 23, 400913) I have no objection even if you want to enter legislatures but in your attempt to do so you need not create differences and quarrels amongst yourselves.
('70', 204, 1, 24, 401066) I leave the work in the legislatures to those who have the desire, resources and leisure for such work.
('70', 204, 1, 25, 401170) I have said that nothing substantial could be achieved by entering the legislatures but if Congress decided to capture them and asked Congress members of the legislatures to carry the Congress flag even into the Council Chambers, it is because Congress wants to prevent undesirables capturing those seats and using them in a way detrimental to the national interests.
('70', 204, 1, 26, 401538) If real swaraj is to be achieved we must give up quarrelling amongst ourselves.
('70', 204, 1, 27, 401618) There should be perfect equality and fraternity.
('70', 204, 1, 28, 401667) All artificial differences between man and man, community and
('70', 205, 0, 1, 401729) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 206
('70', 205, 1, 2, 401771) community, class and class should be immediately obliterated.
('70', 205, 1, 3, 401833) After all we are all human beings, all children of the same God.
('70', 205, 1, 4, 401898) The moment we realize this and translate this in our daily lives swaraj will be within our grasp.
('70', 205, 2, 5, 401996) The Bombay Chronicle, 24 12 1936

('70', 208, 6, 14, 407140) 247. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('70', 208, 7, 15, 407168) December 24, 1936
('70', 208, 8, 16, 407186) Mahatma Gandhi said that he could not conscientiously continue to serve any longer as the President of the League 1, as he could not do without goat’s milk.
