('70', 218, 3, 4, 429194) 253. AWARD IN LABOUR DISPUTE 1
('70', 218, 4, 5, 429225) TILAKNAGAR, December 26, 1936 I. The Ahmedabad Mill owners’ Association has referred to arbitration the following questions: (a) The M. O.A.’s demand for a 20% cut in wages.
('70', 218, 4, 6, 429399) (b) Complaint against the New Maneckchowk Mill.
('70', 218, 4, 7, 429447) (c) Complaint against Motilal Hirabhai Mill.
('70', 218, 4, 8, 429492) (d) Complaint against Rajnagar Mills No.
('70', 218, 4, 9, 429533) 1. The reference is subject to two conditions, viz., 1. The Arbitrators should give a simultaneous award on all the questions referred to them.
('70', 218, 4, 10, 429677) 2. With reference to the mill which might have resigned from the M.O.A. whether the Arbitrators have any jurisdiction in respect of complaints against them before they enter upon merits.
('70', 218, 4, 11, 429864) Sheth Chamanlal Girdhardas Parekh was Permanent Arbitrator on behalf of the M.O.A. but he having resigned the M.O.A. has appointed Sheth Kasturbhai in his place only with reference to the questions referred to above.
('70', 218, 4, 12, 430081) The absence of Sheth Chamanlal has been felt by all.
('70', 218, 4, 13, 430134) The Arbitrators had conversations with representatives of the M.O.A. and T.L.A. on 2nd, 3rd and 4th instant at Wardha and Segaon.
('70', 218, 4, 14, 430264) At these meetings no evidence was taken or registered beyond consultations.
('70', 218, 4, 15, 430340) But at my instance and for my edification certain particulars were supplied as embodied in Appendices 2, 6, 7, 8, and 9. With reference to the admission of these Appendices as part of the record to be submitted to the Umpire, it is likely that my brother Arbitrator will object to their admission.
('70', 218, 4, 16, 430638) I had asked for the information embodied in these Appendices in Wardha and Segaon.
('70', 218, 4, 17, 430721) There was no objection raised by my brother at the time.
('70', 218, 4, 18, 430778) Appendix O
('70', 218, 5, 19, 430789) 1 Gandhiji wrote this in Gujarati and the English translation was arranged by Kasturbhai Lalbhai.
('70', 218, 5, 20, 430887) Vide also “Letter to Kasturbhai Lalbhai”, 3 1 1937
('70', 219, 0, 1, 430938) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 220
('70', 219, 1, 2, 430980) was asked for by us jointly and if that also is objected to, I do not mind its exclusion as it is unnecessary for my decision.
('70', 219, 1, 3, 431107) The evidence that is submitted to the Umpire is embodied in the fourteen appendices attached hereto.
('70', 219, 1, 4, 431208) V. From the evidence submitted it appears that the T.L.A. has been obliged reluctantly to agree to the restricted reference (Appendix II).
('70', 219, 1, 5, 431347) In my opinion, if all the points of dispute between the two parties had been referred to arbitration, the Arbitrators would have found it easier to give their Award because such questions are as a rule closely related to each other.
('70', 219, 1, 6, 431580) Although therefore there seems to me to be validity in the T.L.A’s protest, its letter dated November 30th (Appendix I) is a clear acceptance, however involuntary, of the restriction.
('70', 219, 1, 7, 431764) Nevertheless the T.L.A. has a perfect right to have all these questions referred to arbitration.
('70', 219, 2, 8, 431861) ON WAGE CUT
('70', 219, 3, 9, 431873) After having read the papers herewith and having given full consideration to them on the question of the M.O.A.’s demand for a wage cut, I have come to the conclusion that evidence submitted furnishes no cause for any cut.
('70', 219, 3, 10, 432096) The last Arbitration Award was given on the 17th January 1935 (Appendix IV, sub appendix 1).
('70', 219, 3, 11, 432189) In that Award the Arbitrator has thrown certain responsibilities on both the parties of which three are as follows: (a) Earnest efforts should be made to standardize the wages of piece workers as soon as possible after 1st January 1936. (b) With a view to providing for a prompt settlement of all wages questions on either side in future the parties will meet and try to evolve a scheme for automatic adjustment of wages.
('70', 219, 3, 12, 432611) (c) The mills which are desirous of adopting rationalization will prepare before 30the June 1935 a register of workers who are working and who are likely to be unemployed in the departments to which such schemes will apply.
('70', 219, 3, 13, 432835) From the evidence submitted to the Arbitrators it appears that the M.O.A. has not discharged its share of these responsibilities nor has it taken sufficient pains to do so.
('70', 219, 3, 14, 433008) In my opinion it is possible, with sufficient endeavour, to standardize wages and although it is difficult to evolve a scheme whereby the question of increasing or decreasing wages can be automatically regulated, I do not consider it
('70', 220, 0, 1, 433242) VOL. 70: 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 221
('70', 220, 1, 2, 433290) to be impossible.
('70', 220, 1, 3, 433308) It was the obvious duty of the M.O.A. to keep a registry of hands in connection with rationalazation.
('70', 220, 1, 4, 433410) In all these three matters either party could have availed itself of the assistance of the Arbitrators but it does not apper to have occurred to them to do so.
('70', 220, 1, 5, 433570) X. It is necessary to bear this in mind that the Award of 1935 was originally a voluntary agreement between the parties.
('70', 220, 1, 6, 433691) To give it the form of an Award was obviously in the natural course but in view of the fact that the Award was merely a stabilization of the voluntary agreement, it was doubly the duty of the parties to give effect to it and is so today.
('70', 220, 1, 7, 433929) In my opinion, not until the M.O.A. has made a serious attempt to carry out the terms of the last settlement and the impossibility of its being carried out has been proved is it open for the M.O.A. to ask for a wage cut.
('70', 220, 1, 8, 434150) However, the general understanding arrived at between the two parties has the same value as the Award in determining the question of wage cut.
('70', 220, 1, 9, 434293) The fact that in spite of the admission of the necessity of having a sub arbitrator appointed to adjudicate upon petty disputes arising from time to time the appointment has not been made is injurious to the harmonious relations between the parties and becomes a cause of mutual distrust and this in its turn harms the industry.
('70', 220, 1, 10, 434622) It seems improper that the workmen’s complaints may not be disposed of in time or not at all and that the question of wage cut can still be referred to arbitration.
('70', 220, 1, 11, 434787) That the permanent Arbitrators cannot investigate every complaint is self evident.
('70', 220, 1, 12, 434870) Those who seek justice have to come with clean hands.
('70', 220, 1, 13, 434924) In my opinion the M.O.A. has not performed its duty in this matter and has no right to ask for a wage cut until this duty of appointing a sub arbitrator is discharged.
('70', 220, 1, 14, 435092) Such being my opinion it is unnecessary for me to enter into the merits of the case for wage cut.
('70', 220, 1, 15, 435190) But a study of the papers submitted by the parties has left on me the impression that the period that has elapsed since the last Award was given is too short to warrant a case for wage cut.
('70', 220, 1, 16, 435380) Besides, the M.O.A.’s statement does not substantiate its claim.
('70', 220, 1, 17, 435445) At this stage I would like to restate the principles that for the good of both parties I have presented to them as a result of my close and unbroken contact with the industry for a period of 18 years in the capacity of Arbitrator.
('70', 220, 1, 18, 435676) (a) No cut should be made till the mills have ceased to make any profit and are obliged to fall back upon their capital for continuing the industry.
('70', 221, 0, 1, 435825) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 222
('70', 221, 1, 2, 435867) (b) There should be no cut till the wages have reached the level adequate for maintenance.
('70', 221, 1, 3, 435958) It is impossible to conceive a time when the workmen have begun to regard the industry as if it were their own property and they would then be prepared to help it out of a crisis by taking the barest maintenance consisting of a dry crust and working day and night.
('70', 221, 1, 4, 436223) That would be a voluntary arrangement.
('70', 221, 1, 5, 436262) Such cases are irrelevant to the present consideration.
('70', 221, 1, 6, 436318) (c) There should be a common understanding as to what should be included in determining a living wage.
('70', 221, 1, 7, 436421) (d) The consideration of the deterioration in individual mills cannot form part of a case for a cut in wages of labour in general.
('70', 221, 1, 8, 436552) (e) It is vital to the well being of the industry that workmen should be regarded as equals with the shareholders and that they have therefore every right to possess an accurate knowledge of the transactions of the mills.
('70', 221, 1, 9, 436774) (f) There should be a register of all available mill hands acceptable to both the parties and the custom of taking labour through any agency other than the T.L.A. should be stopped.
('70', 221, 1, 10, 436956) I have not presented these principles in the belief that they will be acceptable either to the brother Arbitrator or to the mill owners or even to the workmen.
('70', 221, 1, 11, 437116) These have not guided my decision in the present case but I am convinced that without the acceptance of these principles the industry, i.e., the owners and the workmen, are in danger.
('70', 221, 1, 12, 437300) Before concluding the discussion on the wage cut it seems to be necessary for me to allude to a thing that has come under my observation in the course of the proceedings.
('70', 221, 1, 13, 437471) The control of the M.O.A. over individual mills appears to have slackened.
('70', 221, 1, 14, 437546) When the M.O.A’.s decisions appear repugnant to individual mill owners, they are tempted to secede.
('70', 221, 1, 15, 437646) This is undoubtedly a regrettable state of things and requires to be mended.
('70', 221, 1, 16, 437723) But it cannot be cited in support of a case for wage cut.
('70', 221, 1, 17, 437781) The burden of maintaining such mills cannot be laid on the shoulders of labour.
('70', 221, 1, 18, 437861) The deterioration of individual mills has been found to be due to the shortcomings of managers, out of date machinery or such other internal defects.
('70', 221, 2, 19, 438011) NEW MANECKCHOWK MILL
('70', 221, 3, 20, 438032) The reduction of wages by this mill is not denied but no mill has any right to initiate a reduction of its own will.
('70', 221, 3, 21, 438149) M.O.A. says
('70', 222, 0, 1, 438161) VOL. 70: 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 223
('70', 222, 1, 2, 438209) that this mill has retired from the Association and the Arbitration has, therefore, no jurisdiction to entertain the case.
('70', 222, 1, 3, 438332) One notice of reduction was issued on 8th August last and the other on the 2nd October last.
('70', 222, 1, 4, 438425) Meanwhile the mill seceded from the Association on the 20th August last.
('70', 222, 1, 5, 438498) The M.O.A’s statement that the reduction was made on September 30th is evidently a slip of the pen.
('70', 222, 1, 6, 438598) Whether it is or not, the fact of the resignation does not debar the T.L.A. from bringing the case before Arbitration.
('70', 222, 1, 7, 438717) If, whenever a mill so acts as to have its action impeached by the Arbitrators and therefore resigns with a view to escaping discipline, the system of arbitration becomes meaningless.
('70', 222, 1, 8, 438901) How the M.O.A. can enforce discipline against a seceder is another question.
('70', 222, 1, 9, 438978) Such a question, when it arises, can be dealt with by resort to arbitration if it becomes necessary.
('70', 222, 1, 10, 439079) In my opinion the mill in question should restore the reduced amount and withdraw the notice.
('70', 222, 1, 11, 439173) If the defaulting mill does not carry out this decision the M.O.A. should co operate with the T.L.A. in adopting all legitimate measures against the defaulter.
('70', 222, 2, 12, 439333) MOTILAL HIRABHAI MILL XX.
('70', 222, 2, 13, 439359) I can give no definite opinion on the papers submitted.
('70', 222, 2, 14, 439415) If the owners of this mill do not furnish the required information the M.O.A. should procure it without delay and if it is not procured the T.L.A. is at liberty to come before the Arbitrators.
('70', 222, 2, 15, 439608) Although the M.O.A. and the mill do not appear to have given the necessary help to the T.L.A., the latter erred in assisting the workmen in resorting to the strike if such assistance was in fact given.
('70', 222, 2, 16, 439810) However provoking the circumstances might be, workmen cannot cease work without due notice nor can owners impose reduction of their own motion.
('70', 222, 2, 17, 439954) This is inherent in the acceptance of the principle of arbitration.
('70', 222, 3, 18, 440022) THE DECISION Thus on the points submitted to arbitration my decision is as follows: 1. The case for wage cut is dismissed for the reason that the M.O.A. has failed to prove it.
('70', 222, 3, 19, 440199) 2. The alleged resignation by the New Maneckchowk Mill does not put it outside the jurisdiction of the Arbitration Board.
('70', 222, 3, 20, 440321) The mill should restore the reduced wages and withdraw the cut notice.
('70', 222, 3, 21, 440392) If the owners do not carry out this decision, the M.O.A. should co operate with the T.L.A., in taking all legitimate steps to enforce discipline and should seek the assistance of the Arbitration Board, if necessary.
('70', 222, 3, 22, 440608) 3. I am unable to give a definite decision about the complaint against Motilal Hirabhai Mill
('70', 222, 4, 23, 440701) History of Wage Adjustments in the Ahmedabad Industry, Vol. IV, pp.

('70', 223, 1, 2, 440811) 254.LETTER TO KASTURBHAI LALBHAI
('70', 223, 2, 3, 440844) December 26, 1936
('70', 223, 3, 4, 440862) BHAI KASTURBHAI,
('70', 223, 4, 5, 440879) I am enclosing herewith my Award 1 with two extra copies, one for the Labour Association and the other for the Mill owners’ Association.
('70', 223, 4, 6, 441016) Please go through the additions and alterations made therein.
('70', 223, 4, 7, 441078) There is a reference to sub appendices in the Appendix.
('70', 223, 4, 8, 441134) As desired by you I have droped sub appendices and have made a note to that effect in the Appendix.
('70', 223, 4, 9, 441234) Please see.
('70', 223, 4, 10, 441246) After writing to you yesterday, I thought about the question at night and while writing this it has occured to me that greater justice would be done by not recommending payment of arrears of the wages and therefore I am revising the decision.
('70', 223, 4, 11, 441489) I have only made a recommendation concerning the wages, which you will see.
('70', 223, 4, 12, 441565) You will also find therein my reasons for not paying the arrears.
('70', 223, 4, 13, 441631) It is in conformity with my nature.
('70', 223, 4, 14, 441667) If you had not drawn my attention to it, I would not perhaps have noticed the error in my approach.
('70', 223, 4, 15, 441767) However, you drove me to hard thinking.
('70', 223, 4, 16, 441807) I very much wanted to accept your suggestion.
('70', 223, 4, 17, 441853) You demonstrated your friendship by drawing my attention to my error.
('70', 223, 4, 18, 441923) Should I thank you for that?
('70', 223, 4, 19, 441952) Truth will cease to exist in this world if friends do not fulfill their duty of cautioning one another.
('70', 223, 4, 20, 442056) I hope you have received the telegram I have sent to you.
('70', 223, 4, 21, 442114) It is good if you are able to act accordingly.
('70', 223, 4, 22, 442161) It hurts me that hundreds of workers are unemployed.
('70', 223, 4, 23, 442214) It also pains me that we are not allowed to hear their case.
('70', 223, 4, 24, 442275) Therefore please do not a waste a single minute.
('70', 223, 4, 25, 442324) I do not have a copy of the letter to the Umpire.
('70', 223, 4, 26, 442374) Has he been given fifteen days’ time limit?
('70', 223, 4, 27, 442418) Whatever it may be, please request the Umpire on behalf of us both that he should give the decision as early as possible even within that time limit.
('70', 223, 5, 28, 442568) Vandemataram from MOHANDAS

('70', 224, 5, 11, 443190) 256. MESSAGE TO STUDENTS1
('70', 224, 6, 12, 443216) FAIZPUR, [December 26, 1936] 2
('70', 224, 7, 13, 443247) What new message can I give you at the age of 68?
('70', 224, 7, 14, 443297) And where is the use of my giving you a message if you pass a resolution there of assassinating me or burning my effigy?
('70', 224, 7, 15, 443418) Assassinating the body of course does not matter, for out of my ashes a thousand Gandhis will arise.
('70', 224, 7, 16, 443519) But what if you assassinate or burn the principles I have lived for?
('70', 224, 8, 17, 443588) Harijan, 16 1 1937
('70', 224, 9, 18, 443607) 257. HINDU CODE OF CONDUCT
('70', 224, 10, 19, 443634) I have preserved the following letter 3 for the past seven months.
('70', 224, 10, 20, 443701) I have been keeping the letter suppressed in the belief that it would be better if I got some learned scholar to reply to it instead of doing so myself.
('70', 224, 10, 21, 443854) Shri Anandshankarbhai has at my request taken the
('70', 224, 11, 22, 443904) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('70', 224, 11, 23, 443954) The message was in response to a request from the secretary of a students’ conference.
('70', 224, 11, 24, 444041) 2 Mahadev Desai says the message was given the day before Gandhiji made his “great speech on the cult of the Charkha”, which was on December 27. 3 Not translated here.
('70', 224, 11, 25, 444209) The correspondent had written to say that it was better to teach Harijans how to observe Hindu religion in day to day life than to give them lectures on culture
('70', 225, 0, 1, 444370) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 226
('70', 225, 1, 2, 444412) work in hand now.
('70', 225, 1, 3, 444430) However, the book which will result will not solve the above question in the manner desired by the correspondent.
('70', 225, 1, 4, 444544) It is my hope that he will glean the required information from the book.
('70', 225, 1, 5, 444617) I am putting forward something of that sort here; because I have spent years working amongst Harijans.
('70', 225, 1, 6, 444720) My experience, therefore, may be useful to other workers like the correspondent.
('70', 225, 1, 7, 444801) I do not talk to Harijans about the basic tenets of Hinduism.
('70', 225, 1, 8, 444863) If they had separate temples I would certainly visit them.
('70', 225, 1, 9, 444922) I would jest with the priest there.
('70', 225, 1, 10, 444958) Ordinarily, the poor man is very ignorant.
('70', 225, 1, 11, 445001) This does not mean that a caste Hindu priest knows more.
('70', 225, 1, 12, 445058) But why should the latter listen to me?
('70', 225, 1, 13, 445098) A Harijan priest would regard me as a great man and lend me an ear at least.
('70', 225, 1, 14, 445175) It is a different thing if he lets my words go out through the other ear.
('70', 225, 1, 15, 445249) I would say the following to a band of Harijans: So far, we have spurned you; we did not even look at you, we did not share your joys and sorrows.
('70', 225, 1, 16, 445396) Let me now tell you what our religion expects of us.
('70', 225, 2, 17, 445449) 1. If we are not in the habit of waking up before dawn, we should form it.
('70', 225, 2, 18, 445524) 2. There are many persons who start smoking immediately on waking up, others, little better, make the whole house aware of their having woken up by talking profanities.
('70', 225, 2, 19, 445693) Instead of doing this, one should take the name of God before leaving the bed and thank Him for the night having passed safely.
('70', 225, 2, 20, 445821) 3. On leaving the bed we should immediately awaken our children and then, sitting in a place which is not frequented by people, we should clean our teeth with babul or some other twig.
('70', 225, 2, 21, 446006) We should use either salt or powdered charcoal which we must keep ready at home to clean our teeth and with the halves of the twig we should scrape the tongue and rinse the mouth well.
('70', 225, 2, 22, 446191) We should sprinkle water over our eyes and remove mucus if there is any.
('70', 225, 2, 23, 446264) Having done that we must wash our face, nose, ears, etc., carefully and wipe these with a clean cloth.
('70', 225, 2, 24, 446367) 4. If one has to evacuate one’s bowels and that particular village has no latrine, or if there is one, but one does not like to use it, this function should be performed in a remote place which people do not frequent.
('70', 225, 2, 25, 446585) The excreta should be properly covered with earth and the organs concerned should be properly cleansed with water.
('70', 225, 2, 26, 446700) As both the excretory organs throw out waste, these should be properly cleansed and the waste material eliminated.
('70', 225, 2, 27, 446815) Thereafter the hands should be
('70', 226, 0, 1, 446846) VOL. 70: 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 227
('70', 226, 1, 2, 446894) washed with water and earth, and the water pot should also be cleaned well.
('70', 226, 1, 3, 446970) 5. While performing this daily routine one should either hum Ramdhun or some devotional song.
('70', 226, 1, 4, 447064) If one does not know any of these, one should merely keep repeating the name of Rama.
('70', 226, 1, 5, 447150) 6. It would be daylight by the time one returns home.
('70', 226, 1, 6, 447204) Other members of the family will also have performed their natural functions as mentioned above.
('70', 226, 1, 7, 447301) All should then get together and sing bhajans or kirtans for five minutes to half an hour.
('70', 226, 1, 8, 447392) So long as one does not know any such thing, one can at least repeat the name of Rama.
('70', 226, 1, 9, 447479) 7. Thereafter, everyone should set out for work after taking breakfast.
('70', 226, 1, 10, 447551) Children who do not work should go to school.
('70', 226, 1, 11, 447597) 8. Before taking the midday meal, everyone should bathe with clean water and scrub the entire body.
('70', 226, 1, 12, 447697) Dhoti, sari and such other garments should be washed.
('70', 226, 1, 13, 447751) The poor who do not have the facility of daily change should wear a loin cloth while bathing.
('70', 226, 1, 14, 447845) The body should be rubbed and wiped after a bath.
('70', 226, 1, 15, 447895) 9. In this manner, when night falls while performing one’s daily tasks, God’s name should be uttered after the evening meal and before going to bed and He should be thanked that the day passed without any mishaps.
('70', 226, 1, 16, 448109) 10. The hands should be washed after every meal and after performing any task which soils the hands.
('70', 226, 1, 17, 448210) After a meal, one should gargle and rinse one’s mouth.
('70', 226, 1, 18, 448265) 11. We should realize that God knows our every thought, sees everything we do.
('70', 226, 1, 19, 448344) Hence no one can deceive Him.
('70', 226, 1, 20, 448374) How then can we deceive out brothers and sisters who are His creatures?
('70', 226, 1, 21, 448446) It may well be that these persons are unaware of our deception.
('70', 226, 1, 22, 448510) If they come to know of the latter, how can we cheat them at all?
('70', 226, 1, 23, 448576) 12. Hence we should sincerely serve those under whom we work and not deceive them.
('70', 226, 1, 24, 448659) 13. And, if we do not deceive anyone, how can we commit any theft?
('70', 226, 1, 25, 448726) Even cheating while weighing goods amounts to theft.
('70', 226, 1, 26, 448779) 14. We certainly would not like anyone to abuse us or beat us or misbehave with our mother or sisters.
('70', 226, 1, 27, 448882) Hence we should not abuse anyone, not even our wives and children.
('70', 226, 1, 28, 448949) 15. Nor should we beat anyone.
('70', 226, 1, 29, 448980) This includes our wives and children.
('70', 226, 1, 30, 449018) These persons have to be separately mentioned because many men regard their wives and children as their property.
('70', 226, 1, 31, 449132) But it is a
('70', 227, 0, 1, 449144) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 228
('70', 227, 1, 2, 449186) grave error.
('70', 227, 1, 3, 449199) In our religion the wife has been regarded the equal of the husband.
('70', 227, 1, 4, 449268) Hence, she is known as the other half, co partner in religion, a goddess.
('70', 227, 1, 5, 449342) Children are not our property.
('70', 227, 1, 6, 449373) Parents are the protectors of children.
('70', 227, 1, 7, 449413) Hence, even with them, we should be gentle, tolerant and patient.
('70', 227, 1, 8, 449479) 16. Just as we should have goodwill towards our wives and children, similarly we should treat our elders and our parents with respect.
('70', 227, 1, 9, 449614) 17. And, as shown in 14 above, it is obvious that a man should treat another man’s wife as his sister or mother and, similarly, a woman should regard another man as her father or brother.
('70', 227, 1, 10, 449802) 18. Just as all men are creatures of God, so also animals are His creatures; hence they are also a part of the family.
('70', 227, 1, 11, 449921) We should therefore be good towards them too.
('70', 227, 1, 12, 449967) We cannot misuse even mud or stones.
('70', 227, 1, 13, 450004) Our religion teaches us even such prayer: “Oh!
('70', 227, 1, 14, 450051) Mother Earth, we walk upon you every day.
('70', 227, 1, 15, 450093) We depend upon your support.
('70', 227, 1, 16, 450122) Forgive us for touching you with our feet.” Having said this, we put a pinch of dust upon our heads.
('70', 227, 1, 17, 450223) 19. And hence we should be kind towards our animals; we should feed them properly; we should certainly not overload them with burdens, we should keep them in clean places; and refrain from beating them.
('70', 227, 1, 18, 450426) 20. Similarly, we should pluck leaves and cut trees only as much as we must.
('70', 227, 1, 19, 450503) We should use discretion while doing so.
('70', 227, 1, 20, 450544) We should not destroy wantonly.
('70', 227, 1, 21, 450576) 21. So far as possible, we should avoid eating meat.
('70', 227, 1, 22, 450629) Beef should be totally shunned.
('70', 227, 1, 23, 450661) Cow protection occupies a very prominent place in our religion.
('70', 227, 1, 24, 450725) 22. In accordance with clause 19, all living creatures are our brothers and sisters.
('70', 227, 1, 25, 450810) Hence, our rishis and munis taught us that we should regard the cow as our mother and should develop friendly relations towards all living beings including non human creatures.
('70', 227, 1, 26, 450987) It is in the fitness of things to regard the cow as our mother as she, like the mother, gives us milk.
('70', 227, 1, 27, 451090) One who gets milk does not require fish or meat.
('70', 227, 1, 28, 451139) Moreover, the cow provides us with bullocks and even after death gives us leather, manure, fat for carts, etc., and such other things.
('70', 227, 1, 29, 451274) Hence, we should never kill a cow.
('70', 227, 1, 30, 451309) 23. And if we may not kill a cow, how can we eat her flesh after her death?
('70', 227, 1, 31, 451385) No sensible people in the world eat carrion.
('70', 228, 0, 1, 451430) VOL. 70: 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 229
('70', 228, 1, 2, 451478) 24. By becoming an addict, a man renders himself virtually insane; sometimes, he completely loses his senses.
('70', 228, 1, 3, 451588) Hence liquor, toddy, bhang, ganja, opium and tobacco should be eschewed.
('70', 228, 1, 4, 451661) 25. Gambling involves deception and the money obtained through it is tainted.
('70', 228, 1, 5, 451739) Hence we should not gamble.
('70', 228, 1, 6, 451767) 26. Others are as fond of their religion as we are of ours.
('70', 228, 1, 7, 451827) Hence we should respect all religions eqully.
('70', 228, 1, 8, 451873) And, therefore we should bear no ill will or have disputes with Muslims, Christians and followers of other faiths.
('70', 228, 1, 9, 451988) 27. If religion teaches us that all are children of God, there can be no high or low among them and there should not be even the faintest trace of untouchability.
('70', 228, 1, 10, 452151) 28. Finally, our religion also tells us that anyone who does not earn his living with the sweat of his brow, eats stolen food.
('70', 228, 1, 11, 452278) Hence, everyone should earn his bread by engaging himself in such manual tasks as farming, or making cloth, etc., and it is for this very reason that each person should produce foodgrains, khadi and such other articles of food and clothing in his own village.
('70', 228, 1, 12, 452538) These things which I have often said on different occasions have been put down in written form here.
('70', 228, 1, 13, 452639) Other clauses may be added to these when the occasion arises bearing in mind the universal elements like truth and non violence, which are involved in them.

('70', 228, 2, 15, 452838) 258. DUTY TOWARDS CHRISTIAN HARIJANS
('70', 228, 3, 16, 452875) A worker in the cause of Harijans has asked me what should be the duty of the Harijan Sevak Sangh towards Christian Harijans.
('70', 228, 3, 17, 453001) His letter contains many subsidiary questions which need not be reproduced here.
('70', 228, 3, 18, 453082) This article is intended to answer those very questions.
('70', 228, 3, 19, 453139) Ordinarily it may be said that the special duty which the Sangh has taken upon itself and attempts to fulfil towards Hindu Harijans, does not hold good in case of those who have become Christians.
('70', 228, 3, 20, 453336) However, the goodwill that one human being should have towards another should also be shown towards Christian Harijans.
('70', 228, 3, 21, 453456) This rule applies to people of all faiths.
('70', 228, 3, 22, 453499) We cannot be displeased with a Harijan because he calls himself a Christian.
('70', 228, 3, 23, 453576) However, if he is in receipt of a
('70', 229, 0, 1, 453610) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 230
('70', 229, 1, 2, 453652) scholarship or any such special assistance from the Sangh, that should be discontinued.
('70', 229, 1, 3, 453740) But if, despite having become a Christian, he is in a Harijan school and wishes to continue in it, he cannot be turned out.
('70', 229, 1, 4, 453864) Perhaps he may be asked to pay his fees.
('70', 229, 1, 5, 453905) He cannot be given the usual free clothes, etc., as the Sangh’s funds are meant for Hindu Harijans only.
('70', 229, 1, 6, 454010) Hindus, other than Harijans, can be admitted to Harijan schools, but they cannot join them withour paying fees.
('70', 229, 1, 7, 454122) The same rule should apply to those who have become Christians.
('70', 229, 1, 8, 454186) Christian Harijans should not be offered temptations to embrace Hinduism again.
('70', 229, 1, 9, 454266) However, if a person wishes to return to his own faith we should not prevent him from doing so.
('70', 229, 1, 10, 454362) But if Christian Harijans ask for facilities such as the use of wells or medical help during illness, it is our common dharma to render such service.
('70', 229, 1, 11, 454512) However, even in these instances assistance cannot be given from Harijan funds.
('70', 229, 1, 12, 454592) But facilities should be provided for these persons to draw water from wells which are used by Hindu Harijans.
('70', 229, 1, 13, 454703) Sangh workers should provide Christian Harijans also the services of a doctor or worker who renders free service to Hindu Harijans.
('70', 229, 1, 14, 454835) It is their dharma to do so.

('70', 230, 2, 3, 455335) December 27, 1936
('70', 230, 3, 4, 455353) This speech was scheduled for 8.30. I am sorry that it is being delivered so late at 9.15. But there was no alternative.
('70', 230, 3, 5, 455474) People have turned up here in such large numbers and as our exhibition has only screens of unseasoned bamboo for walls, if everyone makes a rush for it they would collapse.
('70', 230, 3, 6, 455647) Hence, arrangements had to be made to protect things and the organizers took some time in doing this.

('70', 230, 4, 24, 457093) I said in 1918 that we could win swaraj through the spinning wheel.
('70', 230, 4, 25, 457161) My faith in the ability of the spinning wheel is as bright today as when I first declared it in 1918. It has become richer for the experience and experiment of all these years.
('70', 230, 5, 26, 457338) 1 This is taken from the Gujarati version published in Harijanbandhu.

('70', 231, 1, 2, 457579) But you should know the implications of the wheel or khadi, its product.
('70', 231, 1, 3, 457652) It is not enough that one wears khadi on ceremonial occasions or even wears it to the exclusion of all other cloth if he surrounds himself with videshi in everything else.
('70', 231, 1, 4, 457824) Khadi means the truest swadeshi spirit, identification with the starving millions.
('70', 231, 1, 5, 457907) Let there be no mistake about my conception of swaraj.
('70', 231, 1, 6, 457962) It is complete independence of alien control and complete economic independence.
('70', 231, 1, 7, 458043) So at one end you have political independence, at the other the economic.
('70', 231, 1, 8, 458117) It has two other ends.
('70', 231, 1, 9, 458140) One of them is moral and social, the corresponding end is dharma, i.e., religion in the highest sense of the term.
('70', 231, 1, 10, 458255) It includes Hinduism, Islam, Christianity, etc., but is superior to them all.
('70', 231, 1, 11, 458333) You may recognize it by the name of Truth, not the honesty of expedience but the living Truth that pervades everything and will survive all destruction and all transformation.
('70', 231, 1, 12, 458509) Moral and social uplift may be recognized by the term we are used the term we are used to, i.e., non violence.
('70', 231, 1, 13, 458620) Let us call this the square of swaraj, which will be out of shape if any of its angles is untrue.
('70', 231, 1, 14, 458718) In the language of the Congress we cannot achieve this political and economic freedom without truth and non violence, in concrete terms without a living faith in God and hence moral and social elevation.
('70', 231, 1, 15, 458922) By political independence I do not mean an imitation of the British House of Commons, or the Soviet rule of Russia or the Fascist rule of Italy or the Nazi rule of Germony.
('70', 231, 1, 16, 459095) They have systems suited to their genius.

('70', 231, 1, 20, 459309) The Congress constit utions of Nagpur and Bombay for which I am mainly responsible are an attempt to achieve this type of swaraj.
('70', 231, 1, 21, 459439) Then take economic independence.

('70', 231, 1, 23, 459548) Indian economic independence means to me the economic uplift of every individual, male and female, by his or her own conscious effort.
('70', 231, 1, 24, 459683) Under that system all men and women will have enough clothing—not the mere loin cloth, but what we understand by the term necessary articles of clothing and enough food including milk and butter which are today denied to millions.
('70', 231, 1, 25, 459914) This brings me to socialism.
('70', 231, 1, 26, 459943) Real socialism has been handed down to us by our ancestors who taught: “All land belongs to Gopal, where then is the boundary line?

('70', 232, 0, 1, 460179) VOL. 70: 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 233

('70', 232, 1, 15, 461215) With the destruction of hand ginning, carding, spinning and weaving to a certain extent, perished the other industries of India’s villages.
('70', 232, 1, 16, 461355) Continuous unemployment has induced in the people a kind of laziness which is most depressing.
('70', 232, 1, 17, 461450) Thus whilst the alien rule is undoubtedly responsible for the growing pauperism of the people, we are more responsible for it.

('70', 235, 1, 2, 467912) 261. SPEECH AT CONGRESS SESSION
('70', 235, 2, 3, 467944) December 27, 1936
('70', 235, 3, 4, 467962) Mahatma Gandhi said that he expected that they would be tired by this time.
('70', 235, 3, 5, 468038) He himself had nothing much to say.
('70', 235, 3, 6, 468074) What he had to say he had already said in the morning at the exhibition.
('70', 235, 3, 7, 468147) He did not want to repeat it.

('70', 235, 3, 9, 468298) When the Reception Committee authorities came to him he told them certain things.
('70', 235, 3, 10, 468380) He told them to throw the responsibility on God and start work.
('70', 235, 3, 11, 468444) There had been several criticisms against the step taken in holding the Congress in a village.
('70', 235, 3, 12, 468539) Several newspapers had criticized it and had dwelt upon the shortcomings.
('70', 235, 3, 13, 468613) The Reception Committee did not have sufficient money.
('70', 235, 3, 14, 468668) Nevertheless they all saw that the Congress here was the same as before.
('70', 235, 3, 15, 468741) In fact the village Congress had turned out to be a bigger one than previous Congresses.

('70', 235, 3, 19, 469134) Such a large influx of people had made the Reception authorities fear whether they would be able to meet their needs.

('70', 235, 3, 21, 469436) They no doubt had a hospital, but it was not big enough for a large number of people to be treated at once.

('70', 241, 10, 24, 480842) 272. DISCUSSION WITH KRZENSKI 2
('70', 241, 11, 25, 480874) [January 2, 1937] 3
('70', 241, 12, 26, 480894) GANDHIJI: Do you therefore say that other religions are untrue?
('70', 241, 13, 27, 480958) KRZENSKI: If others are convinced that their religions are true they are saved.
('70', 241, 14, 28, 481038) 1 Not available 2 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('70', 241, 14, 29, 481104) Krzenski was a Polish professor of philosophy.
('70', 241, 15, 30, 481151) 3 From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary 4 Krzenski had said that according to him Catholicism was the only true religion.
('70', 242, 0, 1, 481280) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 243
('70', 242, 1, 2, 481329) G. Therefore you will say that everyone would be saved even through untruth.
('70', 242, 2, 3, 481406) For you say that if a man really and sincerely believes in what is as a matter of fact untruth, he is saved.
('70', 242, 2, 4, 481515) Would you not also hold, therefore, that your own way may be untrue but that you are convinced that it is true and therefore you will be saved?
('70', 242, 3, 5, 481659) K. But I have studied all religions and have found that mine is the only true
('70', 242, 4, 6, 481737) religion.
('70', 242, 5, 7, 481747) G. But so have others studied other religions.
('70', 242, 5, 8, 481794) What about them?
('70', 242, 5, 9, 481811) Well, I go further and tell you that religion is one and it has several branches which are all equal.
('70', 242, 6, 10, 481913) K. I accept that no religion lacks divine inspiration but all have not the same
('70', 242, 7, 11, 481993) truth, because all have not the same light.
('70', 242, 8, 12, 482037) G. It is an essentially untrue position to take, for a seeker after truth, that he alone is in absolute possession of truth.
('70', 242, 8, 13, 482162) What is happening to the poor astronomers today?
('70', 242, 8, 14, 482211) They are changing their position every day, and there are scientists who impeach even Einstein’s latest theory.
('70', 242, 9, 15, 482323) But I have examined the arguments in favour of other religions.
('70', 242, 10, 16, 482387) G. But it is an intellectual examination.
('70', 242, 10, 17, 482429) You require different scales to weigh spiritual truths.
('70', 242, 10, 18, 482485) Either we are all untrue—quite a logical position to take—but since truth does not come out of untruth it is better to say that we all have truth but not the complete truth.
('70', 242, 10, 19, 482659) For God reveals His truth to instruments that are imperfect.
('70', 242, 10, 20, 482720) Raindrops of purest distilled water become diluted or polluted as soon as they come in contact with mother earth.
('70', 242, 10, 21, 482834) My submission is that your position is arrogant.
('70', 242, 10, 22, 482883) But I suggest to you a better position.
('70', 242, 10, 23, 482923) Accept all religions as equal, for all have the same root and the same laws of growth.
('70', 242, 11, 24, 483010) K. It is necessary to examine every religion philosophically and find out
('70', 242, 12, 25, 483084) which is more harmonious, more perfect.
('70', 242, 13, 26, 483124) G. That presupposes that all religions are in watertight compartments.
('70', 242, 13, 27, 483195) That is wrong.
('70', 242, 13, 28, 483210) They are always growing.
('70', 242, 13, 29, 483235) Let us not limit God’s function.
('70', 242, 13, 30, 483268) He may reveal Himself in a thousand ways and a thousand times.
('70', 243, 0, 1, 483331) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 244
('70', 243, 1, 2, 483373) Now the professor switched on to the next question, viz., that of fighting
('70', 243, 2, 3, 483448) materialism.
('70', 243, 3, 4, 483461) G. It is no use trying to fight these forces without giving up the idea of conversion, which I assure you is the deadliest poison that ever sapped the fountain of truth.
('70', 243, 4, 5, 483631) K. But I have a great respect for your religion.
('70', 243, 5, 6, 483680) G. Not enough.
('70', 243, 5, 7, 483695) I had that feeling myself one day, but I found that it was not enough.
('70', 243, 5, 8, 483766) Unless I accept the position that all religions are equal, and I have as much regard for other religions as I have for my own, I would not be able to live in the boiling war around me.
('70', 243, 5, 9, 483951) Any make believe combination of spiritual forces is doomed to failure if this fundamental position is not accepted.
('70', 243, 5, 10, 484067) I read and get all my inspiration from the Gita.
('70', 243, 5, 11, 484116) But I also read the Bible and the Koran to enrich my own religion.
('70', 243, 5, 12, 484183) I incorporate all that is good in other religions.
('70', 243, 6, 13, 484234) K. That is your goodwill.
('70', 243, 7, 14, 484260) G. That is not enough.
('70', 243, 8, 15, 484283) K. But I have great respect for you.
('70', 243, 9, 16, 484320) G. Not enough.
('70', 243, 9, 17, 484335) If I were to join the Catholic Church you would have greater respect for me.
('70', 243, 10, 18, 484412) K. Oh yes, if you became a Catholic you would be as great as St. Francis.
('70', 243, 11, 19, 484486) G. But not otherwise?
('70', 243, 11, 20, 484508) A Hindu cannot be a St. Francis?
('70', 243, 11, 21, 484541) Poor Hindu!
('70', 243, 12, 22, 484553) K. But may I take your photograph?
('70', 243, 13, 23, 484588) G. No, surely you don’t care for materialism!
('70', 243, 13, 24, 484634) And it is all materialism, isn’t it?
('70', 243, 14, 25, 484671) Harijan, 16 1 1937

('70', 253, 4, 15, 499283) 290. RIGHT TO LIVE
('70', 253, 5, 16, 499302) A correspondent from Greenville, S.C., U.S.A., writes enclosing a clipping from an American newspaper: 1
('70', 253, 6, 17, 499407) The clipping contains an account of my illness of last year and ends.
('70', 253, 7, 18, 499477) The recently powerful spokesman, Gandhi, flying in the face of all modern scientific knowledge and ignoring the tremendous number of human beings slain by such small insects, is reported as having stated in The Times of India, June 1935: “We have no right to take the lives of mosquitoes, flies, lice, rats or fleas.
('70', 253, 7, 19, 499794) They have as much right to live as we.” I am afraid my correspondent cannot have the pleasure of espousing my cause in the manner he proposes.
('70', 253, 7, 20, 499937) For I did make the statement attributed to me, though I qualified it by saying that in the present state of modern ignorance, and especially my own ignorance, I did countenance campaigns of killing rats, fleas, mosquitoes and the like.
('70', 253, 7, 21, 500173) But I do believe that all God’s creatures have the right to live as much as we have.
('70', 253, 7, 22, 500258) Instead of prescribing the killing of the so called
('70', 253, 8, 23, 500310) 1 The letter is not reproduced here.
('70', 253, 8, 24, 500347) The correspondent had expressed his disbelief in the newspaper report of Gandhiji’s views concerning killing of flies and mosquitoes and said if Gandhiji would disavow “such nonsense” he would have the disavowal placed in all the newspapers of America.
('70', 254, 0, 1, 500600) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 255
('70', 254, 1, 2, 500649) injurious fellow creatures of ours as a duty, if men of knowledge had devoted their gift to discovering ways of dealing with them otherwise than by killing them, we would be living in a world befitting our status as men—animals endowed with reason and the power of choosing between good and evil, right and wrong, violence and non violence, truth and untruth.
('70', 254, 1, 3, 501009) I prefer to be called a coward or a fool or worse, to denying for the sake of being considered a wise man what I believe to be a fundamental truth of life.
('70', 254, 1, 4, 501165) Marvellous as the progress of physical sciences undoubtedly is, it only humbles us and enables us to know that we know hardly anything of the mysteries of Nature.
('70', 254, 1, 5, 501328) In the spiritual realm, we make little or no progress.
('70', 254, 1, 6, 501383) The physical has overwhelmed the spiritual in us.
('70', 254, 1, 7, 501433) We hardly like to own the latter’s existence.
('70', 254, 1, 8, 501479) And yet the question of killing and non killing, of man’s relation to his human 1 fellow creatures, belongs to the spiritual realm.
('70', 254, 1, 9, 501611) Its proper solution will surely revolutionize our thoughts, speech and action.
('70', 254, 1, 10, 501690) Both my intellect and heart refuse to believe that the so called noxious life has been created for destruction by man.
('70', 254, 1, 11, 501809) God is good and wise.
('70', 254, 1, 12, 501831) A good and wise God cannot be so bad and so unwise as to create to no purpose.
('70', 254, 1, 13, 501910) It is more conducive to reason to own our ignorance and assume that every form of life has a useful purpose which we must patiently strive to discover.
('70', 254, 1, 14, 502062) I verily believe that man’s habit of killing man on the slightest pretext has darkened his reason and he gives himself liberties with other life which he would shudder to take if he really believed that God is a God of Love and Mercy.
('70', 254, 1, 15, 502297) Anyway, though for fear of death I may kill tigers, snakes, fleas, mosquitoes and the like, I ever pray for illumination that will shed all fear of death and, thus refusing to take life know the better way for “Taught by the Power that pities me I learn to pity them.”
('70', 254, 2, 16, 502566) Harijan, 9 1 1937
('70', 254, 3, 17, 502584) 291. HOW TO UTILIZE ELECTIONS
('70', 254, 4, 18, 502614) It was stated in Faizpur during the Congress Week that there are nearly 3 1 2 crores of voters who will vote for candidates for the provincial legislatures.
('70', 254, 4, 19, 502771) Harijan workers can utilize the occasion of the elections for educating the voters on the question of untouchability
('70', 254, 5, 20, 502888) 1 This should be “sub human”; vide “Notes” sub title “An Important Correction”, 16 1 1937
('70', 255, 0, 1, 502978) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 256
('70', 255, 1, 2, 503020) and of committing the candidates definitely to one side or the other.
('70', 255, 1, 3, 503090) They can be asked for instance these questions: Are you in favour of complete removal of untouchability?
('70', 255, 1, 4, 503195) Are you in favour of removing the legal bar on the grounds of custom and legislation permitting temple authorities to open temples to Harijans where savarna Hindu opinion is ripe for the step?
('70', 255, 1, 5, 503388) Are you in favour of enforcing the common law in the matter of Harijans freely using public wells, schools, and the like?
('70', 255, 1, 6, 503510) A correspondent writes to say that there is a conspiracy of silence among candidates on this question.
('70', 255, 1, 7, 503613) If there is, it can be broken by energetic Harijan workers simply putting at voters’ meetings questions like those I have suggested.
('70', 255, 1, 8, 503746) Enlightened voters interested in the purification of Hinduism can do a great deal to educate and mould pubic opinion in this matter.
('70', 255, 1, 9, 503879) It is a pity that the question of untouchability can at all become an issue between rival candidates or between candidates and electors.
('70', 255, 1, 10, 504016) But pity or no pity, we have to face the facts as they are today.
('70', 255, 2, 11, 504082) Harijan, 9 1 1937
('70', 255, 3, 12, 504100) 292. ‘A HUMBLE VILLAGER OF BIRBHUM’
('70', 255, 4, 13, 504136) ‘A Humble Villager of Birbhum’ living in Santiniketan sends me through Deenabandhu Andrews the following questions: 1. What is an ideal Indian village in your esteemed opinion and how far is it practicable to reconstruct a village on the basis of an ‘Ideal Village’ in the present social and political situation of India?
('70', 255, 4, 14, 504458) 2. Which of the village problems should a worker try to solve first of all and how should he proceed?
('70', 255, 4, 15, 504560) 3. What should be the special theme of village exhibitions and museums in a miniature form?
('70', 255, 4, 16, 504652) How should such exhibitons be best utilized for the reconstruction of villages?
('70', 255, 4, 17, 504732) 1. An ideal Indian village will be so constructed as to lend itself to perfect sanitation.
('70', 255, 4, 18, 504823) It will have cottages with sufficient light and ventilation built of a material obtainable within a radius of five miles of it.
('70', 255, 4, 19, 504951) The cottages will have courtyards enabling householders to plant vegetables for domestic use and to house their cattle.
('70', 255, 4, 20, 505071) The village lanes and streets will be free of all avoidable dust.
('70', 255, 4, 21, 505137) It will have wells according to its needs and accessible to all.
('70', 255, 4, 22, 505202) It will have houses of worship for all; also a common meeting place, a village common for
('70', 256, 0, 1, 505292) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 257
('70', 256, 1, 2, 505341) grazing its cattle, a co operative dairy, primary and secondary schools in which industrial education will be the central fact, and it will have panchayats for settling disputes.
('70', 256, 1, 3, 505520) It will produce its own grains, vegetables and fruit, and its own khadi.
('70', 256, 1, 4, 505593) This is roughly my idea of a model village.
('70', 256, 1, 5, 505637) In the present circumstances its cottages will remain what they are with slight improvements.
('70', 256, 1, 6, 505731) Given a good zamindar, where there is one, or co operation among the people, almost the whole of the programme other than model cottages can be worked out at an expenditure within the means of the villagers including the zamindar or zamindars, without Government assistance.
('70', 256, 1, 7, 506006) With that assistance there is no limit to the possibility of village reconstruction.
('70', 256, 1, 8, 506091) But my task just now is to discover what the villagers can do to help themselves if they have mutual co operation and contribute voluntary labour for the common good.
('70', 256, 1, 9, 506258) I am convinced that they can, under intelligent guidance, double the village income as distinguished from individual income.
('70', 256, 1, 10, 506383) There are in our villages inexhaustible resources not for commercial purposes in every case but certainly for local purposes in almost every case.
('70', 256, 1, 11, 506530) The greatest tragedy is the hopeless unwillingness of the villagers to better their lot.
('70', 256, 1, 12, 506619) 2. The very first problem the village worker will solve is its sanitation.
('70', 256, 1, 13, 506694) It is the most neglected of all the problems that baffle workers and that undermine physical well being and breed disease.
('70', 256, 1, 14, 506817) If the worker became a voluntary Bhangi, he would begin by collecting night soil and turning it into manure and sweeping village streets.
('70', 256, 1, 15, 506955) He will tell people how and where they should perform daily functions and speak to them on the value of sanitation and the great injury caused by the neglect.
('70', 256, 1, 16, 507114) The worker will continue to do the work whether the villagers listen to him or no.
('70', 256, 1, 17, 507197) 3. The spinning wheel should be the central theme of all such village exhibitions and the industries suited to the particular locality should revolve round it.
('70', 256, 1, 18, 507357) An exhibition thus arranged would naturally become an object lesson for the villagers and an educational treat when it is accompanied by demonstrations, lectures and leaflets.
('70', 256, 2, 19, 507533) Harijan, 9 1 1937
('70', 257, 0, 1, 507551) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 258
('70', 257, 1, 2, 507593) 293. NOTES
('70', 257, 2, 3, 507604) THE COW AND THE HARIJAN In my conversations with Dr. Mott, at one stage of it I said, “Would you preach the Gospel to a cow?
('70', 257, 2, 4, 507729) Well, some of the untouchables are worse than cows in understanding.
('70', 257, 2, 5, 507798) I mean they no more distinguish between the relative merits of Islam and Hinduism and Christianity than a cow.” 1 Some Missionary friends have taken exception to the analogy.
('70', 257, 2, 6, 507973) I have no remorse about the propriety of the analogy.
('70', 257, 2, 7, 508027) There could be no offence meant to Harijans because the cow is a sacred animal.
('70', 257, 2, 8, 508107) I worship her as I worship my mother.
('70', 257, 2, 9, 508145) Both are givers of milk.
('70', 257, 2, 10, 508170) And so far as understanding is concerned I do maintain that there are, be it said to the discredit of superior class Hindus, thousands of Harijans who can no more understand the merits and demerits of different religions than a cow.
('70', 257, 2, 11, 508403) That after a long course of training Harijans can have their intelligence developed in a manner a cow’s cannot, is irrelevant to the present discussion.
('70', 257, 3, 12, 508556) A STUDENT’S DIFFICULTY A student asks:
('70', 257, 4, 13, 508595) What should a matriculate or an undergraduate who is unfortunately father of two or three children do in order to procure a living wage, and what should he do when he is forced to marry against his will and before even the age of twenty five?
('70', 257, 4, 14, 508838) The simplest answer that occurs to me is that a student who does not know how to support his wife and children or who marries against his will has studied to no purpose.
('70', 257, 4, 15, 509008) But that is past history for him.
('70', 257, 4, 16, 509042) The perplexed student deserves a helpful answer.
('70', 257, 4, 17, 509091) He does not say what is his requirement.
('70', 257, 4, 18, 509132) If he does not pitch it high because he is a matriculate and will put himself on a level with the ordinary labourer, he should have no difficulty in earning a livelihood.
('70', 257, 4, 19, 509303) His intelligence should help his hands and feet and enable him to do better than the labourer who has not had the opportunity of developing his intelligence.
('70', 257, 4, 20, 509461) This is not to say that a labourer who has never learnt English is devoid of intelligence.
('70', 257, 4, 21, 509552) Unfortunately labour has never been helped to develop the mind, and those who pass through schools do have their minds opened even though under a handicap not to be
('70', 257, 5, 22, 509717) 1 Vide “Discussion with John R. Mott”, 13/14 11 1936
('70', 258, 0, 1, 509770) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 259
('70', 258, 1, 2, 509819) found in any other part of the world.
('70', 258, 1, 3, 509857) Even this mental equipment is counter balanced by false notions of dignity inculcated during school and college days.
('70', 258, 1, 4, 509975) And so students think that they can earn their living only at the desk.
('70', 258, 1, 5, 510047) The inquirer has therefore to realize the dignity of labour and seek the maintenance of himself and his family in that field.
('70', 258, 1, 6, 510173) And there is no reason why his wife should not add to the family income by utilizing her spare hours.
('70', 258, 1, 7, 510275) Similarly if the children are at all able to do any work, they too should be inspanned for productive work.
('70', 258, 1, 8, 510383) The utterly false idea that intelligence can be developed only through book reading should give place to the truth that the quickest development of the mind can be achieved by artisan’s work being learnt in a scientific manner.
('70', 258, 1, 9, 510611) True development of the mind commences immediately the apprentice is taught at every step why a particular manipulation of the hand or a tool is required.
('70', 258, 1, 10, 510766) The problem of the unemployment of students can be solved without difficulty if they will rank themselves among the common labourers.
('70', 258, 1, 11, 510900) As for marriage against one’s will, all I can say is that students should develop sufficient strength of purpose to resist any marriage that is sought to be forced on them.
('70', 258, 1, 12, 511073) Students should learn the art of standing alone and resisting in every legitimate manner any attempt to force them to do anything against their will much more so to marry against their will.
('70', 258, 2, 13, 511264) Harijan, 9 1 1937

('70', 259, 10, 22, 512642) 297. LETTER TO JAI SINGH [Before January 10, 1937] 1
('70', 259, 11, 23, 512695) If Sikhism is a part of Hindu culture, as I believe it is, what is the meaning of change of faith and name?
('70', 259, 11, 24, 512803) If Sikhism is not part and product of Hinduism you are simply creating a conflict among the Harijans without achieving any noble purpose.
('70', 259, 12, 25, 512941) The Bombay Chronicle, 12 1 1937
('70', 259, 13, 26, 512973) 1 The report in the source is dated January 10.
('70', 260, 0, 1, 513021) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 261
('70', 260, 1, 2, 513070) 298. INTERVIEW TO PROF.
('70', 260, 2, 3, 513094) [Before January 10, 1937] 2
('70', 260, 3, 4, 513122) GANDHIJI: Passive resistance is a misnomer for non violent resis tance.
('70', 260, 3, 5, 513194) It is much more active than violent resistance.
('70', 260, 3, 6, 513242) It is direct, ceaseless, but three fourths invisible and only one fourth visible.
('70', 260, 3, 7, 513324) In its visibility it seems to be ineffective, e.g., the spinning wheel which I have called the symbol of non violence.
('70', 260, 3, 8, 513443) In its visibility it appears ineffective, but it is really intensely active and most effective in ultimate result.
('70', 260, 3, 9, 513558) This knowledge enables me to detect flaws in the way in which the votaries of non violence are doing their spinning.
('70', 260, 3, 10, 513675) I ask for more vigilance and more untiredness.
('70', 260, 3, 11, 513722) Non violence is an intensely active force when properly understood and used.
('70', 260, 3, 12, 513799) A violent man’s activity is most visible while it lasts.
('70', 260, 3, 13, 513856) But it is always transitory.
('70', 260, 3, 14, 513885) What can be more visible than the Abyssinians done to death by Italians?
('70', 260, 3, 15, 513958) There it was lesser violence pitted against much greater.
('70', 260, 3, 16, 514016) But if the Abyssinians had retired from the field and allowed themselves to be slaughtered, their seeming inactivity would have been much more effective though not for the moment visible.
('70', 260, 3, 17, 514204) Hitler and Mussolini on the one hand and Stalin on the other are able to show the immediate effectiveness of violence.
('70', 260, 3, 18, 514323) But it will be as transitory as that of Jhenghis’s slaughter.
('70', 260, 3, 19, 514385) But the effects of Buddha’s non violent action persist and are likely to grow with age.
('70', 260, 3, 20, 514473) And the more it is practised, the more effective and inexhaustible it becomes, and ultimately the whole world stands agape and exclaims, ‘a miracle has happened’.
('70', 260, 3, 21, 514636) All miracles are due to the silent and effective working of invisible forces.
('70', 260, 3, 22, 514714) Non violence is the most invisible and the most effective.
('70', 260, 4, 23, 514773) MAYS: I have no doubt in my mind about the superiority of non violence but the thing that bothers me is about its exercise on a large scale, the difficulty of so disciplining the mass mind on the point of love.
('70', 260, 4, 24, 514984) It is easier to discipline individuals.
('70', 260, 4, 25, 515024) What should be the strategy when they break out?
('70', 260, 4, 26, 515073) Do we retreat or do we go on?
('70', 260, 5, 27, 515103) GANDHIJI: I have had that experience in the course of our movement here.
('70', 260, 5, 28, 515176) Pepole do not gain the training by preaching.
('70', 260, 6, 29, 515222) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “A Discourse on Non violence”.
('70', 260, 6, 30, 515286) Mays was an American Negro who had come to India along with Dr. Tobias to attend the World’s Meeting of the Committees of Y.M.C.A. 2 According to Mahadev Desai, this interview took place before the meeting with Dr. Tobias; vide “Interview to Dr. Tobias”, 10 1 1937
('70', 261, 0, 1, 515551) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 262
('70', 261, 1, 2, 515593) violence cannot be preached.
('70', 261, 1, 3, 515622) It has to be practised.
('70', 261, 1, 4, 515646) The practice of violence can be taught to people by outward symbols.
('70', 261, 1, 5, 515715) You shoot at boards, then at targets, then at beasts.
('70', 261, 1, 6, 515769) Then you are passed as an expert in the art of destruction.
('70', 261, 1, 7, 515829) The non violent man has no outward weapon and, therefore, not only his speech but his action also seems ineffective.
('70', 261, 1, 8, 515946) I may say all kinds of sweet words to you without meaning them.
('70', 261, 1, 9, 516010) On the other hand I may have real love in me and yet my outward expression may be forbidding.
('70', 261, 1, 10, 516104) Then outwardly my action in both cases may be the same and yet the effect may be different.
('70', 261, 1, 11, 516196) For the effect of our action is often more potent when it is not patently known.
('70', 261, 1, 12, 516277) Thus the unconscious effect you are making on me I may never know.
('70', 261, 1, 13, 516344) It is, nevertheless, infinitely greater than the conscious effect.
('70', 261, 1, 14, 516411) In violence there is nothing invisible.
('70', 261, 1, 15, 516451) Non violence, on the other hand, is three fourths invisible, so the effect is in the inverse ratio to its invisibility.
('70', 261, 1, 16, 516571) Non violence, when it becomes active, travels with extraordinary velocity, and then it becomes a miracle.
('70', 261, 1, 17, 516677) So the mass mind is affected first unconsciously, then consciously.
('70', 261, 1, 18, 516745) When it becomes consciously affected there is demostrable victory.
('70', 261, 1, 19, 516812) In my own experience, when people seemed to be weakening there was no consciousness of defeat in me.
('70', 261, 1, 20, 516913) Thus I was fuller of hope in the efficacy of non violence after the renunciation of Civil Disobedience in 1922, and today I continue to be in the same hopeful mood.
('70', 261, 1, 21, 517078) It is not a mere emotional thing.
('70', 261, 1, 22, 517112) Supposing I saw no signs of dawn coming I should not lose faith.
('70', 261, 1, 23, 517177) Everything has to come in its proper time.
('70', 261, 1, 24, 517220) I have discussions here with my co workers about the scavenging work we are doing.
('70', 261, 1, 25, 517303) ‘Why can’t we do it after swaraj?
('70', 261, 1, 26, 517337) they say.
('70', 261, 1, 27, 517347) ‘We may do it better after swaraj’.
('70', 261, 1, 28, 517383) I say to them, ‘No.
('70', 261, 1, 29, 517403) The reform has to come today, it must not wait for swaraj; in fact the right type of swaraj will come only out of such work.’ Now I cannot show you, as perhaps I cannot show some of my co workers, the connection between swaraj and scavenging.
('70', 261, 1, 30, 517646) If I have to win swaraj non violently I must discipline my people.
('70', 261, 1, 31, 517713) The maimed and the blind and the leprous cannot join the army of violence.
('70', 261, 1, 32, 517788) There is also an age limit for serving in the army.
('70', 261, 1, 33, 517840) For a non violent struggle there is no age limit; the blind and the maimed and the bed ridden may serve, and not only men but women also.
('70', 261, 1, 34, 517978) When the spirit of non violence pervades the people and actually begins to work, its effect is visible to all.
('70', 261, 1, 35, 518089) But now comes your poser.
('70', 261, 1, 36, 518115) There are people, you say, who do not believe in non violence as you do.
('70', 261, 1, 37, 518188) Are you to sit quiet?
('70', 262, 0, 1, 518210) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 263
('70', 262, 1, 2, 518259) friends ask: ‘If not now, when will you act?’ I say in reply: “I may not succeed in my lifetime, but my faith that victory can only come through non violence is stronger than ever.
('70', 262, 1, 3, 518440) When I spoke on the cult of the spinning wheel at Faizpur, a newspaper correspondent imputed astuteness to me.
('70', 262, 1, 4, 518551) Nothing could be further from my mind.
('70', 262, 1, 5, 518590) When I came to Segaon I was told the people might not co operate and might even boycott me.
('70', 262, 1, 6, 518682) I said: ‘That may be.
('70', 262, 1, 7, 518704) But this is the way non violence works.
('70', 262, 1, 8, 518744) If I go to a village which is still farther off, the experiment may work better.
('70', 262, 1, 9, 518825) This thing has come in my search after the technique of non violence.
('70', 262, 1, 10, 518895) And each day that passes makes my faith brighter.
('70', 262, 1, 11, 518945) I have come here to bring that faith to fruition and to die in the process if that is God’s will.
('70', 262, 1, 12, 519043) Non violence to be worth anything has to work in the face of hostile forces.
('70', 262, 1, 13, 519120) But there may be action in inaction.
('70', 262, 1, 14, 519157) And action may be worse than inaction.
('70', 262, 2, 15, 519196) MAYS: Is it ever possible to administer violence in a spirit of love?
('70', 262, 3, 16, 519266) I shall give you an illustration from my own experiment.
('70', 262, 3, 17, 519323) A calf was lame and had developed terrible sores; he could not eat and breathed with difficulty.
('70', 262, 3, 18, 519420) After three days’ argument with myself and my co workers I put an end to its life.
('70', 262, 3, 19, 519503) 1 Now that action was non violent because it was wholly unselfish, inasmuch as the sole purpose was to achieve the calf’s relief from pain.
('70', 262, 3, 20, 519643) Some people have called this an act of violence.
('70', 262, 3, 21, 519692) I have called it a surgical operation.
('70', 262, 3, 22, 519731) I should do exactly the same thing with my child, if he were in the same predicament.
('70', 262, 3, 23, 519817) My point is that non violence as the supreme law of our being ceases to be such the moment you talk of exceptions.
('70', 262, 4, 24, 519932) MAYS: How is a minority to act against an overwhelming majority?
('70', 262, 5, 25, 519997) G. I would say that a minority can do much more in the way of non violence then a majority.
('70', 262, 5, 26, 520089) I had an English friend called Symonds.
('70', 262, 5, 27, 520129) He used to say: ‘I am with you so long as you are in a minority.
('70', 262, 5, 28, 520194) After you are in a majority we are quits.’ I had less diffidence in handling my minority in South Africa than I had here in handling a majority.
('70', 262, 5, 29, 520339) But it would be wholly wrong therefore to say that non violence is a weapon of the weak.
('70', 262, 5, 30, 520428) The use of non violence requires greater bravery than that of violence.
('70', 262, 5, 31, 520500) When Daniel defied the laws of the Meads and Persians, his action was non violent.
('70', 262, 6, 32, 520583) 1 For a fuller account of the episode, vide “The Fiery Ordeal”, 4 10 1928
('70', 263, 0, 1, 520657) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 264
('70', 263, 1, 2, 520699) MAYS: Should the thought of consequences that might accrue to the enemy as a result of your non violence at all constrain you?
('70', 263, 2, 3, 520826) G. Certainly.
('70', 263, 2, 4, 520840) You may have to suspend your movement as I did in South Africa when the Government was faced with the revolt of European labour.
('70', 263, 2, 5, 520969) The latter asked me to make common cause with them.
('70', 263, 2, 6, 521021) I said ‘no’.
('70', 263, 3, 7, 521034) MAYS: And non violence will never rebound on you, whereas violence will be self destroyed?
('70', 263, 3, 8, 521125) G. Yes.
('70', 263, 3, 9, 521133) Violence must beget violence.
('70', 263, 3, 10, 521163) But let me tell you that here too my argument has been countered by a great man who said: ‘Look at the history on non violence.
('70', 263, 3, 11, 521291) Jesus died on the Cross, but his followers shed blood.’ This proves nothing.
('70', 263, 3, 12, 521368) We have no data before us to pass judgement.
('70', 263, 3, 13, 521413) We do not know the whole of the life of Jesus.
('70', 263, 3, 14, 521460) The followers perhaps had not imbibed fully the message of non violence.
('70', 263, 3, 15, 521533) But I must warn you against carrying the impression with you that mine is the final word on non violence.
('70', 263, 3, 16, 521639) I know my own limitations.
('70', 263, 3, 17, 521666) I am but a humble seeker after truth.
('70', 263, 3, 18, 521704) And all I claim is that every experiment of mine has deepened my faith in non violence as the greatest force at the disposal of mankind.
('70', 263, 3, 19, 521841) Its use is not restricted to individuals merely but it can be practised on a mass scale.
('70', 263, 4, 20, 521930) Harijan, 20 3 1937
('70', 263, 5, 21, 521949) 299. THE NEXT CONGRESS SESSION
('70', 263, 6, 22, 521980) Perhaps at the moment it is too early and not proper to write anything about the next Congress session.
('70', 263, 6, 23, 522084) This, however, holds good only if one wishes to write about political matters; that is because politics is constantly changing.
('70', 263, 6, 24, 522212) But I wish to write about the manner in which a rural session of the Congress should be held.
('70', 263, 6, 25, 522306) That is a subject which may be discussed at any time, and preparations should begin from today.
('70', 263, 6, 26, 522402) There is no doubt that the success of the Faizpur Congress has surpassed everyone’s expectations.
('70', 263, 6, 27, 522500) Despite this, the unavoidable drawbacks from which it suffered should and can be remedied in the future.
('70', 263, 6, 28, 522605) No one can be held reponsible for some of the things which were found at Faizpur.
('70', 263, 6, 29, 522687) No one had expected people would come in such large numbers.
('70', 263, 6, 30, 522748) At no other session of the Congress were volunteers made to work as hard as at this session.
('70', 263, 6, 31, 522841) Hence, it may be said that at Faizpur, the ship of the Congress had to be steered through an uncharted sea.
('70', 263, 6, 32, 522949) I give below a few improvements which I feel are necessary as a result of my experiences at Faizpur.
('70', 264, 0, 1, 523050) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 265
('70', 264, 1, 2, 523099) 1. It does not matter how small the village is.
('70', 264, 1, 3, 523147) It should not be more than seven miles from the nearest railway station.
('70', 264, 1, 4, 523220) 2. The necessary site should be obtained free.
('70', 264, 1, 5, 523267) 3. The village must co operate.
('70', 264, 1, 6, 523299) 4. The soil should not be black as at Faizpur, but sandy, capable of soaking up water quickly.
('70', 264, 1, 7, 523394) 5. Water should be provided in sufficient quantity and at various places.
('70', 264, 1, 8, 523468) 6. There should be an adequate number of latrines and urinals at various convenient spots.
('70', 264, 1, 9, 523559) 7. At various places, posters in Gujarati, Hindi, Tamil, Telugu, Urdu and other languages, written in a bold hand, should be put up, saying: “Please use for latrines and urinals only the places provided”.
('70', 264, 1, 10, 523764) The roads should bear names or numbers, preferably the latter.
('70', 264, 1, 11, 523827) Bhangi volunteers should be in attendance on all the roads.
('70', 264, 1, 12, 523887) They should have a map of the Congress Nagar and should constantly guide the visitors.
('70', 264, 1, 13, 523974) They should also have brooms, buckets and small shovels.
('70', 264, 1, 14, 524031) If anyone urinates or defecates outside the urinals or latrines these volunteers should warn him, and remove the filth immediately and dispose of it.
('70', 264, 1, 15, 524181) A Bhangi should be in attendance at each urinal and latrine, whose duty should be to clean these up after they have been used.
('70', 264, 1, 16, 524308) Buckets and shovels made of tin may serve the purpose.
('70', 264, 1, 17, 524363) These are inexpensive and may be used even later.
('70', 264, 1, 18, 524413) If shovels are shaped like winnows they would be cheap and easy to use.
('70', 264, 1, 19, 524485) 8. There must be a good and well built hospital attached to the Congress Nagar.
('70', 264, 1, 20, 524565) It is necessary that it should have walls of unbaked bricks and a tiled roof.
('70', 264, 1, 21, 524643) It should accommodate at least twenty beds with a separate wing for women.
('70', 264, 1, 22, 524718) 9. There should not be one but several kitchens.
('70', 264, 1, 23, 524767) Things should become much easier if selected cooks are engaged.
('70', 264, 1, 24, 524831) It would facilitate matters to have blocks which would accommodate a hundred persons each for meals.
('70', 264, 1, 25, 524932) There should be separate charges for those who have their meals in the blocks and those who prefer to carry their meals away.
('70', 264, 1, 26, 525058) The menu should be simple and such as to suit all the provinces.
('70', 264, 1, 27, 525123) It is necessary to abandon the temptation to serve meals to a large number of people in one place.
('70', 264, 1, 28, 525222) Everyone must have his meal served in his own utensils.
('70', 264, 1, 29, 525278) It is never possible to make arrangements for serving thousands of people at any one place at the same time.
('70', 265, 0, 1, 525387) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 266
('70', 265, 1, 2, 525429) 10. At Faizpur, it was practically impossible to procure cow’s milk and cow’s ghee.
('70', 265, 1, 3, 525513) I think that even from the economic point of view, at Congress gatherings, if not elsewhere , we must make it a rule to use only cow’s milk.
('70', 265, 1, 4, 525654) It is no simple matter to provide cow’s milk to thousands of persons.
('70', 265, 1, 5, 525724) This task can be accomplished if preparations are taken in hand right from today.
('70', 265, 1, 6, 525806) 11. Flour, rice, etc., must be ground and pounded in the Congress Nagar itself.
('70', 265, 1, 7, 525886) 12. The Faizpur exhibition, to my mind, was the best held so far.
('70', 265, 1, 8, 525952) Its success was clearly evident and yet there is scope for improvement.
('70', 265, 1, 9, 526024) These are the principal points which occur to me at the moment.
('70', 265, 1, 10, 526088) Two changes seem to be necessary.
('70', 265, 1, 11, 526122) Under the new constitution, the Working Committee and the A.I.C.C. meet before the Congress session.
('70', 265, 1, 12, 526223) Taking advantage of this, other meetings are also held before the opening session of the Congress.
('70', 265, 1, 13, 526322) This is not proper.
('70', 265, 1, 14, 526342) It puts an unnecessary burden on the Reception Committee and lengthens the period of the session from three to ten days.
('70', 265, 1, 15, 526463) Either all meetings before the Congress session should be stopped or preparations should be made beforehand for a rush of people lasting ten days.
('70', 265, 1, 16, 526610) And if the Congress is to meet in a village only, it should not meet in December.
('70', 265, 1, 17, 526692) There is very little substance in the plea that the Congress session must be held towards the end of December because railway fare concessions are available during Christmas week and the Assembly has a holiday.
('70', 265, 1, 18, 526903) There is a much stronger case for holding the Congress session after the winter is over, for it suits the convenience of the lakhs of people who attend it.
('70', 265, 1, 19, 527059) I feel that the inconvenience suffered by people in winter, farmers being busy with the harvest in December and the difficulty of getting a large area of open ground on account of the standing crops are three difficulties which cancel out the two advantages.
('70', 265, 1, 20, 527318) I believe that the number of persons who came to Faizpur on foot from surrounding areas far exceeded the number who spent money on railway fare to come there.
('70', 265, 1, 21, 527477) Religious fairs such as Kumbh, Magh, etc., are not regulated by such considerations as railway fare concessions.
('70', 265, 1, 22, 527590) Regardless of whether these are available or not, these fairs are held at the appointed time and are attended by millions.
('70', 265, 1, 23, 527713) The Congress session should not be a lesser attraction than these.
