('70', 266, 1, 2, 527870) 300. VAGUE LANGUAGE
('70', 266, 2, 3, 527890) A gentleman who is a careful reader of Harijanbandhu likes my article “Hindu Code of Conduct” 1 in its issue of December 27, but he is not satisfied with clause 14 therein.
('70', 266, 2, 4, 528063) That clause is as follows:
('70', 266, 3, 5, 528090) We certainly would not like anyone to abuse us or beat us or misbehave with our mother or sisters.
('70', 266, 3, 6, 528189) Hence, we should not abuse anyone, not even our wives and children.
('70', 266, 3, 7, 528257) Many of the clauses of this article are interrelated.
('70', 266, 3, 8, 528311) Clause 14 has a bearing on clauses 15, 16 and 17. If read along with these clauses the implication of clause 14 becomes clear.
('70', 266, 3, 9, 528438) Despite this, I must admit that one is likely to get confused if one reads clause 14 by itself.
('70', 266, 3, 10, 528534) I regard its language as vague and inelegant.
('70', 266, 3, 11, 528580) On rereading it I find that its clarity of meaning is lost because I have overburdened it.
('70', 266, 3, 12, 528671) Clauses 15, 16 and 17 have been written to clarify what is contained in clause 14. In order to relieve the burden on clause 14 and for the sake of clarity of thought and language, I write clauses 14, 15 and 17 as follows.
('70', 266, 3, 13, 528893) There is no scope for improvement in clause 16. 14. If anyone abused us or beat us, we would not like it.
('70', 266, 3, 14, 528999) Why then should we abuse others or beat them?
('70', 266, 3, 15, 529045) 15. We cannot abuse our wives and children if we do not abuse others.
('70', 266, 3, 16, 529115) Many men regard their wives and children as their property.
('70', 266, 3, 17, 529175) This is a grave error.
('70', 266, 3, 18, 529198) In our religion, the wife has been regarded as the equal of the husband.
('70', 266, 3, 19, 529271) It is for this reason that she is known as ardhangini and also as sahadharmini.
('70', 266, 3, 20, 529351) She is addressed as devi.
('70', 266, 3, 21, 529377) 2 Parents are the protectors of the children.
('70', 266, 3, 22, 529423) Hence they should be gentle, tolerant, and patient towards them also.
('70', 266, 3, 23, 529493) 17. We shall not tolerate anyone misbehaving with our wife or mother or sister.
('70', 266, 3, 24, 529573) How then can we misbehave with anyone else’s wife?
('70', 266, 3, 25, 529624) To cast a lustful glance at a woman, to pass obscene remarks about her, to touch her with wicked intention—all this would be regarded as misconduct.
('70', 266, 3, 26, 529773) All women except one’s wife are one’s mothers and sisters.

('70', 268, 1, 2, 531558) 303. INTERVIEW TO DR.
('70', 268, 1, 3, 531580) TOBIAS 1
('70', 268, 2, 4, 531589) [January 10, 1937] 2
('70', 268, 3, 5, 531610) TOBIAS: Your doctrine of non violence has profoundly influenced my life.
('70', 268, 3, 6, 531683) Do you believe in it as strongly as ever?
('70', 268, 4, 7, 531725) GANDHIJI: I do indeed.
('70', 268, 4, 8, 531748) My faith in it is growing.
('70', 268, 5, 9, 531775) Negroes in U.S.A. —12 million—are struggling to obtain such fundamental rights as freedom from mob violence, unrestricted use of the ballot, freedom from segregation, etc.
('70', 268, 5, 10, 531947) Have you, out of your struggle in India, a word of advice and encouragement to give us?
('70', 268, 5, 11, 532035) I had to contend against some such thing, though on a much smaller scale, in South Africa.
('70', 268, 5, 12, 532126) The difficulties are not yet over.
('70', 268, 5, 13, 532161) All I can say is that there is no other way than the way of non violence, a way, however, not of the weak and ignorant but of the strong and wise.
('70', 268, 6, 14, 532308) Travancore indicates that your full identification with the untouchables is bearing fruit.
('70', 268, 6, 15, 532399) 3 Do you think Travancore’s example will be followed by other States in the near future?
('70', 268, 6, 16, 532488) I shall be surprised if it is not.
('70', 268, 7, 17, 532523) What word shall I give my Negro brethren as to the outlook for the future?
('70', 268, 7, 18, 532598) With right which is on their side and the choice of non violence as their only weapon, if they will make it such, a bright future is assured.

('70', 271, 5, 8, 536996) As you have in your address very properly said, this is not my first visit to Travancore or its capital Trivandrum.
('70', 271, 5, 9, 537112) Every time I have come to Travancore, I have come almost as a crusader trying to wean savarna Hindus from the curse of untouchability.
('70', 271, 5, 10, 537247) I have had many occasions to address savarna Hindus and avarna Hindus, miscalled untouchables or depressed classes, also on this subject.
('70', 271, 5, 11, 537385) This time, however, I have come as a humble pilgrim to tender my congra tulations to H.H. the Maharaja and his good mother Her Highness the Maharani and his able Dewan.
('70', 271, 5, 12, 537554) With the co operation of this trinity, if I might so describe the distinguished persons, the great Proclamation has been a settled fact and has now been working with success.
('70', 271, 5, 13, 537729) The temples have been sealed to me so far, perhaps voluntarily, and I do not know that if I had made the attempt to enter them I should not have been thrown out of them.
('70', 271, 5, 14, 537899) But even if I had the liberty, having made common cause with the Harijans I could not avail myself of it.
('70', 271, 5, 15, 538005) But now that the doors have been flung open to the Harijans also, I shall for the first time take the opportunity of entering your beautiful temple.
('70', 271, 5, 16, 538154) I take your address as a token of your goodwill.
('70', 271, 5, 17, 538203) I shall have several occasions to speak on the great act of the Maharaja, and I shall therefore refrain from making anything like a speech here.

('70', 271, 5, 19, 538430) Rajas and Maharajas can make good laws, but they cannot make the people give proper effect to them.
('70', 271, 5, 20, 538530) Even tyrants cannot control the hearts of those over whom they hold sway.
('70', 271, 5, 21, 538604) It all depends on your hearts to give proper effect to the Proclamation.

('70', 283, 1, 7, 565840) But if you want to make the experiment you can make it.
('70', 283, 1, 8, 565896) The question of money does not weigh with me.
('70', 283, 1, 9, 565942) It is that of postponing the progress of the boys under training.
('70', 283, 1, 10, 566008) The highest speed has been attained on the flat thing.
('70', 283, 1, 11, 566063) The vertical is cumbersome.
('70', 283, 1, 12, 566091) Remember you are training boys who are unused to any spinning.
('70', 283, 1, 13, 566154) If I were you, I should make them as fit as they can be on the wheel which has proved its worth as the best all round charkha.

('70', 283, 6, 17, 566441) 318. TRAVANCORE PILGRIMAGE
('70', 283, 7, 18, 566468) [January 15, 1937] 1
('70', 283, 8, 19, 566489) I am writing this at the Cape in front of the sea where three waters meet and furnish a sight unequalled in the world.
('70', 283, 8, 20, 566608) For this is no port of call for vessels.
('70', 283, 8, 21, 566649) Like the goddess the waters around are virgin.
('70', 283, 8, 22, 566696) The Cape has no population worth the name.
('70', 283, 8, 23, 566739) The place is therefore eminently fitted for contemplation.
('70', 283, 8, 24, 566798) This is the third day of the pilgrimage.
('70', 283, 8, 25, 566839) Having mentally and voluntarily become an untouchable and therefore shunned the temples which were barred against fellow untouchables, I feel like them the joy of the removal of the bar.
('70', 283, 8, 26, 567026) I approached the great temple in Trivandrum with awe and due veneration.
('70', 283, 8, 27, 567099) Curiosity had given way to the incoming of something that was to fill the void of years.
('70', 283, 8, 28, 567188) As I write these lines I am reminded of the peace I felt in the Cathedral in Madras to which Bishop Whitehead had taken me now over twenty years ago.
('70', 283, 8, 29, 567338) In that Cathedral on the particular morning, so far as I remember, we were the only two persons present.
('70', 283, 8, 30, 567443) In the Trivandrum Temple there were thousands awaiting the arrival of my party.
('70', 283, 8, 31, 567523) But there was no noise, no bustle.
('70', 283, 8, 32, 567558) Untouchables of yesterday were in the silent concourse in perhaps
('70', 283, 9, 33, 567624) 1 Gandhiji was at Cape Comorin on this date,
('70', 284, 0, 1, 567669) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 285
('70', 284, 1, 2, 567718) equal numbers.
('70', 284, 1, 3, 567733) I could not distinguish between the two.
('70', 284, 1, 4, 567774) All had almost the same marks on their bodies, all had the same kind of garments.
('70', 284, 1, 5, 567856) Evidently the custom is to have only seamless wear which need not be more than a lungi, never more than a wrapper added to it.
('70', 284, 1, 6, 567983) The majority, including the priests, were bare bodied.
('70', 284, 1, 7, 568038) In the midst of this vast assemblage, I seemed to enjoy the kind of peace I had felt in the Madras Cathedral.
('70', 284, 1, 8, 568148) And yet the two were quite different.
('70', 284, 1, 9, 568186) The Madras peace had no background.
('70', 284, 1, 10, 568222) This the Padmanabha Temple had.
('70', 284, 1, 11, 568254) And I would not have experienced it if the crowd had been boisterous or at all in a non spiritual mood.
('70', 284, 1, 12, 568358) All those bare bodies in spotlessly white lungis standing row upon row in perfectly silent and reverent attitude produced an impression upon me which will endure till life lasts.
('70', 284, 1, 13, 568537) The entry into the very spacious temple, crowded with images which the guiding priest in his choice Hindi made almost to speak, was no less soul stirring.
('70', 284, 1, 14, 568692) Then we reached the great central image.
('70', 284, 1, 15, 568733) It was all like a day dream.
('70', 284, 1, 16, 568762) The knowledge that I was visiting the temple designed specially for the Maharajas of Travancore and that too in the company of the hitherto despised untouchables, heightened the effect which the images and the surroundings had produced upon me.
('70', 284, 1, 17, 569007) The silence and the attitude of worship have continued at the three temples I visited between Trivandrum and the Cape.
('70', 284, 1, 18, 569126) And this morning I visited the famous temple at the Cape, dedicated to the Virgin.
('70', 284, 1, 19, 569209) Accompained by a large party of Harijans who were singing bhajans, we passed through the street leading to the temple.
('70', 284, 1, 20, 569328) The street like the temple was forbidden to the untouchables.
('70', 284, 1, 21, 569390) But now, without any opposition from anywhere, we walked through it and then into the temple as if we had never been prohibited.
('70', 284, 1, 22, 569519) It is a dream realized in a manner and in a place where the realization seemed almost unthinkable before it was realized elsewhere.
('70', 284, 1, 23, 569651) “You may have temples opened in the North, but you will never succeed in having them opened in Cochin and Travancore—the citadels of orthodoxy,” I used to be told before.
('70', 284, 1, 24, 569822) Now one citadel has yielded with rare generosity and grace.
('70', 284, 1, 25, 569882) The genuineness of the generosity and grace seems to have disarmed all opposition.
('70', 284, 1, 26, 569965) The legend attached to the acts of the Maharajas of Travancore had perhaps its due share in the conversion of the people.
('70', 284, 1, 27, 570087) The Maharajas are called ‘Padmanabhadas’, meaning servants of Padmanabha, i.e., God.
('70', 284, 1, 28, 570172) The Maharajas are supposed to visit the temple every morning (and I understand they do whilst in Trivandrum) and receive instructions for the day’s work from God.
('70', 284, 1, 29, 570335) The Proclamation is therefore an act of God through His servant the present Maharaja.
('70', 284, 1, 30, 570421) Whatever may be the cause, the fact of the Proclamation being given effect to by an overwhelming number of savarnas and being availed of by avarnas stands out as a miracle.
('70', 285, 0, 1, 570594) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 286
('70', 285, 1, 2, 570636) But the very miracle weighs me down with a sense of responsibility which chastens me and affects my elation.
('70', 285, 1, 3, 570745) If what is going on today is to be consolidated, there must be continued effort by all true Harijan workers for the education of both savarnas and avarnas on the meaning of the Proclamation.
('70', 285, 1, 4, 570936) But a few months ago it was the fashion on the part of savarnas to say that avarnas did not want temple entry.
('70', 285, 1, 5, 571047) It was equally the fashion on the part of some vocal members among the avarnas to say that they did not care for temple entry and that they cared only for economic uplift.
('70', 285, 1, 6, 571219) Both mistook the meaning of the anti untouchability campaign.
('70', 285, 1, 7, 571281) The Travancore experience has opened their eyes.
('70', 285, 1, 8, 571330) The right of entering temples abolishes untouchability at a stroke—untouchability that prevented a large section of Hindus from sharing with the rest the privilege of worship in the same manner as the latter.
('70', 285, 1, 9, 571539) Economic uplift was there.
('70', 285, 1, 10, 571566) But the best among the avarnas felt the sting of the deprivation.
('70', 285, 1, 11, 571632) It soured them and angered them against the haughty savarnas.
('70', 285, 1, 12, 571694) Now all that has changed.
('70', 285, 1, 13, 571720) The avarnas feel the glow of freedom which they had never felt before.
('70', 285, 1, 14, 571791) All this marvellous result may easily be nullified if it is not followed up to its logical conclusion.
('70', 285, 1, 15, 571894) Before avarnas can forget the past, they must be made conscious of what they have come to.
('70', 285, 1, 16, 571985) The message of freedom must be carried to the humblest hut.
('70', 285, 1, 17, 572045) The minds of the Pulayas and the Pariahs should be opened to the implications of the suddenly acquired freedom.
('70', 285, 1, 18, 572157) This does not need an elaborate programme of literacy.
('70', 285, 1, 19, 572212) That must come.
('70', 285, 1, 20, 572228) But what is needed is immediate human contact.
('70', 285, 1, 21, 572275) For this an army of volunteer workers of the right type is needed.
('70', 285, 1, 22, 572342) And just as the message of freedom has to be taken to the avarna huts, so has it to be taken to the savarna homes.
('70', 285, 1, 23, 572457) Then there is the question of reform of temples from within.
('70', 285, 1, 24, 572518) Here I cannot do better than quote from a long letter from a Mussalman friend who believes in Hinduism as much as he believes in Islam:
('70', 285, 2, 25, 572654) You will soon be going to Travancore to celebrate the entry of Harijans into the temples thrown open to them.
('70', 285, 2, 26, 572764) It is indeed a step forward.
('70', 285, 2, 27, 572793) But what we need most is the restoration of the temples to their pristine purity and sanctity.
('70', 285, 2, 28, 572888) The ideal thing behind temples is most holy.
('70', 285, 2, 29, 572933) In the temples of ancient India resided great rishis who imparted divine wisdom.
('70', 285, 2, 30, 573014) Today the priest sit there barring the way to those who need instruction and help to solve the problems of life.
('70', 285, 2, 31, 573127) the priests of all religions are more in need of instruction than the poor masses.
('70', 285, 2, 32, 573210) These words are true.
('70', 285, 2, 33, 573232) Never was the need for temple reform more urgent than today.
('70', 285, 2, 34, 573293) Fortunately in Travancore the vast majority
('70', 286, 0, 1, 573337) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 287
('70', 286, 1, 2, 573386) of temples belong to the State and are under special management.
('70', 286, 1, 3, 573451) They are kept clean and often undergo improvement and addition.
('70', 286, 1, 4, 573515) They are never empty.
('70', 286, 1, 5, 573537) They supply a felt want.
('70', 286, 1, 6, 573562) If the priests had better education and would be custodians of the spirituality of the people, the temples would be houses both of worship and spiritual instruction as they were before.

('70', 287, 1, 2, 575274) 321. WHAT IS KHADI SCIENCE?
('70', 287, 2, 3, 575302) I have often said that if khadi is a sound economic proposition it is also a science and a romance.
('70', 287, 2, 4, 575402) I believe there is a book called The Romance of Cotton wherein the origin of cotton has been traced and an attempt made to show how its discovery altered the course of civilization.
('70', 287, 2, 5, 575584) Everything can be turned into a science or a romance if there is a scientific or a romantic spirit behind it.
('70', 287, 2, 6, 575694) Some people scoff at khadi and betray signs of impatience or disgust when one talks of hand spinning.
('70', 287, 2, 7, 575796) But it ceases to be an object of disgust or ridicule immediately you attribute to it the power of removing India wide idleness, unemployment and consequent pauperism.
('70', 287, 2, 8, 575963) It need not be, as a matter of fact, a panacea for the three ills.
('70', 287, 2, 9, 576030) To be absorbingly interesting, the mere honest attributing of the power is enough.
('70', 287, 2, 10, 576113) But you cannot attribute that potency to khadi and pursue it, as some do, in the manner of an ignorant needy artisan who gins, cards, spins or weaves because he must for his bread.
('70', 287, 2, 11, 576294) A believer in its potency will pursue it in a deliberate, wise, methodical manner and in a scientific spirit, taking nothing for granted, testing every proposition, checking facts and figures, undaunted by defeats, unelated by petty successes, never satisfied till the goal is reached.
('70', 287, 2, 12, 576580) The late Maganlal Gandhi had a living faith in the potency of khadi.
('70', 287, 2, 13, 576649) It was for him a thrilling romance.
('70', 287, 2, 14, 576685) And he wrote the elements of the science of khadi.
('70', 287, 2, 15, 576736) No detail was too trifling for him, no scheme was too big for him.
('70', 287, 2, 16, 576803) Richard Gregg had and has the same fire in him.
('70', 287, 2, 17, 576851) He has given it a universal meaning.
('70', 287, 2, 18, 576888) His Economics of Khaddar is an original contribution to the movement.
('70', 287, 2, 19, 576958) He recognizes the spinning wheel as the symbol par excellence of non violence.
('70', 287, 2, 20, 577037) It may or may not be all that.
('70', 287, 2, 21, 577068) But their belief gave Maganlal Gandhi and gives Richard Gregg all the joy and pleasure derivable from any fascination theme.
('70', 287, 2, 22, 577193) A science to be science must afford the fullest scope for satisfying the hunger of body, mind and soul.
('70', 287, 2, 23, 577297) Sceptics have wondered how khadi can afford such satisfaction or, in other words, what I mean when I use the expression “Science of Khadi”.
('70', 287, 2, 24, 577437) I cannot better answer the question than by copying below the questions framed by me hurriedly for a khadi worker who offered to be examined by me.
('70', 287, 2, 25, 577585) The questions were not framed in their logical sequence nor were they exhaustive.
('70', 287, 2, 26, 577667) They admit of rearrangement and addition.
('70', 287, 2, 27, 577709) But I reproduce a translation made for me by a friend from the original in Hindi.

('70', 290, 1, 2, 581869) 322. NOTES
('70', 290, 2, 3, 581880) FOR KHADI ORGANIZATIONS
('70', 290, 3, 4, 581904) The year 1936 is just over and all khadi organizations would do well to examine promptly and carefully the results of the year’s work and submit their statements to the A.I.S.A. office.
('70', 290, 3, 5, 582090) I have asked the latter to produce a brief but full report of the work of the Association during the last year, particularly with reference to the working of the new scheme of increased spinning wages.
('70', 290, 3, 6, 582292) Such a report can be had only if all the branches and the various organizations affiliated to the Association readily co operate and send without delay accurate particulars regarding work done and results achieved by them to the Central Office.
('70', 290, 3, 7, 582537) The plans and programme for the current year have to be prepared at once, and for this, too, full information regarding the previous year’s working is indispensable.
('70', 290, 3, 8, 582703) I hope therefore that khadi organizations will realize the urgency and supply all available information to the A.I.S.A. office at the earliest moment.
('70', 290, 3, 9, 582854) Let them remember that time is of the essence in this matter.
('70', 290, 4, 10, 582916) SPINNERS’ WAGES
('70', 290, 5, 11, 582932) The council of the A.I.S.A. has decided that the A.I.S.A. branches and its certified organizations should give spinning wages on the basis of a scale sufficient to enable the spinner to have, besides minimum clothing requirements, adequate nutritive diet for eight hours’ efficient work.
('70', 290, 5, 12, 583220) The various branches and organizations have, in accordance with this decision, fixed suitable standards of spinning rates which are calculated to enable the spinner to earn a daily wage of Rs. 2 to 2 1/2 .
('70', 290, 5, 13, 583426) This wage is, however, related to efficient work and can be actually earned only if the requisite standard of output and quality of yarn is attained by the spinner.
('70', 290, 5, 14, 583591) The standard fixed, though high, is not difficult to attain, but it must be admitted that at the present time only a small percentage of the spinners has come up to it, partly because of the crudeness of the spinning wheels and slivers they use and partly because of their lack of skill.
('70', 290, 5, 15, 583879) The real objective of the scheme is, however, not merely to lay down a reasonable scale for wage basis but to enable the bulk of the spinners to actually earn the same.
('70', 290, 5, 16, 584048) It, therefore, becomes the duty of all workers engaged in production activity to do all that they can to help the spinners to attain the requisite skill besides securing satisfactory wheels and slivers so as to ensure the actual earning of the desired wage by them.
('70', 290, 5, 17, 584314) It is hoped
('70', 291, 0, 1, 584326) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 292
('70', 291, 1, 2, 584368) the khadi workers will not rest content until the majority of the spinners on their registers actually earn the amount aimed at.
('70', 291, 1, 3, 584497) Let them also realize that the higher scale is not the highest aimed at.
('70', 291, 1, 4, 584570) The real aim in terms of present values is to ensure eight annas for eight hours’ attentive and skilled spinning.
('70', 291, 1, 5, 584684) That may be a far off event.
('70', 291, 1, 6, 584713) But it will never come unless very early ten pice become as natural as three are today.
('70', 291, 1, 7, 584801) Let it be also remembered that in the new scale the increase is roughly distributed half and half between the effort of the spinner and the rise given by the A.I.S.A.
('70', 291, 2, 8, 584968) AN IMPORTANT CORRECTION
('70', 291, 3, 9, 584992) I know there are readers of Harijan who study many articles that appear from time to time in Harijan.
('70', 291, 3, 10, 585094) The weekly is not published for providing momentary amusement or pleasure for the reader.
('70', 291, 3, 11, 585184) It is designed to be a serious contribution to the Harijan cause in the widest sense of the term.
('70', 291, 3, 12, 585282) It therefore often contains writings of more than transitory value.
('70', 291, 3, 13, 585350) Hence serious errors need to be corrected.
('70', 291, 3, 14, 585393) Such an error was detected in the Harijan of the 9th inst.
('70', 291, 3, 15, 585452) at page 382, 2nd column, line 2. Read ‘sub human’ for ‘human’.

('70', 292, 1, 2, 586144) 324. SPEECH AT SHIVAGIRI MATH, VARAKALLA
('70', 292, 2, 3, 586185) January 16, 1937
('70', 292, 3, 4, 586202) It gives me very great pleasure to be in your midst for the third time.
('70', 292, 3, 5, 586274) The first time I was here, I had the pleasure of paying my respects to your Guru, the great Swami.
('70', 292, 3, 6, 586373) 1 You have invited me to study his work in your midst.
('70', 292, 3, 7, 586428) Well, I did so as fervently as I could even on the first occasion I was here.
('70', 292, 3, 8, 586506) I had long and serious discussions with him over matters of common interest, and I had no difficulty in agreeing with him on many subjects of which we spoke.
('70', 292, 3, 9, 586664) I had discussions also at that time with his first and learned disciples.
('70', 292, 3, 10, 586738) After his lamented death, his disciples sent me many things including a collection of the Swami’s sayings.
('70', 292, 3, 11, 586845) I studied them with the respect that the work of such a great man demanded.
('70', 292, 3, 12, 586921) You are quite right in saying that every time I have come here I have taken away something for myself.
('70', 292, 3, 13, 587024) I admit that I have no title whatsoever to the title of “Mahatma”.
('70', 292, 3, 14, 587091) That title has often embarrassed me, sometimes it has stunk in my nostrils.
('70', 292, 3, 15, 587167) This has happened whenever with the name of ‘Mahatma’ on their lips people have done something unworthy.
('70', 292, 3, 16, 587272) I have no new religion to give, no new truth to expound.
('70', 292, 3, 17, 587329) My humble role is that of a scavenger both literally and spiritually.
('70', 292, 3, 18, 587399) I know the outward art of cleaning the streets, commodes and latrines, and I am endeavouring to the extent of my ability to clean my inside also, so that I may become a faithful interpreter of the truth as I may see it.
('70', 292, 3, 19, 587619) Of course I had many things in common with the teachings of the Swami.
('70', 292, 3, 20, 587690) I do believe that there is only one religion in the world, but I also believe that although it is one mighty tree, it has many branches.
('70', 292, 3, 21, 587827) I tried to explain this thing to the Swami as I recollect even today.
('70', 292, 3, 22, 587897) And even as all the branches take their sap from one source, even so all religions derive their essence from one fountain source.
('70', 292, 3, 23, 588027) Of course there can be only one God if there is one religion, and God who is one complete whole cannot have many branches.
('70', 292, 3, 24, 588150) But He is invisible and indefinable and, one might literally say that He has as many names as there are human beings on earth.
('70', 292, 3, 25, 588277) No matter by what name we describe Him, He is the same without a second and if we are all children of the same Creator, naturally there cannot be any caste amongst us.
('70', 292, 3, 26, 588445) We are one brotherhood and sisterhood, and there cannot
('70', 292, 4, 27, 588501) 1 Narayanguru Swami
('70', 293, 0, 1, 588521) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 294
('70', 293, 1, 2, 588563) be any distinction of high and low amongst us.
('70', 293, 1, 3, 588610) There are no savarnas and avarnas, or all are savarnas or all are avarnas.
('70', 293, 1, 4, 588685) But each one of us has his or her occupation cut out for himself or herself.
('70', 293, 1, 5, 588762) This occupation is not caste, but it is known in Hinduism as varna, which has nothing in common with caste as we understand it today.
('70', 293, 1, 6, 588896) Caste is a man made institution only, fit to be destroyed, but varna is a divine law.
('70', 293, 1, 7, 588982) We may disregard it to our harm, and we will profit by it if we follow it.
('70', 293, 1, 8, 589057) A carpenter, a blacksmith, a mason, a scavenger, a bricklayer, a teacher, a soldier—these have different occupations, but none is high and none is low among them.
('70', 293, 1, 9, 589220) And if we begin to overlap one another, we create a sankara (confusion) of all varnas.
('70', 293, 1, 10, 589307) Therefore immediately you take away the sting of distinction from different varnas, it becomes not only a law, but it gives us an opportunity of doing what we are particularly fitted for.
('70', 293, 1, 11, 589495) That is what Hinduism teaches us.
('70', 293, 1, 12, 589529) That is my interpretation of all true religions.
('70', 293, 1, 13, 589578) That is my interpretation of Hinduism pure and undefiled.
('70', 293, 1, 14, 589636) So far as I understood the great Swami, he did not dissent from the view I have just expounded to you.
('70', 293, 1, 15, 589739) You have tickled me by inviting me to come and settle down here.
('70', 293, 1, 16, 589804) The temptation is really great.
('70', 293, 1, 17, 589836) This is one of the pleasantest spots in India and the weather here is magnificent.
('70', 293, 1, 18, 589919) I know that if I should come here I should be surrounded by friends who would provide me with all my needs.
('70', 293, 1, 19, 590027) But the path of life, if taken religiously, is strait and narrow.
('70', 293, 1, 20, 590093) It has been described as sharp as the edge of a sword.
('70', 293, 1, 21, 590148) You cannot look this side or that side without stumbling into an abyss.
('70', 293, 1, 22, 590220) And the Gita says that better by far is the religion which is cut out for you than one for which you are not born.
('70', 293, 1, 23, 590335) Therefore, although the temptation you have held forth is very great, I must resist it just now.

('70', 296, 1, 2, 594931) the Maharani, his mother.

('70', 296, 1, 5, 595317) And every lover of the State, from one end of India to the other, has testified to the fact that the Proclamation lacks nothing in completeness.
('70', 296, 1, 6, 595462) By a stroke of the pen, it opens all State temples to all those who call themselves Hindus without the slightest reservation.
('70', 296, 1, 7, 595588) As I have said so often, such an act could not be prompted by any purely worldly considerations.

('70', 296, 1, 9, 595774) As I have been going from temple to temple and looking at beaming faces of perhaps tens of thousands of men and women, mingling together without the slightest distinction, I confess I have not been able to restrain my joy at the sight.
('70', 296, 1, 10, 596010) I have called it a great religious revival that is going on in Travancore.
('70', 296, 1, 11, 596085) That religious revival began some years ago, but we had no visible sign, no visible demonstration of it.
('70', 296, 1, 12, 596190) But this Proclamation is a visible demonstration of the revival which he who runs may read.
('70', 296, 1, 13, 596282) To me it is a great sign of purification of our ancient faith.
('70', 296, 1, 14, 596345) I have held for now close on half a century that untouchability is the greatest blot on Hinduism, and therefore you can only imagine—I cannot describe it fully—my joy over the Proclamation.
('70', 296, 1, 15, 596535) I congratulate all the Travancorians on this signal gift which you have received from your Prince.

('70', 296, 1, 19, 596871) But if this light is to spread throughout India, it will be purely as a result of your response to the Proclamation.
('70', 296, 1, 20, 596988) You have to understand the implications of this great act and your response must not be purely formal, but must come from the bottom of your heart and then, and not till then, will be manifested the great change of heart for which I have been pining all these years and for which I have always been fervently praying.
('70', 296, 1, 21, 597306) Let me for a few moments consider what Hinduism consists of, what it is that has fired so many saints about whom we have historical record.
('70', 296, 1, 22, 597446) Why has it contributed so many philosophers to the world?
('70', 296, 1, 23, 597504) What is it in Hinduism that has so enthused its devotees for centuries?

('70', 297, 1, 2, 597757) several workers as to the esssence of Hinduism.

('70', 297, 1, 4, 597909) Have we or have we not something that will answer the demands of the most philosophic among the Hindus or the most matter of fact among them?

('70', 297, 1, 6, 598135) I have perhaps recited the Gayatri mantra thousands of times, having understood the meaning of it.

('70', 297, 2, 13, 598901) Many of you, I think, know the Ishopanishad.
('70', 297, 2, 14, 598946) I read it years ago with translation and commentary.

('70', 297, 3, 17, 599381) Now this mantra divides itself in four parts.
('70', 297, 3, 18, 599427) The first part is.
('70', 297, 4, 19, 599446) It means, as I would translate: All this that we see in this great Universe is pervaded by God.
('70', 297, 4, 20, 599542) Then come the second and third parts which read together, as I read them:
('70', 297, 5, 21, 599616) I divide these into two and translate them thus: Renounce it and enjoy it.
('70', 297, 5, 22, 599691) There is another rendering which means the same thing, though: Enjoy what He gives you.
('70', 297, 5, 23, 599779) Even so you can divide it into two parts.
('70', 297, 5, 24, 599821) Then follows the final and most important part:
('70', 297, 6, 25, 599869) which means: Do not covet anybody’s wealth or possession.
('70', 297, 6, 26, 599927) All the other mantras of that ancient Upanishad are a commentary or an attempt to give us the full meaning of the first mantra.
('70', 297, 6, 27, 600055) As I read the mantra in the light of the Gita or the Gita in the
('70', 297, 7, 28, 600120) 1 “There is no God but Allah and Mohammed is His Prophet.” 2 “For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.”

('70', 298, 1, 2, 600374) light of the mantra I find that the Gita is a commentary on this mantra.
('70', 298, 1, 3, 600447) It seems to me to satisfy the cravings of the socialist and the communist, of the philosopher and the economist.
('70', 298, 1, 4, 600560) I venture to suggest to all who do not belong to the Hindu faith that it satisfies their cravings also.
('70', 298, 1, 5, 600664) And if it is true—and I hold it to be true—you need not take anything in Hinduism which is inconsistent with or contrary to the meaning of this mantra.
('70', 298, 1, 6, 600816) What more can a man in the street want to learn than this that the one God and Creator and Master of all that lives pervades the Universe?
('70', 298, 1, 7, 600955) The three other parts of the mantra follow directly from the first.
('70', 298, 1, 8, 601023) If you believe that God pervades everything that He has created, you must believe that you cannot enjoy anything that is not given by Him.
('70', 298, 1, 9, 601162) And seeing that He is the Creator of His numberless children, it follows that you cannot covet anybody’s possession.
('70', 298, 1, 10, 601279) If you think that you are one of His numerous creatures, it behoves you to renounce everything and lay it at His feet.
('70', 298, 1, 11, 601398) That means that the act of renunciation of everything is not a mere physical renunciation but represents a second or new birth.
('70', 298, 1, 12, 601526) It is a deliberate act, not done in ignorance.
('70', 298, 1, 13, 601573) It is therefore a regeneration.
('70', 298, 1, 14, 601605) And then, since he who holds the body must eat and drink and clothe himself, he must naturally seek all that he needs from Him.
('70', 298, 1, 15, 601733) And he gets it as a natural reward of that renunciation.
('70', 298, 1, 16, 601790) As if this was not enough, the mantra closes with this magnificent thought: Do not covet anybody’s possession.
('70', 298, 1, 17, 601901) The moment you carry out these precepts you become a wise citizen of the world, living at peace with all that lives.
('70', 298, 1, 18, 602018) It satisfies one’s highest aspirations on this earth and hereafter.

('70', 299, 3, 16, 604446) 328. COW PROTECTION OR COW SLAUGHTER
('70', 299, 4, 17, 604483) We find that many of the things we do are contrary to our beliefs or our religion.
('70', 299, 4, 18, 604566) We believe that we should speak the truth, yet we practise untruth; we believe that we should not indulge in immoral activities but we do indulge in them; we believe that we should refrain from violence, yet we practise it at every moment; we believe that we should win swaraj, yet do much which is contrary to this belief.
('70', 299, 4, 19, 604890) We do not even do khadi work which will promote swaraj.
('70', 299, 4, 20, 604946) The human race would perish if it always acted against its beliefs in all matters.
('70', 299, 4, 21, 605029) Innum erable persons thoughtlessly do what should not be done.
('70', 299, 4, 22, 605092) The foregoing describes the plight of those who have formed the habit of thinking.
('70', 299, 4, 23, 605175) Failure to serve the cow is an instance of conduct contrary to religion.
('70', 299, 4, 24, 605248) Every Hindu believes that it is his special dharma to serve the cow.
('70', 299, 4, 25, 605317) But only a handful of Hindus will be found to observe the basic rules of goseva.
('70', 299, 4, 26, 605398) Many persons believe that they have done their duty once they have put a couple of pice into the cow protection fund.
('70', 299, 4, 27, 605516) These thoughts came to my mind while reading a letter written by Shri
('70', 300, 0, 1, 605586) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 301
('70', 300, 1, 2, 605635) Purushottam Narhar Joshi who calls himself a “gosevak”.
('70', 300, 1, 3, 605691) Shri Joshi is not only the head of the State goshala of Bhavnagar but also takes interest in cattle development.
('70', 300, 1, 4, 605804) His letter 1 runs as follows.
('70', 300, 1, 5, 605834) Who will not believe while reading this letter that cowslaughter is being practised under the guise of cow protection?
('70', 300, 1, 6, 605953) We do not become murderers only when we commit actual murder with a knife.

('70', 300, 1, 8, 606170) Many of the suggestions made by the gosevak Shri Joshi can be put into practice anywhere in India.
('70', 300, 1, 9, 606269) His letter is mainly addressed to Kathiawar and particularly the ruling princes there, as they can easily take up this work.
('70', 300, 1, 10, 606394) Every State can set up one or more dairies, keep good stud bulls for the benefit of the people, castrate each and every male calf, supply good cows to whosoever needs them, provide facilities for training in animal husbandry, maintain pastures within their own States and prevent the cruel slaughter of buffalo bulls which is being practised.

('70', 302, 1, 2, 610604) 330. SPEECH AT HARIPAD
('70', 302, 2, 3, 610627) January 17, 1937 At this meeting I would love to detain you for a few minutes on the message of Hinduism I gave to the meeting in Quilon last night.
('70', 302, 2, 4, 610776) I ventured at that meeting to say that the whole of Hinduism could be summed up in the first verse of Ishopanishad.
('70', 302, 2, 5, 610892) I suggested then that if all other Hindu scriptures happened to be reduced to ashes and to go out of the memory of men and if only that one verse were to abide with us, the destruction would be no loss.
('70', 302, 2, 6, 611095) Hinduism would even then remain with us.
('70', 302, 2, 7, 611136) The original Sanskrit of the mantra is perhaps as easy as anybody learning Sanskrit could possibly wish.
('70', 302, 2, 8, 611241) This Upanishad enjoys the reputation of being part of the original Vedas.
('70', 302, 2, 9, 611315) It is the shortest Upanishad known to us.
('70', 302, 2, 10, 611357) But, as I have said, if we had only the first verse of that Upanishad remaining with us, it would be enough to supply all our wants.
('70', 302, 2, 11, 611490) Let me repeat that mantra in my faulty Sanskrit pronunciation:
('70', 302, 3, 12, 611553) Those who know a little bit of Sanskrit will find that there is nothing abstruse there that you find in other Vedic mantras, and its meaning is simply this: All that there is in this Universe, great or small, including the tiniest atom, is pervaded by God, known as Creator or Lord.
('70', 302, 3, 13, 611836) Isha means the Ruler, and He who is the Creator naturally by very right becomes the Ruler, too.
('70', 302, 3, 14, 611932) And here in this verse the seer has chosen no other epithet for the Deity but that of the Ruler, and he has excepted nothing from His jurisdiction.
('70', 302, 3, 15, 612080) He says everything that we see is pervaded by the Deity, and from that naturally the other parts of the mantra follow.
('70', 302, 3, 16, 612199) Thus he says: Renounce everything, i.e., everything that is on this Universe, the whole of the Universe, and not only this tiny globe of ours, renounce it.
('70', 302, 3, 17, 612355) He asks us to renounce it as we are such insignificant atoms that if we had any idea of possession it would seem ludicrous.
('70', 302, 3, 18, 612479) And then, says the rishi, the reward of renunciation is
('70', 302, 4, 19, 612535) i.e., enjoyment of all you need.
('70', 302, 4, 20, 612568) But there is a meaning about the word ‘enjoy’—you might as well say use, eat, etc.,—but it means that you may not take more than is necessary for your growth.
('70', 302, 4, 21, 612727) Therefore this enjoyment or use is limited by two conditions.
('70', 302, 4, 22, 612789) One is the act of renunciation or, as the author of the Bhagavata would say, enjoy in the spirit And every day in the morning everyone who believes in Bhagavata Dharma has to dedicate his thoughts, words
('70', 303, 0, 1, 612993) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 304
('70', 303, 1, 2, 613035) thoughts, words and deeds to Krishna, and not until he has performed that daily act of renunciation or dedication has he the right of touching anything or drinking even a cup of water.
('70', 303, 1, 3, 613220) And when a man has performed that act of renunciation and dedication, he derives from that act the right of eating, drinking, clothing, and housing himself to the extent necessary for his daily life.
('70', 303, 1, 4, 613420) Therefore take it as you like, either in the sense that the enjoyment or use is the reward or renunciation, or that the renunciation is the condition of enjoyment, renunciation is essential for our very existence, for our soul.
('70', 303, 1, 5, 613648) And as if that condition given in the mantra was incomplete, the rishi hastened to complete it by adding: ‘Do not covet what belongs to another’.
('70', 303, 1, 6, 613794) Now I suggest to you that the whole of the philosophy or religion found in any part of the world is contained in this mantra, and it excludes everything contrary to it.
('70', 303, 1, 7, 613963) According to the canons of interpretation, anything that is inconsistent with Shruti—and the Ishopanishad is a Shruti—is to be rejected altogether.
('70', 303, 1, 8, 614111) Now I should like to apply this mantra our own condition in virtue of the Proclamation.
('70', 303, 1, 9, 614199) Whilst I have unstintingly associated myself with your rejoicings over this great Proclamation and in tendering my thanks and congratulations to His Highness, Her Highness and their Dewan, in terms of this mantra I am obliged also to say that this Proclamation is a tardy carrying out of the behest contained in this verse of the Ishopanishad that I have recited.
('70', 303, 1, 10, 614563) Only yesterday we were unfit to call ourselves Hindus.
('70', 303, 1, 11, 614618) For if all that there is in the Universe is pervaded by God, that is to say, if the Brahmin and the Bhangi, the learned man and the scavenger, the Ezhava and the Pariah, no matter what caste they belong to—if all these are pervaded by Lord God, in the light of this mantra, there is none that is low, all are absolutely equal, equal because all are the creatures of that Creator.
('70', 303, 1, 12, 614998) And this is not a philosophical thing to be dished out to Brahmins or Kshatriyas, but it enunciates an eternal truth which admits of no reduction, no dilution 1. Therefore the Maharaja himself and the Maharani are not one whit superior to the lowliest being in Travancore.
('70', 303, 1, 13, 615271) We are all creatures and servants of one God.
('70', 303, 1, 14, 615317) If the Maharaja is the first among equals, as he is, he is so not by right of overlordship but by right of service.
('70', 303, 1, 15, 615433) And therefore how nice, how noble it is that that very Maharaja is called ‘Padmanabhadas’.
('70', 303, 1, 16, 615524) It is a proud title and I congratulate those who bestowed that title on the
('70', 303, 2, 17, 615600) 1 The source has “palliation”.
('70', 304, 0, 1, 615631) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 305
('70', 304, 1, 2, 615680) Maharaja of Travancore.
('70', 304, 1, 3, 615704) Therefore when I told you that the Maharaja or the Maharani were not one whit superior to any one of us I told you what was the actual truth accepted by their Highnesses themselves.
('70', 304, 1, 4, 615886) And if that is so, how can anyone here dare to arrogate superiority to himself or herself over any other human being?
('70', 304, 1, 5, 616004) I tell you, therefore, that if the mantra holds good, if there is any man or woman here who believes that the temples are defiled by those called avarnas, that person I declare would be guilty of a grave sin.
('70', 304, 1, 6, 616213) I tell you that the Proclamation has purified our temples of the taint that had attached to them.
('70', 304, 1, 7, 616311) I would like the mantra I have recited to be enshrined in the hearts of all our men and women and children, and if this contains, as I hold, the essence of Hinduism, it should be inscribed on the portals of every temple.
('70', 304, 1, 8, 616532) Don’t you then think that we should be belying that mantra at every step if we excluded anyone from those temples?
('70', 304, 1, 9, 616647) Therefore if you will prove yourselves deserving of the gracious Proclamation and if you will be loyal to yourselves and to those who preside over your destinies, you will carry out the letter and spirit of this Proclamation I regard it as such a great spiritual act that it ought to remove scepticism from the hearts of sceptics or doubt from the hearts of those who doubted the truth of Hinduism or religion itself.
('70', 304, 1, 10, 617065) Rightly understood this Proclamation should dispel the ignorant atheism of so called atheists.
('70', 304, 1, 11, 617160) From the date of the Proclamation the Travancore temples, which, as I once said, were not abodes of God, have become abodes of God, since no one who used to be regarded as untouchable is any more to be excluded from them.
('70', 304, 1, 12, 617382) I therefore hope and pray that throughout Travancore there may be no man or woman who will abstain from going to the temples for the reason that they have been opened to those who were regarded as Pariahs of society.

('70', 308, 6, 24, 623859) 339. SPEECH AT SHERTHALAI 1
('70', 308, 7, 25, 623887) January 18, 1937
('70', 308, 8, 26, 623904) It is a matter of the greatest pleasure to me to be in your midst this afternoon.
('70', 308, 8, 27, 623986) It is unnecessary for me now to say that I associate myself entirely in the expression of gratefulness to the Maharaja of Travancore.
('70', 308, 8, 28, 624120) There can be no doubt that but for his solicitude for the faith of his ancestors and but for the wise guidance of Her Highness the Maharani and the able assistance of Sachivottama.
('70', 308, 8, 29, 624301) Sir C.P. Ramaswami Aiyar, we should not have seen this Proclamation.
('70', 308, 9, 30, 624370) 1 The occasion was the Proclamation celebration organized by the S.N.D.P. Yogam, the principal Ezhava organization.
('70', 309, 0, 1, 624486) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 310
('70', 309, 1, 2, 624528) would like to repeat to you what I have said on other occasions: that if the hand that traced the signature to the Proclamation was that of the Maharaja, the spirit which moved the hand to sign it was that of God.
('70', 309, 1, 3, 624742) In spite of the brave guidance of his wise mother, the youthful ruler of Travancore might well have quailed before taking the unprecedented step of removing, by one stroke of the pen, untouchability which was double distilled in Travancore.
('70', 309, 1, 4, 624983) But whilst many things are impossible for mere man, nothing is impossible for God.
('70', 309, 1, 5, 625066) And in pursuance of the divine voice within, the Maharaja bravely took up the pen and signed the Proclamation which was drafted for him by the Sachivottama.
('70', 309, 1, 6, 625223) I would like you to look on the Proclamation as a divine gift and therefore respond to it in the spirit in which it has been given to you.
('70', 309, 2, 7, 625362) My interpretation of the Proclamation is that it removes the age long, and yet irreligious, distinction of high and low.
('70', 309, 2, 8, 625483) There is before God, whose creatures we are all, absolute equality of all.
('70', 309, 2, 9, 625558) It is man who in his arrogance has disturbed the even justice of his great Deity.
('70', 309, 2, 10, 625640) The Maharaja has now removed the taint of untouchability and declared once for all to all his subjects that all have equal rights in the matter of temple entry, and it follows that if they have equality in the matter of temple entry, they should have equality in all other matters of life.
('70', 309, 2, 11, 625930) And as I have begun to say for the last two or three days, the Proclamation is wholly consistent with the essence of Hinduism which is very briefly, but equally brilliantly, given in the first mantra of Ishopanishad.
('70', 309, 2, 12, 626147) I commend that Upanishad, or at least its first mantra, to the attention of every one of you here.
('70', 309, 2, 13, 626246) I will give you only a free translation of that mantra.
('70', 309, 2, 14, 626302) It means this: God the Ruler and Creator pervades everything that is in the Universe down to the tiniest atom.
('70', 309, 2, 15, 626413) There is nothing, without a single exception, where God is not.
('70', 309, 2, 16, 626477) And naturally therefrom follows what the seer has said in the other part of this mantra, viz., dedicate all at the feet of the Almighty or, in the language of the Gita, renounce everything.
('70', 309, 2, 17, 626667) But renunciation cannot, must not, mean suicide.
('70', 309, 2, 18, 626716) Therefore, the rishi or the seer says in the same breath: renounce or dedicate and then use or enjoy.
('70', 309, 2, 19, 626818) But he felt that he had still not given the whole essence so that even a small child could understand it.
('70', 309, 2, 20, 626924) Therefore, he wound up by saying: “Do not covet anybody’s riches”.
('70', 309, 2, 21, 626991) Therefore your use and enjoyment is limi ted in two ways.
('70', 309, 2, 22, 627049) The first condition is that we should consider nothing, not even our bodies, as our own, because we have got to dedicate or surrender everything to God the Ruler.
('70', 309, 2, 23, 627212) The second condition is that we must not steal what belongs to others.
('70', 309, 2, 24, 627283) That does not mean that we
('70', 310, 0, 1, 627310) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 311
('70', 310, 1, 2, 627359) will not, merely physically, help ourselves to what belongs to our neighbours, but that we will not even cast hungry eyes on it.
('70', 310, 1, 3, 627488) If we really want to enjoy the things we eat or the clothes we wear or the houses we live in, we must make up our minds definitely that the things are not more than we need for our sustenance and for the praise of our Maker.
('70', 310, 1, 4, 627713) Then as creatures or children of God we realize that what we eat or clothe ourselves with or live in, does not belong to us but to God.
('70', 310, 1, 5, 627849) And this advice is not given to a few chosen creatures of God, but to everyone in the world.
('70', 310, 1, 6, 627942) You will see that the dominant part of the mantra is that every atom is pervaded by God.
('70', 310, 1, 7, 628031) Therefore, the advice as to the renunciation or dedication or surrender is given to all His creatures.
('70', 310, 1, 8, 628134) It is, therefore, not as if it was a command given to a few people, but the enunciation of a universal law or universal truth.
('70', 310, 1, 9, 628261) Just imagine if all of us were to live faithfully in accordance with the great law of our being, what a happy world it would be in which we should be living.
('70', 310, 1, 10, 628419) Then there would be no mutual jealousies, no mutual strife.
('70', 310, 1, 11, 628479) And those who are blessed, if I might say so, with certain possessions would constitute themselves trustees for such of those as might want them.
('70', 310, 1, 12, 628625) In virtue of the law that I have endeavoured to explain to you, those who have much possession will use it only to the extent of their own limited requirements.
('70', 310, 1, 13, 628786) And evidently because the tradition among the Maharajas of Travancore is that they are to constitute themselves servants of Padmanabha, the practice that is in vogue today is that the Maharaja goes to the temple and dedicates himself to the Deity and as His agent and viceroy takes definite instructions to conduct his affairs from day to day.
('70', 310, 1, 14, 629130) It is perfectly true that these instructions are not given and taken as from man to man, but that even as I suggested to you, it was the spirit of God which moved the Maharaja to take this action.
('70', 310, 1, 15, 629327) Similarly if he goes to the temple for instructions in a spirit of prayer and humility, he clothes himself with the spirit of God.
('70', 310, 1, 16, 629458) I do not want, therefore, to deceive myself or you into a false belief or superstition.
('70', 310, 1, 17, 629546) Far be it from me to suggest that the Maharaja is an infallible being or that he never commits any error of judgment.
('70', 310, 1, 18, 629664) I do not know what errors of judgment he has committed if any, but assuming that he is a mortal being and, like any one of us, liable to commit errors of judgment, the fact is that he has got to live up to this mantra, and, as it is recognized in the blue blood of Travancore, that tradition requires the Maharaja from day to day to perform this act of dedication, and to the extent that he does so his acts must become infallible.
('70', 310, 1, 19, 630096) Whatever may be the
('70', 311, 0, 1, 630116) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 312
('70', 311, 1, 2, 630158) fact about the acts of the Maharaja, I have used the thing as an illustration to show how this law operates with us in India.
('70', 311, 1, 3, 630284) Consciously or unconsciously, however imperfectly, it must express itself in our acts and our lives.

('70', 318, 5, 12, 648394) As I was being taken round the temple and as I approached the central part of the temple, I had a Pulaya boy shown to me, and he boldly mounted up the steps with me.
('70', 318, 5, 13, 648560) A few months ago, I should not have considered such a thing possible in my lifetime, but what often is impossible for man is easily possible for God to fulfil.

('70', 318, 5, 17, 649214) He could not have made tens of thousands of savarnas brush shoulders with the so called avarnas and go to the temples in a prayerful mood.

('70', 320, 1, 2, 652320) 343. SPEECH AT KUMARANELLOOR 1
('70', 320, 2, 3, 652351) January 19, 1937
('70', 320, 3, 4, 652368) There is a special joy that I am experiencing this morning, having come to this temple and having seen what I have seen.
('70', 320, 3, 5, 652489) I was duly prepared for this upliftment.
('70', 320, 3, 6, 652530) I was told that this was one of the oldest and most important of private temples, that it was the sole property of the Nambudiris, and that when this temple was declared open, people thought that there remained nothing now to be done in connection with temple entry.
('70', 320, 3, 7, 652797) But when I came here and saw what I did see, the joy which was reserved for me was considerably enhanced.
('70', 320, 3, 8, 652903) Here behind me is the trustee of the temple who took me to the temple with great affection.
('70', 320, 3, 9, 652995) For this I was not unprepared, because it has been my rare good fortune to experience that personal affection throughout this pilgrimage.
('70', 320, 3, 10, 653133) But what gladdened my heart was to see that he invited the so called avarnas to come and enter the gates before he took me.
('70', 320, 3, 11, 653257) And it did not appear to me an artificial act, but perfectly natural.
('70', 320, 3, 12, 653327) Nowhere else has it happened like that during these seven days of my pilgrimage.
('70', 320, 3, 13, 653408) Of course I do not notice the omission anywhere, for the so called avarnas, or as I call them by the term of endearment ‘Harijans’, mixed freely with the others, and there was nothing more required by way of coaxing them to go into the temples.
('70', 320, 3, 14, 653653) But it was most striking for me to observe that here our friend the trustee would not be satisfied until he drew the hesitating avarnas and brought them to my notice.
('70', 320, 3, 15, 653820) I felt then that this was really the proper manner of giving effect to the Proclamation.
('70', 320, 3, 16, 653909) The Proclamation does not say that the hitherto proud Nambudiris should take avarnas by their arms and give them the place of preference in the temples.
('70', 320, 3, 17, 654062) Of course I own that the spirit of the Proclamation demands what this friend has done this morning, but then no prince can possibly dictate to the hearts of his people.
('70', 320, 3, 18, 654231) All responses from the heart must be in their very nature spontaneous, and in this, for him, very natural act of expression of brotherhood I saw a proper fulfilment of the spirit of the Proclamation.
('70', 320, 3, 19, 654431) My joy was further enhanced by my knowledge that Nambudiris occupy in this State, as in Cochin, a place of pride and privilege.
('70', 320, 3, 20, 654559) If they even showed secret, sullen opposition to the Proclamation, it could be rendered ineffective.
('70', 320, 4, 21, 654660) 1 Delivered on the occasion of the opening to Harijans of a private Nambudiri temple, about two thousand years old, to which Gandhiji was specially invited
('70', 321, 0, 1, 654816) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 322
('70', 321, 1, 2, 654858) But here in this private temple, the stronghold of orthodox Nambudiris, the Proclamation is evidently being carried out both in letter and spirit.
('70', 321, 2, 3, 655005) I must here tell you a little secret.
('70', 321, 2, 4, 655043) I tell you that I was most disinclined to visit Travancore and it required much effort on the part of Sjts.
('70', 321, 2, 5, 655151) Govindan and Ramachandran to draw me out of Segaon, and at one time it seemed as though all their labours would be in vain.
('70', 321, 2, 6, 655275) But things happened to melt my heart and I am being led, as a docile man or woman may be led, by the nose by Ramachandran and company.
('70', 321, 2, 7, 655410) But the heartening experience that I have undergone here tells me that it would have been a stupid act of foolishness on my part if I had not visited Travancore, if only to see this temple and to see Harijans being led into it.
('70', 321, 2, 8, 655638) Let this be an example to all Nambudiris and other savarnas to follow.
('70', 321, 2, 9, 655709) That is a very fair illustration of what I mean when I say at so many meetings that the Proclamation is to be carried out in its full effect by the savarnas.
('70', 321, 2, 10, 655867) You must know that the avarna Hindus, except those who have undergone training, do not know what the Proclamation is and what it means for them.
('70', 321, 2, 11, 656012) The burden of drawing them out of the ghettos, to which our ignorance and folly have confined them, and letting them see the sunlight which is meant for all, and letting their hearts be warmed up by being led to the temples, lies on the savarnas.
('70', 321, 2, 12, 656259) Let it not be said of Travancoreans that what Nambudiris who are supposed to be the highest caste in Travancore did, others failed to do.
('70', 321, 2, 13, 656397) This burden of drawing the avarna brethren and sisters out of their dens depends no less on savarna women than on men.
('70', 321, 2, 14, 656516) I do hope and pray that all savarna Hindus of Travancore will carry out the Proclamation to the fullest extent and deserve to be called the liberators of Hinduism, if not its saviours.

('70', 324, 1, 2, 662316) 346. SPEECH AT WOMEN’S MEETING, KOTTAYAM 1
('70', 324, 2, 3, 662359) January 19, 1937
('70', 324, 3, 4, 662376) I am delighted to address for the first time during my pilgrim age a women’s meeting.
('70', 324, 3, 5, 662462) I should therefore have given you much longer time and tried to make fuller acquaintance of you who have gathered together in such a larger number and where, for the first time, a sister has made her reception speech in Hindi.
('70', 324, 3, 6, 662689) I thank you both for the welcome and for the Hindi address.
('70', 324, 3, 7, 662749) I shall rest content with saying a few words on the Proclamation.
('70', 324, 3, 8, 662815) Rajkumari Amrit Kaur, who will speak to you after I have done, will address herself to women’s problems as you may know that she is the Secretary of the All India Women’s Conference.
('70', 324, 3, 9, 662998) I have often said that untouchability is a great blot on Hinduism and one that threatened the very life of Hinduism.
('70', 324, 3, 10, 663115) The Proclamation has come in very good time to enable us to wipe out the blot.
('70', 324, 3, 11, 663194) But by itself it cannot do so.
('70', 324, 3, 12, 663225) The Maharaja’s work was finished with the Proclamation.
('70', 324, 3, 13, 663281) It is for you to root out untouchability by carrying the Proclamation into full effect.
('70', 324, 3, 14, 663369) This work of carrying through the process of purification devolves principally on savarna Hindus.
('70', 324, 3, 15, 663467) I have often said that it is women alone who can be protectors of religion in as much as they are the custodians of the purity of the people.
('70', 324, 3, 16, 663609) It is particularly women’s work because the purification of religion is ultimately a matter of the purification of one’s heart.
('70', 324, 3, 17, 663737) And if the women have realized the true spirit of the Proclamation, they can give better effect to it then men.
('70', 324, 3, 18, 663849) We have up to now regarded avarnas as untouchables, not only in our homes and our temples, but in our hearts.
('70', 324, 3, 19, 663959) We have to regard them as our own kith and kin.
('70', 324, 3, 20, 664007) If, therefore, there is anyone amongst you who thinks that the Maharaja has defiled the Hindu religion and the temples by issuing this Proclamation, she will err against humanity and her Maker.
('70', 324, 3, 21, 664201) I must tell you that these temples were impure so long as the temple doors were closed against Harijans.
('70', 324, 3, 22, 664306) This Proclamation has purified them all.
('70', 324, 3, 23, 664347) None of you will, therefore, cease to go to these temples in the belief that they have been defiled.
('70', 324, 3, 24, 664448) I hope that you will discard that superstition and fraternize with Harijan women and actively help in raising them to a level of social equality with you.

('70', 325, 0, 1, 664673) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 326
('70', 325, 1, 2, 664715) 347. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, KOTTAYAM 1
('70', 325, 2, 3, 664757) January 19, 1937 I know that this great assemblage is one of the many signs of rejoicings over the Proclamation which H.H. the Maharaja has given to the people of Travancore.
('70', 325, 2, 4, 664932) Whilst it was but natural and your duty to tender congratulations to Their Highnesses and the Dewan, it would be wholly wrong if you exhausted your effort with these celebrations.
('70', 325, 2, 5, 665112) Let your congratulations Their Highnesses be an earnest of your determination to make every effort to make the Proclamation as successful as human effort can make it.
('70', 325, 2, 6, 665279) As I have suggested at various gatherings, the main burden of successfully working out the Proclamation must fall on the shoulders of those who have been regarded as savarnas.
('70', 325, 2, 7, 665455) It is they who have to carry the message of liberation and hope to the desolate homes of those who are miscalled avarnas.
('70', 325, 2, 8, 665577) It is their privilege and their duty to approach the humble huts of the so called avarna brothers and sisters and take the message to them in a humble and prayerful mood.
('70', 325, 2, 9, 665748) That would be some measure, however tardy, of reparation for wrongs done to those whom we have suppressed.
('70', 325, 2, 10, 665855) It is and should be their proud privilege to stoop in order to raise those whom they have helped to sink lower and lower from day to day.
('70', 325, 2, 11, 665993) So much today for the savarna Hindus.
('70', 325, 2, 12, 666031) I know Kottayam is a stronghold of the Christians of Travancore.
('70', 325, 2, 13, 666096) Christians know there is between them and me an invisible but unbreakable bond.
('70', 325, 2, 14, 666176) I venture, therefore, to suggest to Indian Christians, whether they are born Christians or have been converted to Christianity, that they too may not stand aside but take part in advancing the cause that the Proclamation implies.
('70', 325, 2, 15, 666406) And as briefly as possible I propose to tell you what I mean.
('70', 325, 2, 16, 666468) That document abolishes all distinctions between high and low that reigned supreme in Travancore as in other parts of India.
('70', 325, 2, 17, 666593) If a human document can raise by a stroke of the pen all avarnas to the status of the savarnas— and this Proclamation does really do so—then the Christians in the State owe a duty to the Hindus which they dare not neglect.
('70', 325, 2, 18, 666816) If you believe with me, as I know a large body of Christian opinion today does believe, that all the principal religions of the world are true, then you will aid savarna Hindus in the process of penitence and reparation they are expected to go through under the Proclamation.
('70', 325, 3, 19, 667092) 1 The meeting was held in front of the Krishna temple and was attended by about 1,000 people.
('70', 325, 3, 20, 667186) The Hindu, 20 1 1937, also carried a report of the speech.
('70', 326, 0, 1, 667245) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 327
('70', 326, 1, 2, 667294) It undoubtedly grieved me when some of the Depressed Classes felt in disgust towards Hinduism like going out of Hinduism and embracing some other faith.
('70', 326, 1, 3, 667447) It was a matter of equal grief to me to hear of efforts made by people belonging to different faiths to catch, as it were, the Depressed Classees and remove them from the faith to which they have belonged for centuries.
('70', 326, 1, 4, 667667) If you believe, as I know some do, that Hinduism is nothing but a body of hideous usages and superstitions, that Hinduism is a fraud upon humanity, then you cannot render better service to the avarna and savarna Hindus than by exposing this ‘fraud’.
('70', 326, 1, 5, 667917) In the estimation of those who so believe, this Proclamation is an act which it would be their duty to resist and to show to the Maharaja that by issuing the Proclamation of liberation he is simply prolonging the agony and giving a new lease of life to a body of superstitions which were bound to die their natural death.
('70', 326, 1, 6, 668239) But I know many Christians throughout the length and breadth of India do not regard Hinduism as a fraud upon humanity or a body of bad usages and superstitions.
('70', 326, 1, 7, 668400) A religion which has produced Ramakrishna, Chaitanya, Shankara and Vivekanand cannot be a body of superstitions.
('70', 326, 1, 8, 668513) As you know, and if you do not know it I want to declare, that I personally hold all principal religions of the world to be not only true but also to be equal.
('70', 326, 1, 9, 668673) I have endeavoured to study the Bible with the eyes of a devout Christian and the Koran with the eyes of a devout Mussalman, and I have not hesitated to assimilate whatever I have found to be good in both these scriptures.
('70', 326, 1, 10, 668896) I have studied other scriptures of the world also.
('70', 326, 1, 11, 668947) But I have singled these out for the sake of illustration.
('70', 326, 1, 12, 669006) But, you might well ask, if I declare all these religions to be equally true and equally demanding my respect, what is the meaning of my remaining a Hindu?
('70', 326, 1, 13, 669162) I shall tell you why.
('70', 326, 1, 14, 669184) Latterly I have been endeavouring to describe to vast assemblages of men and women I have addressed what I regard as the essence of Hinduism, and I have been suggesting to them one incredibly simple mantra of the Ishopanishad and, as you know, it is one of the Upanishads that enjoy the sanctity of the Vedas.
('70', 326, 1, 15, 669494) The very first verse of the Ishopanishad means simply this: God pervades everything that is to be found in this universe down to the tiniest atom.
('70', 326, 1, 16, 669641) The mantra describes God as the Creator, the Ruler and the Lord.
('70', 326, 1, 17, 669706) The seer to whom this mantra or verse was revealed was not satisfied with the magnificent statement that God was to be found everywhere.
('70', 326, 1, 18, 669843) But he went further and said:‘Since God pervades everything nothing belongs to you, not even your own body.
('70', 327, 0, 1, 669951) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 328
('70', 327, 1, 2, 669993) the undisputed, unchallengeable Master of everything you possess.’ And so when a person who calls himself a Hindu goes through the process of regeneration or a second birth, as Christians would call it, he has to perform a dedication or renunciation of all that he has in ignorance called his own property.
('70', 327, 1, 3, 670300) And then when he has performed this act of dedication or renunciation, he is told that he will win a reward in the shape of God taking good care of what he will require for food, clothing or housing.
('70', 327, 1, 4, 670500) Therefore the condition of enjoyment or use of the necessaries of life is their dedication or renunciation.
('70', 327, 1, 5, 670608) And that dedication or renunciation has got to be done from day to day, lest we may in this busy world forget the central fact of life.
('70', 327, 1, 6, 670744) And to crown all, the seer says: ‘Covet not anybody’s riches.’ I suggest to you that the truth that is embedded in this very short mantra is calculated to satisfy the highest cravings of every human being— whether they have reference to this world or to the next.
('70', 327, 1, 7, 671008) I have in my search of the scriptures of the world found nothing to add to this mantra.
('70', 327, 1, 8, 671096) Looking back upon all the little I have read of the scriptures—it is precious little I confess—I feel that everything good in all the scriptures is derived from this mantra.
('70', 327, 1, 9, 671270) If it is universal brotherhood—not only brotherhood of all human beings, but of all living beings—I find it in this mantra.
('70', 327, 1, 10, 671394) If it is unshakable faith in the Lord and Master—and all the adjectives you can think of—I find it in this mantra.
('70', 327, 1, 11, 671509) If it is the idea of complete surrender to God and of the faith that He will supply all that I need, then again I say I find it in this mantra.
('70', 327, 1, 12, 671653) Since He pervades every fibre of my being and of all of you, I derive from it the doctrine of equality of all creatures on earth and it should satisfy the cravings of all philosophical communists.
('70', 327, 1, 13, 671850) This mantra tells me that I cannot hold as mine anything that belongs to God, and if my life and that of all who believe in this mantra has to be a life of perfect dedication, it follows that it will have to be a life of continual service of our fellow creatures.
('70', 327, 1, 14, 672114) This, I say, is my faith and should be the faith of all who call themselves Hindus.
('70', 327, 1, 15, 672198) And I venture to suggest to my Christian and Mussalman friends that they will find nothing more in their scriptures if they will search them, and I want the aid of every body on earth— whether he is a Christian or a Mussalman or what else—to help the Hindus of Travancore to realize the lofty purpose that lies in this mantra.
('70', 327, 1, 16, 672525) I do not wish to hide from you the fact that I am not unaware of many superstitions that go under the name of Hinduism.
('70', 327, 1, 17, 672645) I am most painfully conscious of all superstitions that are to be found masqu 
('70', 328, 0, 1, 672724) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 329
('70', 328, 1, 2, 672773) erading as Hinduism and I have no hesitation to call a spade a spade.
('70', 328, 1, 3, 672843) I have not hesitated to describe untouchability as the greatest of these superstitions.
('70', 328, 1, 4, 672931) But in spite of them all, I remain a Hindu.
('70', 328, 1, 5, 672975) For I do not believe that these superstitions form part of Hinduism.
('70', 328, 1, 6, 673044) The very canons of interpretation laid down by Hinduism teach me that whatever is inconsistent with the truth I have expounded to you and what is hidden in the mantra I have named, must be summarily rejected as not belonging to Hinduism.
('70', 328, 1, 7, 673282) And I want you non Hindus to help the so called savarna Hindus to spread this truth in the midst of those whom they have hitherto regarded as untouchables, unapproa chables, invisibles.
('70', 328, 1, 8, 673468) I felt that I could not do justice to this great meeting, especially a meeting that is held in a Christian stronghold, unless I was prepared to utter a truth I held dear as life itself.
('70', 328, 1, 9, 673654) We all consciously or unconsciously pine and strive for peace on earth and goodwill amongst mankind.
('70', 328, 1, 10, 673755) I am convinced that we shall find neither peace nor goodwill among men and women through strife among men of different religions, through disputation among them.
('70', 328, 1, 11, 673917) We shall find truth and peace and goodwill if we approach the humblest of mankind in a prayerful spirit.
('70', 328, 1, 12, 674022) Anyway that is my humble appeal to Christians who may be present in this great meeting.
('70', 328, 1, 13, 674110) It is a privilege that may not occur again to any of you in your lifetime.
('70', 328, 1, 14, 674185) As I have said so often elsewhere, whilst the hand that traced the signature on the Proclamation was that of the Maharaja, the spirit that moved him to do so was that of God.
('70', 328, 1, 15, 674360) Would to God that that spirit might also fire everyone in Travancore to realize the implications of this Proclamation and to fire every one of you to advance the cause that the Proclamation enunciates.
('70', 328, 1, 16, 674562) I thank you from the bottom of my heart for the exemplary silence with which you have listened to my speech.
('70', 328, 2, 17, 674671) Harijan, 30 1 1937

('70', 329, 3, 8, 675324) Fatherhood of God and brotherhood of man has been established and we are in the happy land of Ramarajya in every sense of the term.” Well, if I was an inhabitant of Changanacheri and this address was read in my name and I had been asked to sign it, I should have to undergo various nights of vigil before I could subscribe to the statements therein.
('70', 329, 3, 9, 675674) If you had rested content with saying that all these things had been implied in the Proclamation, of which you have spoken in enthusiastic terms, it would have been quite in place and I should have said that you were right in reading all these implications in the Proclamation and that God might help you to live up to those implications.

('70', 329, 3, 14, 676577) The way to live up to every assertion is by every individual doing these very things in his or her own life, and I tell you that a life of spirituality truly lived is far more infectious than all the microbes put together can prove on this earth.
('70', 329, 3, 15, 676824) And whereas we dread all these infections and would rather escape them, this is an infection which we would all welcome.
('70', 329, 3, 16, 676945) Let me hope and pray that all that you have said in this address may prove true in Travancore, and if it does so, I promise that it will prove true in the whole of India.

('70', 331, 1, 19, 681292) It is not I who say these things, it is what those who wrote these scriptures have said.
('70', 331, 1, 20, 681381) I shall therefore leave this meeting with a free translation of that mantra.
('70', 331, 1, 21, 681458) It simply means this: “God pervades everything that we see” Therefore it is literally true what the Western science tells us, that Nature abhors a vacuum, for there is nothing on earth where God is not.
('70', 331, 1, 22, 681661) And if He occupies everything that is, there is nothing for us to occupy.
('70', 331, 1, 23, 681735) Therefore, the mantra says: “You must renounce everything.” But it does not say: “Renounce everything and perish.” On the contrary it says: “Renounce everything if you want to live.” For that act of renunciation or dedication to God will result in God taking the responsibility of feeding you, of housing you and of clothing you.
