('70', 333, 1, 2, 683683) 352. SPEECH AT ARANMULA
('70', 333, 2, 3, 683707) January 20, 1937 The scene at this meeting is a visible demonstration of the fact that what I am just now doing is nothing but a pilgrimage.
('70', 333, 2, 4, 683848) There is the river Pampa, there is the temple and here are thousands of people gathered together to rejoice over the Proclamation.
('70', 333, 2, 5, 683979) Such are the scenes which are witnessed during the progress of pilgrims all over India.
('70', 333, 2, 6, 684067) But then, if pilgrimages are undoubtedly matters that furnish joy for the soul, they must at the same time continue to remind us that we should purify ourselves continually in order to satisfy our Maker.
('70', 333, 2, 7, 684271) All the more so because of the gracious Proclamation that His Highness the Maharaja has given us.
('70', 333, 2, 8, 684369) I know that here we are all Harijans and non Harijans united without the slightest distinction.
('70', 333, 2, 9, 684465) It is well if our hearts are also equally united.
('70', 333, 2, 10, 684515) But if they are not united and we cherish all kinds of distinctions that have for ages past disfigured Hindu society, we are unworthy of that great Proclamation.
('70', 333, 2, 11, 684677) Great is the responsobility that lies upon the shoulders of those who hitherto regarded themselves as belonging to the superior castes.
('70', 333, 2, 12, 684813) The Proclamation invites such people to descend from the pedestal which they have occupied with no credit but with utter discredit to themselves and the faith which they have hopelessly misrepresented.
('70', 333, 2, 13, 685015) Let me therefore hope and pray that all who have been called savarna Hindus will make the determination to get rid of untouchability from their hearts and make common cause with those whom they have suppressed for ages.
('70', 333, 2, 14, 685235) I must, as the pilgrimage is about to finish, put before you for your consideration and assimilation the Ishopanishad which I have been doing for the last four or five days.
('70', 333, 2, 15, 685409) Let the mantra be your guide and your inspiration in everything you do.
('70', 333, 2, 16, 685481) Its meaning can be understood by even a little child and it is this: God pervades the tiniest atom in this mighty universe, and seeing that He is the sole Ruler and indispensable Master of everything that can be conceived and that there is in this universe, we are called upon to dedicate everything to Him.
('70', 333, 2, 17, 685789) In our ignorance we have fancied that so many things belong to us and that we possess them to the exclusion of everybody else.
('70', 333, 2, 18, 685916) So long as we entertain such a belief, we are not really Hindus, though being born of Hindu parents we may call ourselves Hindus.
('70', 333, 2, 19, 686046) Therefore, to be truly, deliberately and consciously Hindus, we have got to act according to this key mantra of all Upanishads and the whole of
('70', 334, 0, 1, 686190) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 335
('70', 334, 1, 2, 686239) Hinduism and renounce everything, even our body, and all that we hold near and dear to us, and dedicate it at the feet of God.
('70', 334, 1, 3, 686366) Then the mantra says if you do this, but not otherwise, God will give you your daily bread, a house to live in and clothes to cover your limbs with.
('70', 334, 1, 4, 686515) And it proceeds further by saying that since God is all powerful and nothing is impossible for Him and since you have surrendered everything to Him, He is not going to neglect you.
('70', 334, 1, 5, 686696) And hence you shall not covet anything that belongs to others, even a needle.
('70', 334, 1, 6, 686774) Now you can easily understand that in the presence of God, the Ruler of the Universe, who pervades everything—even those whom we have called the lowest of the low—all are equal.
('70', 334, 1, 7, 686952) So you will see how necessary it was for His Highness to issue this Proclamation, if he was to make good his title to be called a Hindu prince.
('70', 334, 1, 8, 687096) Now as I leave you I would like to leave this mantra with you, and if anybody challenges you and says anything in the name of Hinduism which is contrary to this mantra, you can tell him that you know everything about Hinduism and everything contrary to it is not Hinduism.
('70', 334, 2, 9, 687369) The Epic of Travancore, pp.

('70', 335, 3, 9, 689070) 354. SPEECH AT PANDALAM 1
('70', 335, 4, 10, 689096) January 20, 1937
('70', 335, 5, 11, 689113) Many glorious meetings I have had in Travancore have now accustomed me to meetings, however large they may be, and to what I may call pin drop silence.
('70', 335, 5, 12, 689265) It is a unique phenomenon that I have witnessed in this piligrimage of mine.
('70', 335, 5, 13, 689342) I have a vivid and happy recoll ection of meetings addressed in Travancore during my three previous visits.
('70', 335, 5, 14, 689450) I well remember they were very orderly and gave me great satisfaction.
('70', 335, 5, 15, 689521) But somehow or other this being in my opinion a purely religious pilgrimage of a humble penitent, I have been in need of perfect silence and I have been amply rewarded for my prayers.
('70', 335, 5, 16, 689705) At Kottayam I saw before me about this time last evening a vast assemblage of men and women whose number no one could calculate.
('70', 335, 5, 17, 689834) It was a sea of human faces.
('70', 335, 5, 18, 689863) I simply approached it in fear and trembling, because there was unfortunately no microphone arrang ement there.
('70', 335, 5, 19, 689975) The organizers had tried their best to make the arrang ement, but they had failed.
('70', 335, 5, 20, 690058) And yet, you will be pleased to learn from me that in that meeting, which was nearly ten times as large as this, there was wonderful silence for an hour or more.
('70', 335, 5, 21, 690220) I was amazed at this absolutely unexpected silence and patience of thousands of men and women at this vast meeting.
('70', 335, 5, 22, 690336) I am not mentioning these facts in order to satisfy idle curiosity or fill in the idle moments.
('70', 335, 5, 23, 690432) I mention this in order to emphasize the fact that these meetings have a religious character, and I hope I am not wrong to infer from the behaviour of these vast crowds that they were fired within, perhaps unconsciously,
('70', 335, 6, 24, 690653) 1 A report of the speech also appeared in Harijan, 6 2 1937.
('70', 336, 0, 1, 690714) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 337
('70', 336, 1, 2, 690763) by a religious spirit.
('70', 336, 1, 3, 690786) Whatever may have been the cause of this divine silence that you have given me, I know that for me there can be no other meaning.
('70', 336, 1, 4, 690916) I have regarded this, Proclamation as an act of Divinity, though outwardly it is the act of a great prince.
('70', 336, 1, 5, 691024) Any man, if possible even braver than the young Maharaja and his wise mother, would have quailed if he had reasoned out the pros and cons of a Proclamation of this character, and yet it was this young Maharaja who signed the Proclamation which was complete for the purpose for which it was intended.
('70', 336, 1, 6, 691324) And therefore it is that I have often said that though it was his hand that put the signature to the Proclamation, the spirit behind it was that of God working through the Maharaja.
('70', 336, 1, 7, 691506) Having, therefore, looked at the Proclamation in that light and having approached this pilgrimage in fear and trembling, I have pined for the opening out of your hearts.
('70', 336, 1, 8, 691676) I have not made a conscious effort to make any appeal to your reason, but I have made a conscious effort to make an appeal to your hearts and penetrate them, and unless I have deluded myself I fancy that I have made some approaches to your hearts.
('70', 336, 1, 9, 691924) Whether I have done so or not, I want to repeat what I have said at the previous meetings: that the burden of carrying out the Proclamation in letter and in spirit rests principally on savarna Hindus.
('70', 336, 1, 10, 692125) And the implication is emphatically this, that the savarna Hindus have to forget their wrong understanding of the message of Hinduism and the distinctions that they have up to now drawn between themselves and the avarna Hindus.
('70', 336, 1, 11, 692353) The Proclamation emphatically means that untouchability, unapproachability and unseeability are all relics of the past and that those Hindus who have arrogated superiority for themselves will forget that they were superior human beings and will remember that they are the children of the same God and that all savarnas and avarnas are equal.
('70', 336, 1, 12, 692695) The Proclamation is addressed to every Hindu, and every one of you is expected to show that he has understood it and he has to carry it out in his day to day dealings with those whom he has hitherto regarded as Pariahs of socity.
('70', 336, 1, 13, 692925) I do not propose to carry on this appeal to the savarna Hindus any further tonight.
('70', 336, 1, 14, 693009) The Maharaja had nothing to do beyond issuing the Procla mation.
('70', 336, 1, 15, 693074) It was cent per cent truthful in so far as one would want to know his opinion in regard to untouchability.
('70', 336, 1, 16, 693181) So far as I can see, there is nothing to amplify the Proclamation.
('70', 336, 1, 17, 693248) Therefore, in your presence I propose to address a few words to His Highness, Her Highness and to their advisers.
('70', 337, 0, 1, 693362) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 338
('70', 337, 1, 2, 693404) Great as this Proclamation is and great as is its religious merit, greater still is the responsibility that His Highness has taken upon his shoulders, and also that of his advisers.
('70', 337, 1, 3, 693586) Whilst without the effort of every savarna Hindu the Proclamation can undoubtedly be rendered ineffective, I must also say that the Proclamation will not have its full effect unless it is backed in an ample measure by State action.
('70', 337, 1, 4, 693818) So far as I can see the Proclamation demands State activities in all departments of life.
('70', 337, 1, 5, 693908) Of these I propose to take the religious first; because from it must follow activities in all the other departments.
('70', 337, 1, 6, 694025) Temples have been matters of indifference, except to women, who have no capital save divine faith, and to men who from many mixed motives have been going to them.
('70', 337, 1, 7, 694188) They have been neglected by what may be called the intelligentsia.
('70', 337, 1, 8, 694255) The result has been that they have almost ceased to be repositories of Hinduism and have ceased to impart spiritual power to those who have followed the faith.
('70', 337, 1, 9, 694415) They have ceased to shed unmistakeble spiritual fragrance in and about and around them.
('70', 337, 1, 10, 694503) Then I venture to suggest that it is the duty of the State or of the Maharaja—if there is any distinction betweem the two, for he is the custodian of the vast majority of Hindu temples—that he should see to it that the temples are renovated spiritually and have the authority and sanctity that they used undoubtedly to have at one time.
('70', 337, 1, 11, 694840) And I believe that it can only be done if they are in charge of priests who know what they have to do, who know something of the sanctity of them and of the duties to which they are called.
('70', 337, 1, 12, 695030) In other words, they should not be ignorant people following their calling for a livelihood but they should be men who are proud of their privilege of bringing the message of God to temple goers, showing by their own conduct and their life that these temples are abodes of Divinity.
('70', 337, 1, 13, 695313) Then there should be the correct kind of instruction given in these temples.
('70', 337, 1, 14, 695390) The Harijans will be taken by the hand by someone in charge of temples and they will be told what they are expected to gain by temple worship.
('70', 337, 1, 15, 695533) This means undoubtedly, according to modern thought, a revolution in the upkeep and conduct of these temples.
('70', 337, 1, 16, 695643) But the Proclamation itself is nothing short of a revolutionary document and if that revolution is to touch, as it ought to touch, the lives of all Hindus, naturally temples have to be abodes of the living God and not abodes of a mere mass of gold or other metals worked into figures.
('70', 337, 1, 17, 695928) Then I should expect a history of these temples, understandable by the common folk, to be distributed free or at a cheap price to all who want to know what these temples are.
('70', 337, 1, 18, 696103) That means a training school for
('70', 338, 0, 1, 696136) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 339
('70', 338, 1, 2, 696185) training the right kind of teachers who will be entrusted with the religious training of the people.
('70', 338, 1, 3, 696286) If some such thing does not happen, I fear that the purpose of the Proclamation, viz., to expect and to induce lakhs and lakhs of Harijans to go to these temples in a religious spirit, will fail.
('70', 338, 1, 4, 696482) So much for the religious department.
('70', 338, 1, 5, 696520) Then I take the economic.
('70', 338, 1, 6, 696546) The economic life of the Harijans has got to be lifted out of its miserable state.
('70', 338, 1, 7, 696629) I venture to think that by a judicious and thoughtful working out of the programme, it can be prosecuted in a short time and with a limited financial outlay, in such a manner that Harijans may be easily able to hold their own by being taught to turn an honest chakram.
('70', 338, 1, 8, 696898) Nor can the State now dare neglect the mental training—I mean literary—of these people.
('70', 338, 1, 9, 696986) I know to my cost that today it is very difficult to carry on a connected conversation with Pulayas and Pariahs so that you can get a ready response even about simple facts of life.
('70', 338, 1, 10, 697168) Similarly, the State has to raise the social status of these people.
('70', 338, 1, 11, 697237) They should be invited to all State occasions and functions, as for instance Durbars.
('70', 338, 1, 12, 697323) They must not be allowed to feel that these functions are a sealed book to them, and that they should have to have another agitation before they can attain a social status entitling them to be invited or allowed to take part in those functions.
('70', 338, 1, 13, 697568) But if the Proclamation bears the meaning I have given to it, then the social uplift of the Harijans has to come as if by magic, as the religious status of going to the temples has come.
('70', 338, 1, 14, 697755) In my humble opinion, in suggesting this fourfold programme of the uplift of the Harijans in the State I have not suggested any programme beyond the capacity or resources of a State like Travancore.
('70', 338, 1, 15, 697954) But having addressed these few words to the State in all humility, I want to come back to you.
('70', 338, 1, 16, 698049) The State may resolve to do all these things, but its resolution will not mean the coming in of manpower in order to carry out all these things.
('70', 338, 1, 17, 698194) And if, from the few words I have addressed to Their Highnesses and their advisers, you think that after all it is Their Highnesses who have to do everything and you have to do nothing, then I am afraid that my labours will have gone in vain.
('70', 338, 1, 18, 698437) The resquisite manpower has got to be supplied by you, and as a man of experience I will tell you that manpower cannot come by offers of money.
('70', 338, 1, 19, 698581) Thus, for instance, men who are capable of taking the
('70', 339, 0, 1, 698635) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 340
('70', 339, 1, 2, 698677) management of temples cannot be had by offering scholarships of hundreds of rupees.
('70', 339, 1, 3, 698761) For such people have got to be fired by a religious spirit, by love of their own work, and should therefore be ready to work for a bare maintenance.
('70', 339, 1, 4, 698910) It should be their proud privilege to take this training and to fit themselves for this highest task in life.
('70', 339, 1, 5, 699020) Similarly, unless the State gets men required for giving Harijans educational training, the State can do nothing.
('70', 339, 1, 6, 699134) After all, there is a world of meaning about the title that the Maharajas of Travancore have adopted for themselves, viz., Padm anabhadas.They pride themselves in calling themselves servants of God, but that means that they are also servants of their people.
('70', 339, 1, 7, 699393) So, as I said at one of these meetings, the Maharajas are not the first lords among the people of Travancore, but they are the first servants among the people who are also servants.
('70', 339, 1, 8, 699575) But the first servants of the people will fare badly unless they are ably assisted by the people who are their fellow servants.
('70', 339, 1, 9, 699703) Therefore the meaning of His Highness the Maharaja going to the temple every day and taking instructions as to his daily duties from Shri Padmanabhaswami means nothing less than that he should be assisted by his people for their own good—spiritual, religious, social, economic.

('70', 341, 1, 2, 703308) zoological specimen.

('70', 341, 1, 5, 703615) But if such is really the case, I am here to tell you that the whole of my life and growth are due to such figments of imagination and it would be true at least to say of me that I have needed these figments for my growth.

('70', 341, 1, 8, 704393) The meaning of that verse is this: God the Ruler, our Master and Lord, pervades everything in the universe down to the tiniest atom.
('70', 341, 1, 9, 704526) It means that He is not merely in your heart or my heart but he is literally and absolutely in every one of the innumerable pores of our skin and the hair of our head.
('70', 341, 1, 10, 704694) And, therefore, He is nearer to you and to me than our dearest ones.
('70', 341, 1, 11, 704763) Then the first essential of Hinduism is that we realize the truth of this magnificent statement as we realize that we are sitting here and you are listening to me.
('70', 341, 1, 12, 704927) Having realized the truth, the seer proceeds to say that since God is so near to us and dominates all our actions, we must voluntarily renounce and dedicate at His feet all that we have regarded as our own.
('70', 341, 1, 13, 705134) But even after that act of conscious and deliberate dedication and renunciation , we shall want to eat, clothe ourselves and house ourselves, and so the seer says you can only after this dedication use these necessaries of life as if they were given to you by God Himself.
('70', 341, 1, 14, 705407) That requires the same trust, the same faith and the same love that a child without reasoning it out for himself has for his parents.
('70', 341, 1, 15, 705541) He never reasons out for himself that it is all well with them and for him so long as his parents are there and so long as they continue to anticipate and supply his wants.
('70', 341, 1, 16, 705714) Our parents are as much mortal as we ourselves, and therefore it is infinitely more logical and necessary for us that we should have as much faith in God to anticipate and supply our wants.
('70', 341, 1, 17, 705904) And having told us these three things, the seer proceeds to warn us against coveting anybody’s possessions.
('70', 341, 1, 18, 706012) Now you will see that if we
('70', 342, 0, 1, 706040) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 343
('70', 342, 1, 2, 706089) believe in this mantra—and every Hindu is bound to believe in it— there would be no distinctions like those which have been sapping the very foundations of Hinduism and Hindu society.
('70', 342, 1, 3, 706273) Now you can also at once realize why temples are and must be an integral part of our lives.
('70', 342, 1, 4, 706365) We are so easily forgetful of our obligations that we have to renew our vows of loyalty to God, renew our renunciation and dedication from day to day.
('70', 342, 1, 5, 706516) These temples are the visible symbols of God’s power and authority.
('70', 342, 1, 6, 706584) They are, therefore, truly called the houses of God, the houses of prayer.
('70', 342, 1, 7, 706659) We go there in a prayerful mood and perform, first thing in the morning after ablutions, the act of dedication and surrender.

('70', 345, 3, 13, 714882) 358. INTERVIEW TO “THE HINDU”
('70', 345, 4, 14, 714912) MADRAS, January 22, 1937
('70', 345, 5, 15, 714937) This visit to Travancore has been in every sense of the term a pilgrimage for me.
('70', 345, 5, 16, 715019) The Harijan tour of Orissa, which in part I made on foot, I did describe as a pilgrimage.
('70', 345, 5, 17, 715109) But it was not a pilgrimage in the orthodox sense of the term, except perhaps in the language of Nandana.
('70', 345, 5, 18, 715215) Has it not been said that he walked miles in order to see God face to face in the temple of his imagination, while knowing that the temple doors would be shut in his face?
('70', 345, 5, 19, 715387) The difference, however, is that he succeeded in being admitted to the temple, whereas in Orissa, I failed hopelessly.
('70', 346, 0, 1, 715506) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 347
('70', 346, 1, 2, 715555) To Travancore I went in the spirit of an orthodox pilgrim knowing beforehand that the very temples that were closed to me because they were closed to fellow Harijans, were open for me and them.
('70', 346, 1, 3, 715749) In this sense this was the very first pilgrimage I had ever undertaken in my life.
('70', 346, 1, 4, 715832) Though before I decided not to visit temples that were closed to Harijans, I visited some temples, it was not as a pilgrim.
('70', 346, 1, 5, 715956) It was part of the tour or tours undertaken for other purposes, for instance khadi and Khilafat.
('70', 346, 1, 6, 716053) But this was definitely to visit numerous temples in Travancore.
('70', 346, 1, 7, 716118) And I must say that my most sanguine expectations were more than realized.
('70', 346, 2, 8, 716193) The so called savarnas and the so called avarnas mingled without distinction, in their thousands, everywhere I went.
('70', 346, 2, 9, 716310) They entered the numerous temples without let or hindrance.
('70', 346, 2, 10, 716370) The officiating priests conducted their service and distributed flowers, sandal paste and prasadam without the slightest hesitation.
('70', 346, 2, 11, 716503) I saw no sullenness in their faces.
('70', 346, 2, 12, 716539) The whole scene seemed to me to be a spontaneous response to the Proclamation and a recognition of the fact that it was meeting a long felt want.
('70', 346, 2, 13, 716685) I had the fear that Harijans would not flock to the temples as they did.
('70', 346, 2, 14, 716758) I had also the fear that this long deprivation might have made them indifferent to temple worship, nay, indifferent to religion itself.
('70', 346, 2, 15, 716894) Evidently it was not so.
('70', 346, 2, 16, 716919) They must have felt the craving, consciously or unconsciously, for the worship of which they were deprived, when the other Hindus, called savarnas, were not.
('70', 346, 2, 17, 717077) So it appeared to me that they came into their own naturally; and, therefore, there was no difficulty about their knowing what a devotional spirit was or how they should worship.
('70', 346, 3, 18, 717256) I know thousands came to the temples, and lined the roads leading to them.
('70', 346, 3, 19, 717331) The silence that they observed was exemplary and worthy of the sacredness of the occasion.

('70', 349, 6, 18, 724350) QUESTION: What do you think of communism?
('70', 349, 6, 19, 724392) Do you think it would be good for India?
('70', 349, 7, 20, 724433) ANSWER: Communism of the Russian type, that is communism which is imposed on a people, would be repugnant to India.
('70', 349, 7, 21, 724549) I believe in non violent communism.
('70', 349, 8, 22, 724585) Q. But communism in Russia is against private property.
('70', 349, 8, 23, 724641) Do you want private property?
('70', 349, 9, 24, 724671) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter” 2 According to Mahadev Desai the interview took place when Gandhiji was preparing to go to bed because he was to get up at 3 o’clock the next morning to visit the cyclone affected areas.

('70', 350, 0, 1, 724934) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 351
('70', 350, 1, 2, 724983) A. If communism came without any violence, it would be welcome.
('70', 350, 1, 3, 725047) For then no property would be held by anybody except on behalf of the people and for the people.
('70', 350, 1, 4, 725144) The millionaire may have his millions, but he will hold them for the people.
('70', 350, 1, 5, 725221) The State could take charge of them whenever they would need them for the common cause.
('70', 350, 2, 6, 725309) Q. Is there any difference of opinion between you and Jawaharlal in respect of socialism?
('70', 350, 3, 7, 725399) A. There is, but it is a difference in emphasis.
('70', 350, 3, 8, 725448) He perhaps puts an emphasis on the result, whereas I put on the means.
('70', 350, 3, 9, 725519) Perhaps according to him I am putting over emphasis on non violence, whereas he, though he believes in non violence, would want to have socialism by other means if it was impossible to have it by non violence.
('70', 350, 3, 10, 725729) Of course my emphasis on non violence becomes one of principle.
('70', 350, 3, 11, 725793) Even if I was assured that we could have independence by means of violence, I shall refuse to have it.
('70', 350, 3, 12, 725896) It won’t be real independence.
('70', 350, 4, 13, 725927) Q. But do you think the English will leave India to you and go back peacefully as a result of your non violent agitation?

('70', 354, 3, 15, 734112) 367. CONUNDRUMS 1
('70', 354, 4, 16, 734130) A friend has addressed me the following conundrums:
('70', 354, 5, 17, 734182) (1) If temples are thrown open to the Harijans, there is danger of their next insisting on being admitted to all the parts where the priest is admitted, only because they satisfy the test of personal cleanliness.
('70', 354, 6, 18, 734395) (2) Your statement that God does not reside in temples where Harijans are not admitted seems to me to be a one sided and therefore misleading statement.
('70', 354, 6, 19, 734548) In my opinion it is as untrue to say that God is not in temples where Harijans are not admitted as that God is to be found only in temples and not outside.
('70', 354, 6, 20, 734704) It challenged, as it were, the omnipresence of God.
('70', 354, 6, 21, 734756) He is everywhere; there is no place where He is not.
('70', 354, 7, 22, 734809) (3) Then, you say that Hinduism must perish if untouchability lives.
('70', 354, 7, 23, 734878) But Hinduism has continued to exist all these years in spite of the institution of untouchability, and there is no reason why it should be otherwise now or in future.
('70', 354, 7, 24, 735045) Nor should you forget that it is Hinduism with its much abused institution of untouchability that, on your own admission, has in the past brought you spiritual peace and consolation.
('70', 354, 7, 25, 735228) Now, for my reply.
('70', 354, 7, 26, 735247) A man of faith may not shrink from his present duties or deviate from the right path for fear of possible difficulties in the future.
('70', 354, 7, 27, 735381) The only thing for us, therefore, is to
('70', 354, 8, 28, 735421) 1 The Gujarati original of this was published in Harijanbandhu, 24 1 1937. This translation is by Pyarelal.
('70', 355, 0, 1, 735529) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 356
('70', 355, 1, 2, 735571) proceed by implicitly accepting absolute equality between ourselves and the harijans and to give them the same credit for reasonableness as we claim for ourselves.
('70', 355, 1, 3, 735735) All past experience goes to show that they do not resent such restrictions as are reasonable and apply equally to the savarna Hindus, but they naturally do not and cannot be expected to appreciate and accept ex cathedra usages that discriminate between savarnas and avarnas, and between the different groups among the avarnas themselves, as these smack of invidiousness and offend against reason.
('70', 355, 1, 4, 736132) (2) True, the statement that God does not dwell in temples from which Harijans are excluded is one sided and therefore true in a certain and limited sense only.
('70', 355, 1, 5, 736293) But does that not apply to human speech itself?
('70', 355, 1, 6, 736341) But we have not on that account condemned or discarded the use of human speech.
('70', 355, 1, 7, 736421) With all its imperfections as a vehicle for the expression of truth, we must rely on it for all practical purposes, or it would spell an end of all human intercourse.
('70', 355, 1, 8, 736588) Tulsidas has made Rama say in his Ramayana that God dwells only in the hearts of the good and the pure, not of those who are wicked or evil minded.
('70', 355, 1, 9, 736736) Now this statement, again, is only partly true.
('70', 355, 1, 10, 736784) But still more untrue and mischievous in its pragmatic effect would be its reverse, viz, that God dwells in the hearts of the wicked and evil minded too and actuates them in their evil deeds, though as a strictly scientific statement of truth it would be perhaps nearer the mark.
('70', 355, 1, 11, 737064) In a strictly scientific sense God is at the bottom of both good and evil.
('70', 355, 1, 12, 737139) He directs the assassin’s dagger no less than the surgeon’s knife.
('70', 355, 1, 13, 737206) But for all that good and evil are, for human purposes, from each other distinct and incompatible, being symbolical of light and darkness, God and Satan, Ahriman and Ormuzd respectively.
('70', 355, 1, 14, 737393) My statement, therefore, that where Harijans are excluded there God is not, must stand.
('70', 355, 1, 15, 737481) (3) My correspondent’s argument here altogether lacks point.
('70', 355, 1, 16, 737542) The slow disintegration of Hinduism one can see even today taking place under our very nose, mainly and principally in consequence of the curse of untouchability.
('70', 355, 1, 17, 737705) Anyone who has eyes can see it.
('70', 355, 1, 18, 737737) A moribund, life in death sort of existence should not be mistaken for life; in fact it is more distressing than death itself.
('70', 355, 1, 19, 737864) If a person like me can today derive spiritual force and consolation from Hinduism, it is because I have never regarded untouchability as an integral part of Hinduism.
('70', 355, 1, 20, 738032) It may perhaps be objected that the term ‘disintegration of Hinduism’ which I have used is misleading since disintegration of Hindu society need not necessarily mean the disintegration of Hindu
('70', 356, 0, 1, 738226) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 357
('70', 356, 1, 2, 738275) religion.
('70', 356, 1, 3, 738285) The objection is based on a fallacy and is only partly valid.
('70', 356, 1, 4, 738347) In mundane sense a faith can have no existence apart from its votaries.
('70', 356, 1, 5, 738419) It may personally console me even if I can bear witness to my faith as its sole surviving representative; but of what avail would it be to those millions who fell away from it?
('70', 356, 2, 6, 738596) Harijan, 20 2 1937
('70', 356, 3, 7, 738615) 368. HARIJAN ASHRAMS IN KATHIAWAR
('70', 356, 4, 8, 738649) My help is expected in raising of funds for these Ashrams.
('70', 356, 4, 9, 738708) I am sorry to say that my plight is as pitiable as that of the man who having once burnt his tongue with milk, blows even on buttermilk before drinking it.
('70', 356, 4, 10, 738864) This does not mean that no one should help those ashrams.
('70', 356, 4, 11, 738922) I can no longer request people or write to them as I did in the past.
('70', 356, 4, 12, 738992) I do not have the courage to do so.
('70', 356, 4, 13, 739028) But those who have been supporting such ashrams should make inquiries for their own satisfaction and continue to help them if they are satisfied.
('70', 356, 4, 14, 739174) It has never happened with regard to any institution in the world that all the workers have turned out good.
('70', 356, 4, 15, 739283) This should not stop all the public activities.
('70', 356, 4, 16, 739331) If some workers have proved to be false coin, there are others who have been carrying on their work in keeping with moral principles and have brought credit to their institutions.
('70', 356, 4, 17, 739511) The work of Harijan welfare will go on and it should go on.
('70', 356, 4, 18, 739571) All that is necessary is that the organizers who have so far depended on me should give up all hopes of me.
('70', 356, 4, 19, 739679) I am alive today, but may not be tomorrow.
('70', 356, 4, 20, 739722) How long can one trust one’s physical frame?
('70', 356, 4, 21, 739767) Hence the organizers should consider my pitiable condition and, relying on themselves, bring credit to the institutions to which they belong.
('70', 356, 4, 22, 739909) Those who are engaged in Harijan welfare activities or any other service should never give up faith or their work.

('70', 359, 4, 5, 743441) 373. LETTER TO KANTILAL GANDHI
('70', 359, 5, 6, 743472) SEGAON, WARDHA, January 26, 1937
('70', 359, 7, 7, 743505) I got your letter.
('70', 359, 7, 8, 743524) It does not become you to say that you should like to go Rasik’s way.
('70', 359, 7, 9, 743594) If you believe that you are taking due care of your health, I would have nothing to say.
('70', 359, 7, 10, 743683) I thought you were joking when you said that you wished to fly to Paparamma.
('70', 359, 7, 11, 743760) On the subject being mentioned casually, Prabhavati told me that you really wanted to fly to Trivandrum.
('70', 359, 7, 12, 743865) If this is true, then it is something I don’t like.
('70', 359, 7, 13, 743917) The aeroplane is not for the poor or for a man who is patient.
('70', 359, 7, 14, 743980) You probably know that I don’t like even cars, though I do use them when I can’t help it.
('70', 359, 7, 15, 744070) This may be described as a weakness of mine.
('70', 359, 7, 16, 744115) Moreover, where is the plane fare to come from?
('70', 359, 7, 17, 744163) If any friend offers to pay it, I wouldn’t like you to accept it, nor even if Paparamma sends it.
('70', 359, 7, 18, 744261) I can’t stand your becoming a beggar.
('70', 359, 7, 19, 744299) But this is my philosophy.
('70', 359, 7, 20, 744326) You need not ask for my permission to fly in a plane.
('70', 359, 7, 21, 744380) You are free and I should like you to act freely.
('70', 359, 7, 22, 744430) It would be a different thing if you deferred to my views voluntarily and with faith.
('70', 359, 7, 23, 744516) Your freedom will not be compromised thereby.
('70', 359, 7, 24, 744562) But I shouldn’t like it if you did something to please me or out of fear of me.
('70', 359, 7, 25, 744642) That will not be for your good.
('70', 359, 7, 26, 744674) I would rather that you acted upon only those ideas of mine which you can readily accept.
('70', 359, 7, 27, 744764) How can you help it if you can’t like my ideas?
('70', 359, 7, 28, 744812) If I were to find fault with you for that, I myself would be guilty of a wrong.

('70', 364, 10, 23, 752020) 382. A CHRISTIAN LETTER
('70', 364, 11, 24, 752044) Rajkumari Amrit Kaur was with me during the Travancore pilgrimage.
('70', 364, 11, 25, 752111) Though she could not enter the temples, she followed the pilgrimage in all other respects.
('70', 364, 11, 26, 752202) She has felt moved by what she observed during the pilgrimage, and has placed in my hands the following letter 1 which I dare not withhold from the reader:
('70', 364, 12, 27, 752358) I am of opinion that the missionary with the best intention in the world—for we must credit him with honesty of purpose—has wronged Indian Christians in more ways than one.
('70', 364, 12, 28, 752531) Many converts here have been denationalized, e.g., even their names have been changed in many instances

('70', 365, 1, 5, 753190) I say ‘so called Christianity’ advisedly, because I know that not one of these poor people to whom I have spoken—and I have spoken to many— has been able to tell me anything of the spiritual implications of his change of faith.

('70', 366, 1, 2, 755640) For me the different religions are beautiful flowers from the same garden, or they are branches of the same majestic tree.
('70', 366, 1, 3, 755763) Therefore they are equally true, though being received and interpreted through human instruments equally imperfect.
('70', 366, 1, 4, 755879) It is impossible for me to reconcile myself to the idea of conversion after the style that goes on in India and elsewhere today.
('70', 366, 1, 5, 756008) It is an error which is perhaps the greatest impediment to the world’s progress towards peace.
('70', 366, 1, 6, 756103) ‘Warring creeds’ is a blasphemous expression.
('70', 366, 1, 7, 756149) And it fitly describes the state of things in India, the mother as I believe her to be of religion or religions.
('70', 366, 1, 8, 756262) If she is truly the mother, the motherhood is on trial .
('70', 366, 1, 9, 756319) Why should a Christian want to convert a Hindu to Christianity and vice versa?
('70', 366, 1, 10, 756398) Why should he not be satisfied if the Hindu is a good or godly man?
('70', 366, 1, 11, 756466) If the morals of a man are a matter of no concern, the form of worship in a particular manner in a church, a mosque or a temple is an empty formula, it may even be a hindrance to individual or social growth, and insistence on a particular form or repetition of a credo may be a potent cause of violent quarrels leading to bloodshed and ending in utter disbelief in religion, i.e., God Himself.
('70', 366, 2, 12, 756860) Harijan, 30 1 1937
('70', 366, 3, 13, 756879) 383. WANT OF THOROUGHNESS
('70', 366, 4, 14, 756905) There is in Travancore an association called The All Kerala Young Folks’ League.
('70', 366, 4, 15, 756986) Its ambitious motto is ‘We serve’.
('70', 366, 4, 16, 757021) They have also a ‘League of Pity’ as a branch activity.
('70', 366, 4, 17, 757077) For want of time, during the nine days’ rush in Travancore, for a personal discussion, the members sent me a letter from which I cull the following:
('70', 366, 5, 18, 757226) Boys and girls are encouraged to learn some handicrafts by which they can earn some money.
('70', 366, 5, 19, 757317) We are quite glad to tell you that many of our boys have taken to spinning as one of their hobbies.
('70', 366, 5, 20, 757417) As beginners in this field, we have also several problems to be solved and difficulties to be encompassed.
('70', 366, 5, 21, 757524) The one thing that is troubling us much regarding the spinning of yarn is its disposal.
('70', 366, 5, 22, 757612) We submit that the yarn produced by our boys and girls is of a low type and cannot find a good market.
('70', 366, 5, 23, 757715) But the difficulty even for the good type of yarn is that we cannot sell even that to our advantage.
('70', 366, 5, 24, 757816) And hence many of our members have begun to drop the hobby.
('70', 366, 5, 25, 757876) We shall be grateful if you please tell us of some method to dispose of it.
('70', 366, 5, 26, 757952) A portion of the money thus earned by the members is given to the poor.
('70', 367, 0, 1, 758024) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 368
('70', 367, 1, 2, 758066) On every Onam day all our members, regardless of caste or creed, collect together to celebrate our Goodwill Day.
('70', 367, 1, 3, 758179) On that day, they burn in public a devil’s form made of straw to represent untouchability, the day’s programme closing with a common dinner.
('70', 367, 1, 4, 758320) The League has a very ambitious programme and a high sounding motto.
('70', 367, 1, 5, 758389) It seems to me that they will neither serve themselves nor society unless they are thorough in whatever they take up.
('70', 367, 1, 6, 758507) In trying to be thorough they may have to cut out some or even many activities.
('70', 367, 1, 7, 758587) If such be the case, they should not hesitate to do so.
('70', 367, 1, 8, 758643) They seek my advice on spinning as they rightly think I, as the author of the movement, should be able to guide them.
('70', 367, 1, 9, 758761) They call it one of their hobbies.
('70', 367, 1, 10, 758796) But even hobbies need to be thoroughly cultivated if they are to yield the greatest amount of enjoyment.
('70', 367, 1, 11, 758901) They are mistaken in thinking that good yarn has no market.
('70', 367, 1, 12, 758961) If they produce strong and even yarn of 8 counts, it will have a market in Nagercoil.
('70', 367, 1, 13, 759047) I suggest a better use, however, of their yarn.
('70', 367, 1, 14, 759095) They should add weaving to their hobby of spinning.
('70', 367, 1, 15, 759147) If they will do so, the coarse yarn which the beginners will turn out can be woven into tape, nevar, asana, carpets, etc., and the fine into dhotis for men and women.
('70', 367, 1, 16, 759314) They need not seek a market for such wares.
('70', 367, 1, 17, 759358) For they will hardly produce enough for their own personal use.
('70', 367, 1, 18, 759422) If they will specialize in this one hobby, they will sufficiently live up to their motto of service and many young men will most certainly earn a living if they become whole time workers.
('70', 367, 1, 19, 759610) The League has 7,000 members.
('70', 367, 1, 20, 759640) They make a nucleus of true co operative society.
('70', 367, 1, 21, 759690) They can run a store or stores which will sell articles manufactured by the members, and they will be mainly only such articles as the members themselves will require.
('70', 367, 1, 22, 759858) Khadi can assuredly come first in any such co operative activity.
('70', 367, 1, 23, 759924) And Travancore or rather the whole of Kerala is a place where khadi can easily become universal, for the Kerala people, both men and women, have the simplest dress of all India and it is all white.
('70', 367, 1, 24, 760122) Even the border is a late innovation.
('70', 367, 1, 25, 760160) But let the League members remember that spinning includes all the anterior processes beginning with picking of cotton, disengaging it from pods, cleaning, ginning and carding it and turning it into slivers.
('70', 367, 1, 26, 760368) If they are all well done, they are fascinating occupations giving exercise both to the body and the mind.
('70', 367, 1, 27, 760475) If they will turn to spinning in the spirit of scientists, let them read the article ‘What Is Khadi Science?’ 1 in Harijan of the 16th inst.

('70', 368, 1, 2, 760726) 384.LETTER TO SUSHILA GANDHI
('70', 368, 2, 3, 760755) SEGAON, WARDHA, January 30, 1937
('70', 368, 3, 4, 760788) SUSHILA,
('70', 368, 4, 5, 760797) You have been shouldering heavy responsibility.
('70', 368, 4, 6, 760845) May God help you.
('70', 368, 4, 7, 760863) But God will help you only if you help yourself.
('70', 368, 4, 8, 760912) If your health is not good nor Sita’s, how long can you keep yourself up?
('70', 368, 4, 9, 760986) If your health improves you can take up a lot of work.
('70', 368, 4, 10, 761041) But you do not observe self control.
('70', 368, 4, 11, 761078) How did you have the miscarriage?
('70', 368, 4, 12, 761112) You two are not children.
('70', 368, 4, 13, 761138) One’s life should become reflective.
('70', 368, 4, 14, 761175) One should acquire control over the senses.
('70', 368, 4, 15, 761219) Why should the senses drag us?
('70', 368, 4, 16, 761250) Is there anything more shameful than that?
('70', 368, 4, 17, 761293) If you exercise control over your food and your personal habits, then your body will become healthy and both of you will be happy.
('70', 368, 4, 18, 761424) And you will be able to handle a lot of Manilal’s work.
('70', 368, 4, 19, 761480) Instead of making Sita a doll, you should start giving her training in domestic chores right from now.
('70', 368, 4, 20, 761583) If your own life is methodical, she will automatically learn a great deal.
('70', 368, 4, 21, 761658) Sita and you should take both types of Kuhne baths.
('70', 368, 4, 22, 761710) You must take to walking for exercise.
('70', 368, 4, 23, 761749) In diet, you should take fruit and things made from whole wheat flour, drink fresh milk and eat green vegetables in moderate quantities.
('70', 368, 4, 24, 761886) If you get fresh milk, there is not much need for ghee.
('70', 368, 4, 25, 761942) You can make such changes in this as experience may suggest.
('70', 368, 4, 26, 762003) Do not feel unhappy about Shanti.
('70', 368, 4, 27, 762037) Be content with whatever service anyone renders.
('70', 368, 4, 28, 762086) If we do not fail in our duty we shall be able to overcome all obstacles.
('70', 368, 5, 29, 762160) Blessings from BAPU [PS.]
('70', 368, 6, 30, 762186) I won’t write a separate letter to Manilal now.
('70', 368, 6, 31, 762234) I wanted to write one but I have no time.

('70', 369, 1, 2, 762362) 385. NEED FOR TOLERANCE 1
('70', 369, 2, 3, 762388) A Mussalman friend had addressed me a long letter of which the following is the gist: 2
('70', 369, 3, 4, 762476) (1) I turned a vegetarian several years ago, being struck by the iniquitous cruelty of slaughtering God’s dumb creatures to provide meat for our tables.
('70', 369, 3, 5, 762629) Ever since then I have completely abjured the taking of meat though meat eating is allowed by Islam.
('70', 369, 3, 6, 762730) But I have not been able to induce my children to abjure meat eating likewise, with the result that I have still to procure meat for them from the bazzar.
('70', 369, 3, 7, 762885) Sometimes, however, I am troubled by a doubt whether this is not all wrong.
('70', 369, 3, 8, 762961) Would I remain a silent witness, if my children took to theft and murder, for instance?
('70', 369, 4, 9, 763049) (2) What I have said with regard to meat also holds good in respect of tea, betel leaf, soda water, lemonade, etc.
('70', 369, 5, 10, 763164) (3) I belong to the trader class and hence am quite conversant with the various shadowy tricks and devices that are in vogue among this class, e.g., how to exploit the inexperience and weakness of the buyer in order to palm off upon him goods that are utterly worthless, charging prices not according to the cost or to any fixed principle but according to what an unwary customer can be made to fork out and so on.
('70', 369, 5, 11, 763579) For years I have felt an innate repugnance against all this which Mrs. Besant once described as “white loot”.
('70', 369, 5, 12, 763689) But I feel utterly helpless.
('70', 369, 6, 13, 763718) (4) You regard Mahomed as a Prophet of God and hold him in high regard.
('70', 369, 6, 14, 763790) You have even publicly spoken of him in the highest terms.
('70', 369, 6, 15, 763849) I have heard and even seen reports in cold print to the effect that you have studied the Koran itself.
('70', 369, 6, 16, 763952) All this, I must confess, has puzzled me.
('70', 369, 6, 17, 763994) I am at a loss to understand how a person like you, with all your passion for truth and justice, who has never failed to gloss over [sic ] a single fault in Hinduism or to repudiate as unauthentic the numerous corruptions that masquerade under it, can holus bolus accept all that is in the Koran.
('70', 369, 6, 18, 764291) I am not aware of your ever having called into question or denounced any iniquitous injunction of Islam.
('70', 369, 6, 19, 764396) Against some of these I learnt to revolt when I was scarcely 18 or 20 years old and time has since only strengthened that first feeling.
('70', 369, 6, 20, 764533) I have tried as far as was possible to retain the language of the original, taking liberty only to soften a few expressions here and there, but have otherwise scrupulously kept the sense intact.
('70', 369, 6, 21, 764728) To come to the
('70', 369, 7, 22, 764743) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 31 1 1937. The translation is by Pyarelal.
('70', 369, 7, 23, 764845) 2 Only extracts have been reproduced here.
('70', 370, 0, 1, 764888) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 FEBRUARY, 1937 371
('70', 370, 1, 2, 764937) various points mentioned by my correspondent.
('70', 370, 1, 3, 764983) He deserves to be congratulated on his giving up meat eating and on the various other disciplines that he has cultivated.
('70', 370, 1, 4, 765105) But he may not impose the same on his unwilling or half willing relations or dependents.
('70', 370, 1, 5, 765194) Let him try to touch their hearts and reason by the means of persuasion at his command; but anything more than that before the desired conversion has come about would be compulsion and therefore unjustifiable.
('70', 370, 1, 6, 765404) It would obviously be too much for him to expect the members of his family all of a sudden to break with a life long habit that has never been regarded as contrary to Islam, which is almost universal among the Mussalmans today and till yesterday was followed by the friend in question himself.
('70', 370, 1, 7, 765698) Let him not forget the long years of strenuous introspection and struggle which he took before he arrived at his decision.
('70', 370, 1, 8, 765821) To require now his dependents to adopt that decision at a stroke would only betray impatience on his part.
('70', 370, 1, 9, 765928) The golden rule to be observed always in this connection is that you can never be too severe in dealing with yourself but you must be deliberately liberal in judging others.
('70', 370, 1, 10, 766102) For, experience has shown that no matter how severe we may try to be with regard to ourselves, we shall, in the result, still be found to have acted partially towards ourselves, for the simple reason that our unconscious bias always prepossesses us in our favour and seldom allows the test to be carried beyond our capacity for endurance.
('70', 370, 1, 11, 766441) But in the case of others we do not know their weaknesses and limitations, which are known only to God who alone can read our hearts.
('70', 370, 1, 12, 766575) There is therefore always a danger, with all our desire to be liberal, of our being betrayed into a hollow harshness and intolerance when we proceed to apply our personal standards to others; and paradoxical though it may sound, the more liberal, the more patient, the more considerate we are in such cases, the quicker the results are likely to be; they will certainly be more permanent and lasting.
('70', 370, 2, 13, 766976) The analogy between meat eating and theft or murder drawn by the correspondent in question is altogether untenable.
('70', 370, 2, 14, 767092) Theft and murder, unlike meat eating, are universally held to be crimes and are heavily punishable under the law.
('70', 370, 2, 15, 767206) But even so one may not, in the hypothetical case cited above, try to wean dependents and relations from their career of theft and murder through compulsion.
('70', 370, 2, 16, 767364) My correspondent must, therefore, try to convert members of his household to his view by patient argument alone, tempered by love, and pending their conversion, cultivate an attitude of the broadest tolerance and forbearance towards them.
('70', 371, 0, 1, 767603) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 372
('70', 371, 1, 2, 767645) To proceed to the next question.
('70', 371, 1, 3, 767678) I do not hold dishonest practices in business to be warranted or excusable.
('70', 371, 1, 4, 767754) The principle of unconditional honesty is as binding in this as in any other field of life, and it is up to a business man never to compromise his principle no matter what it may cost him.
('70', 371, 1, 5, 767943) In the end, of course, honesty pays, though that can hardly be a consideration for observing it.
('70', 371, 1, 6, 768040) One has a perfect right to fix and regulate the scale of prices that he shall charge from a particular set of customers, but it must be done according to a clear fixed principle and not out of mere opportunism or immoral expediency.
('70', 371, 1, 7, 768273) There should be in it no room for fraud, sharp practice or finesse, to bamboozle the simple, unsuspecting customer.
('70', 371, 1, 8, 768389) Now for Islam.
('70', 371, 1, 9, 768404) I stand by every word that I have written in that connection.
('70', 371, 1, 10, 768466) I have nowhere said that I believe literally in every word of the Koran, or for the matter of that of any scripture in the world.
('70', 371, 1, 11, 768596) But it is no business of mine to criticize the scriptures of other faiths or to point out their defects.
('70', 371, 1, 12, 768701) It is and should be, however, my privilege to proclaim and practise the truths that there may be in them.
('70', 371, 1, 13, 768807) I may not, therefore, criticize, or condemn things in the Koran or the life of the Prophet that I cannot understand.
('70', 371, 1, 14, 768924) But I welcome every opportu nity to express my admiration for such aspects of his life as I have been able to appreciate and understand.
('70', 371, 1, 15, 769061) As for things that present difficulties, I am content to see them through the eyes of devout Mussalman friends, while I try to understand them with the help of the writings of eminent Muslim expounders of Islam.
('70', 371, 1, 16, 769273) It is only through such a reverential approach to faiths other than mine that I can realize the principle of equality of all religions.
('70', 371, 1, 17, 769409) But it is both my right and duty to point out the defects in Hinduism in order to purify it and to keep it pure.
('70', 371, 1, 18, 769522) But when non Hindu critics set about criticizing Hindu ism and cataloguing its faults they only blazon their own ignorance of Hinduism and their incapacity to regard it from the Hindu viewpoint.
('70', 371, 1, 19, 769717) It distorts their vision and vitiates their judgement.
('70', 371, 1, 20, 769772) Thus my own experience of the non Hindu critics of Hinduism brings home to me my limitations and teaches me to be wary of launching on a criticism of Islam or Christianity and their founders.
('70', 371, 2, 21, 769964) Harijan, 13 3 1937

('70', 373, 1, 2, 771237) 388. LETTER TO KANTILAL GANDHI
('70', 373, 2, 3, 771268) SEGAON, February 1, 1937
('70', 373, 4, 4, 771293) I got your letter.
('70', 373, 4, 5, 771312) Take Rs. 15 from Ramdas.
('70', 373, 4, 6, 771337) Prabhavati will stay on for this month at any rate.
('70', 373, 4, 7, 771389) You may come.
('70', 373, 4, 8, 771403) I am very much afraid of you.
('70', 373, 4, 9, 771433) You are very touchy.
('70', 373, 4, 10, 771454) Even Paparamma is afraid of you, to say nothing of Saraswati.
('70', 373, 4, 11, 771516) Ramachandran is the only one who is not afraid of you.
('70', 373, 4, 12, 771571) But you do not spare him either.
('70', 373, 4, 13, 771604) I absolutely did not understand the meaning of your letters.
('70', 373, 4, 14, 771665) You may read any meaning in my letters that you like.
('70', 373, 4, 15, 771719) I do not at all like the transaction with Kunvarjibhai.
('70', 373, 4, 16, 771775) Please bear in mind that we always go down in the eyes of those from whom we borrow money.
('70', 373, 4, 17, 771866) But there is no question of going down in the eyes of one’s parents.
('70', 373, 4, 18, 771935) We may, therefore, take from them whatever they can give and be satisfied.
('70', 373, 4, 19, 772010) But my yardstick seems to you too big.
('70', 373, 4, 20, 772049) Does it not?
('70', 373, 4, 21, 772062) Big or small, know that that is the only right yardstick for human beings.
('70', 373, 4, 22, 772137) It is not a yardstick for gods.
('70', 373, 4, 23, 772169) Instead of dismissing me as a superhuman being, if you coolly weigh what I am writing in the scales of your reason, it will assuredly do you good.
('70', 373, 4, 24, 772316) When you read and remember it for examination, it is called memory.
('70', 373, 4, 25, 772384) Perhaps it can be cultivated.
('70', 373, 4, 26, 772414) But reason can only be developed by discriminating between good and bad.
('70', 373, 4, 27, 772487) Prabhavati is sleeping.
('70', 373, 4, 28, 772511) But why need I detain the letter?
('70', 373, 4, 29, 772545) I am, therefore, sending it for being posted.
('70', 373, 4, 30, 772591) I myself have sealed it.
('70', 373, 5, 31, 772616) Blessings from BAPU

('70', 374, 1, 2, 772756) 389. LETTER TO GOKULBHAI
('70', 374, 2, 3, 772781) February 1, 1937
('70', 374, 3, 4, 772798) BHAI GOKULBHAI,
('70', 374, 4, 5, 772814) I have your letter about Surajbehn and also the note about Faizpur.
('70', 374, 4, 6, 772882) I have much to say about the kitchen.
('70', 374, 4, 7, 772920) I believe that the work will become very easy if it is entrusted to persons who have the experience of running large messes.

('70', 374, 4, 11, 773160) Their talent should on no account be ignored.
('70', 374, 4, 12, 773206) I think it is easy to supervise a hundred catering experts and get work from them than to train a thousand volunteers for the kitchen.
('70', 374, 4, 13, 773341) And that is good for the nation as a whole.
('70', 374, 4, 14, 773385) It is true that caterers should be highly efficient.
('70', 374, 4, 15, 773438) I shall be happy if they can serve food to five thousand persons at a time and manage it efficiently.
('70', 374, 4, 16, 773540) I do not think it is an impossible task.
('70', 374, 4, 17, 773581) We do arrange feasts for nine communities.

('70', 381, 1, 2, 784734) 401. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK
('70', 381, 2, 3, 784766) Unnrevised SEGAON, February 5, 1937
('70', 381, 4, 4, 784802) My right hand needs rest and it takes time to write with the left hand.
('70', 381, 4, 5, 784874) How can I spare that much time?
('70', 381, 4, 6, 784906) The burden of work has increased considerably and so I dictate most of the things I have to write.
('70', 381, 4, 7, 785005) On Mondays I make full use of my right hand.
('70', 381, 4, 8, 785050) The amanuenses are Vijaya and Manu, and also sometimes Prabhavati.
('70', 381, 4, 9, 785117) Probably you do not know Vijaya.
('70', 381, 4, 10, 785150) She is a Patel woman and hails from Bardoli.
('70', 381, 4, 11, 785195) She has, so to say, forced herself on us, for we had made a firm rule not to make any fresh admission.
('70', 381, 4, 12, 785298) Vijaya prevailed upon us to break that rule.
('70', 381, 4, 13, 785343) She put her case in such a manner that I could not send her away.
('70', 381, 4, 14, 785409) So far I have not regretted admitting her.
('70', 381, 4, 15, 785452) She goes on doing her work silently and makes up for Lilavati’s absence.
('70', 381, 4, 16, 785525) Shankarrao must be all right now.
('70', 381, 4, 17, 785559) I have asked Haribhau Phatak to give me news about his health.
('70', 381, 4, 18, 785622) But I think you will be able to give detailed news.
('70', 381, 4, 19, 785674) I had told Patwardhan that he could come whenever he wished.
('70', 381, 4, 20, 785735) But, then, don’t the hills seem beautiful only from a distance, as they say?
('70', 381, 4, 21, 785812) You seem to be going through a fairly severe test.
('70', 381, 4, 22, 785863) It is at once easy and difficult to put more money in villagers’ pockets.
('70', 381, 4, 23, 785937) If they follow our advice, we can, without any capital or with a minimum of it, double the earnings of all villages.
('70', 381, 4, 24, 786054) I am not including in this the money earned from villages by those who exploit the villagers.
('70', 381, 4, 25, 786148) If, however, they do not follow our advice, that is, refuse to do the work suggested by us or to learn the crafts we try to teach them, it is not only difficult but impossible to increase their earnings.
('70', 381, 4, 26, 786352) Another big difficulty is this.
('70', 381, 4, 27, 786384) Only a handful of workers are willing to go to villages, and they, too, are inexperienced.
('70', 381, 4, 28, 786475) Their bodies are not accustomed to the hardships of village life.
('70', 381, 4, 29, 786541) They don’t know the villagers’ nature and are ignorant of their needs.
('70', 381, 4, 30, 786612) They cannot use their hands or their intelligence.
('70', 381, 4, 31, 786663) The knowledge acquired by them in schools and colleges is of little use to them.
('70', 381, 4, 32, 786744) In these circumstances we have to be patient.
('70', 381, 4, 33, 786790) We should have faith in ourselves.
('70', 381, 4, 34, 786825) If the villagers
('70', 382, 0, 1, 786842) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 BEBRUARY, 1937 383
('70', 382, 1, 2, 786891) possess sound health, even without Government help we can improve the economic condition of villages considerably, say, to the extent of 50 per cent.
('70', 382, 1, 3, 787041) I mention 50 per cent as the minimum.
('70', 382, 1, 4, 787079) My belief is that we can improve it to the extent of 90 per cent.
('70', 382, 1, 5, 787145) Improvement in physical health, social reform and moral uplift, these are the three main things.
('70', 382, 1, 6, 787242) They require no Government help at all.
('70', 382, 1, 7, 787282) If we get a little Government help only in economic improvement, our task would be very much easier.
('70', 382, 1, 8, 787383) But in the absence of progress in respect of the foregoing three things, Government help will be of little use.
('70', 382, 1, 9, 787495) If, therefore, you become a real expert in the science of khadi and refuse to leave the village despite all temptations, you will realize from first hand experience the truth of all that I have said above.
('70', 382, 1, 10, 787701) You are not doing right in not insisting on cow’s milk.
('70', 382, 1, 11, 787757) Whenever you go out, you can carry with you ghee and pendas made from cow’s milk.
('70', 382, 1, 12, 787839) The pendas should be without sugar, i.e., made from mava only.
('70', 382, 1, 13, 787902) If you wish, you may eat jaggery with it.
('70', 382, 1, 14, 787944) This keeps down the expense and fully meets one’s requirement of milk.
('70', 382, 1, 15, 788015) Instead of eating dry pendas you can turn them into powder and mix them in warm water to make milk.
('70', 382, 1, 16, 788115) Such milk lacks only vitamins, but absence of vitamins from the diet for a few days does no harm.
('70', 382, 1, 17, 788213) Narmada is Narmada Rana.
('70', 382, 1, 18, 788238) This whole episode is a pitiable one.
('70', 382, 1, 19, 788276) It is perfectly easy to understand that everybody cannot observe life long brahmacharya.
('70', 382, 1, 20, 788365) Those who cannot curb their physical senses may by all means marry.
('70', 382, 1, 21, 788433) But I cannot tolerate secret indulgence.
('70', 382, 1, 22, 788474) Man falls through such secret indulgence for no restraints are observed then.
('70', 382, 1, 23, 788552) I have no prejudice at all against grihasthashrama.

('70', 384, 4, 19, 792153) 403. WHAT IS NON VIOLENCE?
('70', 384, 5, 20, 792180) MY DEAR MAHATMAJI,
('70', 384, 6, 21, 792199) As you were fully engaged with the Congress affairs these past few weeks, I did not before now acknowledge your postcard which you kindly wrote in reply to my query about ‘non violence in word’ nor thanked you for your courtesy in discussing at length the point at issue in the Harijan of December 19th.
('70', 384, 6, 22, 792503) 1 I have carefully read and weighed your argument, but I cannot help believing that you were not non violent in the words you used with reference to the missionaries in general who have been working, and working so nobly, for the good of our motherland for the past hundred years.
('70', 384, 7, 23, 792784) You say: ‘The essence of violence is that there must be a violent intention behind a thought, word or act, i.e., an intention to do harm to the opponent so called’.
('70', 384, 7, 24, 792949) I don’t think you are right here.
('70', 384, 7, 25, 792983) Take, for instance, a father smacking the face of his unruly and intractable child for some offence or other.
('70', 384, 7, 26, 793093) No one could for a moment believe that there was ‘a voilent intention behind’ that act of the father or that he had ‘an intention to do harm’ to his own child.
('70', 384, 7, 27, 793253) Nevertheless that smacking of the child was an act of violence,
('70', 384, 8, 28, 793317) 1 Vide “What is Non violence?”, 19 12 1936
('70', 385, 0, 1, 793360) THE COLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 386
('70', 385, 1, 2, 793401) pure and simple, because it hurt the child’s face.
('70', 385, 1, 3, 793452) Similarly, when a man uses words against his ‘opponent so called’ which are likely to hurt his feelings or, as you put it, wound his susceptibilities, then quite regardless of his non violent intention behind his word, he has been violent in word simply because he has hurt his so called opponent’s feelings, just as the father hurt his child’s face in the instance given.
('70', 385, 1, 4, 793825) You say further on: ‘The acid test of non violence is that one thinks, speaks and acts non violently even when there is the gravest provocation to be violent.’ Here again I do not agree with you.
('70', 385, 1, 5, 794021) The acid test of non violence is that one thinks, speaks and acts in a manner so as not to hurt ‘the opponent so called’ in body, mind or spirit, even when there is the gravest provocation to be violent.
('70', 385, 1, 6, 794225) It is true where you say: “If non violence of thought is to be evolved in individuals or societies or nations, truth has to be told, however harsh or unpopular it may appear to be for the moment.’ But it is not true that harsh truth must be told in harsh words, when a gentler mode of expressing the same ideas might have, with a little more patience, self control and goodwill, been used against the party opposing.
('70', 385, 1, 7, 794642) In that discussion how strong in contrast stood Mr. Andrews’ gentler mode of arguing to the harsh mode of your expression!
('70', 385, 1, 8, 794765) In this harshness which you, Mahatmaji, with your habitual and exemplary calm, patience and self control might have easily avoided, lay, I repeat, your ‘violence in word’ against the missionaries in general.
('70', 385, 2, 9, 794973) With my best wishes for your health and strength,
('70', 385, 3, 10, 795023) As always yours, A. S. WADIA POONA Jan.
('70', 385, 3, 11, 795063) 10, 1937 PS.
('70', 385, 4, 12, 795076) You are at liberty to print this letter in my name in the Harijan, if you so
('70', 385, 5, 13, 795153) I gladly publish the foregoing.
('70', 385, 5, 14, 795185) But I profoundly differ from the view presented by Shri Wadia.
('70', 385, 5, 15, 795248) The smacking of a boy, if it is not done out of anger and impatience, is most decidedly not violence as when he is, say, bitten by a snake and it is necessary to keep him awake or as when a youngster in high fever was running amuck and came to his senses only after he was severely smacked.
('70', 385, 5, 16, 795539) It caused hurt, but he would most assuredly have died if he had not been smacked.
('70', 385, 5, 17, 795621) Every surgeon causes hurt, but he is every time not only not violent but benevolent and receives thanks and heavy fees for causing hurt, sometimes very serious indeed.
('70', 385, 5, 18, 795789) He does not conform to Shri Wadia’s
('70', 386, 0, 1, 795825) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 BEBRUARY, 1937 387
('70', 386, 1, 2, 795874) definition, he does wholly conform to mine.
('70', 386, 1, 3, 795918) According to my learned correspondent, Jesus Christ was hopelessly violent when he called some people of his times ‘a generation of vipers’.
('70', 386, 1, 4, 796059) His phrases and his actions so hurt his generation that they compassed his death.
('70', 386, 1, 5, 796141) And if truth can be harsh, as the writer admits it can be, what is the gentle way of uttering it so that you can render it proof against your opponent’s wrath?
('70', 386, 1, 6, 796301) If a man utters a downright lie or commits a daylight robbery or a murder, am I to call this brother of mine, as he most assuredly is, a liar or a thief or a murderer, or am I to use Churchillian language and say ‘he perambulates round the suburbs of veracity,’ or ‘he helps himself to the goods that do not belong to him without perhaps any intention of stealing,’ or, ‘he spills innocent blood, though perhaps he does not want to kill?’ And if I were to use such circumlocutory speech, is there the slightest guarantee that I shall never hurt the party of whom I may be speaking?
('70', 386, 1, 7, 796883) Harsh truth may be uttered courteously and gently, but the words would read hard.
('70', 386, 1, 8, 796965) To be truthful you must call a liar a liar—a harsh word perhaps, but the use is inevitable.
('70', 386, 1, 9, 797057) In the instance to which Shri Wadia has taken exception, I have no sense of repentance.
('70', 386, 1, 10, 797145) I suggest to my friend that like many good people he has allowed his judgment to be warped by the nobility of the actions of missionaries in that they have founded schools, hospitals and the like.
('70', 386, 1, 11, 797342) Whereas, giving the fullest due for their philanthropic activities, my sober judgment tells me that the lustre of their deeds is diminished by the motive of proselytizing that lies behind them.
('70', 386, 1, 12, 797536) I may be wrong in my estimate of religious conduct and proselytizing itself.
('70', 386, 1, 13, 797613) That does not make my characterization in any sense violent.
('70', 386, 1, 14, 797674) Therefore I am not going to subscribe to Shri Wadia’s judgment or his comparison of Deenabandhu Andrews at my expense in matters of non violence.
('70', 386, 1, 15, 797820) And if he really believes that I am gifted with ‘habitual and exemplary calm, patience and self control’, I want to assure him that on the occasion referred to I had not lost any of the virtues he imputes to me.
('70', 386, 1, 16, 798032) This is not to say that I never lose self control.
('70', 386, 1, 17, 798083) I do indeed, and those are occasions of my shame.
('70', 386, 1, 18, 798133) If Shri Wadia has had no occasion to observe them it is because of the hard training I have given myself of exercising self control in public life and especially in respect of those who regard me as their enemy.
('70', 386, 1, 19, 798345) But I cannot say the same of my private life.
('70', 386, 1, 20, 798391) Those who are nearest me do alas!
('70', 386, 1, 21, 798425) know how impatient I can be with them, even to the extent of behaving like a wild bear let loose.
('70', 386, 1, 22, 798523) I know that even with them I must
('70', 387, 0, 1, 798557) THE COLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 388
('70', 387, 1, 2, 798598) not lose patience.

('70', 387, 1, 4, 798735) Their certificate, however, is of little worth to me.
('70', 387, 1, 5, 798789) It has never deceived me.
('70', 387, 1, 6, 798815) I know that I would be a better man and their better guide if I could regard them with sufficient detachment and not take it amiss when, in my opinion, they fall short of the standard they have themselves accepted for their daily conduct.

('70', 390, 4, 32, 807295) 407. MILL WORKERS AND MILL OWNERS
('70', 390, 5, 33, 807329) Some of the points of dispute which arose between the mill owners and mill workers of Ahmedabad, were referred for arbitration and its result has been announced.
('70', 390, 5, 34, 807491) Both the parties deserve to be congratulated on their having agreed to refer the issue to arbitration in this manner.
('70', 390, 5, 35, 807609) And the mill owners also on having accepted the Award.
('70', 390, 5, 36, 807664) The Umpire also deserves to be congratulated on having given his Award along with many arguments merely out of a spirit of service
('70', 391, 0, 1, 807795) THE COLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 392
('70', 391, 1, 2, 807836) without charging any fee.
('70', 391, 1, 3, 807862) All of us hope that all disputes arising between the two parties will always be speedily resolved through arbitration.
('70', 391, 1, 4, 807981) It is clear enough for everyone to understand that by accepting the Award of the Umpire both the parties, as also the industry on which the prosperity of Ahmedabad depends, have gained.
('70', 391, 1, 5, 808167) But my object in writing this article is not to examine the situation in the past or to praise the principal parties concerned.
('70', 391, 1, 6, 808295) My object is to find means by which future security could be ensured.
('70', 391, 1, 7, 808365) I have hinted at these means in clause 16 of my Award.
('70', 391, 1, 8, 808420) I quote it below along with the clause that follows:
('70', 391, 2, 9, 808473) At this stage I would like to restate the principles that for the good of both parties I have presented to them as a result of my close and unbroken contact with the industry for a period of 18 years in the capacity of Arbitrator.
('70', 391, 3, 10, 808704) (a) No cut should be made till the mills have ceased to make any profit and are obliged to fall back upon their capital for continuing the industry.
('70', 391, 4, 11, 808853) (b) There should be no cut till the wages have reached the level adequate for maintenance.
('70', 391, 4, 12, 808944) It is impossible to conceive a time when the workmen have begun to regard the industry as if it were their own property and they would then be prepared to help it out of a crisis by taking the barest maintenance consisting of a dry crust and working day and night.
('70', 391, 4, 13, 809209) That would be a voluntary arrangement.
('70', 391, 4, 14, 809248) Such cases are irrlevant to the present consideration.
('70', 391, 5, 15, 809303) (c) There should be a common undestanding as to what should be included in determining a living wage.
('70', 391, 6, 16, 809405) (d) The consideration of the deterioration in individual mills cannot form part of a case for a cut in wages of labour in general.
('70', 391, 7, 17, 809536) (e) It is vital to the well being of the industry that workmen should be regarded as equals with the shareholders and that they have therefore every right to possess an accurate knowledge of the transactions of the mills.
('70', 391, 8, 18, 809758) (f) There should be a register of all available mill hands acceptable to both the parties and the custom of taking labour through any other than the T.L.A. should be stopped,
('70', 391, 9, 19, 809933) I have not presented these principles in the belief that they will be acceptable either to my brother Arbitrator or to the mill owners or even to the workmen.
('70', 391, 9, 20, 810092) These have not guided my decision in the present case but I am convinced that without the acceptance of these principles the industry i.e., the owners and the workmen are in danger.
('70', 392, 0, 1, 810274) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 BEBRUARY, 1937 393
('70', 392, 1, 2, 810323) The Umpire has described these principles as idealistic and incapable of being implemented.
('70', 392, 1, 3, 810415) 1 He did not have to pass judgment on those points.
('70', 392, 1, 4, 810467) I had merely jotted them down in my Award for my own satisfaction and with the object that they might prove useful to both parties in future.
('70', 392, 1, 5, 810609) Hence, it is possible that the Umpire has not given serious thought to them.

('70', 392, 3, 12, 811401) The Umpire has strongly recommended that mill owners should speedily take a decision regarding the scale of wages applicable to all mills and with the same speed frame a scheme whereby an increase or decrease in wages can be effected automatically.

('70', 393, 1, 2, 812854) Before fixing a standard for wage cut it is necessary to decide what should be called a living wage.
('70', 393, 1, 3, 812955) (16 B) If a consideration of the living wage is regarded as essential, it is absolutely necessary to consider what are the items to be included in it.
('70', 393, 1, 4, 813106) (16 C) While considering a cut in the wages of the entire body of workers a consideration of the plight of any individual mill necessarily becomes irrelevant.
('70', 393, 1, 5, 813265) (16 D) In order that workers may be able to accept the demands of the mill owners they should have the right to know about the detailed working of the mill.
('70', 393, 1, 6, 813422) (16 E) And, in order that workers may willingly accept a cut in wages and to reassure them, it will become absolutely necessary to keep a register of all possible labourers.
('70', 393, 1, 7, 813596) (16 F) The Mill owners’ Association will have to gain greater control over the mills than it enjoys at present if the principle of arbitration is to become permanent.
('70', 393, 1, 8, 813763) It will collapse if the individuals ignore the Mill owners’ Association while pursuing their own interests alone.
('70', 393, 1, 9, 813877) Similarly, if workers pursue their own interest and violate the rules of the Labout Association the principle of arbitration will cease to operate.
('70', 393, 1, 10, 814025) In order to prevent such an eventuality uniform scales of pay should be introduced everywhere.
('70', 393, 1, 11, 814120) If, while doing so, a particular mill is put to a strain, the other mill should get together and compensate it.
('70', 393, 1, 12, 814232) Similarly, whenever it is found that workers have to suffer, those among them who stand to gain should compensate the loss to those who would be adversely affected.
('70', 393, 1, 13, 814397) I am also of the opinion that the practice of having different scales of wages for labourers working in different departments should be abolished and uniform wages should be accepted for all labourers.
('70', 393, 1, 14, 814599) I know that this may seem to be an impossibele task, but a further consideration will show that the need for this will become obvious if the united strength of labourers is to be made invincible.
('70', 393, 1, 15, 814795) Why should anyone working the power loom for sixty hours get Rs. 30, while a person looking after the spindle for the same number of hours gets Rs. 13?
('70', 393, 1, 16, 814947) It whould not be proper to conclude that the former has to work more than the latter.
('70', 393, 1, 17, 815033) If is not also fitting for one labourer to say that he has to use more intelligence than another.
('70', 393, 1, 18, 815131) So long as such discrepancies exist, jealousies are bound to be there and, as long as there is jealousy, there can be no true unity.

('70', 394, 1, 4, 815472) Everyone’s basic needs are more or less the same.
('70', 394, 1, 5, 815522) The larger part of the world will always consist of labourers, hence the only way for their uplift is to accept the principle of equal wages.
('70', 394, 1, 6, 815664) There is no other way but to do so.

('70', 394, 1, 8, 815792) But unless workers make such dreams come true, their real authority, which is only a dream today, will always remain so.
('70', 394, 1, 9, 815913) Yes, there is one exception.
('70', 394, 1, 10, 815942) If workers wish to establish their authority with the use of arms, that is, through force, it may appear to be possible.

('70', 394, 1, 12, 816170) But, for the moment, let us, assume that the working class is even prepared to use force.
