('70', 401, 6, 10, 829206) 418. AHMEDABAD MILL INDUSTRY
('70', 401, 7, 11, 829235) Now that the Ahmedabad Mill Industry has tided over the difficulty that had arisen over the mill owners’ demand for a cut in the wages of labour, it is well to examine the conditions of its stability.
('70', 401, 7, 12, 829436) The Umpire, Sir Govindrao Madgavkar, deserves the thanks of both the parties for his great labour of love.
('70', 401, 7, 13, 829543) The public do not know that he undertook the onerous burden without any fees which he might have insisted upon, if he had so chosen.
('70', 401, 7, 14, 829676) Having entered upon the task he might have lightened it by merely giving his decision without any argument.
('70', 401, 7, 15, 829784) Instead he has reasoned out his Award and made valuable suggestions for the guidance of both capital and labour.
('70', 401, 7, 16, 829897) It is to be hoped that both parties will whole heartedly act up to the Umpire’s suggestion and work out the Delhi agreement.
('70', 401, 7, 17, 830022) The Umpire has made it perfectly clear that no cut is possible without fully implementing the Delhi agreement which has also the merit of being turned into an award of the then Umpire, Mr. Patkar, retired High Court Judge.
('70', 401, 7, 18, 830245) The essential conditions of that agreement are that wages must be standardized for the whole mill industry and that there should
('70', 402, 0, 1, 830374) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 BEBRUARY, 1937 403
('70', 402, 1, 2, 830423) be a scheme for automatic adjustment whenever there is a demand for a cut or a rise in the wages.
('70', 402, 1, 3, 830521) It has been argued on behalf of the mill owners that neither standardization not automatic adjustment is a practical proposition.
('70', 402, 1, 4, 830651) The Umpire has rejected that argument.
('70', 402, 1, 5, 830690) Indeed he could not do otherwise.
('70', 402, 1, 6, 830724) Surely the parties knew what they were doing when they entered into the agreement at Delhi.
('70', 402, 1, 7, 830816) They would never have introduced the two clauses if they had thought them to be unworkable.
('70', 402, 1, 8, 830908) It may be that the parties may not agree to a common scheme.
('70', 402, 1, 9, 830969) It is for them to refer their differences then to the arbitrators and, the latter failing, to an Umpire.
('70', 402, 1, 10, 831074) Standardization of wages is a mechanical or arithmetical proposition.
('70', 402, 1, 11, 831144) It may be that an intermediate stage is necessary before all the mills can be induced to adopt an even scale of wages or labour can in all cases be induced to accept a level which in some cases must mean a large reduction in wages though the whole total remains unaffected.
('70', 402, 1, 12, 831418) But a scheme of automatic adjustment of wages is undoubtedly a complicated matter.
('70', 402, 1, 13, 831501) It demands for its fruition a spirit of give and take on both sides.
('70', 402, 1, 14, 831570) And any such scheme must, in the nature of things, be of a temporary character subject to periodical revision.
('70', 402, 1, 15, 831681) No scheme of automatic adjustment is possible without reference to the maxims I have ventured to mention in my Award and which Sir Govindrao has been pleased to dismiss as idealistic.
('70', 402, 1, 16, 831865) Of course it was no part of his duty as Umpire to examine or refer to them at all.
('70', 402, 1, 17, 831948) I have myself stated in my Award that the maxims have not guided my decision.
('70', 402, 1, 18, 832026) But having referred to them at all, the learned Umpire might have shown how or why they were idealistic.
('70', 402, 1, 19, 832131) I propose to show that whether they are idealistic or otherwise it is impossible to arrive at a satisfactory scheme of automatic adjustment without reference to them.
('70', 402, 1, 20, 832298) They must be the measuring rod for action which may and will probably fall short of it.
('70', 402, 1, 21, 832386) Let me reproduce below a translation 1 of the original which is in Gujarati: Now take the first maxim.
('70', 402, 1, 22, 832489) Why should mills desire a cut so long as they have profits?
('70', 402, 1, 23, 832549) It would be like a man desiring to cut off his feet to ease some derangement of the belly, Do they cut out machinery in order to ensure a certain percentage of profits?
('70', 402, 1, 24, 832718) Are men and women who may be called living machines less than inert machinery?
('70', 402, 1, 25, 832797) Is there anything very idealistic in the suggestion that the wages of the
('70', 402, 2, 26, 832871) 1 Not reproduced here.
('70', 402, 2, 27, 832894) For the text, vide clauses XVI and XVII of Award in Labout Dispute, 26 12 1936
('70', 403, 0, 1, 832973) THE COLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 404
('70', 403, 1, 2, 833014) operatives, who are at least as much a foundation of the industry as the machinery and buildings, may not be reduced to ensure a minimum of profits?
('70', 403, 1, 3, 833163) I make bold to say that if the votes of humane shareholders (and I regard the shareholders of mills as humane) were taken, they would summarily reject the proposition that their profits should be preferred to the wages of labour on whom depend their profits.
('70', 403, 1, 4, 833422) And if the first maxim must at least be seriously considered, the second about the living wage follows from it.
('70', 403, 1, 5, 833534) If there can be no cut before profits are on the brink of sinking, it is necessary to know the limit beyond which reduction in wages cannot go.
('70', 403, 1, 6, 833678) In other words, there must be a decision as to what constitutes a living wage.
('70', 403, 1, 7, 833757) I am not concerned with the name.
('70', 403, 1, 8, 833791) Call it the minimum wage, if that expression sounds sweeter.
('70', 403, 1, 9, 833852) The process is the same.
('70', 403, 1, 10, 833877) Living wage to my mind is the most accurate description for an irreducible wage.
('70', 403, 1, 11, 833958) And the acceptance of the principle of a living wage implies an examination of what may be included in it.
('70', 403, 1, 12, 834065) Should intoxicants form part, should tobacco be included, may milk or ghee or gur be excluded?
('70', 403, 1, 13, 834160) These are no visionary things.
('70', 403, 1, 14, 834191) They touch the very existence of labour.
('70', 403, 1, 15, 834232) Its efficiency depends very largely upon the right kind of living.
('70', 403, 1, 16, 834299) And the greater the efficiency, the greater the possibility of enhanced profits.
('70', 403, 1, 17, 834380) Maxim (d) is self evident and accepted by the arbitrators as well as the Umpire.
('70', 403, 1, 18, 834461) Who can deny the reasonableness of the statement (Maxim c) that workmen should be regarded as equal owners with the shareholders?
('70', 403, 1, 19, 834591) If conflict between capital and labour is to be avoided, as I believe it can and must be, labour should have the same status and dignity as capital.
('70', 403, 1, 20, 834740) Why should a million rupees put together be more than a million men or women put together?
('70', 403, 1, 21, 834831) Are they not infinitely more than metal, white or yellow?
('70', 403, 1, 22, 834889) Or should holders of metal always assume that labour cannot be organized and put together as metal can?
('70', 403, 1, 23, 834993) For the past eighteen years, consciously or unconsciously, capital and labour have acted in Ahmedabad on the assumption that there is no inherent conflict between the two.
('70', 403, 1, 24, 835165) It is true that peace between the two has been precarious.
('70', 403, 1, 25, 835224) But it has been so because the parties have not recognized the full validity of the maxims as the conditions of an abiding peace.
('70', 403, 1, 26, 835354) If then labourers are co equal owners, their organization should have the same access to the transactions of mills as the shareholders.
('70', 404, 0, 1, 835490) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 BEBRUARY, 1937 405
('70', 404, 1, 2, 835539) Indeed there can be no confidence on the part of labour if material information is withheld from it.
('70', 404, 1, 3, 835640) The last maxim admits of no weakening.
('70', 404, 1, 4, 835679) If the Labour Union is regarded as a desirable organization as much as is the mill owners’, and is not merely tolerated as a necessary evil, it follows that there should be an agreed register of available hands and that the mill owners should not accept or engage any person outside the Labour Union.
('70', 404, 1, 5, 835980) Thus it seems to me that the maxims are not visionary, but on examination they are found to be absolutely essential to the healthy existence or growth of the great industry in whose interest they have been humbly suggested.
('70', 404, 1, 6, 836204) It need not be stated that the list submitted is by no means exhaustive.
('70', 404, 1, 7, 836277) I must suggest some more, when I am able to revert to the question.

('70', 405, 4, 15, 837959) 421. WHAT KHADI WORKERS SHOULD KNOW 2
('70', 405, 5, 16, 837997) In previous article I have tried to explain what should be covered by the science of khadi.
('70', 405, 5, 17, 838089) In my opinion it should be made obligatory on every khadi worker engaged in any of the production centres of the A.I.S.A. to know the elements of this science.
('70', 405, 5, 18, 838249) Lakshmidas is a khadi lover and one of the most careful students of the science of khadi that we have.

('70', 405, 5, 20, 838407) In the course of a letter which he addressed me in November 1935, he laid down what he considered to be the minimum test which every khadi worker ought to satisfy.
('70', 405, 5, 21, 838571) The test is reproduced below:
('70', 405, 6, 22, 838601) (1) The worker should know how to distinguish between superior and inferior grades of cotton, cotton seed and lint.
('70', 405, 7, 23, 838717) 1 Not reproduced here.
('70', 405, 7, 24, 838740) The correspondent had suggested that to make the Proclamation a real success people should introduce inter dining and also employ poor Harijans as cooks and domestic servants.

('70', 406, 0, 1, 838971) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 BEBRUARY, 1937 407
('70', 406, 1, 2, 839020) (2) He should be able to fix in position the rolling pin of a hand ginning machine and to make the necessary correction and adjustment to make it exactly fit with the fixed roller, when the former happens to be bent or of unequal thickness.
('70', 406, 1, 3, 839261) (3) He should be able to fit up a carding bow and to prepare the gut and the hide piece for the shoulder blade.
('70', 406, 1, 4, 839373) (4) He should be able to show a ginning speed of five pounds an hour on a hand ginning machine over a period of four hours.
('70', 406, 1, 5, 839497) (5) He must show a carding speed of ten tolas of cotton wool per hour, excluding the time required for making slivers.
('70', 406, 1, 6, 839616) (6) He must know the construction of every type of spinning wheel and how to assemble it.
('70', 406, 1, 7, 839706) He must be able to straighten a spindle gone out of shape and to prepare the mal and the daman the cross bands of the motor wheel.
('70', 406, 1, 8, 839837) (7) He must be able to maintain a spinning speed of 300 rounds (400 yards) of yarn of 20 s, with a tensile strength of over 80% and evenness 95% in a four hours’ test.
('70', 406, 1, 9, 840005) (8) He should know the Andhra process of spinning and must be able to spin 200 rounds of 70 s to 80 s , strength 80% and evenness 95% during a two hours’ test.
('70', 406, 1, 10, 840165) (9) He should know the construction of a pit loom as well as a fly shuttle loom and be able to prepare together the reeds, the healds and the sizing brush.
('70', 406, 1, 11, 840321) (10) He should be able to weave khadi of 50” width on a fly shuttle loom from yarn of 20 s and to make all necessary adjustments to produce at least five different kinds of border designs for saris.
('70', 406, 1, 12, 840520) (11) The speed of weaving should come up to one square yard in an hour from yarn of 20 s .
('70', 406, 1, 13, 840611) (12) He should know all about the growing of different varieties of cotton and should be able to get hand gins, carding bows, spinning wheels, looms and their accessories locally prepared, preferably out of local material.
('70', 406, 1, 14, 840834) This would involve a knowledge of: (a) Rainfall, its extent and distribution over different parts of the year, and a knowledge of manures and the nature of the soil.
('70', 406, 1, 15, 841000) (b) Different kinds of wood and of calculations relating to measurement.
('70', 406, 1, 16, 841073) (c) A workable knowledge of drawing for the above mentioned needs.
('70', 406, 1, 17, 841140) (13) A knowledge of carpentry sufficient for repairing the various machines.
('70', 406, 1, 18, 841217) It is not quite easy to fulfil this test.

('70', 408, 1, 2, 843562) 424. MY NOTES
('70', 408, 2, 3, 843576) THE PROBLEM IN REVERSE
('70', 408, 3, 4, 843599) A Hindu gentleman having read my reply 1 to a Muslim gentleman’s letter in the Harijanbandhu of 31 1 1937 writes to say.
('70', 408, 4, 5, 843720) I feel that the reply to this question is contained in what I had written previously.
('70', 408, 4, 6, 843806) In that case, the Muslim gentleman had introduced a new custom and consequently had to put up with the orthodoxy of his relations.
('70', 408, 4, 7, 843937) In this case, people wish to give up their existing tradition and eat meat.
('70', 408, 4, 8, 844013) A vegetarian Hindu is by no means bound to encourage them.
('70', 408, 4, 9, 844072) It depends on each individual as to how far he is prepared to abandon existing tradition in such matters.
('70', 408, 4, 10, 844178) Those who regard giving up meat as a part of religion are likely to find it intolerable if other members of the family eat meat.
('70', 408, 4, 11, 844307) We should follow ahimsa dharma or the religion of love in all our conduct.
('70', 408, 4, 12, 844382) There should be no anger towards those who give up their religion, they should be won over through love alone.
('70', 408, 4, 13, 844493) How this may be done, is to be considered in each particular case.
('70', 408, 5, 14, 844560) WRONG THINKING
('70', 408, 6, 15, 844575) A co worker committed an error in a fit of rage.
('70', 408, 6, 16, 844624) I explained to him that it was a grave error and that he should atone for it by apologizing to the person he had wronged.
('70', 408, 6, 17, 844746) He admitted his fault and also the need for apologizing but he told me that he was not worthy of what I had asked him to do, that he had not risen so high and was not capable of doing so at one stroke.
('70', 408, 6, 18, 844948) After that, this co worker, saw his mistake.
('70', 408, 6, 19, 844993) He is a mature and balanced person.
('70', 408, 6, 20, 845029) The object of writing this is merely to show that like this co worker many of us are given to erroneous thinking.
('70', 408, 6, 21, 845143) To apologize for an offence which has already been committed is even less than paying back a debt without any interest.
('70', 408, 6, 22, 845263) It can be compared to a promise to repay a debt, as an offence already committed is not wiped out by an apology; but it does imply a promise not to commit such an offence in the future.
('70', 408, 6, 23, 845449) No debtor to this day has argued that he is not fit to repay his debts.
('70', 408, 7, 24, 845521) 1 Vide “Need for Tolerance”, 13 3 1937 2 The letter has not been translated here.
('70', 408, 7, 25, 845603) The correspondent had stated that Gandhiji’s reply to the Muslim gentleman might be in conformity with Islam but it was not in conformity with Hinduism.
('70', 408, 7, 26, 845756) He had asked whether it was proper for a vegetarian to buy meat for his family members.
('70', 409, 0, 1, 845844) THE COLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 410
('70', 409, 1, 2, 845885) may happen that at that moment he does not have a sufficient sum to repay his debts.
('70', 409, 1, 3, 845970) However, it would provoke laughter if a debtor argued that he was unworthy of repaying his debts.
('70', 409, 1, 4, 846068) This may even be regarded as impudence.
('70', 409, 1, 5, 846108) But in moral matters, very often people deceive themselves.
('70', 409, 1, 6, 846168) Impatience and subtle pride lie at the root of this.
('70', 409, 1, 7, 846221) If this were not the case, how could we fail to see something which is as clear as daylight?
('70', 409, 1, 8, 846314) We do not have the capacity to do many things.
('70', 409, 1, 9, 846361) And there is no room for any effort if, because of this want of ability, we regard ourselves as unfit for that task.
('70', 409, 1, 10, 846478) Hence no one should consider himself unworthy of doing any good work.
('70', 409, 1, 11, 846548) No one should doubt that repeated efforts are certain to make us capable of doing it.

('70', 409, 2, 13, 846675) 425. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL JOSHI
('70', 409, 3, 14, 846707) SEGAON, WARDHA, February 14, 1937
('70', 409, 4, 15, 846741) CHHAGANLAL,
('70', 409, 5, 16, 846753) I got your letter.
('70', 409, 5, 17, 846772) Whatever Valji may do, you cannot come out of Saurashtra in the manner suggested by you.
('70', 409, 5, 18, 846861) I can understand your resorting to satyagraha just to oppose the Foreigners’ Act, after giving the Government a sufficiently long notice, though I wouldn’t approve even of that.
('70', 409, 5, 19, 847039) I do not think you will have to wait long now.
('70', 409, 5, 20, 847086) After the new constitution starts functioning, the Government will probably find it difficult to keep such notices in force.

('70', 422, 7, 9, 870794) 446. SO CALLED INCONSISTENCIES
('70', 422, 8, 10, 870825) I have some very persistent correspondents who put posers before me.
('70', 422, 8, 11, 870894) Here is a specimen letter from one such correspondent:
('70', 422, 9, 12, 870949) Whenever economic troubles arise and whenever questions have been put to you on the economic relations of capital and labour, you have put forth the theory of trusteeship which has always puzzled me.
('70', 422, 9, 13, 871149) You want the rich to hold all their property in trust for the poor and expend it for their benefit.
('70', 422, 9, 14, 871249) If I ask you whether this is possible, you will tell me that my question arises from a belief in the essential selfishness of human nature and that your theory is based on the essential goodness of human nature.
('70', 422, 9, 15, 871461) However, in the political sphere, you do not hold such views without at the same time losing your faith in the fundamental goodness of human nature.
('70', 422, 9, 16, 871610) The British claim the same trusteeship for their domination of India.
('70', 422, 9, 17, 871680) But you have lost faith in the British Empire long ago, and today there is no greater enemy to it than you.
('70', 422, 9, 18, 871788) Is it consistent to have one law for the political world and another for the economic world?
('70', 422, 9, 19, 871881) Or, do you mean to say that you have not lost faith in capitalism and capitalists just as you have lost faith in British Imperialism and the British?
('70', 422, 9, 20, 872031) For your trusteeship theory sounds very much like the Divine Right theory of kings which has been exploded long ago.
('70', 422, 9, 21, 872148) When one man, who was allowed to hold political power in trust for all the others and who derived it from them, misused it, people revolted against it and democracy was born.
('70', 422, 9, 22, 872323) Similarly now, when a few, who ought to hold the economic power in trust for the others from whom they derive it, use it for their own self aggrandisement and to the detriment of the rest, the inevitable result is the deprivation of the few of the means of economic power by the many, i.e., the birth of socialism.
('70', 423, 0, 1, 872638) THE COLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 424
('70', 423, 1, 2, 872679) Hitherto violence was the only recognized means to attain anything good or bad.
('70', 423, 1, 3, 872759) When violence is employed even with a view to achieve good, it brings evil in its train and compromises the good achieved.
('70', 423, 1, 4, 872882) Now I take it that your definite contribution to the world lies in your having successfully demonstrated the efficacy of another means, namely, non violence, which is superior to violence and does not poison human relations.
('70', 423, 1, 5, 873107) Therefore my fondest hope is that you should fight and end the present economic order non violently and help to create a new one.
('70', 423, 2, 6, 873237) Secondly, you may answer another question agitating my mind.
('70', 423, 2, 7, 873298) In 1930 when you launched your Satyagraha campaign, you declared that the fight was a fight to the finish and you would either return victorious or your dead body would float on the waters of the sea.
('70', 423, 2, 8, 873499) Even in your subsequent statements you emphasized this and called upon all Indians to fight determinedly.
('70', 423, 2, 9, 873605) Now, though you have reserved the right to civil disobedience to yourself, you have abandoned the fight against the Government.
('70', 423, 2, 10, 873733) At the present moment you are devoting yourself heart and soul to the infusing of life into and raising the standard of the Indian village.
('70', 423, 2, 11, 873873) I do not know whether you consider this phase of your activity as fight against the Government.
('70', 423, 2, 12, 873969) The A.I.V.I.A. is divorced from all politics, and therefore your activity in the promotion of the objects of the A.I.V.I.A. cannot be called a part of the political fight to win political freedom for our country.
('70', 423, 2, 13, 874182) Or do you think there can be gaps, intervening periods of lull in a fight called a fight to the finish?
('70', 423, 2, 14, 874286) If so, why did you differentiate the fight of 1930 from that of 1920 and call the former a fight to the finish?
('70', 423, 3, 15, 874398) To take the first part, I see no inconsistency in my treatment of capitalism or imperialism.
('70', 423, 3, 16, 874491) My correspondent has been led into a confusion of thought.
('70', 423, 3, 17, 874550) I have not talked or thought of what kings, imperialists or capitalists claim and have claimed.
('70', 423, 3, 18, 874646) I have talked and written of how capital may be treated.
('70', 423, 3, 19, 874703) And then it is one thing to make a claim and another to live up to it.
('70', 423, 3, 20, 874774) Not everyone like me (say) who claims to be a servant of the people becomes that by the mere assertion.
('70', 423, 3, 21, 874878) And yet all would appreciate persons like me if we were found to be living up to our claim.
('70', 423, 3, 22, 874970) Similarly would all rejoice if a capitalist were to divest himself of exclusive ownership and declare himself to be in possession as a trustee for the people.
('70', 423, 3, 23, 875129) It is highly probable that my advice will not be accepted and my dream will not be realized.
('70', 423, 3, 24, 875222) But who can guarantee that the socialists’ dream will be realized?
('70', 423, 3, 25, 875289) Socialism was not born with the discovery of the misuse of capital by capitalists.
('70', 423, 3, 26, 875372) As I have contended, socialism, even
('70', 424, 0, 1, 875409) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 BEBRUARY, 1937 425
('70', 424, 1, 2, 875458) communism, is explicit in the first verse of Ishopanishad.
('70', 424, 1, 3, 875517) What is true is that when some reformers lost faith in the method of conversion, the technique of what is known as scientific socialism was born.
('70', 424, 1, 4, 875663) I am engaged in solving the same problem that faces scientific socialists.
('70', 424, 1, 5, 875738) It is true, however, that my approach is always and only through unadulterated non violence.
('70', 424, 1, 6, 875831) It may fail.
('70', 424, 1, 7, 875844) If it does, it will be because of my ignorance of the technique of non violence.
('70', 424, 1, 8, 875925) I may be a bad exponent of the doctrine in which my faith is daily increasing.
('70', 424, 1, 9, 876004) The A.I.S.A. and the A.I.V.I.A. are organizations through which the technique of non violence is being tested on an all India scale.
('70', 424, 1, 10, 876137) They are special autonomous bodies created by the Congress for the purpose of enabling me to conduct my experiments without being fattered by the vicissitudes of policy to which a wholly democratic body like the Congress is always liable.
('70', 424, 1, 11, 876376) Trusteeship, as I conceive it, has yet to prove its worth.
('70', 424, 1, 12, 876435) It is an attempt to secure the best use of property for the people by competent hands.
('70', 424, 1, 13, 876522) Now for the second part of the letter.
('70', 424, 1, 14, 876561) I do not divide life into water tight compartments.
('70', 424, 1, 15, 876613) The life of a nation like that of individuals is an indivisible whole.
('70', 424, 1, 16, 876684) My retirement from the Congress or political life so called does not mean the slightest diminution in my yearning for India’s complete independence; nor is civil disobedience any distinct process of non violence.
('70', 424, 1, 17, 876897) It is one of the many non violent processes which are in no way inconsistent with one another.
('70', 424, 1, 18, 876992) What I have to do is to give a clear demonstration of non violence in all my actions.
('70', 424, 1, 19, 877078) I claim to be conducting my experiment in a scientific spirit.
('70', 424, 1, 20, 877141) In the garden of non violence are many plants.
('70', 424, 1, 21, 877188) They are all from the same parent.
('70', 424, 1, 22, 877223) They may not be all used simultaneously.
('70', 424, 1, 23, 877264) Some are less powerful than others.
('70', 424, 1, 24, 877300) All are harmless.
('70', 424, 1, 25, 877318) But they have to be handled skilfully.
('70', 424, 1, 26, 877357) I am applying such skill to their use as God has given me.
('70', 424, 1, 27, 877416) But because I use one plant rather than another at any time, it does not follow that I give up the fight.
('70', 424, 1, 28, 877522) It is a fight to the finish.
('70', 424, 1, 29, 877551) Defeat has no place in the dictionary of non violence.
('70', 424, 2, 30, 877606) Harijan, 20 2 1937

('70', 425, 2, 3, 877685) An advocate from Tamil Nad writes: 1

('70', 425, 4, 6, 877955) All members of the Association are Brahmins except fot three, of whom one is a Christian.
('70', 425, 4, 7, 878045) The members pay a monthly subscription and the Association is maintained from the subscriptions.

('70', 425, 4, 9, 878227) On account of this there was an uproar in the Association and the Brahmin members objected to our taking water from the pot kept in the room on the sentimental ground of pollution .
('70', 425, 5, 10, 878409) I am writing this to you so that you can give us the lead and valuable advice for us to follow, lest we should err.
('70', 425, 5, 11, 878525) This is an old letter.
('70', 425, 5, 12, 878548) Probably the Bar Association referred to by my correspondent has settled the differences in an honourable manner.
('70', 425, 5, 13, 878662) But I know the evil persists in many places.

('70', 425, 5, 16, 878966) Those who have prejudices such as the correspondent describes may make their own individual arrangements but cannot deprive fellow members and fellow students of the right of using common property in a manner common to all.

('70', 425, 7, 18, 879209) 448. OUR VILLAGES
('70', 425, 8, 19, 879227) A young man who is trying to live in a village and earn his livelihood has sent me a pathetic letter.
('70', 425, 8, 20, 879329) He does not know much English.
('70', 425, 8, 21, 879360) I am therefore giving the letter below in an abridged form:
('70', 425, 9, 22, 879420) Three years ago when I was 20 years old I came to this village after spending 15 years in a town.
('70', 425, 9, 23, 879518) My domestic circumstances did not allow me to have college education.
('70', 425, 9, 24, 879588) The work you have taken up for village revival has
('70', 425, 10, 25, 879639) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('70', 426, 0, 1, 879676) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 BEBRUARY, 1937 427
('70', 426, 1, 2, 879725) encouraged me to pursue village life.
('70', 426, 1, 3, 879763) I have some land.
('70', 426, 1, 4, 879781) My village has a population of nearly 2,500. After close contact with this village I find the following among more than three fourths of the people:
('70', 426, 2, 5, 879930) (1) Party feelings and quarrels,
('70', 426, 3, 6, 879963) (2) Jealousy,
('70', 426, 4, 7, 879977) (3) Illiteracy,
('70', 426, 5, 8, 879993) (4) Wickedness,
('70', 426, 6, 9, 880009) (5) Disunion,
('70', 426, 7, 10, 880023) (6) Carelessness,
('70', 426, 8, 11, 880041) (7) Lack of manners,
('70', 426, 9, 12, 880062) (8) Adherence to the old meaningless customs,
('70', 426, 10, 13, 880108) (9) Cruelty.
('70', 426, 11, 14, 880121) This is an out of the way place.
('70', 426, 11, 15, 880154) No great man has ever visited such remote villages.
('70', 426, 11, 16, 880206) The company of great ones is essential for advancement.
('70', 426, 11, 17, 880262) So I am afraid to live in this village.
('70', 426, 11, 18, 880302) Shall I leave this village?
('70', 426, 11, 19, 880330) If not, what guidance will you give me?
('70', 426, 12, 20, 880370) Though no doubt there is exaggeration in the picture drawn by the young correspondent, his statement may be generally accepted.
('70', 426, 12, 21, 880498) The reason for the tragic state is not far to seek.
('70', 426, 12, 22, 880550) Villages have suffered long from neglect by those who have had the benefit of education.
('70', 426, 12, 23, 880639) They have chosen the city life.
('70', 426, 12, 24, 880671) The village movement is an attempt to establish healthy contact with the villages by inducing those who are fired with the spirit of service to settle in them and find self expression in the service of villagers.
('70', 426, 12, 25, 880884) The defects noticed by the correspondent are not inherent in village life.
('70', 426, 12, 26, 880959) Those who have settled in villages in the spirit of service are not dismayed by the difficulties facing them.They knew before they went that they would have to contend against many difficulties including even sullenness on the part of villagers.
('70', 426, 12, 27, 881205) Only those, therefore, who have faith in themselves and in their mission will serve the villagers and influence their lives.
('70', 426, 12, 28, 881330) A true life lived amongst the people is in itself an object lesson that must produce its own effect upon immediate surroundings.
('70', 426, 12, 29, 881459) The difficulty with the young man is, perhaps, that he has gone to the village merely to earn a living without the spirit of service behind it.
('70', 426, 12, 30, 881603) I admit that village life does not offer attractions to those who go there in search of money.
('70', 426, 12, 31, 881698) Without the incentive of service village life would jar after the novelty has worn out.
('70', 426, 12, 32, 881786) No young man having gone to a village may abandon the pursuit on the slightest contact with difficulty.
('70', 427, 0, 1, 881890) THE COLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 428
('70', 427, 1, 2, 881931) Patient effort will show that villagers are not very different from city dwellers and that they will respond to kindliness and attention.
('70', 427, 1, 3, 882069) It is no doubt true that one does not have in the villages the opportunity of contact with the great ones of the land.
('70', 427, 1, 4, 882188) With the growth of village mentality the leaders will find it necessary to tour in the villages and establish a living touch with them.
('70', 427, 1, 5, 882324) Moreover, the companionship of the great and the good is available to all through the works of saints like Chaitanya, Ramakrishna, Tulsidas, Kabir, Nanak, Dadu, Tukaram, Tiruvalluvar, and others too numerous to mention though equally known and pious.
('70', 427, 1, 6, 882575) The difficulty is to get the mind tuned to the reception of permanent values.
('70', 427, 1, 7, 882653) If it is modern thought—political, social, economical, scientific—that is meant, it is possible to procure literature that will satisfy curiosity.
('70', 427, 1, 8, 882800) I admit, however, that one does not find such as easily as one finds religious literature.
('70', 427, 1, 9, 882891) Saints wrote and spoke for the masses.
('70', 427, 1, 10, 882930) The vogue for translating modern thought to the masses in an acceptable manner has not yer quite set in.
('70', 427, 1, 11, 883035) But it must come in time.
('70', 427, 1, 12, 883061) I would, therefore, advise young men like my correspondent not to give in but persist in their effort and by their presence make the villages more livable and lovable.
('70', 427, 1, 13, 883229) That they will do by serving the villages in a manner acceptable to the villagers.
('70', 427, 1, 14, 883312) Everyone can make the beginning by making the villages cleaner by their own labour and removing illiteracy to the extent of their ability.
('70', 427, 1, 15, 883451) And if their lives are clean, methodical and industrious, there is no doubt that the infection will spread in the villages in which they may be working.
('70', 427, 2, 16, 883604) Harijan, 20 2 1937
('70', 427, 3, 17, 883623) 449. DUTY OF A HARIJAN SEVAK 1
('70', 427, 4, 18, 883654) A Harijan Sevak writes: 2
('70', 427, 5, 19, 883680) It is not impossible to say when the reformers irritate people and when they dispel their misapprehension.

('70', 427, 5, 21, 883890) It should be left to each individual to make his own decision regarding this.
('70', 427, 5, 22, 883968) This much can be said with certainty, that we should do nothing
('70', 427, 6, 23, 884032) 1 This appeared under “Notes”.
('70', 427, 6, 24, 884063) 2 The letter is not translated here.
('70', 427, 6, 25, 884100) The correspondent had said that while reformers readily accepted food and drink from Harijans in public they did not do so in their homes for fear that doing so might irritate people.
('70', 428, 0, 1, 884284) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 BEBRUARY, 1937 429
('70', 428, 1, 2, 884333) with a view to irritating anyone; and at the same time we must certainly endeavour to dispel any misapprehension.
('70', 428, 1, 3, 884447) When the work of reform has become a second nature with one, the question of wanting to irritate anyone does not arise.
('70', 428, 1, 4, 884567) For who can give up his own nature?
('70', 428, 1, 5, 884603) And when action or word becomes natural no one will feel irritated by it.
('70', 428, 1, 6, 884677) Therefore, the proper thing would be for the reformer to pursue his duty as duty, and not with any other motive.
('70', 428, 1, 7, 884790) By doing so, misappreh ension will be dispelled automatically.

('70', 429, 3, 4, 886210) MY DEAR JOSHI, Having read the correspondence between you and Mahadev Desai I took charge of it myself—hence the delay in acknowledging your letter.
('70', 429, 3, 5, 886359) I see that you are labouring under a sense of injustice and irritation.
('70', 429, 3, 6, 886431) Let me give you my assurance that no one has the slightest intention of giving you any cause for offence.

('70', 429, 3, 8, 886678) Of course I know that you undertook to come and organize the paper department at my instance and request.
('70', 429, 3, 9, 886784) I know your worth and I do not want to lose your services so patriotically given.
('70', 429, 3, 10, 886866) I know, too, that in our country we have very few experts.
('70', 429, 3, 11, 886925) Of these those who will give their free service for the benefit of the villagers can be counted on one’s finger tips and you are one of them.
('70', 429, 3, 12, 887067) It will not do for you, therefore, to be offended.
('70', 429, 3, 13, 887118) Do please, therefore come as soon as you can spare the time and I will personally see to it that every cause of offence is removed.
('70', 429, 3, 14, 887250) With your assistance I want the paper department to be put in a first class condition.
('70', 429, 3, 15, 887337) I know that this is not so at present.
('70', 429, 4, 16, 887376) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI [PS.] I like the specimen of the sugar you have made from date palm and I want your [help] in developing this village industry also.

('70', 431, 0, 1, 888918) THE COLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 432
('70', 431, 1, 2, 888959) 455. MY NOTES
('70', 431, 2, 3, 888973) INNOCENT HUMOUR Last year, Shri Kishorelal Mashruwala had gone on a tour of Bihar on behalf of the Gandhi Seva Sangh.
('70', 431, 2, 4, 889091) He had also visited the Santhal Paragana.
('70', 431, 2, 5, 889133) Generally the people there are very poor.
('70', 431, 2, 6, 889175) It can be said that they are largely untouched by modern civilization.
('70', 431, 2, 7, 889246) During his tour of the Paragana Kishorelal happened to go to a village.
('70', 431, 2, 8, 889318) The headman of the village, although illiterate, knew his work well.
('70', 431, 2, 9, 889387) Shri Kishorelal writes about him as follows:
('70', 431, 3, 10, 889432) Though he is illiterate, he told me his tale in a very touching manner.
('70', 431, 3, 11, 889504) It did not appear that he was repeating someone else’s words.
('70', 431, 3, 12, 889566) I found in this headman the naive humour which is characteristic of villagers.
('70', 431, 3, 13, 889645) He said: “We have only one difficulty: when there is famine in our parts, the crops die, the cattle die, human beings die, well water dies but revenue and interest—these two never die.
('70', 431, 3, 14, 889830) This is our only sorrow.” Man cannot survive without humour.
('70', 431, 3, 15, 889891) Moreover, people in the villages do not have the means to kill time which city dwellers have.
('70', 431, 3, 16, 889985) I do not believe that these are necessary.
('70', 431, 3, 17, 890028) Wherever things are well planned, there is no need to kill time.
('70', 431, 3, 18, 890093) Man hardly has time enough to spare.
('70', 431, 3, 19, 890130) He has sufficient time just to carry out his duties.
('70', 431, 3, 20, 890183) Instead, we waste a great deal of time and, as a result, suffer starvation.
('70', 431, 3, 21, 890259) Human beings do not get worn out through work.
('70', 431, 3, 22, 890306) It is by working that man remains fresh and makes progress in every direction.
('70', 431, 3, 23, 890385) He gets worn out through worry, by doing that which should not be done and by wasting time.
('70', 431, 3, 24, 890477) That headman was capable of laughing despite bitter experiences because he would not have been idle in his own work.
('70', 431, 3, 25, 890594) His humour may be taken as a sign of the joy he could feel in the midst of difficulties.
('70', 431, 3, 26, 890683) SELF SUFFICIENCY IN CLOTH In the very same letter, Shri Kishorelal writes as follows about other Santhals: 1
('70', 431, 4, 27, 890792) What has been made possible with these simple Santhals should be possible at any place if the effort is made.
('70', 431, 4, 28, 890902) Despite this, self sufficiency in cloth has made little progress in our society.
('70', 431, 4, 29, 890983) It is the
('70', 431, 5, 30, 890993) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('70', 431, 5, 31, 891030) Mashruwala had stated that the Manjhi Santhals of Hazaribagh district were the only industrious people he found in Bihar.
('70', 431, 5, 32, 891152) They were truly self sufficient in the matter of clothing.
('70', 432, 0, 1, 891211) VOL. 70 : 21 OCTOBER, 1936 24 BEBRUARY, 1937 433
('70', 432, 1, 2, 891260) task of the khadi worker to find out its causes.
('70', 432, 1, 3, 891309) How could self sufficiency be attained in the above mentioned village?
('70', 432, 1, 4, 891380) Was it there even before khadi activity started?
('70', 432, 1, 5, 891429) Was it done through the inspiration of some workers?
('70', 432, 1, 6, 891482) How much khadi do they use?
('70', 432, 1, 7, 891510) What is the count of the khadi which they make?
('70', 432, 1, 8, 891558) What is their speed in spinning and carding?
('70', 432, 1, 9, 891603) What are their tools like and what other activities do they pursue?
('70', 432, 1, 10, 891671) Answers to these and similar questions should be obtained with regard to this village.
('70', 432, 1, 11, 891758) If we have this information we shall know why self sufficiency has not been achieved elsewhere.
('70', 432, 1, 12, 891854) Whatever the conditions in this village may be, it is my confirmed belief that we can certainly succeed in such work if we can produce experts in the science of khadi for there is no flaw to be seen in the idea of self sufficiency.
('70', 432, 1, 13, 892086) And it is a historical fact that at one time India was self sufficient in cloth.

('70', 436, 1, 2, 896273) APPENDIX
('70', 436, 2, 3, 896282) TRAVANCORE TEMPLE ENTRY RULES
('70', 436, 3, 4, 896312) The following rules and regulations on temple entry have been issued over the sign manual of H.H. the Maharaja of Travancore:
('70', 436, 4, 5, 896438) Whereas we have by Proclamation issued under date November 12 declared, ordained and commanded that, subject to rules and conditions that we may impose, no restriction shall be placed on any Hindu entering and worshipping at temples controlled by us and our Government, we are hereby pleased to enact the following rules:
('70', 436, 5, 6, 896760) 1. The expression ‘temple’ occurring in these rules shall include not only the temple and sub shrines but also mandapams and other buildings as well as tanks or wells appurtenant to the temple.
('70', 436, 6, 7, 896954) 2. The expression ‘Chief Officer of the Devaswom’ occurring in these rules shall mean the officer in charge of the Devaswom.
('70', 436, 6, 8, 897079) It shall also include every officer superior to him and having jurisdiction when such superior officer exercises the powers of the Chief Officer of the Devaswom.
('70', 436, 7, 9, 897241) 3. In order that the customs and usages obtaining in the several temples under the control of His Highness the Maharaja and the Government in regard to the Poojas (service), Nivedyams (offerings), Vazhivadus (gifts) the Nithy anidhanam, Masavisesham, Attavisesham (special ceremonies), Utsavam (festival), and other ordinary and special ceremonies and rituals shall continue to be observed as heretofore, it shall be competent to the Chief Officer of the Devaswom to give, consistently with the objects of the Proclamation, such directions as may be necessary from time to time for regulating the time of entry and worship or limiting the number of those who may enter for worship at a time or maintaining such special customs and usages as are applicable to certain individuals and communities for specific purposes.
('70', 436, 8, 10, 898059) 4. The permission to enter temples shall not be exercised so as to empower entrance into the Srikoil (sanctum sanctorum), Thidapally (kitchen), and other portions of the temple where specific restrictions even now exist in regard to all persons except those who are allowed to use those portions by custom.
('70', 436, 9, 11, 898366) 5. All worshippers are bound to conform to the directions given by the Chief Officer of the Devaswom in regard to the carrying out of the objects of the Proclamation and these Rules and in regard to places which have to be reserved for the time being for the proper conduct of the rituals in the temple or observances such as the feeding of persons as heretofore conducted.
('70', 436, 10, 12, 898740) 6. The classes of persons mentioned hereunder shall not enter within the compound walls of a temple, or its premises in case there is no compound wall:
('70', 437, 0, 1, 898892) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 438
('70', 437, 1, 2, 898934) (a) Persons who are not Hindus; (b) persons under pollution arising out of birth or death in their families; (c) women at such time during which they are not by custom and usage allowed to enter temples; (d) drunken or disorderly persons; (e) persons suffering from any loathsome or contagious disease; (f) persons of unsound mind except when taken for worship under proper control and with the sanction of the Chief Officer of the Devaswom concerned; and (g) professional beggars.
('70', 437, 2, 3, 899416) 7. No person shall enter into any temple premises unless he wears clean clothes of such materials and in such manner as may be customary.
('70', 437, 2, 4, 899554) The directions of the Chief Officer of the Devaswom concerned shall prevail until set aside by a higher authority.
('70', 437, 2, 5, 899669) None shall be allowed to enter temple premises with any footwear, except those who are allowed to do so by custom and usage obtaining in the temple.
('70', 437, 3, 6, 899818) 8. No person shall, within the temple and premises, spit, chew betel, tobacco or any similar article or smoke or carry with him any article for smoking, or take with him fish, eggs, meat, flesh, toddy, arrack or other intoxicants or any other article or animal inappropriate according to custom and usage to be introduced into the temple.
('70', 437, 4, 7, 900157) 9. No person shall enter the Belikkalpura (the hall in which the main altar stone is installed), Valiambalam, (central shrine), Nalambalam, (the halls on four sides) or the Elamathil which in some temples takes the place of a Nalambalam, with any coat, shirt, vest or such other garment, except women who may wear their usual dress.
('70', 437, 4, 8, 900490) No head dress shall be worn except by those who are allowed to do so by custom and usage obtaining in the temple.
('70', 437, 4, 9, 900604) No one shall take therein any cloth umbrella, kerosene light or other article inappropriate to be introduced into such places by custom or usage.
('70', 437, 4, 10, 900750) In temples where the above restrictions obtain even in regard to entering within the compound walls, the same shall be observed.
('70', 437, 5, 11, 900879) 10. (1) No one shall enter the portions of a temple specified in the last preceding rule without having, in accordance with custom and usage, bathed, and without the customary caste mark and without wearing clean clothes of such material and in such manner as may be customary in the temple concerned.
('70', 437, 6, 12, 901181) (2) No one except a Hindu shall enter a tank appurtenant to a temple, and every person permitted to enter a tank shall obey such directions as may be given by the Chief Officer of the Devaswom concerned.
('70', 437, 6, 13, 901385) The direction of the Chief Officer of the Devaswom shall prevail until set aside by a higher authority.
('70', 437, 7, 14, 901489) (3) Tanks reserved for the exclusive use of particular functionaries of the temple shall continue to be so reserved.
('70', 437, 8, 15, 901606) 11. Restrictions as to entry and worship, which according to usage and custom apply to all communities alike, shall continue to apply.
('70', 437, 9, 16, 901741) 12. No one shall interrupt the worship in a temple by loud conversation or other demonstration which would derogate from the solemnity and the proper atmosphere of the temple.
('70', 437, 10, 17, 901917) 13. It shall not be lawful to any person to use the temple buildings and premises for purposes not connected with or arising from worship, usages and observances of such temples.
('70', 438, 0, 1, 902096) VOL. 70 : 20 OCTBER, 1936 24 BEBRUARY, 1937 439
('70', 438, 1, 2, 902144) 14. No one shall do any act which would tend to derogate from the purity and cleanliness of the temple and its premises.
('70', 438, 2, 3, 902265) 15. If any doubt arises in regard to the applicability of, or conformity to, any of these provisions, the decision of the Chief Officer of the Devaswom concerned shall prevail until set aside by a higher authority.
('70', 438, 3, 4, 902480) 16. It shall be lawful for the Chief Officer of the Dewaswom concerned to direct that any person who contravenes or is suspected or believed by the Chief Officer of the Devaswom to have contravened any of the provisions of these rules, or disobeys any lawful direction given to him, shall remove himself from the temple and, in case such person does not so remove himself, to cause him to be removed from the temple.
('70', 438, 3, 5, 902897) In case he resists such removal, or in case when asked to give his name and address he refuses to do so or gives information which is not believed to be true, he shall be liable to be arrested and removed by any Police Officer not below the rank of a Head Constable, and to be dealt with as if he had been arrested under Section 38 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.
('70', 438, 4, 6, 903264) 17. If any person contravenes any of the provisions of these rules, or disobeys any direction lawfully given in pursuance thereof, and thereby renders necessary any purificatory ceremonies, according to the customs and usages of the temple, such person shall be liable to pay the cost of the necessary purificatory ceremonies at the approved rates, and the same shall be recoverable from him as arrears of public or land revenue or otherwise.
('70', 438, 4, 7, 903707) A person thus contravening or disobeying shall, besides being subject to any penalty to which he may be liable under any other law, be also punishable on conviction by a Magistrate with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months or with fine or with both.
('70', 438, 5, 8, 903999) 18. No prosecution under these rules shall lie except on a complaint by a Gazetted Officer having jurisdiction in respect of the temple.
('70', 438, 6, 9, 904136) 19. No action shall lie against any Devaswom Officer or other public servant who bona fide does any act in pursuance of these rules, and no action in a Criminal Court shall lie without sanction of Government.
('70', 438, 7, 10, 904345) 20. In case of any doubt or dispute regarding the interpretation or the carrying out of any provisions of these rules, the decision of the Dewan thereon shall be final.
('70', 438, 8, 11, 904514) 21. In cases of emergencies and unforeseen difficulties that may arise in carrying out the provisions and objects of the Proclamation or of these rules, the Dewan shall be competent to pass such orders as he may deem fit.
('70', 438, 9, 12, 904736) Harijan, 5 12 1936
